docs.title: 四時氣
docs.text:
1: 黃帝問于歧伯曰：夫四時之氣，各不同形，百病之起，皆有所生，灸刺之道，何者為定？歧伯答曰：四時之氣，各有所在，灸刺之道，得氣穴為定。故春取經、血脈、分肉之間，甚者，深刺之，間者，淺刺之；夏取盛經孫絡，取分間絕皮膚；秋取經俞。邪在府，取之合；冬取井滎，必深以留之。 The Yellow Emperor asked Guan Pu, The Qi of the four seasons has different forms, and all diseases arise from some source. What is the method of acupuncture and moxibustion for defining this? Guan Pu replied, The Qi of the four seasons have their respective locations. The method of acupuncture and moxibustion is to find the Qi points. Therefore, in spring, you should take the meridians, blood vessels, and muscles between, with the former being deep and the latter being shallow; in summer, you should take the full meridian and sinews, and separate the skin and subcutaneous tissue; in autumn, you should take the meridian channels. In evil cases, you should take from where they are located; in winter, you should take from the wells and ensure depth.

2: 溫瘧汗不出，為五十九痏，風㽷膚脹，為五十七痏。取皮膚之血者，盡取之。飧泄補三陰之上，補陰陵泉，皆久留之，熱行乃止。 Sweating is not forthcoming, with 59 degrees of Yin; the complexion is sallow and swollen, at 57 degrees of Yin. When bleeding is taken from the skin, it should all be taken. Supplementing the Stomach, supplementing the Kidney Yuan, and supplementing the Kidney Spring, all can last for a long time, and the fever will subside.

3: 轉筋於陽，治其陽；轉筋於陰，治其陰。皆卒刺之。徒㽷先取環谷下三寸，以鈹鍼鍼之，已刺而筩之，而內之，入而復之，以盡其㽷，必堅。來緩則煩悗，來急則安靜，間日一刺之，㽷盡乃止。飲閉藥，方刺之時徒飲之，方飲無食，方食無飲，無食他食，百三十五日。 Treat the tendons of the Yang and treat the Yang; treat the tendons of the Yin and treat the Yin. All are ultimately punctured. The patient must be treated with acupuncture, and the needle will be inserted and withdrawn to ensure thoroughness. If the situation worsens, it becomes uncomfortable; if it becomes urgent, it calms down. After one treatment, the patient's condition improves, and they will recover after 30-35 days. The patient is to take medicine only when being punctured, or only drink water, or only eat food. There should be no other food besides this prescribed diet

4: 著痺不去，久寒不已，卒取其三里。骨為幹。腸中不便，取三里，盛寫之，虛補之。癘風者，素刺其腫上。已刺，以銳鍼鍼其處，按出其惡氣，腫盡乃止。常食方食，無食他食。 The ailment does not go away, and the cold lasts for a long time. It suddenly took three li. Bones are the axis. The intestines have discomfort, taking three li, summarizing it, and applying the vacuum. For those with wind abscesses, gently pierce the swollen area. After puncturing, use a sharp lancet to prick the location, press out the evil qi, and the swelling will cease when it is gone. Eat only regular food and do not eat other foods.

5: 腹中常鳴，氣上衝胸，喘不能久立。邪在大腸，刺肓之原，巨虛上廉、三里。小腹控睪，引腰脊，上衝心。邪在小腸者，連睪系，屬于脊，貫肝肺，絡心系。氣盛則厥逆，上衝腸胃，燻肝，散于肓，結于臍，故取之肓原以散之，刺太陰以予之，取厥陰以下之，取巨虛下廉以去之，按其所過之經以調之。 The text is in classical Chinese, but it appears to describe the symptoms and treatment of an abdominal condition. Here's a translation:

Constantly feeling pain in the abdomen, gas builds up and presses on the chest, making it difficult to breathe and stand for long. The disease is located in the large intestine, by piercing the intestines at the original site of the 'great emptiness' and three li points. For a small intestinal issue, grip the navel and pull towards the spine, pressing upwards towards the heart. If the disease is in the small intestine, tie the navel and connect it to the spine, running through the liver and lungs, connecting to the heart. When qi is abundant, it can cause dysfunction of the stomach and intestines, causing the liver to overheat and dispersing throughout the intestines, clumping in the gallbladder, hence piercing at the intestinal site to disperse it, piercing the Conception Vessel to provide it, taking from the Bubble Vessel to expel it, taking from the Great Vacuity to eliminate it, and pressing on the points along its meridian to regulate it.

6: 善嘔，嘔有苦，長太息，心中憺憺，恐人將捕之；邪在膽，逆在胃，膽液泄，則口苦，胃氣逆，則嘔苦，故曰嘔膽。取三里以下。胃氣逆，則刺少陽血絡，以閉膽逆，卻調其虛實，以去其邪。 Good hiccup, having hiccups with pain, prolonged sighing, the mind being worried, fearing that people will capture it; evil in the gallbladder, reverse in the stomach, gallbladder fluid leakage causes the mouth to be bitter, stomach qi reversal causes hiccup bitterness, so it is called hiccup gallbladder. Take three ri below. Stomach qi reversal, then insert a needle into the small yang blood vessel to close gallbladder reversal, adjust its emptiness, and remove its evil.

7: 飲食不下，膈塞不通，邪在胃脘，在上脘，則刺抑而下之，在下脘，則散而去之。小腹痛腫，不得小便，邪在三焦，約取之太陽大絡，視其絡脈與厥陰小絡結而血者，腫上及胃脘，取三里。 Unable to eat or drink, the qi is blocked and not flowing smoothly. The pathogenic factor is in the stomach and lower abdomen. If it's in the upper abdomen, use acupuncture to tonify and bring downward. If it's in the lower abdomen, use herbal medicine to disperse and expel. Small intestinal pain and swelling, unable to urinate, pathogenic factor is in the triple burner. Take a small amount of qi from the conception vessel and blend with the small yin vessel. If there is bleeding, the swelling will spread and affect the stomach region, take three catties of this mixture.

8: 睹其色，察其以，知其散復者，視其目色，以知病之存亡也。一其形，聽其動靜者，持氣口人迎以視其脈，堅且盛且滑者，病日進，脈軟者，病將下，諸經實者，病三日已。氣口候陰，人迎候陽也。 By examining its color, investigating its cause, and knowing whether it is improving or deteriorating, one can discern the presence or absence of illness through observing the patient's eye color. By listening to their speech and noting their movement and stillness, one can gauge the state of the qi by observing their pulse. If the pulse is strong, abundant, and smooth, the patient is improving; if it is soft, the illness may be about to decline, and if the pulse follows the patterns described in the classics, then the illness has lasted for three days. The qi and pulse correspond to yin and yang respectively.

docs.title: 五邪
docs.text:
1: 邪在肺，則病皮膚痛，寒熱，上氣喘，汗出，欬動肩背。取之膺中外喻，背三節五藏之傍，以手疾按之，快然，乃刺之。取之缺盆中以越之。 If the evil is in the lung, there will be pain of the skin and flesh, fever and chills, shortness of breath, sweating, and difficulty in swallowing and shoulder and back pain. To remove it, locate it at the armpit outside the three junctions and five viscera, press firmly with your hand quickly, and then pierce it. To take it out, locate it at the lower abdomen and draw it out.

2: 邪在肝，則兩脅中痛，寒中，惡血在內，行善掣節，時腳腫。取之行間，以引脅下，補三里以溫胃中，取血脈以散惡血；取耳間青脈，以去其掣。 If evil is in the liver, there will be pain in both flanks and chills. Cold exists inside, bad blood is present. Act virtuously and restrain yourself. At a proper time, the feet will swell. Take something from your pocket to pull down the pain, supplement with three li of warmth to disperse cold and evil in the middle energizer, take the green-colored blood vessel at the earlobe to remove the obstruction.

3: 邪在脾胃，則病肌肉痛，陽氣有餘，陰氣不足，則熱中善飢；陽氣不足，陰氣有餘，則寒中腸鳴、腹痛；陰陽俱有餘，若俱不足，則有寒有熱，皆調于三里。 Evil lies in the spleen and stomach, causing muscle pain and stiffness. If yang qi is abundant but yin qi is deficient, one will have a preference for heat and be prone to hunger. If yang qi is deficient and yin qi is abundant, one will suffer from cold with abdominal rumbling and abdominal pain. If both yin and yang are abundant or deficient, one will experience both cold and heat symptoms, which can be treated by adjusting the balance within the three li (channels).

4: 邪在腎，則病骨痛，陰痺。陰痺者，按之而不得，腹脹，腰痛，大便難，肩背頸項痛，時眩。取之湧泉、崑崙。視有血者，盡取之。 Evil resides in the kidneys, resulting in pain in the bones. This refers to yin deficiency. Symptoms include: when pressed, there is no relief; abdominal distention and lower back pain; difficulty with bowel movements; shoulder, back, neck, and jaw pain; and dizziness at times. Prescription: take from Qiong Mountain springs (medicine from Yunnan, China). If you see blood, take it all.

5: 邪在心，則病心痛，喜悲時眩仆；視有餘不足而調之其輸也。 Evil in the heart causes pain, and the heart is weakened during times of joy or grief; if there is still some vision left, one should adjust it accordingly.

docs.title: 寒熱病
docs.text:
1: 皮寒熱者，不可附席，毛髮焦，鼻槁臘。不得汗，取三陽之絡，以補手太陰。肌寒熱者，肌痛，毛髮焦而唇槁臘。不得汗，取三陽于下，以去其血者，補足太陰，以出其汗。 For those with chills and fever, they should not attend court sessions. The hairs on the body are brittle, and the nose cartilage is shriveled. No sweating; take the sinews of the Triple Burner, to supplement the hand-yang. For those with muscle chills and fever, there is muscle pain and the hairs are brittle while the lips are shriveled. No sweating; take the Triple Burner below to remove its blood, and supplement the yin of the foot-Taiyang, causing it to sweat.

2: 骨寒熱者，病無所安，汗注不休。齒未槁，取其少陰于陰股之絡；齒已槁，死不治。骨厥亦然。骨痺，舉節不用而痛，汗注、煩心。取三陰之經，補之。 Those who suffer from bone cold and heat disorders have no peace from their illnesses, with perspiration unceasing. Before the teeth are loose, take the Shao Yin at the Yin Groin channel; once the teeth are loose, it is incurable. The same applies to Bone Paralysis. Aches in the bones that prevent the use of joints, accompanied by perspiration and restlessness. Take the Qi of the San Jiao channel and supplement it.

3: 身有所傷，血出多及中風寒，若有所墮墜，四肢懈惰不收，名曰體惰。取其小腹臍下三結交。三結交者，陽明太陰也，臍下三寸關元也。厥痺者，厥氣上及腹。取陰陽之絡，視主病也，寫陽補陰經也。 If one has an injury, with blood flowing out and being affected by cold wind, if there is a fall or stumble, the limbs become limp and fail to withdraw, this is called body weakness. At the lower abdomen, below the umbilicus, are three knots intertwined. These three knots intertwined represent Yang Ming and Yin Qi. The umbilical cord is located at the center of these three knots. If there is a blockage in the channels, the vital energy ascends to the abdomen. Examining the relation between yin and yang, one can diagnose the primary cause and write the Treatment of Yang Deficiency and Yin Supplementation.

4: 頸側之動脈人迎。人迎，足陽明也，在嬰筋之前。嬰筋之後，手陽明也，名曰扶突。次脈，足少陽脈也，名曰天牖。次脈，足太陽也，名曰天柱。腋下動脈，臂太陰也，名曰天府。 On the front of the neck, there is the Radiant Pulse. The Radiant Pulse corresponds to the Yangming channel, which lies in front of the Governing Vessel. After the Governing Vessel, there is the Taiyang channel, also known as Heaven's Pillar. Then comes the ShaoYang channel, also known as Heaven's Wall. At the armpit, there is the TaiYang channel, also known as the Celestial Pivot.

5: 陽迎頭痛，胸滿不得息，取之人迎。暴瘖氣鞭，取扶突與舌本出血。暴襲氣蒙，耳目不明，取天牖。暴攣癎眩，足不任身，取天柱。暴痺內逆，肝肺相搏，血溢鼻口，取天府。此為天牖五部。 Sunny welcome headache, chest full and unable to breathe, the one who takes it is welcomed. Violent itchiness from gas, taking a whip, bleeding from the tongue base. Sudden attack dizziness, unstable feet, taking heaven pillar. Violent spasms leading to confusion, legs not supporting, taking heaven pavilion. Violent paralysis of internal organs, liver and lung fighting, blood overflowing from the nose and mouth, taking heaven residence. These are the five departments of the Heaven Pavilion.

6: 臂陽明，有入頄遍齒者，名曰大迎。下齒齲，取之臂。惡寒補之，不惡寒寫之。足太陽有入頄遍齒者，名曰角孫。上齒齲，取之在鼻與頄前。方病之時，其脈盛，盛則寫之，虛則補之。一曰取之出鼻外。 Beams of the Arm (Ulnar) - Great Reception In cases where there is entering and spreading to the teeth, it is called Great Reception. When the lower teeth are involved, take from the arm. In cases where there is not an involvement of the lower teeth, do not take from the arm. Beams of the Foot (Lesser Yang) - Horny Son In cases where there is entering and spreading to the teeth, it is called Horny Son. When the upper teeth are involved, take from the nose and the area in front of the throat. In times of disease, the pulse will be full. If full, write (the needle); if empty, supplement (with moxa). Alternative: Take from outside the nostrils.

7: 足陽明有挾鼻入于面者，名曰懸顱。屬口，對入繫目本，視有過者取之。損有餘，益不足，反者益其。足太陽有通項入于腦者，正屬目本，名曰眼系。頭目苦痛，取之在項中兩筋間。入腦乃別陰蹻、陽蹻，陰陽相交，陽入陰，陰出陽，交于目銳眥，陽氣盛則瞋目，陰氣盛則瞑目。 There is a point on the foot Yinning called Sūiyǐng, which is located near the root of the nose. Its name means suspended nostril. It belongs to the channel of the mouth and intersects with the channel of the eyes. When there are symptoms, take it. If there are remnants, increase what is insufficient and decrease what is excessive. There is a point on the foot Yangming called Tōngtícóng, which enters the brain. It belongs to the channel of the eyes and is named Eye Chain (Yǎnshē). For headache pain, take it at the level of the two muscles of the neck. Entering the brain separates Yin and Yang, and they exchange with each other. When Yang enters Yin, the pupil becomes dull; when Yin enters Yang, the pupil becomes clear.

8: 熱厥取足太陰、少陽，皆留之；寒厥取足陽明、少陰於足，皆留之。舌縱涎下，煩悗，取足少陰。振寒洒洒鼓頷，不得汗出，腹脹煩悗，取手太陰，刺虛者，刺其去也；刺實者，刺其來也。 In the case of fever chills, take the Sinew Chrono (Taiyin) and Lesser Yang Ming (Shaoyang) points on the feet and leave them. In the case of cold chills, take the Foot Yang Ming (Jingwell) and Lesser Yin on the foot and leave them. If the tongue is dry with saliva dripping down, and there is vexation and discomfort, take the Sinew Chrono (Sanyinjiao) point on the foot. Shake off the cold, sprinkle, and pound the throat, do not let sweat come out, if there is fullness and discomfort in the abdomen, take the Hand Taiyin (Quepen) points, and pierce the empty points, that is to say, pierce them away; pierce the real points, that is to say, pierce them coming.

9: 春取絡脈，夏取分腠，秋取氣口，冬取經輸。凡此四時，各以時為齊。絡脈治皮膚，分腠治肌肉，氣口治筋脈，經輸治骨髓。五藏，身有五部：伏兔一；腓二，腓者腨也；背三，五藏之輸四；項五。此五部有癰疽者死。 In the spring, take the luo-connecting vessels, in summer, take the sinews, in autumn, take the qi channels, and in winter, take the meridians. At each of these four seasons, one should regulate according to the time. The luo-connecting vessels treat the skin, the sinews treat the muscles, the qi channels treat the tendons and joints, and the meridians treat the bone marrow. The five organs, the body has five parts: genitals (1), bladder (2) which is also called back, back (3), four meridians of the five organs, neck (5). If any of these five parts have boils or carbuncles, they will die.

10: 病始手臂者，先取手陽明、太陰而汗出；病始頭首者，先取項太陽而汗出；病始足脛者，先取足陽明而汗出。臂太陰可汗出，足陽明可汗出，故取陰而汗出甚者，止之于陽，取陽而汗出甚者，止之於陰。 For someone whose illness begins with the arm, first take the hand's Shao Yang and Tai Yin channels and make them sweat. For someone whose illness begins with the head, first take the Jiao Yang channel and make it sweat. For someone whose illness begins with the leg, first take the Zusanli (ST-36) point of the Yang Ming channel and make it sweat. The Tai Yin channel can make one sweat from the hand, and the Yang Ming channel can make one sweat from the foot, so if sweating becomes excessive when taking the Shu points of the Yin channels, stop at the Yang levels, and if sweating becomes excessive when taking the Shu points of the Yang channels, stop at the Yin levels.

11: 凡刺之害，中而不去則精泄；不中而去則致氣。精泄則病甚而慪，致氣則生為癰疽也。 All injuries that do not go away when pierced will cause the vital essence to be depleted; if it is not pierced correctly, it will lead to a buildup of qi. Depletion of vital essence can result in severe illness and emotional distress, while a buildup of qi can lead to the development of boils or abscesses

docs.title: 癩狂病
docs.text:
1: 目眥外決於面者，為銳眥；在內近鼻者，為內眥；上為外眥，下為內眥。 The outer corner of the eye determines the sharpness of the gaze, being outside close to the cheek; inside near the nose, it is the inner corner; above it is the outer corner and below it is the inner corner.

2: 癲疾始生，先不樂，頭重痛，視舉目赤，甚作極，已而煩心。候之於顏。取手太陽、陽明、太陰，血變為止。 Initially, the patient was in a hurry and not happy. They had a heavy headache, red eyes, and were extremely uncomfortable, causing their heart to be restless. Waiting for the face to change, they took the Radiant Sun, Yang Brightness, and Yin Migration formulas. The bleeding was stopped.

3: 癲疾始作，而引口啼呼喘悸者，候之手陽明、太陽。左強者，攻其右；右強者，攻其左，血變為止。癲疾始作，先反僵，因而脊痛，候之足太陽、陽明、太陰、手太陽，血變為止。 When the mania and madness begin, with one urging their mouth to cry out, gasp, and pant, wait until the hand Yang Brightness and Great Sun appear. If it is strong on the left side, attack its right; if it is strong on the right side, attack its left, and the bleeding will stop. When mania and madness begin, first stiffen and then become rigid, causing a backache, wait until the foot Yang Brightness, Great Sun, Kidney Yang Brightness, and Hand Yang Brightness appear. The bleeding will stop.

4: 治癲疾者，常與之居，察其所當取之處。病至，視之有過者寫之，置其血於瓠壺之中，至其發時，血獨動矣，不動，灸窮骨二十壯。窮骨者，骶骨也。 Treating the insane, one should always live with them and examine the proper places to take. When the illness is severe, note any abnormalities and write them down. Place their blood in a bowl, when it begins to move on its own, it will stop moving without manipulation, and needling the bone marrow twenty times. Needling the bone marrow refers to the vertebrae.

5: 骨癲疾者，顑、齒諸腧、分肉皆滿而骨居，汗出、煩悗，嘔多沃沫，氣下泄，不治。 A patient with a fracture, the bones are filled but there is no flesh, they sweat and itch, vomit much foam, release gas, and cannot be cured.

6: 筋癲疾者，身倦攣急大，刺項大經之大杼脈，嘔多沃沫，氣下泄，不治。 The patient with convulsions, exhausted and suffering from great haste, had needles inserted into the Jiao Xu points of the large intestine meridian, with copious vomiting and gas release, but to no avail.

7: 脈癲疾者，暴仆，四肢之脈皆脹而縱，脈滿，盡刺之出血，不滿，灸之挾項太陽，灸帶脈於腰相去三寸，諸分肉本輸。嘔吐沃沫，氣下泄，不治。癲疾者，疾發如狂者，死不治。 For a rapid pulse, violent vomiting of saliva and gastric fluids, release of qi, and failure to be treated, the condition is severe. This disease is similar to madness; if not treated, it will result in death.

The patient has a quick pulse and violent vomiting, with qi being released but no blood being drawn out. The pulse is full and upon puncturing, bleeding occurs; if not full, moxibustion should be applied at the governor vessel and conception vessel points, with the moxa stick used 3 inches away from the pulse at the waist, stimulating the muscles to release excess heat. This treatment is effective for vomiting and releasing qi, but has failed to resolve the issue. The rapid onset of symptoms in this case is comparable to insanity; if left untreated, it will lead to death.

8: 狂始生，先自悲也，喜忘、苦怒、善恐者得之憂飢，治之取手太陽、陽明，血變而止，及取足太陰、陽明。狂始發，少臥不飢，自高賢也，自辯智也，自尊貴也，善罵詈，日夜不休，治之取手陽明太陽太陰舌下少陰，視之盛者，皆取之，不盛，釋之也。 In the case of mania onset, one initially feels sadness and then experiences joy, anger, anxiety, fear, and eventually becomes troubled by hunger. Treatment involves taking the pulse at the Taiyang (Radiant Sun) and Yangming (Brightness) points, with blood flow normalizing and stopping after a short time. Additionally, taking the pulse at the Taiyang, Yangming, and Tongzhong Yimen (Gathering Life Gate) points is necessary for cases where there is persistent lying in bed without appetite. The patient feels proud and wise, debating and respectful of themselves, prone to verbal abuse without rest day or night. Treatment involves taking the pulse at Yangming, Taiyang, Taiyang (Radiant Sun), and Shao Shang (Little Pulse) points, with those who respond being treated while others are dismissed.

9: 狂言，驚，善笑，好歌樂，妄行不休者，得之大恐，治之取手陽明太陽太陰。狂，目妄見，耳妄聞，善呼者，少氣之所生也；治之取手太陽太陰陽明，足太陰頭兩顑。 The text translates to: Insanity, fear, skillful laughter, good songs and music, those who act recklessly without stopping, are greatly feared. Treating them involves using the Yang Ming (Hand Yang) and Taiyang (Great Yang), as well as the Yin Ming (Hand Yin) and Taiyin (Great Yin). Madness is characterized by hallucinations of the eyes and hearing delusions through the ears; those who can call upon it have a deficiency of Qi. Treatment involves using the Hand Yang, Great Yang, Hand Yin, and Great Yin, as well as the Jueyin (Mingmen) point.

10: 狂者多食，善見鬼神，善笑而不發於外者，得之有所大喜，治之取足太陰太陽陽明，後取手太陰太陽陽明。狂而新發，未應如此者，先取曲泉左右動脈，及盛者見血，有頃已，不已，以法取之，灸骨骶二十壯。 Persons who are mad often eat too much, can see spirits and gods, and smile without showing it on the outside. People are very pleased when such a person appears, and they treat them by taking sufficient Kidney-Yang and Bright Yang and then taking Hand-Kidney-Yang and Bright Yang. If the madness is new and not as described above, first take Curved Vessel Left and Right channels and Blood Vessels, and when it becomes apparent, stop immediately. Do not continue, use this method to treat them, press the bones and vertebrae twenty times.

11: 風逆，暴四肢腫，身漯漯，唏然時寒，飢則煩，飽則善變，取手大陰表裏，足少陰陽明之徑，肉清取滎，骨清取井、經也。 Against the wind, with four limbs swollen, body trembling, feeling cold at times, hungry irritable and satisfied easily, taking hands as an example, the palm side is the way of yin, the back side is the way of yang. The meat is clear when taken in a flood, and the bones are clear when taken from a well or a spring (referring to meridians).

12: 厥逆為病也，足暴清，胸若將裂，腸若將以刀切之，煩而不能食，脈大小皆澀，暖取足少陰，清取足陽明，清則補之，溫則寫之。厥逆腹脹滿，腸鳴，胸滿不得息，取之下胸二脅，咳而動手者，與背輸，以手按之，立快者是也。 The reversal of the channels is a disease. The feet are numb and cold, the chest seems about to rupture, the intestines seem about to be cut with a knife, and one is bothered but cannot eat. Both pulse readings are irregular. Take warm from the Kidney Yin and clear from the Foot-Yangming. If it clears, reinforce; if it warms, disperse. The reversal of the channels causes abdominal distention, the feet feel heavy, and the chest is full and cannot be exhaled; take from the lower abdomen at both Kidney positions, make the person cough and move their hands, and that's it.

13: 內閉不得溲，刺足少陰太陽，與抵上以長鍼。氣逆，則取其太陰、陽明、厥陰，甚取少陰、陽明，動者之經也。 Internal blockage, not allowed to be released. Puncture the foot's Kidney-1 (Bubbling Spring) and join with the long needle. If the Qi is reversed, then take its Spleen-6 (Three Mile Point), Stomach-40 (Joining Vessel), Liver-8 (Governor Vessel) and even more so for Spleen-10 (Liv 3), Stomach-44 (Communion Point). These are the moving channels.

14: 少氣，身漯漯也，言吸吸也，骨痠體重，懈惰不能動，補足少陰。短氣息短，不屬，動作氣索，補足少陰，去血絡也。 Weak, the body trembling and weak-voiced, bones aching and heavy, unable to move due to laziness. Supplements the kidney Yang. Short breath and short exhalation, not fitting, movements lacking in Qi, supplementing the kidney Yang, expelling blood stagnation.

docs.title: 熱病
docs.text:
1: 偏枯，身偏不用而痛，言不變，志不亂，病在分腠之間，巨鍼取之，益其不足，損其有餘，乃可復也。 Dry and withered, the body feels pain where it is not used, speech does not change, resolve does not become disordered, the illness lies between the divisions of the hair, a large needle can be inserted to restore what is lacking, and remove what is in excess, thus it can be cured.

2: 痱之為病也，身無痛者，四肢不收；智亂不甚，其言微知，可治；甚則不能言，不可治也。病先起于陽，復入于陰者，先取其陽，後取其陰，浮而取之。 Aches and pains are signs of illness; if the limbs are not contracted, one can still be treated when intelligence is slightly disordered. If it becomes more severe, the patient cannot speak and cannot be treated. Illness first manifests in the Yang and eventually enters the Yin; treat the Yang first, then treat the Yin, and administer the medicine by floating it down

3: 熱病三日，而氣口靜、人迎躁者，取之諸陽，五十九刺，以寫其熱，而出其汗，實其陰，以補其不足者。身熱甚，陰陽皆靜者，勿刺也；其可刺者，急取之，不汗出則泄。所謂勿刺者，有死徵也。 The patient had a fever for three days, and the breath was quiet with noisy person; take from Zhongyang, 59 needles, to disperse the fever and induce sweating, and reinforce what is deficient. If the body's fever is severe, with both Yin and Yang being still, do not pierce. Those who can be pierced, take urgent action, without sweating, release it (the Qi). The one referred to as do not pierce has a sign of death.

4: 熱病七日八日，脈口動，喘而短者，急刺之，汗且自出，淺刺手大指間。 On the seventh or eighth day of a fever, if the pulse is uneven and there is short, labored breathing, urgently perform acupuncture. Sweat will then spontaneously emerge, and lightly puncture between the knuckles of the thumb.

5: 熱病七日八日，脈微小，病者溲血，口中乾，一日半而死。脈代者，一日死。 On the seventh and eighth day of the fever, the pulse was weak and small. The patient had blood in their stool, their mouth was dry, and they died half a day later. If there was a change in the pulse, they would die on the same day.

6: 熱病已得汗出，而脈尚躁，喘且復熱，勿刺膚，喘甚者死。 The patient has a fever and is sweating, but the pulse is still agitated, and the person is panting and feels hot again. Do not puncture the skin, as those who are panting heavily are likely to die.

7: 熱病七日八日，脈不躁，躁不散數，後三日中有汗，三日不汗，四日死。未曾汗者，勿腠刺之。 Hot disease seven days eight days, pulse not agitated, agitated not dispersed in number, after three days there is sweating, three days without sweating, four days death. Those who have never sweat, do not acupuncture the sinew.

8: 熱病先膚痛，窒鼻充面，取之皮，以第一鍼，五十九，苛軫鼻，索皮于肺，不得，索之火，火者，心也。 A fever disease begins with skin pain and a closed nose, take the skin from the tip of the nose, use the first needle, number 59, prick the nostril, get the skin from the lung, do not let it go, burn it and it will be the heart.

9: 熱病先身澀倚而熱，煩俛，乾唇口溢，取之皮，以第一鍼，五十九；膚脹口乾，寒汗出，索脈於心，不得，索之水，水者，腎也。 A feverish illness precedes a hot bodily sensation, followed by irritability. The mouth and lips are parched, saliva flows out, the skin is flushed, the pulse is taken at the wrist, using the first needle, number fifty-nine. The skin feels swollen in the mouth, the lips are dry, cold sweat appears, take the pulse at the heart, if it cannot be found, take it from the water (meaning the kidney).

10: 熱病溢乾多飲，善惊，臥不能起，取之膚肉，以第六鍼，五十九，目眥青，索肉於脾，不得，索之水，木者，肝也。 The patient has a high fever, is thirsty, and cannot get up from bed. Take a piece of flesh from the sixth lumbar region, 59 points, and apply it to the eyes which turn green. Poke the flesh into the spleen; if not successful, draw water - wood represents the liver.

11: 熱病面青，腦痛，手足躁，取之筋間，以第四鍼於四逆；筋躄目浸，索筋於肝，不得，索之金，金者，肺也。 The patient has a fever, feeling chilly, headache, and restless in hands and feet. For this condition, take a needle at the four corners of the patient and insert it into the sinew channels. The sinew channel is submerged in the eye, and when it cannot be obtained, seek gold. Gold refers to the lung.

12: 熱病數驚，瘈瘲而狂，取之脈，以第四鍼，急寫有餘者，癲疾毛髮去，索血於心，不得，索之水，水者，腎也。 The fever was alarming, the patient delirious and incoherent. Upon taking their pulse with the fourth finger, if it was still rapid, shave the hair and beard, tie a ligature around the heart to stop the bleeding, and if this is not possible, tie one around the water (i.e., the kidney).

13: 熱病身重骨痛，耳聾而好瞑，取之骨，以第四鍼，五十九，刺骨；病不食，齧齒耳青，索骨於腎，不得，索之土，土者，脾也。 The patient has a fever and is heavy with bone pain, deafness, and likes to sleep. Take the bones using the fourth needle, number 59, to pierce the bones. The illness does not allow eating, the teeth are grinding and the ears are green. Pierce the bone in the kidney; if unable, pierce the soil which is the spleen.

14: 熱病不知所痛，耳聾，不能自收，口乾，陽熱甚，陰頗有寒者，熱在髓，死不可治。 The patient has a high fever with unknown pain, deafness that cannot be self-retracted, dry mouth, severe yang heat, a little yin cold. The heat is in the marrow, and it cannot be treated.

15: 熱病頭痛，顳顬目𤸪，脈痛，善衄，厥熱病也，取之以第三鍼，視有餘不足，寒熱痔。 Hot disease with headache, dizziness, pain in the pulse, good scabbing, and severe fever; this is a case of yin deficiency and excess heat. The treatment is to use the third needle, observing that there is still some insufficiency, cold-heat sores.

16: 熱病，體重，腸中熱，取之以第四鍼，於其俞，及下諸趾間，索氣于胃胳得氣也。 Hot disease, body weight, heat in the stomach, take it with the fourth lancet at the tip and below the toes, and extract gas from the abdomen and intestines

17: 熱病挾臍急痛，胸脅滿，取之涌泉與陰陵泉，取以第四鍼，鍼嗌裏。 The patient has a fever and is experiencing severe pain in the liver area, feeling oppressed in the chest. Obtain the medicine called Jiuquan Yulin Wan from the fourth prong of the needle holder and insert it into the tongue's interior.

18: 熱病，而汗且出，及脈順可汗者，取之魚際、太淵、大都、太白。寫之則熱去，補之則汗出，汗出大甚，取內踝上橫脈以止之。 For fever, if the sweat comes out and the pulse is regular, take from the herbs of fish-wing, great profundity, capital city, and Tai He. Write it down and the fever will disappear, apply it and the sweat will come out. If the sweat comes out in great quantity, stop it by taking the horizontal pulse at the inside of the ankle.

19: 熱病已得汗而脈尚躁盛，此陰脈之極也，死；其得汗而脈靜者，生。 If a person has a fever and sweats, but their pulse is still rapid and strong, this indicates the extreme state of the yin pulse, meaning death; if they sweat but their pulse becomes calm, it means they will live.

20: 熱病者，脈尚盛躁而不得汗者，此陽脈之極也，死；脈盛躁得汗靜者，生。 In the case of a feverish patient whose pulse is still strong and agitated but fails to perspire, this indicates an extreme state of the Yang-pulse, resulting in death. If the pulse is strong and agitated but the patient does eventually sweat and recover, they will survive.

21: 熱病不可刺者有九：一曰：汗不出，大顴發赤噦者死；二曰：泄而腹滿甚者死；三曰：目不明，熱不已者死；四曰：老人嬰兒熱而腹滿者死；五曰：汗不出嘔下血者死；六曰：舌本爛，熱不已者死；七曰：咳而衄，汗不出，出不至足者死；八曰：髓熱者死；九曰：熱而痙者死。腰折，瘈瘲，齒噤齘也。凡此九者，不可刺也。 There are nine conditions in which one should not lance a fever: 1. A person with high fever, red face and tongue, but no sweating will die; 2. If there is discharge of pus from the abdomen accompanied by great fullness, that person will die; 3. If the eyes are not clear and the fever persists, that person will die; 4. If an elderly person or infant has a high fever with fullness in the abdomen, that person will die; 5. If there is no sweating and vomiting of blood from below the mouth, that person will die; 6. If the tongue is originally scorched and the fever persists, that person will die; 7. If one coughs and has hemoptysis, with no sweating and not reaching sufficient amount, that person will die; 8. If the marrow is affected by fever, that person will die; 9. If there is a convulsion due to fever, that person will die. Dislocation of the waist, scrofula, and tooth decay also occur. All these nine conditions should not be lanced

22: 所謂五十九刺者，兩手外內側各三，凡十二痏。五指間各一，凡八痏，足亦如是。頭入髮一寸傍三分各三，凡六痏。更入髮三寸邊五，凡十痏。耳前後口下者各一，項中一，凡六痏。巔上一，聰會一，髮際一，廉泉一，風池二，天柱二。 Regarding the fifty-nine needles [term], on the outer side of each hand there are three, making a total of twelve. Between the five fingers, there is one needle each, making a total of eight. The feet are also like this. For the head, one inch entering the hair and each side has three, making a total of six. Adding another three inches entering the hair and five at the edge, making a total of ten. There is one each for the front and back of the ears, the lower mouth, and the center of the throat, making a total of six. One for the top, one for understanding, one for the hairline, one for the modest wellspring, two for the wind pond, and two for the pillar of heaven.

23: 氣滿胸中喘息，取足太陰大趾之端，去爪甲如薤葉，寒則留之，熱則疾之，氣下乃止。 The chest is filled with gasping breath, seize the tip of the great toe of the foot yin, remove the nails like pearl leaves, cold then keep it, hot then rush it, when the gasp stops.

24: 心疝暴痛，取足太陰厥陰，盡刺去其血絡。 The pain in the chest is intense; take the foot too-yin and pinch it to remove its blood vessels.

25: 喉痺舌卷，口中乾，煩心，心痛，臂內廉痛，不可及頭，取手小指次指爪甲下，去端如韭葉。 Throat constriction and tongue twisted, dry mouth, irritable heart, heartache, pain in the arms, cannot reach the head, take the hand little finger and ring finger nails, cut off the end like a radish leaf.

26: 目中赤痛，從內眥始，取之陰蹻。 In the heart's red pain, from the inner corner [of the eye] it begins, taken from the yin secretion (tears).

27: 風痙身反折，先取足太陽及膕中及血絡出血，中有寒，取三里。 The patient experiences chills and their body is twisting. First, take the moxa at the Sinew Channel points on the foot (such as Yanglingquan, Qiahai, and Shenmen) and apply bleeding cupping therapy. If there is coldness, take three li of medicine.

28: 癃，取之陰蹻及三毛上及血絡出血。 Literary Chinese, also known as Classical Chinese, is a form of the Chinese language that has been used for over 2000 years. It is characterized by its use of ancient vocabulary and grammar rules. The given sentence does not seem to be in Literary Chinese but rather in Modern Standard Mandarin with traditional characters.

Translation: Shoot, take away the yin fluid from the belly and the hair of the three hairs, and there will be blood vessels bleeding.

Note that this translation is based on the assumption that it is not Classical Chinese, but Modern Standard Mandarin written in traditional characters. If you meant to ask for a translation of Literary Chinese, please provide an accurate representation of the text as the grammar structure and vocabulary can be quite different.

29: 男子如蠱，女子如怚，身體腰脊如解，不欲飲食，先取涌泉見血，視跗上盛者，盡見血也。 A man is like a snake, and a woman is like a weaver. Their bodies are as flexible as a rope being untied. They do not wish to eat or drink. First, they take the gushing spring water and see blood. Those who see it abundant also see blood.

docs.title: 厥病
docs.text:
1: 厥頭痛，面若腫起而煩心，取之足陽明太陰。厥頭痛，頭脈痛，心悲，善泣，視頭動脈反盛者，刺盡去血，後調足厥陰。 Headache, with the face feeling swollen and disturbing the mind, take sufficient Yang Ming and Yin Bai. Headache, headache, heartache, crying well, looking at the pulsating head blood vessel that is full, pierce to let blood and then apply moxa to the Kidney Yin.

2: 厥頭痛，貞貞頭重而痛，寫頭上五行，行五，先取手少陰，後取足少陰。厥頭痛，意善忘，按之不得，取頭面左右動脈，後取足太陰。 Headache, headache with heaviness and pain, write the five elements on the forehead, perform the five, first take the hand shao yin, then take the foot shao yin. For headache, mind good and forgetting, pressing it does not alleviate, take the head's left and right dynamic vessels, then take the foot tai yin.

3: 厥頭痛，項先痛，腰脊為應，先取天柱，後取足太陽。厥頭痛，頭痛甚，耳前後脈湧有熱，寫出其血，後取足少陽。 The text describes a condition and the corresponding acupuncture points to alleviate the symptoms. Here is the translation:

Headache and neck pain, back pain, first take the Heaven's Pillar and then take the Bladder's Brightness. Headache severe, with hot pulse at both temples, release the blood by writing, then take the Minor Yin.

Note that writing here refers to a specific acupuncture technique, not literally writing with a pen or pencil. The text also mentions some acupoints by their traditional names in Chinese medicine: 天柱 (Heaven's Pillar), 足太陽 (Bladder's Brightness), and 足少阳 (Minor Yin).

4: 真頭痛，頭痛甚，腦盡痛，手足寒至節，死不治。 Extreme headache, headache severe, brain pain completely, hands and feet cold to the bone, cannot be cured until death.

5: 頭痛不可取於腧者，有所擊墮，惡血在於內，若肉傷，痛未已，可則刺，不可遠取也。頭痛不可刺者，大痺為惡，日作者，可令少愈，不可已。頭半寒痛，先取手少陽陽明，後取足少陽陽明。 For headache at the temples that cannot be relieved by pressing, there is a fall and bad blood inside. If there is muscle injury and the pain has not yet stopped, then one can needle it, but do not take it too far away. For headaches that should not be needled, severe headache is bad, caused by a daytime evil spirit, which can make it slightly better, but do not let it persist. For half-cold headache, first take the hand Shaoyang Jingming, then take the foot Shaoyang Jingming.

6: 厥心痛，與背相控，善瘈，如從後觸其心，傴僂者，腎心痛也，先取京骨、崑崙，發狂不已，取然谷。厥心痛，腹脹胸滿，心尤痛甚，胃心痛也，取之大都、大白。 The patient's heart aches, leaning against the back. It hurts on the right side, as if one is poked in the heart from behind. The patient is dizzy and restless, taking herbal medicine to no avail. Then, take rhubarb root. The patient's heart aches severely, with abdomen distended and chest full. The heart pain is particularly severe, due to stomach discomfort. Take ginseng and liquorice.

7: 厥心痛，痛如以錐鍼刺其心，心痛甚者，脾心痛也，取之然谷、太谿。 Extreme pain in the heart, as if a needle were piercing it. If the heart pain is severe, it is due to a disharmony between the spleen and heart. Treat with rhizoma atractylodis macrococcae (dang shen) and rhizoma blemia (tong caulis).

8: 厥心痛，色蒼蒼如死狀，終日不得太息，肝心痛也，取之行間、太衝。 The heart aches, the color turns pale like death, unable to take a deep breath all day, it is a pain in the liver and gallbladder, taking medicine while walking or sitting.

9: 厥心痛，臥若徒居，心痛間，動作，痛益甚，色不變，肺心痛也，取之魚際、太淵。 The heart aches, lying as if constantly dwelling, the pain in the heart increases with movement, the color remains unchanged, it is pain between the lungs and heart, taking from the lower back/kidneys.

10: 真心痛，手足清至節，心痛甚，日發夕死，夕發旦死。心痛不可刺者，中有盛聚，不可取於腧。 Deep grief, hands and feet thoroughly washed, heart grieves greatly, daytime sending forth, evening dying, evening sending forth, dawn dying. The pain of the heart cannot be pierced; there is a great accumulation in the middle, and it cannot be obtained from the liver.

11: 腸中有蟲瘕及蛟蛕，皆不可取以小鍼；心腸痛，憹作痛，腫聚，往來上下行，痛有休止，腹熱喜渴涎出者，是蛟蛕也。以手聚按而堅持之，無令得移，以大鍼刺之，久持之，蟲不動，乃出鍼也。㤣腹憹痛，形中上者。 Inside the intestines, there are parasites and Leeches. They cannot be removed with a small lancet. When the abdomen and heart hurt, they cause pain that comes and goes, swelling that gathers and disperses, moving up and down. The pain has periods of relief, and the abdomen is hot, thirsty, and produces saliva. This is the case with Leeches. Holding the area with one hand and pressing firmly will prevent movement. Continuously pierce it with a large lancet until the parasite does not move and then comes out. 2. Pain in the abdomen and chest

12: 耳聾無聞，取耳中；耳鳴，取耳前動脈；耳痛不可刺者，耳中有膿，若有乾聆聊，耳無聞也；耳聾取手小指次指爪甲上與肉交者，先取手，後取足；耳鳴取手中指爪甲上，左取右，右取左，先取手，後取足。 Deafness without hearing, take from the ear; tinnitus, take from the front of the carotid artery; painful ears that cannot be lanced, there is pus in the ear, if there is dry yellow ears, it is deafness; taking the ear with the fingertips of the small finger and the second finger, first take the hand and then take the foot; tinnitus, take from the finger joints of the hands, left take right, right take left, first take the hand and then take the foot.

13: 足髀不可舉，側而取之，在樞合中，以員利鍼，大鍼不可刺。病注下血，取曲泉。 The thigh cannot be lifted; it must be taken from the side. In the joint, use a small needle with an advantageous handle. The large needle should not be inserted. Blood is drained below the disease site, and take curved water.

14: 風痺淫礫，病不可已者，足如履冰，時如入湯中，股脛淫礫，煩心頭痛，時嘔時悗，眩已汗出，久則目眩，悲以喜恐，短氣，不樂，不出三年死也。 The person with a venereal disease, if it is not treatable, walks as if treading on ice and feels as though submerged in hot water. The genitals are inflamed like a pustule, causing headache, nausea, and occasional vomiting. Dizziness leads to sweating, which in turn causes the eyes to become dizzy, eventually leading to blindness. Overcome by sadness and fear, they experience shortness of breath, cannot find joy, and may die within three years.

docs.title: 病本
docs.text:
1: 先病而後逆者，治其本；先逆而後病者，治其本；先寒而後生病者，治其本；先病而後生寒者，治其本；先熱而後生病者，治其本。 Those who become ill and then develop chills should be treated at the root; those who develop chills before becoming ill should also be treated at the root; those who become ill due to cold and then develop a fever should be treated at the root; those who develop a fever before becoming ill due to cold should also be treated at the root.

2: 先泄而後生他病者，治其本，必且調之，乃治其他病。先病而後中滿者，治其標；先病後泄者，治其本；先中滿而後煩心者，治其本。 In the case of a patient who first complained of another illness before developing this one, treat its root cause and also regulate it; then treat the other illness. In the case of someone who first fell ill before eventually being fully affected, treat their symptoms; in the case of someone whose initial condition led to subsequent agitation of the heart, treat its root cause.

3: 有客氣，有同氣。大小便不利治其標，大小便利，治其本。 Have courtesy and politeness; have intimacy and friendship. When the bowels are not easy to move, establish a remedy for the symptoms, when the bowels are easy to move, treat the underlying cause.

4: 病發而有餘，本而標之，先治其本，後治其標；病發而不足，標而本之，先治其標，後治其本，謹詳察間甚，以意調之，間者並行，甚為獨行；先小大便不利而後生他病者，治其本也。 In the case of a disease with ample resources, one should first address the root and then treat the manifestation; in the case of a disease without sufficient resources, one should treat the manifestation and then address the root. This distinction is crucial, as it requires careful attention to determine when to prioritize treatment and when to focus on prevention. When a person experiences minor discomfort before developing another illness, one must address the root cause.

docs.title: 雜病
docs.text:
1: 厥挾脊而痛者，至頂，頭沉沉然，目𥆨𥆨然，腰脊強。取足太陽膕中血絡。 For a person with pain in the spine, when they arrive at the top [of the condition], their head feels heavy and their eyes are sunken. Their waist and back feel strong. Apply pressure to the Joint Well point on the sole of the foot.

2: 厥胸滿面腫，唇漯漯然，暴言難，甚則不能言，取足陽明。 The chest is bloated, the face swollen, the mouth drools, speech is difficult, sometimes it's impossible to speak, and taking the Yang Ming pulse.

3: 厥氣走喉而不能言，手足清，大便不利，取足少陰。 The qi is not circulating through the throat, making it difficult to speak. The hands and feet are cold, bowel movements are infrequent, and the pulse is shallow in the left foot.

4: 厥而腹嚮嚮然，多寒氣，腹中穀穀，便溲難，取足太陰。 The abdomen was moving and tumbling, there was much cold qi, grains in the abdomen were scattered, defecation was difficult, and the foot too yang was taken.

5: 嗌乾，口中熱如膠，取足少陰。 Dry up the leaky faucet, the saliva in your mouth is as hot as glue, and take a little of the Small Yin.

This passage appears to be an idiomatic or colloquial expression. The first part seems to refer to stopping something that is dripping or leaking. The phrase saliva in your mouth is as hot as glue could be a figure of speech meaning to have difficulty speaking, while the mention of Small Yin might refer to an herbal remedy used in traditional Chinese medicine for treating certain conditions.

6: 膝中痛，取犢鼻，以員利鍼，發而間之。鍼大如氂，刺膝無疑。 The knee hurts, take a rooster comb, use an employee's acupuncture needle, and insert it between. The needle is as large as a weasel, without a doubt, the needle penetrates the knee.

7: 喉痺不能言，取足陽明；能言，取手陽明。 If one cannot speak due to a throat obstruction, take the Yang Ming from the foot; if one can speak, take the Yang Ming from the hand.

8: 瘧不渴，間日而作，取足陽明；渴而日作，取手陽明。 If you're thirsty and your body is hot during the day, take Yang Ming from the foot. If you're thirsty and your body is hot during the night, take Yang Ming from the hand.

9: 齒痛，不惡清飲，取足陽明；惡清飲，取手陽明。 Toothache, not averse to clear drinks, take the Jiao Yin; averse to clear drinks, take the Shé Yín.

10: 聾而不痛者，取足少陽；聾而痛者，取手陽明。 For those who are deaf but not in pain, take the foot Jueyin; for those who are deaf and in pain, take the Hand Yangming.

11: 衄而不止，衄血流，取足太陽；衄血，取手太陽。不已，刺宛骨下；不已，刺膕中出血。 Bleeding does not stop, bleeding blood, take foot Taiyang; Bleeding, take hand Taiyang. Not yet done, acupuncture Yuan point below; Not yet done, acupuncture Ligament channel bleeding.

12: 腰痛，痛上寒，取足太陽陽明；痛上熱，取足厥陰；不可以俛仰，取足少陽。中熱而喘，取足少陰膕中血絡。 Back pain, with pain cold rising, take foot Taiyang and Yangming; with pain hot rising, take foot Wei Yin. Not to bend over, take foot Shaoyang. With internal heat and shortness of breath, take foot Shao Yin's Chong middle blood vessels. Note: The translation provided is for the text as-is without taking into account any context or additional information. A more accurate translation would require further clarification on the specific condition being treated and the desired outcome. This translation attempts to provide a basic understanding of the Chinese text in English.

13: 喜怒而不欲食，言益小，刺足太陰；怒而多言，刺足少陽。 Desiring food but not eating, speaking less, and needing more acupuncture at the small intesture; getting angry and talking a lot, needing more acupuncture at the bladder.

14: 顑痛，刺手陽明與顑之盛脈出血。 Achilles, the doctor Yang Ming pierced his pulse and blood flowed out.

15: 項痛不可俛仰，刺足太陽；不可以顧，刺手太陽也。 If there is pain in the area of the armpit, do not lean over; acupuncture the sun at the foot; and do not look back, also acupuncture the sun at the hand.

16: 小腹滿大，上走胃，至心，淅淅身時寒熱，小便不利，取足厥陰。 The stomach is distended and full, the qi ascends to the chest, disturbing the heart, causing intermittent feelings of coldness and heat, difficult urination, and use the foot-Taiyang (Exterior) method.

17: 腹滿，大便不利，腹大，亦上走胸嗌，喘息喝喝然，取足少陰。 Full, constipated bowel movements, abdomen enlarged, also ascending and descending urethral discharge, wheezing and swallowing, taking little yin foot.

18: 腹滿食不化，腹嚮嚮然，不能大便，取足太陰。 Full of food but unable to transform, the stomach is rumbling and one cannot defecate. Take sufficient Pinellia.

19: 心痛引腰脊，欲嘔，取足少陰。 Heartache causing pain in the back, wanting to vomit, taking the foot-Taiyang.

Translation: Heartache causing back pain and nausea, use Taiyang (foot) acupuncture.

20: 心痛，腹脹，牆牆然，大便不利，取足太陰。 Heartache, bloated abdomen, feeling confined, difficult bowel movements, take the foot Taiyin.

21: 心痛，引背不得息，刺足少陰；不已，取手少陽。 Heartache, causing one to take shallow breaths and lean back; accompanied by stabbing pain in the soles of the feet. This does not subside, leading one to grasp at the wrist joint.

22: 心痛引小腹滿，上下無常處，便溲難，刺足厥陰。 Heartache causing pain in the lower abdomen, unsteady on both sides, difficult to relieve, insert needles at the foot Jueyin.

23: 心痛，但短氣不足以息，刺手太陰。 Heartache, but the breath is too short to sigh, the pulse is too weak.

24: 心痛，當九節刺之，按，已刺按之，立已；不已，上下求之，得之立已。 Heartache, when it is at the nine orifices and pressed, if pressed and pierced, it is done; if not done, seek up and down until found, and then it is done

25: 顑痛，刺足陽明曲周動脈，見血，立已；不已，按人迎於經，立已。 Insert the needle quickly, and stimulate the Yangming channel at the Zhongdu point on the wrist. Observe for bleeding, then cease. If there is no bleeding, press the person firmly against the meridian, observe for any reaction, then cease.

26: 氣逆上，刺膺中陷者，與下胸動脈。 Upon reversal of Qi, when piercing the diaphragm and sinking into the lower chest, connect with the chest's dynamic vessels.

27: 腹痛，刺臍左右動脈，已刺按之，立已；不已，刺氣街，已刺按之，立已。 Abdominal pain, puncture the umbilicus left and right to locate the pulse. Already done? Stand up; if not yet, puncture Qi Street and when you have located the pulse, stand up.

28: 痿厥為四末束悗，乃疾解之，日二；不仁者，十日而知，無休，病已止。 Paralysis caused by the four extremities being numb and bound is treated urgently, resolving within two days; if not compassionate, it will be known in ten days, without rest, and once the illness has ceased.

29: 歲以草刺鼻，嚏，嚏而已；無息，而疾迎引之，立已；大驚之，亦可已。 Year after year, grass pricks the nose, sneezes, sneezes and that's all; without rest, hastily rushing to greet and catch it, standing already; greatly surprised, it can also be enough.

docs.title: 周痺
docs.text:
1: 黃帝問于歧伯曰：周痺之在身也，上下移徒隨脈，其上下左右相應，間不容空，願聞此痛，在血脈之中邪？將在分肉之間乎？何以致是？其痛之移也，間不及下鍼，其慉痛之時，不及定治，而痛已止矣。何道使然？願聞其故？歧伯答曰：此眾痺也，非周痺也。 The Yellow Emperor asked Chi Bo: In the case of the 'Week-recurrent pain,' it moves up and down following the pulse, with corresponding changes above and below. There is no room for anything in between, and I wish to know if this pain is within the blood vessels or in the muscles. How did this occur? The moving pain does not allow time for needle insertion, nor does there seem to be a proper time for treatment, yet the pain has already subsided. What can be said about this? Please explain the cause. Chi Bo replied: This is a case of 'massive pain,' not 'week-recurrent pain.'

2: 黃帝曰：願聞眾痺。歧伯對曰：此各在其處，更發更止，更居更起，以右應左，以左應右，非能周也。更發更休也。黃帝曰：善。刺之奈何？歧伯對曰：刺此者，痛雖已止，必刺其處，勿令復起。 Yellow Emperor said: I wish to hear about various joint pains. Hua Tuo replied: Each one is located in its place, with treatment and rest, moving and raising, right responding to left and left responding to right, not in the circle. Treating with needles, how should it be done? Hua Tuo said: The one who is pricked feels pain and stops, but must be pricked at the location to prevent it from rising again.

3: 帝曰：善。願聞周痺何如？歧伯對曰：周痺者，在於血脈之中，隨脈以上，隨脈以下，不能左右，各當其所。黃帝曰：刺之奈何？歧伯對曰：痛從上下者，先刺其下以過之，後刺其上以脫之。痛從下上者，先刺其上以過之，後刺其下以脫之。 The Emperor asked: Good. I wish to hear about the jaundice of the Zhou Dynasty? Taoist master Qi Bo replied: The jaundice of the Zhou Dynasty is within the blood vessels, moving along with the blood flow above and below, not being able to turn left or right, each according to its place. Emperor asked: How should it be needled? Taoist master Qi Bo said: If the pain comes from above and below, first needle below and then above to expel it; if the pain comes from below and above, first needle above and then below to expel it.

4: 黃帝曰：善。此痛安生？何因而有名？歧伯對曰：風寒濕氣，客於外分肉之間，迫切而為沫，沫得寒則聚，聚則排分肉而分裂也，分裂則痛，痛則神歸之，神歸之則熱，熱則痛解，痛解則厥，厥則他痺發，發則如是。帝曰：善。余已得其意矣。此內不在藏，而外未發於皮，獨居分肉之間，真氣不能周，故名曰周痺。故刺痺者，必先切循其下之六經，視其虛實，及大絡之血結而不通，及虛而脈陷空者而調之，熨而通之。其瘈堅轉引而行之。黃帝曰：善。余已得其意矣，亦得其事也。九者經巽之理，十二經脈陰陽之病也。 Yellow Emperor said: Good. Is this pain related to a new generation? What caused it to be named as such? Huang Di replied: Cold, dry winds and dampness, invading from the outside and acting between layers of flesh, causing a coating that becomes cold, which then accumulates and separates the flesh, leading to pain, and the spirit returns to this area, causing heat, heat resolves the pain, pain dissipates and leads to collapse, collapse triggers paralysis, paralysis occurs as such. Yellow Emperor said: Good. I have now understood it completely. This is not inside the stores, but outside manifesting on the skin, uniquely situated between layers of flesh, where true qi cannot circulate fully, so it is called circumferential paralysis. Therefore, when needling circumferential paralysis, one must first cut along its course below the six channels, observe its emptiness or fullness, and address any blood stagnation blocking the great vessels that do not flow freely and any empty veins causing a sunken pulse, using moxa to open them up. Finally, lead it in a firm, turning manner. Yellow Emperor said: Good. I have now understood completely, and also know how to apply this. These nine channels are related to the Pure Yang channel, and the twelve channels correspond to Yin-Yang diseases

docs.title: 口問
docs.text:
1: 黃帝閒居，辟左右而問於歧伯曰：余已聞九鍼之經，論陰陽逆順，六經已畢，願得口問。歧伯避席再拜曰：善乎哉問也，此先師之所口傳也。黃帝曰：願聞口傳。歧伯答曰：夫百病之始生也，皆生於風雨寒暑，陰陽喜怒，飲食居處，大驚卒恐。則血氣分離，陰陽破敗，經絡厥絕，脈道不通，陰陽相逆，衛氣稽留，經脈虛空，血氣不次，乃失其常。論不在經者，請道其方。 Emperor Yellow was leisurely at home, he separated to the left and right and asked Master Qi of Guo: I have already heard the Nine Needles Classic, discussing yin and yang, order and disorder, the six classics are complete, I wish to ask with my mouth. Master Qi avoided the seat and bowed again, saying: How wonderful is this question! This is what the master teaches in person. Emperor Yellow said: I want to hear the teaching from his mouth. Master Qi answered: The hundred diseases all originate from wind, rain, cold, and heat; yin and anger, drinking, eating, dwelling, great shock and fear. Thus blood and qi are separated, yin and yang are broken, channels and vessels are cut off, the flow of the meridians is blocked, yin and yang reverse each other, defensive qi stagnates, the channels and vessels are empty, blood and qi do not circulate, and thus they lose their normality. The discussion is not in the classic; please explain its method

2: 黃帝曰：人之欠者，何氣使然？歧伯答曰：衛氣晝日行於陽，夜半則行於陰，陰者主夜，夜者臥；陽者主上，陰者主下；故陰氣積於下，陽氣未盡，陽引而上，陰引而下，陰陽相引，故數欠。陽氣盡，陰氣盛，則目瞑；陰氣盡而陽氣盛，則寤矣。寫足少陰，補足太陽。 The Yellow Emperor asked: What causes people to be indebted? Zhou Yan answered: The Qi of Wei circulates during the daytime in the Yang aspect and at midnight in the Yin aspect. Yin governs night and rest; Yang governs above, while Yin governs below. Therefore, Yin Qi accumulates below, and Yang Qi is not yet exhausted. Yang pulls upward, and Yin pulls downward; Yin and Yang attract each other, so one often owes money. When Yang Qi is complete, and Yin Qi is abundant, the eyes are obscured. When Yin Qi is complete and Yang Qi is abundant, one will awaken. Prescribe more Kidney Yin and supplement Foot Yang.

3: 黃帝曰：人之噦者，何氣使然？歧伯曰：穀入于胃，胃氣上注于肺。今有故寒氣與新穀氣，俱還入于胃，新故相亂，真邪相攻，氣並相逆，復出於胃，故為噦。補手太陰，寫足少陰。 Yellow Emperor said: What causes the speech of people? The Duke of Shou replied: Grains enter the stomach, and stomach qi rises to the lungs. Now there is both old cold qi and new grain qi, both returning to the stomach, with old and new mixed up, true and false attacking each other, qi going opposite directions, causing it to come out of the stomach, thus leading to speech disorders. Supplement the hand with the Conception vessel, and write the Foot Yang Ming with the Lesser Yin.

4: 黃帝曰：人之唏者，何氣使然？歧伯曰：此陰氣盛而陽氣虛，陰氣疾而陽氣徐，陰氣盛而陽氣絕，故為唏。補足太陽，寫足少陰。 Yellow Emperor said: What causes people to feel fatigued? Qi Bo replied: When the yin qi is abundant and the yang qi is deficient, when the yin qi is rushing and the yang qi is slow, and when the yin qi is abundant and the yang qi is absent, this leads to fatigue. To supplement the great yang, write the foot-yang.

5: 黃帝曰：人之振寒者，何氣使然？歧伯曰：寒氣客於皮膚，陰氣盛，陽氣虛，故為振寒寒慄，補諸陽。 Yellow Emperor said: What causes people to shake with cold? Hua Tuo replied: The cold qi resides in the skin, yin qi is abundant, and yang qi is deficient, thus causing shaking from the cold and trembling. It should be supplemented with yang

6: 黃帝曰：人之噫者，何氣使然？歧伯曰：寒氣客於胃，厥逆從下上散，復出於胃，故為噫。補足太陰陽明，一曰補眉本也。 Yellow Emperor asked, What kind of qi causes people to belch? Huang Di replied, Cold qi accumulates in the stomach, and the evil qi rises from below and disperses, then exits through the stomach, which is why it results in belching. This also demonstrates the clarity of yin and yang.

7: 黃帝曰：人之嚏者，何氣使然？歧伯曰：陽氣和利，滿於心，出於鼻，故為嚏。補足太陽榮眉本，一曰眉上也。 Yellow Emperor said: What is the cause of a person's sneezing? The Duke of Shou replied: Yin energy harmonizes and nourishes, filling the heart, and emanates from the nose, which is why it is called sneezing. [Note from the supplementary commentary: The brightness of the sun comes from its eyebrows.]

8: 黃帝曰：人之嚲者，何氣使然？歧伯曰：胃不實則諸脈虛；諸脈虛則筋脈懈惰；筋脈懈惰則行陰用力，氣不能復，故為嚲。因其所在，補分肉間。 Yellow Emperor said: What is the cause of people being thin? Huangdi replied: If the stomach is not full, the vessels will be empty; if the vessels are empty, the muscles and vessels will become sluggish; when the muscles and vessels become sluggish, the vital energy cannot be restored, leading to thinness. Therefore, strengthen the area where it is lacking.

9: 黃帝曰：人之哀而泣涕出者，何氣使然？歧伯曰：心者，五藏六府之主也；目者，宗脈之所聚也，上液之道也；口鼻者，氣之門戶也。故悲哀愁憂則心動，心動則五藏六府皆搖，搖則宗脈感，宗脈感則液道開，液道開，故泣涕出焉。液者，所以灌精濡空竅者也，故上液之道開則泣，泣不止則液竭；液竭則精不灌，精不灌則目無所見矣，故命曰奪精。補天柱經俠頸。 Yellow Emperor said: What is the Qi that causes people to shed tears? Zhang Bao replied: The heart is the master of the five zang and six fu organs; the eyes are where the conception vessel, the pathway for fluid, gathers. The mouth and nose are the gates of Qi. Therefore, when one feels sorrow or sadness, the heart moves, causing all the zang and fu to shake. When they shake, the conception vessel is affected, opening up the fluid pathway. This leads to tears flowing out. Tears flow because the fluid serves to moisten the channels, so when the fluid pathway opens up, tears are shed; when they do not stop, the fluid is depleted. When the fluid is depleted, Qi cannot be nourished, and without Qi nourishment, one will see nothing with their eyes. Thus it is called losing one's essence. This is from the Lingshui Jing: Treatise on the Celestial Pillar.

10: 黃帝曰：人之太息者，何氣使然？歧伯曰：憂思則心系急，心系急則氣道約，約則不利，故太息以伸出之，補手少陰心主，足少陽留之也。 Yellow Emperor said: Why would excessive breathing lead to the loss of Qi? The Duke of Shou replied: When one is anxious and thinking, the heart becomes tense, and when the heart is tense, the meridians become constricted. Constricted meridians are not beneficial, so excessive breathing extends them outward. By supplementing the Kidney's deficient Yin and nourishing the Heart, and tonifying the Yang in the limbs.

11: 黃帝曰：人之涎下者，何氣使然？歧伯曰：飲食者，皆入于胃，胃中有熱則蟲動，蟲動則胃緩，胃緩則廉泉開，故涎下，補足少陰。 Yellow Emperor asked: What Qi causes the fluidity from below? The Duke of Zhou replied: Those who consume food and drink, all enter the stomach. If the stomach has heat, the worms move, the stomach becomes relaxed, the stomach relaxes and the spring opens, thus causing the fluidity from below, supplementing the kidney yin.

12: 黃帝曰：人之耳中鳴者，何氣使然？歧伯曰：耳者，宗脈之所聚也，故胃中空則宗脈虛，虛則下溜，脈有所竭者，故耳鳴，補客主人，手大指爪甲上與肉交者也。 Yellow Emperor said: What causes the sound in a person's ear? Huang Di replied: The ear is where the primeval Qi gathers, so if the stomach is empty, the primeval Qi will be deficient, causing it to leak. When there is a lack of Qi, one might experience ringing in the ears. To treat this condition, apply pressure with the tip of the thumbnail and the base of the nail on the flesh where the skin meets, as if supplementing the chief organ.

13: 黃帝曰：人之自齧舌者，何氣使然？此厥逆走上，脈氣輩至也。少陰氣至則齧舌，少陽氣至則齧頰，陽明氣至則齧唇矣。視主病者，則補之。 Emperor Yellow said: Why do people grind their tongues? This is due to the rebellious qi rising up, and vital energy reaching a critical point. When deficient yin energy reaches this point, it causes tongue grinding; when deficient yang energy reaches this point, it causes tongue grinding as well; and when yang brightness energy reaches this point, it causes lip grinding. In treating the patient's main complaint, one should supplement accordingly.

14: 凡此十二邪者，皆奇邪之走空竅者也。故邪之所在，皆為不足。故上氣不足，腦為之不滿，耳為之苦鳴，頭為之苦傾，目為之眩。中氣不足，溲便為之變，腸為之苦鳴。下氣不足，則乃為痿厥心悗。補足外踝下留之。 Regarding these twelve evils, all are of the strange and unusual type who walk through empty passages. Therefore, evil lies in what is insufficient. Therefore, with Qi insufficiency, the brain is not filled, causing ear pain and ringing, headache, and dizziness of the eyes. With middle-Qi insufficiency, the defecation changes, causing abdominal pain and rumbling. With lower-Qi insufficiency, it leads to flaccid paralysis and weak pulse. Supplementing the sole of the foot can help.

15: 黃帝曰：治之奈何？歧伯曰：腎主為欠，取足少陰；肺主為噦，取手太陰、足少陰；唏者，陰與陽絕，故補足太陽，寫足少陰；振寒者，補諸陽；噫者，補足太陰陽明；嚏者，補足太陽眉本；嚲，因其所在，補分肉間；泣出補天柱經俠頸，俠頸者，頭中分也；太息，補手少陰、心主、足少陽，留之；涎下補足少陰；耳鳴補客主人，手大指爪甲上與肉交者；自嚙舌，視主病者，則補之。目眩頭傾，補足外踝下留之；痿厥心悗，刺足大趾間上二寸，留之，一曰足外踝下留之。 Emperor Yellow asked: What method should be used to treat this? Master Qi Bo replied: The kidney is responsible for deficiency, so take the foot Shaoyang; the lung is rebelling, take the hand Taiyang and foot Shaoyang; the one who stagnates, the yin and yang are blocked, so supplement the foot Taiyang, and write the foot Shaoyang; those who disperse cold, supplement the Zhong Yang; those who cough, supplement the foot Taiyang from the Mingmen; those who hawk, supplement the foot Taiji Yangming; those with a hoarse voice, supplement the foot Taiji; those who have difficulty breathing, supplement the hand Shaoyang and heart governor, leave it in; those who drool, supplement the foot Shaoyin; those with tinnitus, supplement the client master; those who self-eat saliva, treat the chief disease; dizziness and headache, supplement the foot Kunlun; paralysis of the extremities, supplement the foot outside the ankle and leave it in; weak pulse and shortness of breath, puncture the foot Jing well at the top of the big toe for two inches and leave it in, one says to supplement the foot outside the ankle and leave it in.

docs.title: 五藏生成
docs.text:
1: 心之合脈也，其榮色也，其主腎也。肺之合皮也，其榮毛也，其主心也。肝之合筋也，其榮爪也，其主肺也。脾之合肉也，其榮脣也，其主肝也。腎之合骨也，其榮髮也，其主脾也。 The harmonization of the heart with the pulse and its luster; the heart governs the kidneys. The harmony of the lung with the skin and its luster; the lung governs the heart. The harmony of the liver with the tendons and its luster; the liver governs the lungs. The harmony of the spleen with the flesh and its luster; the spleen governs the liver. The kidney's harmonization with the bones and its luster; the kidney governs the spleen.

2: 是故多食鹹則脈凝泣而變色；多食苦則皮槁而毛拔；多食辛則筋急而爪枯；多食酸則肉胝䐢而脣揭；多食甘則骨痛而髮落，此五味之所傷也。故心欲苦，肺欲辛，肝欲酸，脾欲甘，腎欲鹹，此五味之所合也。五藏之氣，故色見青如草茲者死，黃如枳實者死，黑如尚炱者死，赤如衃血者死，白如枯骨者死，此五色之見死也。青如翠羽者生，赤如雞冠者生，黃如蟹腹者生，白如豕膏者生，黑如烏羽者生，此五色之見生也。生於心，如以縞裹朱；生於肺，如以縞裹紅；生於肝，如以縞裹紺；生於脾，如以縞裹栝樓實，生於腎，如以縞裹紫，此五藏所生之外榮也。色味當五藏：白當肺，辛，赤當心，苦，青當肝，酸，黃當脾，甘，黑當腎，鹹，故白當皮，赤當脈，青當筋，黃當肉，黑當骨。 Therefore, an excess of salty leads to the solidification and weeping of the veins, changing color; an excess of bitter causes the skin to thicken and hair to fall out; an excess of pungent makes tendons urgent and nails dry; an excess of sour makes the flesh swell and jaws protrude, and an excess of sweet causes bones to hurt and hair to fall, which are the damages caused by the five tastes. Thus, if the heart desires bitter, the lungs desire pungent, the liver desires sour, the spleen desires sweet, and the kidneys desire salty, these are the damages caused by the five tastes. The vital energy of the five organs, therefore, the person who sees colors like green grass will die, yellow like chestnuts will die, black like charcoal will die, red like vermilion blood will die, and white like dry bones will die, these are the colors that see death. Green like jade feathers is alive, red like chicken combs is alive, yellow like crab bellies is alive, white like pig lard is alive, black like crow feathers is alive, these are the colors that see life. Born in the heart, it's like wrapping with vermilion; born in the lungs, it's like wrapping with red; born in the liver, it's like wrapping with dark blue; born in the spleen, it's like wrapping with the color of lotus seeds; born in the kidneys, it's like wrapping with purple, these are the external honors of the five organs. Colors and flavors correspond to the five organs: white corresponds to the lungs, pungent, red corresponds to the heart, bitter, green corresponds to the liver, sour, yellow corresponds to the spleen, sweet, black corresponds to the kidneys, salty, so white corresponds to skin, red corresponds to blood vessels, green corresponds to tendons, yellow corresponds to flesh, and black corresponds to bones.

3: 諸脈者皆屬於目，諸髓者皆屬於腦，諸筋者皆屬於節，諸血者皆屬於心，諸氣者皆屬於肺，此四支八谿之朝夕也。故人臥，血歸於肝，肝受血而能視，足受血而能步，掌受血而能握，指受血而能攝。臥出而風吹之，血凝於膚者為痺，凝於脈者為泣，凝於足者為厥。此三者，血行而不得反其空，故為痺厥也。人有大谷十二分，小谿三百五十四名，少十二俞，此皆衛氣之所留止，邪氣之所客也，鍼石緣而去之。 All the vessels are under the jurisdiction of the eyes; all the marrows are under the jurisdiction of the brain; all the tendons are under the jurisdiction of the bones; all the blood is under the jurisdiction of the heart; all the qi is under the jurisdiction of the lungs. The four limbs and eight vessels change day and night. Therefore, when a person lies down, blood returns to the liver, the liver receives blood and can see, the feet receive blood and can walk, the palms receive blood and can grip, and the fingers receive blood and can grasp. Upon rising from lying down and being exposed to the wind, if the blood congeals at the skin it is a case of rigidity; if it congeals in the vessels it is a case of weeping; if it congeals at the feet it is a case of stroke. These three cases are when the blood fails to return and reverse its pathway, resulting in rigidity and stroke. A person has large intestines divided into twelve parts and small intestines with 354 sections, some of which are missing, all of these being the locations where defensive qi resides and evil qi lodges. Use acupuncture and moxibustion to drive them out.

4: 診病之始五決為紀，欲知其始，先建其母，所謂五決者五脈也。是以頭痛巔疾，下虛上實過在足少陰，巨陽甚則入腎。徇蒙招尤目冥耳聾，下實上虛，過在足少陽，厥陰甚則入肝。腹滿䐜脹，支鬲胠脇，下厥上冒，過在足太陰，陽明。欬嗽上氣，厥在胸中，過在手陽明太陰。心煩頭痛病在鬲中，過在手巨陽，少陰。 The onset of disease is determined by five signs, and in order to know its origin, one must first investigate its mother. The term five signs refers to the five pulse positions. Therefore, headache with sudden onset, pain that is acute, is due to an excess condition in the foot Shaoyang. If there is a strong excess, it will enter the Spleen. Deafness, blindness, and tinnitus, with internal symptoms and external manifestations, are due to an excess condition in the foot Shao Yang, with a strong Bladder involved, potentially entering the Liver. Abdominal fullness, distension, and constipation, with internal stagnation and external manifestations, is due to a deficiency-excess condition in the foot Taiyin, involving the Yin and Yang of the Stomach. Dysphagia and difficulty speaking, with Qi rising upward, is due to a deficiency-excess condition in the foot Shaoyang, involving the Yin of the Lungs. Heart palpitations and headache, with disease located in the region of the Gallbladder, are due to an excess condition in the Gallbladder, involving the Shao Yang and the foot Shaoyang.

5: 夫脈之小大滑濇浮沈，可以指別；五藏之象，可以類推；五藏相音，可以意識；五色微診，可以目察。能合脈色，可以萬全。赤脈之至也喘而堅，診曰有積氣在中，時害於食，名曰心痺，得之外疾，思慮而心虛，故邪從之。白脈之至也喘而浮，上虛下實。驚，有積氣在胸中，喘而虛名曰肺痺寒熱，得之醉而使內也。青脈之至也長而左右彈有積氣在心下支胠，名曰肝痺，得之寒濕，與疝同法，腰痛足清頭痛。黃脈之至也大而虛，有積氣在腹中，有厥氣名曰厥疝，女子同法，得之疾使四支汗出當風。黑脈之至也上堅而大有積氣在小腹與陰，名曰腎痺，得之沐浴清水而臥。 Regarding the pulse, its smallness, largeness, smoothness, and turbidity can be distinguished. The signs of the Five Organs can be inferred; the sounds of the Five Organs can be discerned; subtle variations in color can be observed. One who can harmonize the pulse, color, and complexion can diagnose thoroughly.

The superiority of the red pulse is that it becomes hard upon panting; it is diagnosed as having accumulated Qi within, which may harm eating, and is called Heart stagnation. Obtained externally, thinking and worrying lead to Heart vacuity, causing pathogens to invade.

The superiority of the white pulse is that it becomes float upon panting, with emptiness above and fullness below. Shock, having accumulated Qi in the chest, is diagnosed as Lung stagnation, hot or cold; obtained from drunkenness, it indicates internal injury.

The superiority of the blue-green pulse is that it becomes long and fluctuates with the presence of accumulated Qi in the lower abdomen and intestines, diagnosed as Liver stagnation, similar to dampness Dysuria, causing back pain, clear headache, and dizziness.

The superiority of the yellow pulse is that it becomes large and empty, with accumulated Qi in the abdomen and deficiency of vital Qi, diagnosed as Kidney stagnation; similar for women, obtained from a sudden illness causing sweating, fever, and wind-stroke symptoms.

The superiority of the black pulse is that it becomes hard above and large with the presence of accumulated Qi in the lower abdomen and Yin, diagnosed as Bladder stagnation; obtained from bathing in clear water while lying down.

6: 凡相五色之奇脈，面黃目青，面黃目赤，面黃目白，面黃目黑者，皆不死也。面青目赤，面赤目白，面青目黑，面黑目白，面赤目青，皆死也。 Anyone with the remarkable meridian of five colors, having a yellow face and green eyes, or a yellow face and red eyes, or a yellow face and white eyes, or a yellow face and black eyes; those with a green face and red eyes, a red face and white eyes, a green face and black eyes, or a black face and red eyes, will all not die.

docs.title: 師傳
docs.text:
1: 黃帝曰：余聞先師，有所心藏，弗著於方，余願聞而藏之，則而行之，上以治民，下以治身，使百姓無病，上下和親，德澤下流，子孫無優，傳於後世，無有終時，可得聞乎？歧伯曰：遠乎哉問也。夫治民與自治，治彼與治此，治小與治大，治國與治家，未有逆而能治之也，夫惟順而已矣。順者，非獨陰陽脈，論氣之逆順也，百姓人民皆欲順其志也。 Yellow Emperor said: I have heard that the esteemed master has a secret heart, which is not revealed in the four directions, and I wish to hear it and put it into practice. It will govern the upper and the lower, govern the people and govern oneself so that there are no diseases among the common folk; relations between the upper and lower are harmonious, virtues permeate downstream, having no descendants in inferior positions, being passed down to future generations without end, can this be heard? Duke of Zhou said: How distant is this matter! Governing others and governing oneself, governing that which is outside and governing that which is within, governing the state and governing the family, none who are not in accordance with it will be able to govern. Only those who follow it can achieve success. Following refers not only to the yin and yang channels, but also discusses the order of qi. All common people desire to follow their aspirations.

2: 黃帝曰：順之奈何？歧伯曰：入國問俗，入家問諱，上堂問禮，臨病人問所便。 Yellow Emperor asked, How about following? Duke of Zhou replied, When entering a country, one should inquire about customs; when entering a family, one should inquire about traditions; when entering a hall, one should inquire about etiquette; and when facing illness, one should ask what is appropriate.

3: 黃帝曰：便病人奈何？歧伯曰：夫中熱消癉，則便寒；寒中之屬，則便熱。胃中熱則消谷，令人懸心善飢。臍以上皮熱，腸中熱，則出黃如糜。臍以下皮寒，胃中寒，則腹脹；腸中寒，則腸鳴飧泄。胃中寒，腸中熱，則脹而且泄，胃中熱，腸中寒，則疾飲，小腹痛脹。 Yellow Emperor asked, What can be done for a person who is not feeling well? Qi Bo replied, If there is internal heat, it causes cold; if it is cold inside, then it causes heat. When the stomach has heat, it consumes grain, causing the person to have a hollow appetite and feel hungry. If the gallbladder and liver are heated, then there will be yellow stool like diarrhea. If the lower layer of the skin and muscles are cold, and the stomach is cold, there will be bloating; if the intestines are cold, there will be abdominal rumbling, loose stools, and pain. If the stomach is cold and the intestines are hot, then there is bloating with loose stools. If the stomach is hot and the intestines are cold, there is rapid drinking, lower abdominal pain, bloating, and diarrhea.

4: 黃帝曰：胃欲寒飲，腸欲熱飲，兩者相逆，便之奈何？且夫王公大人，血食之君，驕恣從欲輕人，而無能禁之，禁之則逆其志，順之則加其病，便之奈何？治之何先？歧伯曰：人之情，莫不惡死而喜生，告之以其敗，語之以其善，導之以其所便，開之以其所苦，雖有無道之人，惡有不聽者乎？ Yellow Emperor said: The stomach desires warmth in drinks, while the intestines desire coolness in drinks. If these two desires are opposite to each other, how can one regulate them? As for the king, noblemen, and great men, who govern the empire through blood and food, they cannot help but indulge their desires and lightly humble the people. If they try to control this, it will go against their intentions, and if they follow along with it, they will only increase the illnesses. How can one regulate it? The Duke asked: People all dislike death and love life. Inform them of their defeat, teach them what is good, lead them according to what suits them, open them to what causes them pain, even though there are those who do not follow the way, would anyone dislike this?

5: 黃帝曰：治之奈何？歧伯曰：春夏先治其標，後治其本；秋冬先治其本，後治其標。 Yellow Emperor asked: How should one govern? Huan Bo replied: First govern according to the seasons, treating the manifestations before addressing the roots during spring and summer; in autumn and winter, first address the roots before treating the manifestations.

6: 黃帝曰：便其相逆者奈何？歧伯曰：便此者，食飲衣服，亦欲適寒溫，寒無淒愴，暑無出汗。食飲者，熱無灼灼，寒無滄滄。寒溫中適，故氣將持，乃不致邪僻也。 Yellow Emperor asked: What about those who find it hard to follow the natural order? Guo Bo replied: Those who follow it, want their food, drink, clothing to be appropriate for the cold or heat, and want the cold without frostbite and the heat without excessive sweating. With suitable food and drink, they can maintain balance and avoid internal harm

7: 黃帝曰：本藏以身形肢節䐃肉，候五藏六府之大小焉。今夫王公大人，臨朝即位之君，而問焉，誰可捫循之，而後答乎？歧伯曰：身形肢節者，藏府之蓋也，非面部之閱也。 Yellow Emperor said: The essential spirit resides in the body's shape and limbs, and interacts with the five viscera and six bowels. Now, you are a ruler who has ascended to the throne at this time, and yet you ask this question. Who can guide you, and then provide an answer? Duke of Zhou said: The body's shape and limbs are the receptacles of the viscera, not merely the features of the face.

8: 黃帝曰：五藏之氣，閱於面者，余已知之矣，以肢節知而閱之，奈何？歧伯曰：五藏六府者，肺為之蓋，巨肩陷咽，候見其外。黃帝曰：善。 Yellow Emperor said: I know the Qi of the Five Organs, as read in The Face. I have known it through the movements of my limbs and studied it. What shall I do now? Qi Bo said: The Five Organs and Six Depots are covered by the Lung. The groove at the base of the neck is where it resides, and one can observe its exterior. Yellow Emperor said: Good

9: 歧伯曰：五藏六府，心為之主，缺盆為之道，骷骨有余以候𩩲𩨗。黃帝曰：善。 Huang Di said: Good.

10: 歧伯曰：肝者，主為將，使之候外，欲知堅固，視目小大。黃帝曰：善。 Bo says: The liver is in charge of the general, making it timely and sending it outward. If you want to know if it is firmly established, look at the size of the pupils. Emperor Huang says: Good.

11: 歧伯曰：脾者，主為衛，使之迎糧，視唇舌好惡，以知吉凶。黃帝曰：善。 Bo said: The spleen is responsible for governing the defense and ensuring that it receives nourishment, observes whether the lips and tongue are good or bad, and thus discerns good and evil omens. Yellow Emperor said: Good.

12: 歧伯曰：腎者，主為外，使之遠聽，視耳好惡，以知其性。黃帝曰：善。願聞六府之候。 Huang Di said: Good. I would like to hear about the weather conditions of the Six Ministries.

13: 歧伯曰：六府者，胃為之海，龐骸、大頸、張胸，五穀乃容。鼻隧以長，以候大腸。唇厚、人中長，以候小腸。目下果大，其膽乃橫。鼻孔在外，膀胱漏泄。鼻柱中央起，三焦乃約，此所以候六府者也。上下三等，藏安且良矣。 Duke Zhou said: The six palaces are the sea of the abdomen, which includes the hunchback, the large neck, and the spread chest; these five grains are their nourishment. The nasal passage is long and the large intestine is long, indicating the health of the large intestine. The lips are thick and the person is tall, indicating the health of the small intestine. The eyes are large, which indicates the strength of the gallbladder. The nostrils are on the outside, and the bladder is leaking. When the nasal column is in the center, the three burners are regulated, and this is why the six palaces are mentioned. Up and down, there are three levels, and they are safe and beneficial.

docs.title: 決氣
docs.text:
1: 黃帝曰：余聞人有精、氣、津、液、血、脈，余意以為一氣耳，今乃辨為六名，余不知其所以然。歧伯曰：兩神相搏，合而成形，常先身生，是謂精。何謂氣？歧伯曰：上焦開發，宣五穀味，熏膚、充身、澤毛，若霧露之溉，是謂氣。何謂津？歧伯曰：腠理發泄，汗出溱溱，是謂津。何謂液？歧伯曰：穀入氣滿，淖澤注于骨，骨屬屈伸，泄澤補益腦髓，皮膚潤澤，是謂液。何謂血？歧伯曰：中焦受氣，取汁變化而赤，是謂血。何謂脈？歧伯曰：壅遏營氣，令無所避，是謂脈。 Yellow Emperor said: I have heard that there are the spirit, qi, fluids, body fluids, blood, and pulse. I thought they were all one qi, but now they are distinguished as six names, and I do not know why. Hui Bo said: The two spirits struggle, combine to form a shape, constantly preceding the body's birth, which is called the spirit. What is qi? Hui Bo said: The upper burner refines the grain flavors, disperses them through the skin and fills the body, like the mist on dew-covered grass. What is fluids? Hui Bo said: The sinews discharge waste, sweat drips droplet by droplet, this is called fluids. What is body fluids? Hui Bo said: The grain enters the qi and nourishes the bones, the bones belong to bending and stretching, releasing fluids to supplement and nurture the marrow and brain, making the skin moist and soft, this is called body fluids. What is blood? Hui Bo said: The middle burner receives qi and transforms it into red, this is called blood. What is pulse? Hui Bo said: Accumulated stagnation of qi, causing no place to avoid, this is called the pulse.

2: 黃帝曰：六氣有，有餘不足，氣之多少，腦髓之虛實，血脈之清濁，何以知之？歧伯曰：精脫者，耳聾；氣脫者，目不明；津脫者，腠理開，汗大泄；液脫者，骨屬屈伸不利，色夭，腦髓消，脛痺，耳數鳴；血脫者，色白，夭然不澤，其脈空虛，此其候也。 Yellow Emperor said: There are six types of energy. How can one tell whether there is an excess or deficiency, the abundance or scarcity of energy, the truth or falseness of the brain and marrow, and the clarity or turbidity of blood and vessels? Bo Yi replied: Those who lose their vital essence will have hearing problems; those who lose their energy will not see clearly; those who lose their body fluids will have diarrhea and excessive sweating; those who lose their bodily fluids will have bones that are rigid, withered, and unable to bend or stretch, pale complexion, brain and marrow deterioration, paralysis of the limbs, and frequent ringing in the ears; those who lose blood will have a pale complexion, withering without vitality, their pulse is empty and weak, and this is indicative of their condition.

3: 黃帝曰：六氣者，貴賤何如？歧伯曰：六氣者，各有部主也，其貴賤善惡，可為常主，然五穀與胃為大海也。 Yellow Emperor said: What about the six energies, noble and base? Duke of Zhou said: The six energies each have their own master, and their nobility and baseness can be a constant master. However, five grains and the stomach are like a great sea.

docs.title: 腸胃
docs.text: 1: 黃帝問於伯高曰：余願聞六府傳谷者，腸胃之大小長短，受谷之多少奈何？伯高曰：請盡言之，谷所從出入淺深遠近長短之度：唇至齒長九分，口廣二寸半；齒以後至會厭，深三寸半，大容五合；舌重十兩，長七寸，廣二寸半；咽門重十兩，廣一寸半。至胃長一尺六寸，胃紆曲屈，伸之，長二尺六寸，大一尺五寸，徑五寸，大容三斗五升。小腸後附脊，左環回日迭積，其注于回腸者，外附於臍上。回運環十六曲，大二寸半，徑八分分之少半，長三丈三尺。回腸當臍左環，回周葉積而下，回運還反十六曲，大四寸，徑一寸寸之少半，長二丈一尺。廣腸傳脊，以受回腸，左環葉脊上下，辟大八寸，徑二寸寸之大半，長二尺八寸。腸胃所入至所出，長六丈四寸四分，回曲環反，三十二曲也。 Emperor Yellow asked Bo Gao: I wish to hear the classic of the Six Canons. How do the intestines and stomach differ in size, length, and capacity? Bo Gao replied: Please proceed with your explanation. The extent of the intestines and stomach in terms of shallow, deep, near or far, long or short is as follows: the lips reach to the teeth and are nine parts long; the mouth is two and a half inches wide; the teeth lead to the heel, which is three and a half inches deep; it is five fists in size; the tongue weighs ten pounds and is seven feet long, two and a half inches wide; the throat weighs ten pounds and is one and a half inches wide; the stomach is one foot six inches long, curved, stretched out, reaching two feet six inches long, three feet five inches in size, five inches in width, and has a capacity of three bushels and five pints. The small intestine adheres to the spine, coils to the left, day after day accumulating, and is connected to the large intestine at the coil. The large intestine is connected to the right side of the abdomen. The coiled intestine is one foot six inches in length, two feet three feet in diameter, slightly less than half an inch wide, and three feet three inches in length. The coiled intestine passes through the right side of the abdomen, coils around the large intestine, and returns to its original state after 16 turns, measuring four inches, slightly less than a third of an inch wide, and two feet one inch in length. The expanded intestine extends from the spine, takes in the coiled intestine, left-coiling at the spine above and below, occupying eight inches, with a width of two inches; the large and small intestines enter and exit the body, measuring six feet four inches in total length, curving and coiling 32 times.

docs.title: 平人絕穀
docs.text:
1: 黃帝曰：願聞人之不食，七日而死，何也？伯高曰：臣請言其故。 Yellow Emperor said: I would like to hear why a person who does not eat would die in seven days. Grand Preceptor asked: Your servant would like to explain the reason.

Yellow Emperor replied, That is impossible. Those who do not eat will not die within a week.

2: 胃大一尺五寸，徑五寸，長二尺六寸，橫屈受水谷三斗五升，其中之谷，常留二斗，水一斗五升而滿，上焦泄氣，出其精微，慓悍滑疾，下焦下溉諸腸。 The stomach is approximately 18 inches long and 5 inches wide. It has a capacity of about 5 feet in length when fully extended, receiving water and grain in the amount of three and a half catty (dou), with five shi (升). Inside this amount, there are always left two catty of grains, while water is filled to one catty and five shi. The upper part of the stomach releases gas, expelling its refined essence, slipping smoothly and quickly. The lower part irrigates the intestines.

3: 小腸大二寸半，徑八分分之少半，長三丈二尺，受谷二斗四升，水六升三合合之大半。 The intestine is two and a half inches in diameter, with circumference slightly less than eight-tenths of an inch, measuring three rods and two feet in length, holding two measures of grain (two pecks) and four pints, containing six pints and three drams.

4: 回腸大四寸，徑一寸寸之少半，長二丈一尺，受谷一斗，水七升半。 The intestine is five inches in diameter, half an inch narrower than its circumference, two yards and one foot long, can hold a measure of grain equivalent to one bushel, and holds seven and a half liters of water.

5: 廣腸大八寸，徑二寸寸之大半，長二尺八寸，受谷九升三合八分合之一。 Broad waist, large with a circumference of eight inches, path one inch in diameter, long at two feet and eight inches, holds nine shi and three cun, eight parts of one cun.

6: 腸胃之長，凡五丈八尺四寸，受水谷九斗二升一合合之大半，此腸胃所受水谷之數也。平人則不然，胃滿則腸虛，腸滿則胃虛，更虛更滿，故氣得上下，五藏安定，血脈和利，精神乃居，故神者，水谷之精氣也。故腸胃之中，當留谷二斗，水一斗五升；故平人日再後，後二升半，一日中五升，七日五七三斗五升，而留水谷盡矣；故平人不食飲七日而死者，小谷精氣津液皆盡故也。 The length of the intestines and stomach is approximately five zhang eight chi four cun. When they receive water and food, it amounts to nine shi two cun one li, which is half of the total capacity. This is the amount of water and food that the intestines and stomach can hold. However, for ordinary people, when the stomach is full, the intestines become empty, and when the intestines are full, the stomach becomes empty. As they continue to be emptied or filled, their qi will rise upwards and downwards, stabilizing the five organs, regulating blood circulation, and purifying channels. Thus, their spirit resides in peace. Therefore, a sage's vitality comes from the essence of water and food.

Therefore, in the intestines and stomach, it is necessary to reserve two shi of grain and one shi five cun of water. For an ordinary person, they should consume less by half a cun after each meal, drinking five cun of water per day, and after seven days, they will have consumed 573 catties and five cun of water; at this point, they have fully consumed the grain and water. Therefore, an ordinary person who abstains from eating and drinking for seven days will die because their small grain essence and body fluids are all depleted.

docs.title: 海論
docs.text:
