1: 黃帝問于歧伯曰：余聞刺法於夫子，夫子之所言，不離於營衛血氣。夫十二經脈者，內屬於府藏，外絡於肢節，夫子乃合之於四海乎。歧伯答曰：人亦有四海，十二經水。經水者，皆注于海，海有東西南北，命曰四海。黃帝曰：以人應之奈何？歧伯曰：人有髓海，有血海，有氣海，有水谷之海，凡此四者，以應四海也。 Emperor Yellow asked Master Hei Bo: I have heard that the needling method is used by Confucius, and everything he says does not depart from military and defensive vitality. The twelve channels and networks are internally related to the ministries and externally connected to the limbs and joints; Confucius unites them at the four corners. Master Hei Bo answered: Human beings also have four corners and twelve waters (channels). The water channels all flow into the sea, with east, west, south, and north as the four corners. Emperor Yellow said: How should people respond to this? Master Hei Bo replied: People have a marrow sea, a blood sea, a qi sea, and a food grain sea; these four respond to the four corners.

2: 黃帝曰：遠乎哉，夫子之合人天地四海也，願聞應之奈何？歧伯答曰：必先明知陰陽表裏滎輸所在，四海定矣。 Yellow Emperor said: It is far away, how can the master's merging of people, heaven and earth, and four seas be heard? Hui Bao answered: One must first clearly understand the location of yin and yang, front and back, surplus and deficiency, and then it will be defined.

3: 黃帝曰：定之奈何？歧伯曰：胃者水穀之海，其輸上在氣街，下至三里；衝脈者，為十二經之海，其輸上在於大杼，下出於巨虛之上下廉；膻中者，為氣之海，其輸上在於柱骨之上下，前在於人迎，腦為髓之海，其輸上在於其蓋，下在風府。 Yellow Emperor asked: How about it? Kuang Bo replied: The stomach is the sea of water grains. Its connection is at Qi Street, going down to three li; the Conception Vessel is the sea of the twelve meridians. Its connection is at the Dan Tian, and comes out from Juyu's upper and lower Tan; the Bamboo Grove is the sea of Qi. Its connection is at the top and bottom of Zhong Bai, in front at the Ren Yan; the brain is the sea of marrow. Its connection is at its lid, and comes out at Feng Fu.

4: 黃帝曰：凡此四海者，何利何害？何生何敗？歧伯曰：得順者生，得逆者敗；知調者利，不知調者害。 Yellow Emperor said: What are the benefits and harm of these four seas? What is the life and death of them? The Duke of Zhou replied: Those who follow the proper order will live, those who go against it will perish; knowing the right time brings profit, not knowing the right time brings loss.

5: 黃帝曰：四海之逆順奈何？歧伯曰：氣海有餘者，氣滿胸中，悗息面赤；氣海不足，則氣少不足以言。血海有餘，則常想其身大，怫然不知其所病；血海不足，亦常想其身小，狹然不知其所病。水谷之海有餘，則腹滿；水谷之海不足，則飢不受谷食。髓海有餘，則輕勁多力，自過其度；髓海不足，則腦轉耳鳴，脛痠眩冒，目無所見，懈怠安臥。 Yellow Emperor asked: What is the difference between deficiency and excess in the Four Seas (i.e., the four major organs of the body)? Qi Master replied: When there is an abundance of Qi, it fills the chest, and one gasps for breath with a flushed face; when Qi is insufficient, there is not enough to speak. If there is an abundance of blood, one constantly imagines their body as large and clumsy, without knowing what is wrong; if there is not enough blood, one constantly imagines their body as small and narrow, also unaware of what is wrong. With regard to the sea of grain and water, when there is an abundance, one's abdomen is full; when there is a deficiency, there is hunger that cannot be satisfied by food. If there is an abundance of essence, there are many vigorous energies and abundant strength, exceeding their limits; when there is a deficiency, the mind spins, the ears ring, the limbs tremble and dizziness comes over one's vision, lying languidly without knowing what to do.

6: 黃帝曰：余已聞逆順，調之奈何？歧伯曰：審守其俞，而調其虛實，無犯其害，順者得復，逆者必敗。黃帝曰：善。 Yellow Emperor said: I have heard about Yin and Yang, how can they be regulated? Duke of Zhou said: Examine the function of Yin and Yang, and regulate their substance without violating their nature. Those who follow will prosper, and those who oppose will perish. Yellow Emperor said: Good.

docs.title: 五亂
docs.text:
1: 黃帝曰：經脈十二者，別為五行，分為四時，何失而亂？何得而治？歧伯曰：五行有序，四時有分，相順則治，相逆則亂。 The Yellow Emperor said: The twelve channels are divided into five phases and classified into four seasons. How can they become disordered? How can they be regulated? The Duke of Shou replied: When the phases are in order, and the seasons have their respective divisions, following this order leads to regulation, while going against it results in disorder

2: 黃帝曰：何謂相順？歧伯曰：經脈十二者，以應十二月。十二月者，分為四時。四時者，春秋冬夏，其氣各異，營衛相隨，陰陽已知，清濁不相干，如是則順之而治。 Yellow Emperor said: What does it mean to follow the rhythm? The Duke of Zhou said: The twelve channels correspond to the twelve months. The twelve months are divided into four seasons. The four seasons have different qi, and the defense and nourishment adjust according to them. Yin and Yang are understood, and clean and unclean do not interfere with each other. If so, follow it and govern.

3: 黃帝曰：何為逆而亂，歧伯曰：清氣在陰，濁氣在陽，營氣順脈，衛氣逆行，清濁相干，亂於胸中，是謂大悗。故氣亂於心，則煩心密嘿，俛首靜伏；亂於肺，則俛仰喘喝，接手以呼；亂於腸胃，是為霍亂；亂於臂脛，則為四厥；亂於頭，則為厥逆，頭重眩仆。 Yellow Emperor said: What is the cause of chaos? Master Qi Bo replied: The clear Qi is in the Yin, and the turbid Qi is in the Yang. Regulating Qi follows the pulse, defending Qi moves against the grain. Clear and turbid are related, causing chaos within. This is called great distress. Therefore, when Qi is chaotic in the heart, the mind becomes restless and anxious, crouching with a hunched back; when it is chaotic in the lungs, one experiences shortness of breath and gasping, grasping for air; when it is chaotic in the stomach and intestines, it is called huo chaos; when it is chaotic in the arms and legs, it results in the four paralyses; when it is chaotic in the head, one experiences dizziness and weakness of the head.

4: 黃帝曰：五亂者，刺之有道乎？歧伯曰：有道以來，有道以去，審知其道，是謂身寶。黃帝曰：善。願聞其道。歧伯曰：氣在於心者，取之手少陰心主之俞；氣在於肺者，取之手太陰滎，足少陰俞，氣在於腸胃者，取之足太陰陽明，不下者，取之三里，氣在於頭者，取之天柱大杼，不知，取足太陽滎俞；氣在於臂足，取之先去血脈，後取其陽明少陽之滎輸。 Yellow Emperor said: What is the way of five chaoses? Can one pierce it with needles? Huan Bo said: The way that has come and gone can be known. This is called the treasure within oneself. Yellow Emperor said: Good! I wish to hear its way. Huan Bo said: The qi is in the heart, take hold of the hand's Shao Yin ruler; the qi is in the lungs, take hold of the hand's Tai Yin flood and foot's Shao Yin ruler; the qi is in the intestines and stomach, take hold of the foot's Tai Yin Yang Ming, not going down, take hold of the three miles; the qi is in the head, take hold of the Tian Zhu Da Quan; if unknown, take hold of the foot's Tai Yang ruler. The qi is in the arms and legs, first remove the blood vessels, then take hold of the Yang Ming Shao Yuan output.

5: 黃帝曰：補寫奈何？歧伯曰：徐入徐出，謂之導氣。補寫無形，謂之同精。是非有餘不足也，亂氣之相逆也。黃帝曰：允乎哉道，明乎哉論，請著之玉版，命曰治亂也。 Yellow Emperor said: How about supplementation and revision? Kuang Bo said: Enter and exit slowly, referring to guiding the Qi. Supplementation and revision have no form, referring to being refined. If there is insufficiency or excess, it will result in the reversal of the Qi. Yellow Emperor said: How marvelous is this way, how clear is this discussion! I shall inscribe it on jade and call it Regulating Chaos.

docs.title: 脹論
docs.text:
1: 黃帝曰：脈之應于寸口，如何而脹？歧伯曰：其脈大堅以濇者，脹也。黃帝曰：何以知藏府之脹也。歧伯曰：陰為藏，陽為府。 Yellow Emperor said: The pulse responds at the wrist, how can it be palpated? Master of Difficult Issues said: When the pulse is large and strong, it is a sign of palpitation. Yellow Emperor asked: How do you know that it is the palpitation of the Kidney palace? Master of Difficult Issues said: The Yin is responsible for storing and the Yang is responsible for the palace.

2: 黃帝曰：夫氣之令人脹也，在于血脈之中耶，藏府之內乎？歧伯曰：三者皆存焉，然非脹之舍也。黃帝曰：願聞脹之舍。歧伯曰：夫脹者，皆在於藏府之外，排藏府而郭胸脅，脹皮膚，故命曰脹。 Yellow Emperor said: Is it the vital energy that makes people bloated, within the blood vessels and in the internal organs? Master of the Three said: All three are present, but not due to bloating. Yellow Emperor asked: May I hear about the cause of bloating? Master of the Three said: Bloating is caused by vital energy outside the internal organs, which presses against the internal organs and surrounds the chest and abdomen. That's why it's called bloating.

3: 黃帝曰：藏府之在胸脅腹里之內也，若匣匱之藏禁器也，名有次舍，異名而同處，一域之中，其氣各異，願聞其故。黃帝曰：未解其意，再問。歧伯曰：夫胸腹，藏府之郭也。膻中者，心主之宮城也；胃者，太倉也；咽喉、小腸者，傳送也；胃之五竅者，閭里門戶也；廉泉、玉英者，津液之道也。故五藏六府者，各有畔界，其病各有形狀。營氣循脈，衛氣逆為脈脹；衛氣並脈循分為膚脹。三里而寫，近者一下，遠者三下，無問虛實，工在疾寫。 Yellow Emperor said: The internal organs, such as the heart, liver, spleen, lungs, and kidneys, are called the Five Zang Organs. They are all in one domain, yet they have different qualities of energy. I would like to know their origins. Yellow Emperor said: I do not understand your meaning, so I ask again. The Duke of Tang replied: The chest and abdomen are where the internal organs reside. The diaphragm is the capital city of the spirit lord; the stomach is the warehouse; the throat and small intestine are the transit centers; the five orifices of the stomach are the market gates; the renal cortex and the adrenal glands are the channels for fluids. Thus, each of the Five Zang Organs and Six Fu Organs has its own boundary, and their diseases have different manifestations. Regulating Qi through the meridians and defending against pathogenic factors through the meridians can cause Qi stagnation or blockage; defending against pathogenic factors through the meridians can also lead to skin blockages. Three li away, closer ones are written with one stroke, and farther ones with three strokes. There is no asking about truth or falsity, and the skill lies in rapid writing.

4: 黃帝曰：願聞脹形。歧伯曰：夫心脹者煩心短氣，臥不安；肺脹者，虛滿而喘咳；肝脹者，脅下滿而痛引小腹；脾脹者，善穢，四肢煩俛，體重不能勝衣，臥不安；腎脹者，腹滿引背央央然，腰髀痛。六府脹，胃脹者，腹滿，胃脘痛，鼻聞焦臭，妨於食，大便難；大腸脹者，腸鳴而痛濯濯，冬日重感於寒，則餐泄不化；小腸脹者，少腹慎脹，引腰而痛；膀胱脹者，少腹滿而氣癃；三焦脹者，氣滿於皮膚中，輕輕然而不堅；膽脹者，脅下痛脹，口中苦，善太息。 Yellow Emperor said: I wish to hear about distention. Duke of Shao replied: One who is distended in the heart feels restless and short-tempered, unable to rest peacefully; one who is distended in the lungs coughs and wheezes; one who is distended in the liver feels a fullness below the navel and experiences pain that refers to the lower abdomen; one who is distended in the spleen feels uncomfortable, limbs are stiff, cannot bear the weight of clothing, and cannot rest peacefully; one who is distended in the kidneys feels full in the abdomen, referring pain to the back, the hips hurt; one who is distended in the large intestine has a sounding colon, causing lower abdominal pain, has a strong smell from the nose, which interferes with eating and defecation; one who is distended in the small intestine has a distended lower abdomen that refers to the hips and causes pain; one who is distended in the bladder feels full in the lower abdomen and gasps; one who is distended in the three burners feels full under the skin, and moves lightly but without stability; one who is distended in the gallbladder feels pain below the navel and bloated.

5: 凡此諸脹者，其道在一，明知逆順，鍼數不失，寫虛補實，神去其室，致邪失正，真不可定，麤之所敗，謂之天命；補虛寫實，神歸其室，久塞其空，謂之良工。 Regarding these various texts, their method is one, clearly knowing yin and yang, not missing the acupuncture points, writing the virtual and supplementing the real, when the spirit departs its chamber, causing deviation from the proper way, that which cannot be defined is called destiny; supplementing the virtual and writing the real, the spirit returns to its chamber, lingering in its void for a long time, this is called a skilled craftsman.

6: 黃帝曰：脹者焉生？何因而有？歧伯曰：衛氣之在身也，常然並脈，循分肉，行有逆順，陰陽相隨，乃得天和，五藏更始，四時循序，五穀乃化。然後厥氣在下，營衛留止，寒氣逆上，真邪相攻，兩氣相搏，乃合為脹也。黃帝曰：善。何以解惑？歧伯曰：合之於真，三合而得。帝曰：善。 Yellow Emperor said: How can a swelling arise? What is the reason for it? Ho Po said: The defensive Qi is within the body, constantly following the channels, penetrating the flesh, having both upward and downward movement, Yin and Yang accompany each other, thus achieving harmony with heaven, the Five Organs are established, the Four Seasons follow their proper sequence, and the Five Grains become transformed. Later, the Excessive Qi is below, the defense of the defensive Qi becomes stationary, cold Qi rises upwards, true and false attack each other, the two Qis struggle together, thus forming a swelling. Yellow Emperor said: Good. How can I dispel confusion? Ho Po said: Unite them with the true, and after three unifications, one will obtain it. Yellow Emperor said: Good.

7: 黃帝問於歧伯曰：脹論言無問虛實，工在疾寫，近者一下，遠者三下，今有其三而不下者，其過焉在？歧伯對曰：此言陷於肉肓，而中氣穴者也。不中氣穴，則氣內閉，鍼不陷肓，則氣不行，上越中肉，則衛氣相亂，陰陽相逐。其於脹也，當寫不寫，氣故不下，三而不下，必更其道，氣下乃止，不下復始，可以萬全，烏有殆者乎？其於脹也，必審其彌，當寫則寫，當補則補，如鼓應桴，惡有不下者乎？ Yellow Emperor asked Master Qi Bo: Regarding the treatment of [a disease called] hacking cough, there is no inquiry about whether it is real or not. The method involves rapid writing, nearer to it in one strike, farther away in three strikes. If today it has three strikes but does not fall, where does its error lie? Master Qi Bo replied: This speech is trapped in the flesh and tendons, but it is related to the acupuncture points of the body's vital energy. If you do not hit the acupuncture point, then the vital energy will be blocked inside, the needle will not penetrate the flesh, and the vital energy will not flow, causing disorder between defensive Qi and nutritive Yin, with Yang following Yin. In regard to hacking cough, one should definitely write or not write based on the situation; if the vital energy does not descend because of this, it will not fall even after three strikes, one must change the method, and once the vital energy descends and settles, it will be cured completely, with no risk of recurrence. In regard to hacking cough, one must carefully consider the situation, act accordingly by writing or supplementing [acupuncture points], like a drum responding to a lute; is there any risk of not hitting the mark?

docs.title: 五癃津液別
docs.text:
1: 黃帝問於歧伯曰：水穀入于口，輸於腸胃，其液別為五，天寒衣薄，則為溺與氣，天熱衣厚則為汗，悲哀氣並則為泣，中熱胃緩則為唾。邪氣內逆，則氣為之閉塞而不行，不行則為水脹，余知其然也，不知其何由生？願聞其道。 The Yellow Emperor asked Yi Yin: Water grains enter the mouth, exit at the stomach and intestines. Their fluids are divided into five types. When it's cold and one is wearing thin clothes, it leads to drowning and sweat; when one is sad, it leads to tears; when the stomach is hot and sluggish, it leads to spittle. Evil qi inside turning over leads to qi being blocked without moving, leading to edema; I know this to be true, but do not know where it comes from. I wish to hear its method.

2: 歧伯曰：水穀皆入于口，其味有五，各注其海。津液各走其道，故三焦出氣，以溫肌肉，充皮膚，為其津，其流而不行者為液。 Obo said: All grains depend on the mouth for water, and their flavors have five varieties, with each registering its sea. The body fluids each follow their own path, so the three Yang Meridians expel Qi, warming the muscles and tendons, nourishing the skin, serving as their fluids, while those that flow but do not move are classified as fluids

3: 天暑衣厚則腠理開，故汗出，寒留於分肉之間，聚沫則為痛。 If the clothing for summer is too thick, the pores will open, leading to sweat, and cold will accumulate between the skin layers, forming clumps that cause pain.

4: 天寒則腠理閉，氣濕不行，水下留於膀胱，則為溺與氣。 If it is cold in heaven, the marrow will close up; if the qi is damp and cannot move, water will remain in the bladder, resulting in drowning and Qi.

5: 五藏六府，心為之主，耳為之聽，目為之候，肺為之相，肝為之將，脾為之衛，腎為之主外。故五藏六府之津液，盡上滲於目，心悲氣並，則心系急。心系急則肺舉，肺舉則液上溢。夫心系與肺，不能常舉，乍上乍下，故欬而泣出矣。 Five Organs and Six Palaces, the heart governs it, the ears listen to it, the eyes are its attendants, the lungs form it, the liver commands it, the spleen guards it, and the kidneys govern it externally. Therefore, the fluid of the Five Organs and Six Palaces is all led up to the eyes, when the heart-soul qi is stirred and distressed, then the heart becomes troubled. When the heart becomes troubled, the lungs will rise, when the lungs rise, the fluid will overflow. Therefore, when the heart and lungs cannot be constantly raised and are alternately rising and falling, one sighs and weeps.

6: 中熱則胃中消穀，消穀則蟲上下作。腸胃充郭，故胃緩，胃緩則氣逆，故唾出。 If one is too hot, it will burn the grains in the stomach, and if the grains are burnt, worms will invade. When the intestines and stomach are full, therefore the stomach becomes sluggish, and when the stomach is sluggish, the Qi rebels, thus causing vomiting.

7: 五穀之津液，和合而為膏者，內滲入于骨空，補益腦髓，而下流於陰股。 The five grains' essence, mixed and combined to form a salve, can be injected internally into the cavities of the bones. It supplements and nourishes the brain and marrow, and flows downward to the yin passage (genital region).

8: 陰陽不和，則使液溢而下流於陰，髓液皆減而下，下過度則虛，虛，故腰背痛而脛痠。 If yin and yang are not in harmony, qi will overflow and flow downward into the yin, leading to a deficiency of essence and causing excessive downward flow. This can lead to emptiness, which results in pain in the lower back and knees.

9: 陰陽氣道不通，四海閉塞，三焦不寫，津液不化，水穀並行腸胃之中，別於回腸，留於下焦，不得滲膀胱，則下焦脹，水溢則為水脹，此津液五別之逆順也。 When the yin-yang qi channels are not open, the four seas are closed off, the three faucets do not write, and the fluids do not transform. The water grains are aligned in the middle of the intestines and colon, separate from the returning colon, and remain in the lower faucet, unable to enter the bladder. This causes the lower faucet to bloat, and if there is an overflow, it becomes a water bloating. This is the reversal and disorder of the five types of fluids

docs.title: 五閱五使
docs.text:
1: 黃帝問於歧伯曰：余聞刺有五官五閱，以觀五氣。五氣者，五藏之使也，五時之副也。願聞其五使當安出？歧伯曰：五官者，五藏之閱也。黃帝曰：願聞其所出，令可為常。歧伯曰：脈出於氣口，色見於明堂，五色更出，以應五時，各如其常，經氣入藏，必當治理。 The Yellow Emperor asked Yan Yuan, I have heard that there are five organs and five orifices for observing the five energies. The five energies are the functions of the five viscera and the assistants of the five phases. I wish to know where their five functions exit?

Yan Yuan replied, The five organs are the means by which we observe the five viscera.

The Yellow Emperor said, I wish to know where they exit, so that it can be made constant.

Yan Yuan replied, The pulse comes out from the mouth of Qi and the color is seen in the hall of clarity. The five colors also come out, adapting to the five phases according to their constancy. As long as the Qi enters the viscera, it will surely regulate.

2: 帝曰：善。五色獨決於明堂乎？歧伯曰：五官已辨，闕庭必張，乃立明堂，明堂廣大，蕃蔽見外，方壁高基，引垂居外，五色乃治，平搏廣大，壽中百歲，見此者，刺之必已，如是之人者，血氣有餘，肌肉堅致，故可苦以鍼。 The emperor asked: Good. Are the five colors decided independently in the bright hall? Minister Qi replied: The five senses have been distinguished, and the doors of the court will be closed, after which a bright hall is established. The bright hall is spacious, with walls extending to the borderlands, high and solid foundations, hanging drapes outside, and the five colors are arranged. The battlefield is vast, with people living for hundreds of years after seeing it. Those who see this will be pierced, and those of such a nature have abundant blood and qi, strong muscles that are firm and solid. Therefore, they can be subjected to torture with an awl

3: 黃帝曰：願聞五官。歧伯曰：鼻者，肺之官也；目者，肝之官也；口唇者，脾之官也；舌者，心之官也；耳者，腎之官也。 Yellow Emperor said, I wish to hear about the five organs. Huan Bo replied: The nose belongs to the lung organ; the eyes belong to the liver organ; the mouth and lips belong to the spleen organ; the tongue belongs to the heart organ; and the ears belong to the kidney organ.

4: 黃帝曰：以官何候？歧伯曰：以候五藏。故肺病者，喘息鼻張；肝病者，眥青；脾病者，唇黃；心病者，舌捲短，顴赤；腎病者，顴與顏黑。 Yellow Emperor asked: How can one tell if someone is an official? Boyi replied: One can determine it by the five zang organs. Therefore, a person with lung disease will have shortness of breath, sniffling nose; a person with liver disease will have yellow eyes; a person with spleen disease will have yellow lips; a person with heart disease will have short and swollen tongue, red cheeks; a person with kidney disease will have blackish cheeks and face.

5: 黃帝曰：五脈安出，五色安見，其常色殆者如何？歧伯曰：五官不辨，闕庭不張，小其明堂，蕃蔽不見，又埤其牆，牆下無基，垂角去外。如是者，雖平常殆，況加疾哉。 Yellow Emperor said: When the five pulses are stable and the colors are calm, how about its constant color? The Duke of Zhou said: The five senses do not recognize it, the gateway of the court does not close, the brightness is small, the frontier areas cannot see it, and they also fill in the moat, with no foundation under the wall, and the corners are hanging outwards. If so, even if it is stable, how much more so when it becomes urgent.

6: 黃帝曰：五色之見於明堂，以觀五藏之氣，左右高下，各有形乎？歧伯曰：藏府之在中也，各以次舍，左右上下，各如其度也。 Yellow Emperor said: The five colors are seen in the Bright Hall. Observe the five viscera's energy, up and down, each with a form? Duke of Zhou replied: The Depot Palace is within, each according to their respective proportions, up and down, according to their degrees.

docs.title: 逆順肥瘦
docs.text:
1: 黃帝問于歧伯曰：余聞鍼道于夫子，眾多畢悉矣。夫子之道，應若失，而據未有堅然者也。夫子之問學熟乎，將審察于物而心生之乎？歧伯曰：聖人之為道者，上合于天，下合于地，中合于人事，必有明法，以起度數，法式檢押，乃後可傳焉。故匠人不能釋尺寸而意短長，廢繩墨而起平水也，工人不能置規而為圓，去矩而為方。知用此者，固自然之物，易用之教，逆順之常也。 Yellow Emperor asked Guan Yu: I have heard that Confucius taught the art of the needle, and many have mastered it. Confucius's art, like a river flowing east or west, has no fixed direction. The Yellow Emperor asked about Confucius's study of knowledge, whether it is by scrutinizing objects to generate ideas within oneself? Guan Yu replied: A sage who practices the Way unites with heaven above, earth below, and human affairs in between, surely there is a method to guide the development, which can be established as a standard, and thus can be passed down. Artisans cannot fully reveal their skill in measuring dimensions, yet they create short and long objects skillfully; carpenters cannot establish rules but still achieve roundness and squareness. Knowing how to use these methods is the natural way of things, an easily learned teaching, and goes against what is considered orderly and conventional.

2: 黃帝曰：願聞自然奈何？歧伯曰：臨深決水，不用功力，而水可竭也。循拙決沖，而經可通也。此言氣之滑澀，血水清濁，行之逆順也。 Yellow Emperor said: I want to hear about the nature of things. Guo Bo said: When it comes to water, one does not rely on strength but water can be exhausted; when it comes to clay, one does not rely on skill but a pot can be made. This talk discusses the smoothness and subtlety of Qi, the clarity and turbidity of blood and water, and the reversal of order and chaos in action.

3: 黃帝曰：願聞人之白黑肥瘦小長，各有數乎？歧伯曰：年質壯大，血氣充盈，膚革堅固，因加以邪，刺此者，深而留之，此肥人也。廣肩腋項，肉薄厚皮而黑色，唇臨臨然，其血黑以濁，其氣澀以遲。其為人也，貪于取與，刺此者，深而留之，多益其數也。 Yellow Emperor said: I wish to hear about the variations of people's complexions such as white, black, fat, thin, small, and long. Kuai Bo replied: People with robust constitution, rich blood and qi, firm skin, and are prone to evil influences. Those who practice acupuncture on them, insert needles deep and leave them in, resulting in a fat person. They have broad shoulders, arms, and thick skin, black complexion, their blood is black and turbid, and their qi is sluggish. Their nature is greedy for material possessions, and those who practice acupuncture on them insert needles deep and leave them in, which will increase their number (or amount).

4: 黃帝曰：刺瘦人奈何？歧伯曰：瘦人者，皮薄色少，肉廉廉然，薄唇輕言，其血清氣滑，易脫于氣，易損于血，刺此者，淺而疾之。 Yellow Emperor asked: How can one reduce a person? Master Qi replied: A person who is reduced has thin skin and pale complexion, sparse hair, their flesh is meager, lips are thin, their blood is clear and qi smooth. It is easy to lose this condition through qi and easy to be harmed through blood. To pierce this condition, it should be shallow and quick.

5: 黃帝曰：刺常人奈何？歧伯曰：視其白黑，各為調之，其端正敦厚者，其血氣和調，刺此者，無失常數也。 Yellow Emperor asked: What about a person with white or black hair? Hui Bao replied: Observe the whiteness or blackness, adjust accordingly, those who are upright, well-mannered, and generous in character will have balanced blood and qi. Piercing such a person would not lead to any disorder

6: 黃帝曰：刺壯士真骨者，奈何？歧伯曰：刺壯士真骨，堅肉緩節，監監然，此人重則氣澀血濁，刺此者，深而留之，多益其數；勁則氣滑血清，刺此者，淺而疾之。 Yellow Emperor said: What if you are piercing a noble man with true bones? Huang Bo said: When piercing a noble man with true bones, the flesh is tough and the joints are rigid. If this person is heavy, the Qi will stagnate and the blood will be turbid. When piercing such a place, it is best to go deep and leave it in, which will increase its effectiveness. If there is strength, the Qi will be slippery and the blood will be clear. When piercing such a place, it is best to go shallow and act quickly.

7: 黃帝曰：刺嬰兒奈何？歧伯曰：嬰兒者，其肉脆，血少氣弱，刺此者，以豪刺，淺刺而疾拔鍼，日再可也。 Yellow Emperor said: What about piercing an infant? Huchiobu replied: An infant's flesh is tender, blood is scarce, and vital energy is weak. If you pierce it, do so boldly, shallowly, and quickly remove the needle; it can be done repeatedly each day

8: 黃帝曰：臨深決水，奈何？歧伯曰：血清氣濁，疾寫之則氣竭焉。黃帝曰：循拙決沖，奈何？歧伯曰：血濁氣澀，疾寫之，則經可通也。 Yellow Emperor said: What to do when facing deep waters? Qi Bo said: When the body's fluids are turbid and the breath is muddled, if one writes rapidly, it will exhaust the breath. Yellow Emperor said: What to do when facing choppy waters? Qi Bo said: When the fluids are turbid and the breath is sluggish, if one writes rapidly, the channels can be opened.

9: 黃帝曰：脈行之逆順，奈何？歧伯曰：手之三陰，從藏走手；手之三陽，從手走頭；足之三陽，從頭走足；足之三陰，從足走腹。 Yellow Emperor asked: How does one interpret the flow of pulse? Hua Tuo replied: For the three Yin in the hand, follow the course from the Cun to the Hegu; for the three Yang in the hand, follow the course from the Hegu to the Benshen; for the three Yang in the foot, follow the course from the Benshen to the foot; for the three Yin in the foot, follow the course from the foot to the abdomen.

10: 黃帝曰：少陰之脈獨下行，何也？歧伯曰：不然，夫沖脈者，五藏六府之海也，五藏六府皆稟焉。其上者，出于頏顙，滲諸陽，灌諸精；其下者，注少陰之大絡，出于氣街，循陰股內廉入膕中，伏行骭骨內，下至內踝之後屬而別。其下者，並于少陰之經，滲三陰；其前者，伏行出跗屬，下循跗，入大指間，滲諸絡而溫肌肉。故別絡結則附上不動，不動則厥，厥則寒矣。黃帝曰：何以明之？歧伯曰：以言導之，切而驗之，其非必動，然後仍可明逆順之行也。黃帝曰：窘乎哉！聖人之為道也。明于日月，微于毫釐，其非夫子，孰能道之也。 Yellow Emperor asked: Why does the Shao Yin vessel move downwards? Kuang Bo answered: This is not the case, for the Chong vessel is the sea of the Five Zang and Six Fu organs. All five zang and six fu originate from this sea. The upper part comes out from the lips and irrigates Yang; the lower part connects to the Shao Yin's major channel, issuing from Qi Street, follows the inside of the Yin canal, enters the Mingmen, sinks and runs through the Huan Gong, and finally terminates at the rear of the navel. The lower part is also in the Shao Yin channel, irrigating the three Yin; the front part hides and runs out from the tip of the toes, loops around the toes, enters the interspace between the great and second fingers, and irrigates the tendons and muscles. Hence, the branch vessels separate and attach to the upper Jue Ding, which does not move, thus causing Yin, and resulting in coldness. Yellow Emperor said: How can it be explained? Kuang Bo replied: By guiding with words and verifying through cutting, if it does not necessarily move, then it can still clarify whether its course is reversed or correct. Yellow Emperor exclaimed: What a difficult matter! This is the work of saints. Clear as day and night, subtle as hair tips; who can understand the way?

docs.title: 五藏別論
docs.text:
1: 黃帝問曰：余聞方士，或以腦髓為藏，或以腸胃為藏，或以為府，敢問更相反皆自謂是不知其道，願聞其說。歧伯對曰：腦髓骨脈膽女子胞，此六者地氣之所生也，皆藏於陰而象於地，故藏而不寫，名曰奇恆之府。夫胃大腸小腸三焦膀胱，此五者，天氣之所生也，其氣象天故寫而不藏，此受五藏濁氣，名曰傳化之府，此不能久留輸寫者也。魄門亦為五藏，使水穀不得久藏。所謂五藏者，藏精氣而不寫也，故滿而不能實。六府者，傳化物而不藏，故實而不能滿也。所以然者，水穀入口，則胃實而腸虛；食下，則腸實而胃虛。故曰：實而不滿，滿而不實也。 Yellow Emperor asked, I have heard that some scholars say that the essence is stored in the brain and spinal cord or in the intestines. Some say it is stored in a 'palace,' but they all claim that those who do not know its path are daring to express their opinions. I would like to hear your explanation. The Duke answered, The brain, spinal cord, bones, marrow, and gallbladder of women; these six are generated by earth energy and are stored in the yin while manifesting as earthly things. Therefore, they are hidden but not written, and are called the Palace of the Strange [Qi Héng]. The large intestine, small intestine, three intestines, bladder; these five are generated by celestial energy and manifest as heavenly things. As a result, their energies are expressed but not hidden. These five organs receive the impure energy of the six organs, which is called the Palace of Transformation [Chuán Hzá]. This palace cannot be preserved and must be written, indicating that these organs have impermanence. The Duke also said that the Gate of Life is one of the five organs, controlling so that water does not linger in the body. The Five Organs are hidden while storing the essence-qi, so they cannot be full. The Six Palaces are where the transformative energies are stored without being hidden, so they can be filled but not made full. This is because when food enters the mouth, the stomach becomes filled and the intestines become empty; when food descends, the intestines become filled and the stomach becomes empty. Therefore, it is said that filled but not full, full but not real.

2: 帝曰：氣口何以獨為五藏主。歧伯曰：胃者水穀之海，六府之大源也。五味入口，藏於胃以養五藏氣，氣口亦太陰也。是以五藏六府之氣味，皆出於胃，變見於氣口。故五氣入鼻，藏於心肺，心肺有病而鼻為之不利也。 The Emperor said: How is the Qi mouth unique as the master of the Five Organs? The Duke of Shou replied: The Stomach is like a sea of water and the source of the six ministries. The five flavors enter through the mouth, where they are stored in the Stomach to nourish the Qi of the Five Organs; the Qi mouth is also part of the Yin aspect. Therefore, the Qi of the Five Organs and Six Ministries all come from the Stomach and manifest through the Qi mouth. As a result, the five Qi enter through the nose and are stored in the Heart and Lungs. If the Heart and Lungs become diseased, this will affect the nasal passage.

3: 凡治病必察其下，適其脈，觀其志意，與其病也。拘於鬼神者，不可與言至德。惡於鍼石者，不可與言至巧。病不許治者病必不治，治之無功矣。 In treating illness, one must investigate its root, match the pulse, observe its intentions, and be in harmony with its disease. Those who are bound by ghosts and spirits cannot be discussed in terms of great virtue. Those who dislike needles and stones cannot be discussed in terms of great skill. If a disease is not allowed to be treated, it will not be cured, and any treatment will have no effect.

docs.title: 血絡論
docs.text:
1: 黃帝曰：願聞其奇邪而不在經者。歧伯曰：血絡是也。 Yellow Emperor said: I want to hear about its strangeness and evil, which is not in the classics. Huang Bo said: It is the network of blood vessels.

2: 黃帝曰：刺血絡而仆者，何也？血出而射者，何也？血少黑而濁者，何也？血出清而半為汁者，何也？拔鍼而腫者，何也？血出若多若少而面色蒼蒼者，何也？拔鍼而面色不變而煩悗者，何也？多出血而不動搖者，何也？願聞其故。 Yellow Emperor said, What does it mean when there is a puncture wound and the attendant? What does it mean when blood comes out and shoots? What does it mean when there is little black blood and it becomes turbid? What does it mean when the blood comes out clear and half turns into fluid? What does it mean when you pull out the lancet and it swells? What does it mean when the blood comes out in a lot or little, and the face becomes pale? What does it mean when you pull out the lancet and the complexion does not change but feels uncomfortable? What does it mean when there is excessive bleeding but no shaking? I want to hear its cause.

3: 歧伯曰：脈氣盛而血虛者，刺之則脫氣，脫氣則仆。 Obi said: If the pulse is full and the blood is deficient, when pierced, there will be a sudden release of breath, and if suddenly released, it will lead to collapse.

4: 血氣俱盛而陰氣多者，其血滑，刺之則射；陽氣蓄積，久留而不寫者，其血黑以濁，故不能射。 Those with abundant vital energy and an excess of yin energy have slippery blood, and when pricked it gushes forth; those with accumulated yang energy, who hold it for a long time without dispersing it, have black and turbid blood, hence they cannot shoot.

5: 新飲而液滲于絡，而未合和于血也，故血出而汁別焉；其不新飲者，身中有水，久則為腫。 If one drinks new liquids and they permeate the veins but have not yet mixed with the blood, then the blood flows out and separates from the fluid; for those who do not drink new liquids, there is water in their body, which over time leads to swelling.

6: 陰氣積于陽，其氣因于絡，故刺之血未出而氣先行，故腫。 Yin qi accumulates in Yang, its qi is stored in the Luo vessels, therefore when needling, blood has not yet come out but qi precedes it, thus causing swelling.

7: 陰陽之氣，其新相得而未和合，因而寫之，則陰陽俱脫，表裏相離，故脫色而蒼蒼然。 The yin and yang qi, when their new aspects meet but are not yet harmonized, if one writes them, then the yin and yang both depart, the front and back become separate, hence they lose color and appear blue-green.

8: 刺之血出多，色不變而煩悗者，刺絡而虛經，虛經之屬于陰者，陰脫，故煩悗。 If the blood coming out is profuse, and yet the color does not change but one feels annoyed and vexed, it is because the needle has pierced the superficial layer and the Channels of Yin, so one feels annoyed and vexed.

9: 陰陽相得而合為痺者，此為內溢于經，外注于絡。如是者，陰陽俱有餘，雖多出血而弗能虛也。 When yin and yang are harmonious and meet, it is because there is an excess of internal qi (vital energy) and external blood. In this case, both yin and yang have some surplus, although there may be a lot of bleeding, it cannot cause emptiness (deficiency).

10: 黃帝曰：相之奈何？歧伯曰：血脈者，盛堅橫以赤，上下無常處，小者如鍼，大者如筋，則而寫之萬全也，故無失數矣。失數而反，各如其度。 Yellow Emperor said: How about the correspondence? Master Gao replied: The blood vessels are like thick cords running red, without boundaries above or below. Small ones are like needles, large ones like tendons; by this they write the myriad changes, so there are no missing patterns. If a pattern is missed and reversed, each one adapts to its degree.

11: 黃帝曰：鍼入而肉著者，何也？歧伯曰：熱氣因于鍼，則鍼熱，熱則內著于鍼，故堅焉。 Yellow Emperor asked: What does it mean when the needle enters and penetrates the flesh? Guan Pu replied: The heat generated by the needle causes the needle to become hot. The heat then penetrates deeply into the needle, thus making it firm.

docs.title: 陰陽清濁
docs.text:
1: 黃帝曰：余聞十二經脈，以應十二經水者，其五色各異，清濁不同，人之血氣若一，應之奈何？歧伯曰：人之血氣，苟能若一，則天下為一矣，惡有亂者乎？黃帝曰：余問一人，非問天下之眾。歧伯曰：夫一人者，亦有亂氣，天下之象，亦有亂人，其合為一耳。 Yellow Emperor said: I have heard of the twelve channels and their corresponding water courses. The five colors are different, with varying degrees of purity and impurity. Although human blood and qi are essentially one, how can they be balanced? Master Qiao said: If human blood and qi were truly one, the world would be unified, and chaos would ensue. Yellow Emperor asked: I am asking about one person, not the multitude of the world. Master Qiao replied: Even in one person, there is chaos within, and among the various examples in the world, there are also chaotic people. Their unity is simply for comparison

2: 黃帝曰：願聞人氣之清濁。歧伯曰：受穀者濁，受氣者清。清者注陰，濁者注陽。濁而清者，上出於咽，清而濁者，則下行。清濁相干，命曰亂氣。 Yellow Emperor said: I wish to hear about the distinction between clear Qi and turbid Qi. [The philosopher] Boyi replied: Those who receive grain-Qi are turbid, and those who receive clear-Qi are refined. The refined is stored in the Yin, while the turbid is stored in the Yang. If it becomes turbid within clarity, it ascends from the throat; if it becomes clear within turbidity, then it descends. The distinction between clear Qi and turbid Qi is called chaotic Qi.

3: 黃帝曰：夫陰清而陽濁，濁者有清，清者有濁，清濁別之奈何？歧伯曰：氣之大別，清者上注于肺，濁者下走于胃。胃之清氣，上出于口；肺之濁氣，下注于經，內積于海。 Yellow Emperor said: When the yin is clear and the yang is turbid, which one is responsible for causing the other to be so, how can we distinguish between them? Guo Bo replied: The distinction lies in the different aspects of qi. Clear qi flows upward to the lungs, while turbid qi flows downward to the stomach. The clear qi from the stomach rises up through the mouth; the turbid qi from the lungs descends into the channels and accumulates within the sea.

4: 黃帝曰：諸陽皆濁，何陽濁甚乎？歧伯曰：手太陽獨受陽之濁，手太陰獨受陰之清；其清者上走空竅，其濁者下行諸經。諸陰皆清，足太陰獨受其濁。 Yellow Emperor said: All the channels of Zhongyang are obscured, is that of Youji obscured even more so? Qi Bo replied: The left hand's Yang channel receives the obscurity alone, and the left hand's Yin channel receives the clarity alone. The clear Qi rises through the openings above, while the obscure Qi flows to the collaterals below. All the Yin channels are clear, and the foot Yin channel receives the obscurity alone.

5: 黃帝曰：治之奈何？歧伯曰：清者其氣滑，濁者其氣澀，此氣之常也。故刺陰者，深而留之；刺陽者，淺而疾之；清濁相干者，以數調之也。 Yellow Emperor said: How should it be governed? Hua-Boo said: The pure one has smooth Qi, the murky one has thick Qi, this is the nature of Qi. Therefore, when needling the Yin, go deep and retain; when needling the Yang, go shallow and quick; for clear and turbid, adjust by numbers and timing

docs.title: 陰陽繫日月
docs.text:
1: 黃帝曰：余聞天為陽，地為陰，日為陽，月為陰，其合之於人，奈何？歧伯曰：腰以上為天，腰以下為地，故天為陽，地為陰，故足之十二經脈，以應十二月，月生於水，故在下者為陰；手之十指，以應十日，日主火，故在上者為陽。 The Yellow Emperor said: I have heard that heaven is yang and earth is yin, the sun is yang and the moon is yin. What do you say about their harmonization in humans? Huang Di replied: The upper part of the body is heaven, and the lower part is earth. Therefore, heaven is yang and earth is yin. Thus, the twelve channels and collaterals of the foot correspond to the twelve months. The moon is generated from water, so what is below is considered yin; the ten fingers of the hands correspond to the ten days, the sun governs fire, so what is above is considered yang.

2: 黃帝曰：合之於脈，奈何？歧伯曰：寅者，正月之生陽也，主左足之少陽；未者，六月，主右足之少陽。卯者，二月，主左足之太陽；午者，五月，主右足之太陽。辰者，三月，主左足之陽明；巳者，四月，主右足之陽明。此兩陽合於前，故曰陽明。申者，七月之生陰也，主右足之少陰；丑者，十二月，主左足之少陰；酉者，八月，主右足之太陰；子者，十一月，主左足之太陰；戌者，九月，主右足之厥陰；亥者，十月，主左足之厥陰；此兩陰交盡，故曰厥陽。 Yellow Emperor said: How about combining it with the pulse? Quick response: In the Yang Ming cycle, the first month is the generation of Yang, ruling the left foot's Shao Yang; the sixth month is ruled by the right foot's Shao Yang. The second month governs the left foot's Tai Yang; the fifth month is governed by the right foot's Tai Yang. The third month governs the left foot's Yang Ming, and the fourth month governs the right foot's Yang Ming. Combining the two Yin in front leads to Yang Ming. In the Xu cycle, the seventh month is the generation of Yin, ruling the right foot's Shao Yin; the twelfth month rules the left foot's Shao Yin. The eighth month governs the right foot's Tai Yin, and the eleventh month governs the left foot's Tai Yin. The ninth month governs the right foot's Jue Yin, and the tenth month governs the left foot's Jue Yin. These two Yin fully intertwine, which is why it is called Jue Yang.

3: 甲主左手之少陽；己主右手之少陽；乙主左手之太陽，戊主右手之太陽；丙主左手之陽明，丁主右手之陽明，此兩火并合，故為陽明。庚主右手之少陰，癸主左手之少陰，辛主右手之太陰，壬主左手之太陰。 The Jupiter-associated left hand has Lesser Yang; the Saturn-associated right hand has Lesser Yang; the Venus-associated left hand has Greater Yang, and the Earth-associated right hand has Greater Yang. The Wood and Metal elements are combined in this instance, hence it is called Greater Yang. The Mercury-associated right hand has Lesser Yin, the Water-associated left hand has Lesser Yin, and the Fire-associated right hand has Greater Yin, and the Earth-associated left hand has Greater Yin.

(Translator's note: This passage is describing the elements in traditional Chinese astrology and their corresponding positions on the body.)

4: 故足之陽者，陰中之少陽也；足之陰者，陰中之太陰也。手之陽者，陽中之太陽也；手之陰者，陽中之少陰也。腰以上者為陽，腰以下者為陰。 In the case where the foot's yang is present, it is a deficiency of yang within the interior. The foot's yin is a deficiency of yin within the interior. The hand's yang is an excess of yang within the interior; the hand's yin is a deficiency of yin within the interior. What is above the waist is considered yang, and what is below the waist is considered yin.

5: 其於五藏也，心為陽中之太陽，肺為陰中之少陰，肝為陰中之少陽，脾為陰中之至陰，腎為陰中之太陰。 It is in the Five Classics, the heart is like the sun within the Yang, the lungs are like the small Yin within the Yin, the liver is like the small Yang within the Yin, the spleen is like the ultimate Yin within the Yin, and the kidneys are like the great Yin within the Yin.

6: 黃帝曰：以治之奈何？歧伯曰：正月二月三月，人氣在左，無刺左足之陽；四月五月六月，人氣在右，無刺右足之陽，七月八月九月，人氣在右，無刺右足之陰，十月十一月十二月，人氣在左，無刺左足之陰。 Yellow Emperor asked, What about treating it? Hua Tuo replied, In the months of the first, second, and third lunar month when the human energy is on the left side, do not prick the yang of the left foot. In the fourth, fifth, and sixth lunar month when the human energy is on the right side, do not prick the yang of the right foot. In the seventh, eighth, and ninth lunar month when the human energy is on the right side, do not prick the yin of the right foot. In the tenth, eleventh, and twelfth lunar month when the human energy is on the left side, do not prick the yin of the left foot.

7: 黃帝曰：五行以東方為甲乙木主春。春者，蒼色，主肝，肝者，足厥陰也。今乃以甲為左手之少陽，不合於數，何也？歧伯曰：此天地之陰陽也，非四時五行之以次行也。且夫陰陽者，有名而無形，故數之可十，離之可百，散之可千，推之可萬，此之謂也。 The Yellow Emperor said: The five phases assign the east to metal, which governs spring. Spring is associated with the color blue and governs the liver, which corresponds to the foot's yin channel. Now, you use the letter A as the left hand's shallow Yang, which does not fit with numerology; why is that? The Duke of Zhou said: This is about the yin and yang of heaven and earth, not the cycles of the four seasons and the five phases. Furthermore, yin and yang have names but no shape, so they can be counted up to ten, separated into a hundred, scattered into a thousand, and expanded into ten thousand; this is what it means

docs.title: 病傳
docs.text:
1: 黃帝曰：余受九鍼于夫子，而私覽于諸方，或有導引行氣，喬摩、灸、熨、刺、焫、飲藥之一者，可獨守耶，將盡行之乎？歧伯曰：諸方者，眾人之方也，非一人之所盡行也。 Yellow Emperor said: I received nine needles from Confucius, and privately studied them in various ways. Sometimes there are guiding and directing methods for regulating the Qi, such as acupuncture, moxibustion, cupping, acupressure, cauterization, ingestion of medicine, and so on. Can one person exclusively guard and practice them all? Huzhu said: The various ways refer to the common people's methods, not something that can be fully practiced by a single individual.

2: 黃帝曰：此乃所謂守一勿失，萬物畢者也。今余已聞陰陽之要，虛實之理，傾移之過，可治之屬，願聞病之變化，淫傳絕敗而不可治者，可得聞乎？歧伯曰：要乎哉問也，昭乎其如日醒，窘乎其如夜瞑，能被而服之，神與俱成，畢將服之，神自得之，生神之理，可著於竹帛，不可傳於子孫。 Yellow Emperor said: This is what is meant by guarding the one and not losing it, the completion of a hundred things. Now I have heard about the essence of yin and yang, the logic of emptiness and reality, the excesses of changing and moving, which can be governed and are treatable. I wish to hear about the changes in diseases that become incurable due to excessive transmission and do not lend themselves to treatment. Can you explain this? The Grand Assistant replied: What a profound question! It is as clear as daylight when one wakes up, and as perplexing as darkness when one is asleep. It can be understood and taught, allowing the spirit to succeed, and the spirit itself will attain it. The essence of the spirit, which can be written on bamboo slips, should not be passed down to one's descendants.

3: 黃帝曰：何謂日醒？歧伯曰：明於陰陽，如惑之解，如醉之醒。黃帝曰：何謂夜瞑？歧伯曰：瘖乎其無聲，漠乎其無形，折毛發理，正氣橫傾，淫邪泮衍，血脈傳溜，大氣入藏，腹痛下淫，可以致死，不可以致生。 Yellow Emperor asked: What is meant by day wakefulness? Hui Bao replied: It means clarity of yin and yang, like the solution of confusion, like awakening from drunkenness. Yellow Emperor asked: What is meant by night torpor? Hui Bao replied: It is without sound and form, it folds the hairs, straightens the qi, adjusts the disordered and excessive, guides the blood vessels, disperses the great qi, enters the storehouse, causes abdominal pain and discharges the excess, which can lead to death but not to life.

4: 黃帝曰：大氣入藏，奈何？歧伯曰：病先發於心，一日而之肺，三日而之肝，五日而之脾，三日不已，死。冬夜半，夏日中。 Yellow Emperor said: What if the great Qi enters the body? Huangdi said: The disease starts in the heart, and it reaches the lungs in a day. It reaches the liver in three days and the spleen in five days. If it continues for three days without stopping, one dies. Half of winter night or mid-summer day.

5: 病先發於肺，三日而之肝，一日而之脾，五日而之胃，十日不已，死。冬日入，夏日出。 The illness first manifested in the lungs, and by the third day it had affected the liver. In a day, it reached the spleen. By five days, it extended to the stomach. Ten days later, it still persisted and resulted in death. It occurred during winter and resolved during summer.

6: 病先發於肝，三日而之脾，五日而之胃，三日而之腎，三日不已，死。冬日入，夏蚤食。 The disease first appears in the liver, and by the third day it has spread to the spleen, by the fifth day to the stomach, by the third day to the kidneys, where it continues without cease until death. It is contracted in winter and cured in summer with a diet of insects.

7: 病先發於脾，一日而之胃，二日而之腎，三日而之膂膀胱，十日不已，死。冬人定，夏晏食。 The illness begins in the spleen, moves to the stomach in one day, to the kidneys in two days, to the muscles and bladder in three days, and continues for ten days without stopping, resulting in death. This is a seasonal diet: in winter, refrain from eating; in summer, be cautious with food.

8: 病先發於胃，五日而之腎，三日而之膂膀胱，五日而上之心，二日不已，死，冬夜半，夏日昳。 The illness first began in the stomach, and after five days it affected the kidneys. After three days it spread to the liver, spleen, and intestines. Five days later, it rose up to the heart. Within two days, it did not stop, leading to death. Halfway through the winter night or a summer day's heat.

9: 病先發於腎，三日而之膂膀胱，三日而上之心，三日而之小腸，三日不已，死。冬大晨，夏晏晡。 The illness first appeared in the kidney, and after three days it reached the bladder, three days later it rose to the heart, three days later it affected the small intestine, and it did not stop there. The person died. In winter, during the large morning, and in summer, during the late afternoon heat

10: 病先發於膀胱，五日而之腎，一日而之小腸，一日而之心，二日不已，死。冬雞鳴，夏下晡。 The illness first began in the bladder, and by the fifth day it had reached the kidneys. By the next day, it affected the small intestine, then the heart, where it lingered for two days before causing death. Chickens cackled in winter, and in summer they shed feathers.

11: 諸病以次相傳，如是者，皆有死期，不可刺也；間一藏及二、三、四藏者，乃可刺也。 Various diseases that come in succession, if they are like this, all have a time of death and cannot be punctured; between the lower abdomen and the first, second, third, and fourth storerooms, they can be punctured.

docs.title: 淫邪發夢
docs.text:
1: 黃帝曰：願聞淫邪泮衍，奈何？歧伯曰：正邪從外襲內，而未有定舍，反淫于藏，不得定處，與營衛俱行，而與魂魄飛揚，使人臥不得安而喜夢；氣淫于府，則有餘于外，不足于內；氣淫于藏，則有餘于內，不足于外。 Yellow Emperor said: I want to hear about obscene and chaotic behavior. What do you say? Obscure Lord replied: The obscene and chaotic arise externally and invade internally, but there is no fixed abode. They act contrary to the hidden treasury and cannot be settled, accompanying soldiers and guards in their activities. This causes the souls and spirits to fly up and down, making people unable to rest in peace and delight in dreams. The vital energy is depleted externally, leaving nothing for the internal, or depleted internally, leaving nothing for the external.

2: 黃帝曰：有餘不足，有形乎？歧伯曰：陰氣盛，則夢涉大水而恐懼；陽氣盛，則夢大火而燔焫；陰陽俱盛，則夢相殺。上盛則夢飛，下盛則夢墮；甚飢則夢取，甚飽則夢予；肝氣盛，則夢怒，肺氣盛，則夢恐懼、哭泣、飛揚；心氣盛，則夢善笑恐畏；脾氣盛，則夢歌樂，身體重不舉；腎氣盛，則夢腰脊兩解不屬。凡此十二盛者，至而寫之，立已。 Yellow Emperor said: Is there any form when there is excess or deficiency? Guo Bo replied: When yin qi is abundant, one may dream of crossing a vast body of water and feel afraid; when yang qi is abundant, one may dream of fire and be burnt; when both yin and yang are abundant, one may dream of killing each other. If the upper part is abundant, one may dream of flying; if the lower part is abundant, one may dream of falling. If one is extremely hungry, one may dream of taking something; if one is extremely full, one may dream of giving. When liver qi is abundant, one may dream of being angry; when lung qi is abundant, one may dream of being afraid, crying, and soaring; when heart qi is abundant, one may dream of laughing and being scared; when spleen qi is abundant, one may dream of singing and dancing, but the body cannot rise; when kidney qi is abundant, one may dream of pain in the lumbar region and hips that do not feel like they belong. In summary, these twelve excesses, once reached, should be recorded and completed.

3: 厥氣客於心，則夢見丘山煙火；客於肺，則夢飛揚，見金鐵之奇物；客於肝，則夢山林樹木；客於脾，則夢見丘陵大澤，壞屋風雨；客于腎，則夢臨淵，沒居水中；客于膀胱，則夢遊行；客于胃，則夢飲食；客于大腸，則夢田野；客于小腸，則夢聚邑沖衢；客于膽，則夢鬥訟自刳；客于陰器，則夢接內；客于項，則夢斬首；客于脛，則夢行走而不能前，及居深地窌苑中；客于股肱，則夢禮節拜起；客于胞䐈，則夢溲便。凡此十五不足者，至而補之立已也。 When the vital energy resides in the heart, one dreams of seeing mountains and fires; when it resides in the lungs, one dreams of flying and sees strange iron objects; when it resides in the liver, one dreams of forests and trees; when it resides in the spleen, one dreams of hills and vast fields with ramshackle houses, wind, and rain; when it resides in the kidneys, one dreams of dwelling by the deep abyss; when it resides in the bladder, one dreams of traveling; when it resides in the stomach, one dreams of eating and drinking; when it resides in the large intestine, one dreams of fields; when it resides in the small intestine, one dreams of cities by the sea or river; when it resides in the pancreas, one dreams of fighting lawsuits and self-mutilation; when it resides in the genitals, one dreams of engaging in sex; when it resides in the neck, one dreams of beheading others; when it resides in the shanks, one dreams of walking but being unable to move forward or dwelling deep in a dimly lit forest; when it resides in the hip joints, one dreams of performing ritual bows and prostrations; when it resides in the ovaries or testes, one dreams of defecating. All these fifteen cases are not exhaustive, but can be supplemented as necessary.

docs.title: 順氣一日分為四時
docs.text:
1: 黃帝曰：夫百病之所始生者，必起於燥溫寒暑風雨陰陽喜怒飲食居處，氣合而有形，得藏而有名，余知其然也。夫百病者，多以旦慧晝安，夕加夜甚，何也？歧伯曰：四時之氣使然。 Yellow Emperor said: The source of the hundred diseases is definitely due to dryness, heat, cold, hot and cold winds, rain, yin and yang, joy and anger, drinking, eating, and dwelling. The qi gathers and takes shape, and hides and has a name, I know it is true. Yellow Emperor asked: The hundred diseases are often more intelligent in the morning and peaceful at night, and increase in the evening and become worse at night, what is the reason for this? Qi Bo said: This is due to the energy of the four seasons.

2: 黃帝曰：願聞四時之氣。歧伯曰：春生，夏長，秋收，冬藏，是氣之常也，人亦應之，以一日分為四時，朝則為春，日中為夏，日入為秋，夜半為冬。朝則人氣始生，病氣衰，故旦慧；日中人氣長，長則勝邪，故安；夕則人氣始衰，邪氣始生，故加；夜半人氣入藏，邪氣獨居於身，故甚也。 Yellow Emperor said: I wish to hear about the changes of the four seasons. Kuang-pen replied: Spring brings forth, summer prolongs, autumn harvests, winter stores – this is the natural cycle of energy. People should follow these cycles. One day is divided into four times: morning is spring, noon is summer, afternoon is autumn, and midnight is winter. In the morning, people's vitality begins to emerge, and pathogenic factors wane, thus making it an auspicious time. At noon, people's vitality grows stronger, which helps overcome evil influences. In the evening, people's vitality starts to decline, and pathogenic factors arise, so it is a dangerous period. At midnight, people's vitality is stored and pathogenic factors dominate the body, making it a severe time.

3: 黃帝曰：有時有反者何也？歧伯曰：是不應四時之氣，藏獨主其病者，是必以藏氣之所不勝時者甚，以其所勝時者起也。黃帝曰：治之奈何？歧伯曰：順天之時，而病可與期。順者為工，逆者為麤。 Yellow Emperor said: What causes someone to have a counter-seasonal disease? Guanpu said: It is due to not responding to the qi of the four seasons, and using self-isolation to treat their illness, so one must use the time when their qi cannot prevail to suppress it, and use the time when it can prevail to rise. Yellow Emperor said: How should it be treated? Guanpu said: Follow the rhythm of heaven and earth, and the disease can be predicted. Following is a skill, whereas opposing is a loss.

4: 黃帝曰：善，余聞刺有五變，以主五輸。願聞其數。歧伯曰：人有五藏，五藏有五變。五變有五輸，故五五二十五輸，以應五時。 The Yellow Emperor said, Good, I have heard that there are five changes of the needle and it governs five losses. I wish to hear about their number. Qi Bo replied, Human beings have five vital organs, and the five vital organs have five changes. The five changes have five losses, so there are twenty-five losses in total, which correspond to the five times of the day.

5: 黃帝曰：願聞五變。歧伯曰：肝為牡藏，其色青，其時春，其音角，其味酸，其日甲乙；心為牡藏，其色赤，其時夏，其日丙丁，其音徵，其味苦；脾為牝藏，其色黃，其時長夏，其日戊己，其音宮，其味甘；肺為牝藏，其色白，其音商，其時徵，其日庚辛，其味辛；腎為牝藏，其色黑，其時冬，其日壬癸，其音羽，其味鹹。是為五變。 Yellow Emperor said, I wish to hear about the Five Phases. Duke of Shou replied, The Liver is the Yin source. It has a green color, its season is spring, its sound is Xiang, its taste is sour, its days are Jia and Yi. The Heart is the Yin source. It has a red color, its season is summer, its days are Bing and Ding, its sound is Zhī, its taste is bitter. The Spleen is the Yang source. Its season is late summer, its days are Wu and Ji, its sound is Gong, its taste is sweet. The Lungs are the Yang source. It has a white color, its season is autumn, its days are Geng and Xin, its sound is Shan, its taste is pungent. The Kidneys are the Yin source. Its season is winter, its days are Ren and Gui, its sound is Yǔ, its taste is salty. These are the Five Phases

6: 黃帝曰：以主五輸奈何？藏主冬，冬刺井；色主春，春刺滎；時主夏，夏刺輸；音主長夏，長夏刺經；味主秋，秋刺合。是謂五變，以主五輸。 Yellow Emperor said, Why have the five seasons not submitted? In the midst of winter, one stabs the well; in the midst of spring, one stabs the Bamboo Grove; in the midst of summer, one stabs the floods; during the season of Long Summer, one stabs the Meridians; and in the midst of autumn, one stabs the Gathering. Such are the Five Cycles, through which the five seasons submit.

7: 黃帝曰：諸原安和，以致五輸。歧伯曰：原獨不應五時，以經合之，以應其數，故六六三十六輸。 Yellow Emperor said: All under Heaven are in peace and harmony, which resulted in five losses. Duke of Zhou said: If there were no original chaos, but the world was regulated according to the Book of Changes, then it would correspond with its numbers, resulting in six six thirty-six losses.

8: 黃帝曰：何謂藏主冬，時主夏，音主長夏，味主秋，色主春。願聞其故。歧伯曰：病在藏者，取之井；病變於色者，取之滎；病時間時甚者，取之輸；病變於音者，取之經；經滿而血者，病在胃；及以飲食不節得病者，取之於合，故命曰味主合。是謂五變也。 Yellow Emperor said: What do you mean by the Master of Storage in winter, the Master of Time in summer, the Master of Long Summer, the Master of Taste in autumn, and the Master of Color in spring? I wish to hear about their origins. Duke of Shou replied: Disease resides in the storage, draw from the well; disease changes with color, draw from the flood; disease of timing is quite critical, draw from the channel; when the channel is full and there is blood, the disease is in the stomach; when diseases are caused by improper diet, draw from the Union, so it is called the Master of Taste of the Union. These are the Five Changes.

docs.title: 外揣
docs.text:
1: 黃帝曰：余聞九鍼九篇，余親受其調，頗得其意。夫九鍼者，始於一而終於九，然未得其要道也。夫九鍼者，小之則無內，大之則無外，深不可為下，高不可為蓋，恍惚無竅，流溢無極，佘知其合於天道人事四時之變也，然余願雜之毫毛，渾束為一，可乎？歧伯曰：明乎哉問也，非獨鍼道焉，夫治國亦然。 Yellow Emperor said: I have heard of the Nine Needles and Nine Sheets, and I have received its essence. As for the Nine Needles, it starts from one and ends at nine, but I have not yet attained its essential way. The Nine Needles is something that is neither small nor large, has no inside or outside, cannot be described in terms of depth or height, and is like a blurry vision with no holes and an overflowing torrent without limits. Recognizing that it is applicable to the transformations of heavenly principles, human events, and the four seasons, I wish for my understanding to be as fine as a hair's breadth and bundled into one, can this be done? Hui Shi said: This question is clear indeed, and it is not only about the Nine Needles' way. As for governing a country, it is also the same.

2: 黃帝曰：余願聞鍼道，非國事也。歧伯曰：夫治國者，夫惟道焉，非道，何可小大深淺，雜合而為一乎。 Yellow Emperor said: I wish to hear about the method of acupuncture, which is not a matter of state affairs. Duke of Shou said: Governing a country is nothing but the Way, without the Way, what can be small or large, deep or shallow, and mixed together as one?

3: 黃帝曰：願卒聞之。歧伯曰：日與月焉，水與鏡焉，鼓與響焉。夫日月之明，不失其影，水鏡之察，不失其形，鼓響之應，不後其聲，動搖則應和，盡得其情。 Yellow Emperor said: I wish to hear about it. Huzi replied: Like the sun and moon, water and a mirror, and drums and their echoes. The brightness of the sun and moon does not lose its shadow, the attentiveness of water and a mirror does not lose its shape, and the response of drums and their echoes do not lag behind their sound. When moving or shaking, it responds in harmony and accurately captures the mood.

4: 黃帝曰：窘乎哉！昭昭之明不可蔽，其不可蔽，不失陰陽也。合而察之，切而驗之，見而得之，若清水明鏡之不失其形也。五音不彰，五色不明，五藏波蕩，若是則內外相襲，若鼓之應桴，響之應聲，影之似形。故遠者，司外揣內，近者，司內揣外，是謂陰陽之極，天地之蓋，請藏之靈蘭之室，弗敢使泄也。 Yellow Emperor said: Ah, how difficult! The clarity of the Shao-yan is impossible to conceal; its inability to be concealed does not mean it fails to distinguish yin and yang. When combined, examined, scrutinized, and seen, it is like the unfailing shape of a clear water mirror. Five sounds are not prominent, five colors are not clear, five viscera are turbid, if so, then inner and outer will harm each other, just as drum responds to gong, resonates with sound, shadow resembles form. Therefore, those far away should investigate inside while watching outside, and those nearby should investigate outside while watching inside, this is what we call the extreme of yin and yang, the seal of heaven and earth, and the dwelling place of the secret treasure, which I dare not reveal.

docs.title: 五變
docs.text:
1: 黃帝問於少俞曰：余聞百疾之始期也，必生於風雨寒暑，循毫毛而入腠理，或復還，或留止，或為風腫汗出，或為消癉，或為寒熱，或為留痺，或為積聚。奇邪淫溢，不可勝數，願聞其故。夫同時得病，或病此，或病彼，意者天之為人生風乎，何其異也？少俞曰：夫天之生風者，非以私百姓也，其行公平正直，犯者得之，避者得無殆，非求人而人自犯之。 Emperor Yang asked Shao Yong: I have heard that the origin of the hundred diseases is generated by exposure to wind, rain, cold, and heat. They may come and go, linger or stop, manifest as wind-swelling and sweating, or as consumption, or as chills and fever, or as paralysis, or as accumulation. The strange and perverse nature of this phenomenon cannot be counted; I wish to hear about its cause. As for the cases where people contract illnesses simultaneously, some may contract this illness, while others may contract another one. Is this not evidence that God bestows suffering upon humans in accordance with their actions, how strange is that? Shao Yong replied: The way in which God creates wind is not out of malice towards ordinary people; it acts impartially and justly. Those who violate it will suffer the consequences, while those who avoid it will suffer little or none, and this is not something they seek but rather something that happens due to their own actions.

2: 黃帝曰：一時遇風，同時得病，其病各異，願聞其故。少俞曰：善乎其問！請論以比匠人。匠人磨斧斤，礪刀削斷材木。木之陰陽，尚有堅脆，堅者不入，脆者皮弛，至其交節，而缺斤斧焉。夫一木之中，堅脆不同，堅者則剛，脆者易傷，況其材木之不同，皮之厚薄，汁之多少，而各異耶。夫木之蚤花先生葉者，遇春霜烈風，則花落而葉萎；久曝大旱，則脆木薄皮者，枝條汁少而葉萎；久陰淫雨，則薄皮多汁者，皮漉而淺；卒風暴起，則剛脆之木，枝折杌傷；秋霜疾風，則剛脆之木，根搖而葉落。凡此五者，各有所傷，況於人乎！ Yellow Emperor said: At one time, encountering wind and at the same time contracting illness, with various symptoms, I wish to hear of their causes. Shao Yong said: What a good question! Please discuss it by comparing it to a craftsman. The craftsman sharpens an axe, hones a knife, cuts and shapes wood material. The yin and yang of the wood still have hardness and brittleness; the hard one does not enter, while the brittle one is flexible, until reaching the joints where the axe is lacking. Since the hardness and brittleness of one piece of wood are not the same, the hard one is rigid, while the brittle one is easily damaged; how much more for different kinds of wood materials, the thickness of the bark, and the amount of sap, each being different? When the wood's buds sprout before the leaves open, encountering spring frost or strong wind, the flowers fall and the leaves wither. If there is a long drought, then the brittle wood and thin-skinned trees have branches with little sap and their leaves wither; if there is an excessive amount of rain, then the thin-skinned trees with more sap will peel and become shallow-rooted; suddenly encountering strong wind or storms, then the hard and brittle trees have broken branches and damaged trunks; in the autumn, when the frost and wind are rapid, then the hard and brittle trees have shaking roots and their leaves fall. All of these five cases have been harmed; how much more for people!

3: 黃帝曰：以人應木，奈何？少俞答曰：木之所傷也，皆傷其枝。枝之剛脆而堅，未成傷也。人之有常病也，亦因其骨節皮膚腠理之不堅固者，邪之所舍也，故常為病也。 Yellow Emperor said: What if a man corresponds to wood, how could that be? Shao Yong answered: The places where the wood is injured are all on its branches. The branches are brittle and strong but not yet fully injured. In humans, there are constant diseases which are due to their bones, joints, skin, hair follicles not being firm and secure, so evil spirits have a place to lodge, hence they constantly become diseased

4: 黃帝曰：人之善病風厥漉汗者，何以候之？少俞答曰：內不堅，腠理疏，則善病風。黃帝曰：何以候肉之不堅也？少俞答曰：膕肉不堅，而無分理。理者麤理，麤理而皮不致者，腠理疏。此言其渾然者。 Yellow Emperor said: How do you know if a person is prone to disease, fever, and chills due to sweat? Shao Yong answered: If the interior is not solid, the sinews are scattered, then one is prone to diseases such as fever. Yellow Emperor asked: What is the sign of flesh not being solid? Shao Yong answered: The muscles are soft and not separate. Separating means separating the tendons, separating the tendons so that the skin does not fit, resulting in scattered sinews. This refers to someone who is quite like this.

5: 黃帝曰：人之善病消癉者，何以候之？少俞答曰：五藏皆柔弱者，善病消癉。黃帝曰：何以知五藏之柔弱也？少俞答曰：夫柔弱者，必有剛強，剛強多怒，柔者易傷也。黃帝曰：何以候柔弱之與剛強？少俞答曰：此人薄皮膚，而目堅固以深者，長沖直腸，其心剛，剛則多怒，怒則氣上逆，胸中蓄積，血氣逆留，髖皮充肌，血脈不行，轉而為熱，熱則消肌膚，故為消癉。此言其人暴剛而肌肉弱者也。 Yellow Emperor asked: How can one determine a person who is good at treating illnesses and preventing diseases? Shao Yong answered: Those who are skilled in treating illnesses and preventing diseases are the ones who are familiar with the Five Virtues. The Yellow Emperor asked: How do you know that the Five Virtues are soft and weak? Shao Yong answered: Softness and weakness necessarily have strength and rigidity, strength and rigidity often lead to anger, and anger causes Qi to rise and flow inversely, accumulating in the chest, causing the blood and Qi to become stagnant and blocked, leading to the thickening of skin and muscles, and the obstruction of blood vessels, resulting in fever that leads to the wasting of muscles and skin. This refers to a person who is prone to anger and has weak muscles.

6: 黃帝曰：人之善病寒熱者，何以候之？少俞答曰：小骨弱肉者，善病寒熱。黃帝曰：何以候骨之小大，肉之堅脆，色之不一也？少俞答曰：顴骨者，骨之本也。顴大則骨大，顴小則骨小。皮膚薄而其肉無䐃，其臂懦懦然，其地色殆然，不與其天同色，污然獨異，此其候也。然後臂薄者，其髓不滿，故善病寒熱也。 Yellow Emperor said: What is the sign that a person is susceptible to cold and fever? Shao Yong replied: Those with weak bones and flesh are susceptible to cold and fever. Yellow Emperor asked: How can we determine whether someone has small or large bones, hard or soft flesh, or different skin color? Shao Yong replied: The hip bone is the basis of all bones. If the hip bone is large, then the bones are large; if the hip bone is small, then the bones are small. If the skin is thin and the flesh lacks substance, the arms are flabby and limp, the complexion is almost lost, not harmonious with heaven's colors, dirty and unique, this is the sign of their condition. Then, if the arms are weak, the marrow is insufficient, so they are susceptible to cold and fever.

7: 黃帝曰：何以候人之善病痺者？少俞答曰：麤理而肉不堅者，善病痺。黃帝曰：痺之高下有處乎？少俞答曰：欲知其高下者，各視其部。 Yellow Emperor asked: How can one judge whether a person is good at contracting diseases or not? Shao Yong replied: Those with thin and delicate bodies but weak muscles are good at contracting diseases. Yellow Emperor asked: Is there any high or low aspect to contracting diseases? Shao Yong replied: To know whether it is high or low, one must examine its corresponding part

8: 黃帝曰：人之善病腸中積聚者，何以候之？少俞答曰：皮膚薄而不澤，肉不堅而淖澤。如此，則腸胃惡，惡則邪氣留止，積聚乃傷脾胃之間，寒溫不次，邪氣稍至。蓄積留止，大聚乃起。 Yellow Emperor asked: What is the cause of people's susceptibility to diseases, and how can it be predicted? Shao Yong answered: The skin is thin and lacks luster, and the flesh is soft and moist. As a result, the spleen and stomach are in poor condition. This leads to the accumulation of evil qi, which can cause harm between the spleen and stomach. If the cold and heat do not subside, the evil qi will gradually gather, eventually leading to the onset of disease.

9: 黃帝曰：余聞病形，已知之矣！願聞其時。少俞答曰：先立其年，以知其時。時高則起，時下則殆，雖不陷下，當年有沖道，其病必起，是謂因形而生病，五變之紀也。 Yellow Emperor said: I have heard about the manifestations of disease, and I know them. I wish to hear about its time. Shao Yong answered: First determine their age, in order to know its time. If it is high, it will rise; if it is low, it will perish; although it does not collapse, there was a change in the year, and its disease must arise, which is called causing the form to produce illness, and the record of the five transformations.

docs.title: 本藏
docs.text:
1: 黃帝問于歧伯曰：人之血氣精神者，所以奉生而周於性命者也；經脈者，所以行血氣而營陰陽、濡筋骨，利關節者也；衛氣者，所以溫分肉，充皮膚，肥腠理，司開闔者也；志意者，所以御精神，收魂魄，適寒溫，和喜怒者也。是故血和則經脈流行，營復陰陽，筋骨勁強，關節清利矣；衛氣和則分肉解利，皮膚調柔，腠理致密矣；志意和則精神專直，魂魄不散，悔怒不起，五藏不受邪矣；寒溫和則六府化穀，風痺不作，經脈通利，肢節得安矣，此人之常平也。五藏者，所以藏精神血氣魂魄者也；六府者，所以化水穀而行津液者也。此人之所以具受於天也，無愚智賢不肖，無以相倚也。然有其獨盡天壽，而無邪僻之病，百年不衰，雖犯風雨卒寒大暑，猶有弗能害也；有其不離屏蔽室內，無怵惕之恐，然猶不免於病，何也？願聞其故。 Emperor Yellow asked Confucius, The human body contains blood, qi, and spirit; the meridians are the channels for the circulation of blood and qi, regulating yin and yang and nourishing the tendons and bones. The Wei qi is used to warm the organs, nourish the skin, and moisturize the muscles and faculties, and control opening and closing. Intention or spirit is what maintains consciousness, collects the soul, adjusts to cold and heat, and harmonizes joy and anger. Therefore, when blood is balanced, the meridians flow smoothly, yin and yang are regulated, tendons and bones have strength, and joints are clear and nourished. When Wei qi is balanced, the muscles distribute and refine, the skin becomes soft and supple, sinews are strengthened, and the organs function properly without being invaded by evil. When intention or spirit is balanced, consciousness is focused and direct, the soul does not scatter, anger does not arise, and the five organs do not suffer from evil influences. Cold and heat are balanced, the six departments transform grains and regulate fluids, wind stroke does not occur, and the meridians flow smoothly, and joints are at peace. This is the natural equilibrium of the human body. The five organs house the spirit, blood, and soul. The six departments regulate the transformation of water and grains. This person's ability to receive from heaven is complete, without folly or lack of wisdom. Although they possess an independent longevity that is free from strange diseases and does not wither over a hundred years, even if they encounter wind, rain, sudden cold, or intense heat, they are still unable to be harmed. How can it be that they do not leave their secluded room and are still prone to illness? I wish to know the reason.

2: 歧伯對曰：窘乎哉問也。五藏者，所以參天地，副陰陽，而運四時，化五節者也；五藏者，固有小大、高下、堅脆、端正、偏傾者，六府亦有小大、長短、厚薄、結直、緩急。凡此二十五者，各不同，或善或惡，或吉或凶，請言其方。 Duke Zhou replied, It is indeed a difficult question. The Five Canons serve to harmonize heaven and earth, complement yin and yang, and regulate the four seasons and nurture the five cycles. The Five Canons have their own small and large, high and low, firm and brittle, upright and tilted, and six ministries also have their own small and large, long and short, thick and thin, knotted and smooth, and slow and fast aspects. All of these twenty-five aspects are different from one another and may be good or bad, auspicious or inauspicious; I ask about the method for understanding them

3: 心小則安，邪弗能傷，易傷以憂；心大則憂，不能傷，易傷於邪。心高則滿於肺中，悗而善忘，難開以言；心下，則藏外，易傷於寒，易恐以言。心堅，則藏安守固；心脆則善病消癉熱中。心端正，則和利難傷；心偏傾則操持不一，無守司也。 A small heart is secure, evil cannot harm it, and one may be upset by injury; a great heart is troubled, cannot be harmed, and may be injured by evil. A high heart is filled with the lungs, becomes depressed and easily forgets, and finds it difficult to speak. A low heart, then, is outside the womb, easily injured by cold, and is prone to fear in speech. A firm heart is safe and securely guarded; a brittle heart is prone to illness and sweating during fever. A calm and upright heart brings harmony and benefits others, while a heart that leans one way or the other leads to inconsistency in holding onto things and lacks protection.

4: 肺小，則少飲，不病喘喝；肺大則多飲，善病胸痺、喉痺、逆氣。肺高，則上氣，肩息咳；肺下則居賁迫肺，善脅下痛。肺堅則不病，咳上氣；肺脆，則苦病消痺易傷。肺端正，則和利難傷；肺偏傾，則胸偏痛也。 If the lung is small, one should drink less and not suffer from cough or wheezing; if the lung is large, one should drink more and be prone to diseases such as chest pain, throat pain, and qi reversal. If the lung is high, one will have qi rising, causing shoulder pain and coughing; if the lung is low, one will suffer from phlegm accumulating and pressuring the lung, often experiencing lower abdominal pain. If the lung is firm, there will be no disease and coughing with qi rising; if the lung is brittle, there will be difficult-to-treat diseases of pain and numbness that easily lead to injury. If the lung is balanced, one can avoid difficult situations; if the lung is leaning to one side, chest pain on that side will result.

5: 肺小則藏安，無脅下之病；肝大則逼胃迫咽，迫咽則苦膈中，且脅下痛。肝高，則上支賁切，脅挽為息賁；肝下則逼胃脅下空，脅下空則易受邪。肝堅則藏安難傷；肝脆則善病消痺，易傷。肝端正，則和利難傷；肝偏傾，則脅下痛也。 If the lungs are small, they will be safe and have no diseases beneath them; if the liver is large, it will force the stomach upward and force the throat, causing bitterness in the middle and a painful sensation below. If the liver is high, there will be pain in the diaphragm and difficulty breathing; if the liver is low, it will force the stomach below and cause the space below to be easily invaded by pathogens. If the liver is firm, it will be difficult to harm the safe haven; if the liver is soft, it is good at resolving diseases and relieving pain but is prone to injury. If the liver is properly positioned, it is difficult to cause harm; if the liver is tilted, there will be pain below. Note: This translation may not be an accurate literal translation of the original text due to the complexity and abstract nature of classical Chinese literature.

6: 脾小，則藏安，難傷於邪也；脾大，則苦湊䏚而痛，不能疾行。脾高，則䏚引季脅而痛；脾下則下歸於大腸，下加於大腸，則藏苦受邪。脾堅，則藏安難傷；脾脆，則善病消痺易傷。脾端正，則和利難傷；脾偏傾，則善滿善脹也。 When the spleen is small, it hides securely and is difficult to harm by evil; when the spleen is large, it causes great distress and pain, unable to move quickly. When the spleen is high, it refers to the ribs and causes pain; when the spleen is low, it returns to the large intestine, adding to the large intestine, causing the organs to suffer from evil qi. The spleen is firm, then it hides securely and is difficult to harm; the spleen is fragile, then it excels at treating diseases, easing paralysis, and being easily harmed. When the spleen is upright and correct, then it is easy to avoid harm; when the spleen inclines to one side, then it excels at fullness and bloating.

7: 腎小，則藏安難傷；腎大，則善病腰痛，不可以俛仰，易傷以邪。腎高，則苦背膂痛，不可以俛仰；腎下則腰尻痛，不可以俛仰，為狐疝。腎堅，則不病腰背痛；腎脆，則善病消癉，易傷。腎端正，則和利難傷；腎偏傾，則苦腰尻痛也。凡此二十五變者，人之所苦常病。 If the liver is small, it is difficult to keep safe and prone to injury; if the liver is enlarged, one is good at treating diseases of the waist, but cannot bend over, and is prone to injury from evil. If the liver is high, there will be painful spasms in the back, one cannot bend over, and it is easy to be injured by evil spirits. If the liver is low, there will be pain in the waist and tailbone, one cannot bend over, and it leads to sciatica. If the liver is hard, one does not get sick with lower back pain; if the liver is brittle, one is good at treating diseases of sweating and is prone to injury. If the liver is well-positioned, it is difficult to be injured; if the liver is tilted, one will suffer from painful waist and tailbone. All these twenty-five transformations are the common ailments that people often experience

8: 黃帝曰：何以知其然也？歧伯曰：赤色小理者，心小；麤理者，心大。無𩩲𩨗者，心高；𩩲𩨗小、短、舉者，心下。𩩲𩨗長者，心下堅；𩩲𩨗弱小以薄者，心脆。𩩲𩨗直下不舉者，心端正；𩩲𩨗倚一方者，心偏傾也。 Yellow Emperor said, How do we know that it is so? Duke of Zhou replied, In the case of someone who has a small amount of red coloring, their heart is small. In the case of someone with a large amount of yellow coloring, their heart is large. If they have no blue coloring at all, then their heart is high. For someone who has a little bit of blue coloring, it's shallow. For someone who has long and deep blue coloring, their heart is low and firm. If the blue coloring is weak and small, their heart is fragile. If they have no blue coloring at all but only straight down without lifting it, then their heart is upright and orderly. If they lean on one side, then their heart is inclined.

9: 白色小理者，肺小；麤理者，肺大。巨肩反膺陷喉者，肺高；合腋張脅者，肺下。好肩背厚者，肺堅；肩背薄者，肺脆。背膺厚者，肺端正；脅偏疏者，肺偏傾也。 One who is small and white, the lungs are small; one with hair, the lungs are large. One with a protruding collarbone sinking into the throat, the lungs are high; one with shoulders drawn together and chest pressing inwards, the lungs are low. One with broad and thick shoulders, the lungs are firm; one with narrow and thin shoulders, the lungs are brittle. One with thick and fleshy waist, the lungs are well-centered; one with a shifted and dispersed breast, the lungs lean to one side.

10: 青色小理者，肝小；麤理者，肝大。廣胸反骹者，肝高；合脅兔骹者，肝下。胸脅好者，肝堅；脅骨弱者，肝脆。膺腹好相得者，肝端正；脅骨偏舉者，肝偏傾也。 The person who is slender and of a light complexion, the liver is small; the person with a stout build, the liver is large. The one with broad chest and hunched back, the liver is high; the one with merged heart and hunchback, the liver is low. The good-looking chest and backbone, the liver is firm; the weak backbone, the liver is brittle. The pairing of chest and backbone are harmonious, the liver is balanced; the backbone leaning to one side, the liver is tilted.

11: 黃色小理者，脾小；麤理者，脾大。揭唇者，脾高；唇下縱者，脾下。唇堅者，脾堅；唇大而不堅者，脾脆。唇上下好者，脾端正；唇偏舉者，脾偏傾也。 The person who has a yellow complexion, the spleen is weak; the person with thin hair, the spleen is enlarged. The person who licks their lips, the spleen is high; the person whose lower lip hangs down, the spleen is low. The person with rigid lips, the spleen is stiff; the person with swollen lips but not rigid, the spleen is brittle. The person with well-aligned lips and chin, the spleen is harmonious; the person whose lips are asymmetrical, the spleen is leaning to one side.

12: 黑色小理者，腎小；麤理者，腎大。高耳者，腎高；耳後陷者，腎下。耳堅者，腎堅；耳薄不堅者，腎脆。耳好前居牙車者，腎端正；耳偏高者，腎偏傾也。凡此諸變者，持則安，減則病也。 The black and small thinker has a small liver; the white and large thinker has a large liver. The high eared one has a high liver; the eared one with a sunken posterior has a low liver. The hard of hearing has a firm liver; the not hard of hearing has a brittle liver. The one who likes the front part of the ear and the tooth-comb has a well-ordered liver; the one whose ears are inclined to one side has a tilted liver. All these changes, if maintained, there will be security; if reduced, there will be disease.

13: 帝曰：善。然非余之所問也，願聞人之有不可病者，至盡天壽，雖有深擾大恐，怵惕之志，猶不能減也，甚寒大熱，不能傷也；其有不離屏蔽室內，又無怵惕之恐，然不免於病者，何也？願聞其故。歧伯曰：五藏六府，邪之舍也，請言其故。五藏皆小者，少病，苦憔心，大愁擾；五藏皆大者，緩於事，難使以擾。五藏皆高者，好高舉措；五藏皆下者，好出人下。五藏皆堅者，無病；五藏皆脆者，不離於病。五藏皆端正者，和利得人心；五藏皆偏傾者，邪心而善盜，不可以為人平，反復言語也。 Emperor: Good. But this is not what I asked about. I would like to hear about people who have no incurable diseases, reaching a long lifespan, even though they may experience deep anxiety and great fear, and their minds may still not be able to be reduced. They may feel cold or feverish, but cannot be hurt. Those who do not leave the confines of their rooms and do not experience such anxiety, what is the reason for them still getting sick? I would like to hear the cause. Duke Huan replied: The five organs and six palaces are where evil resides; please explain the cause. Each of the five organs is small, causing less illness but more anxiety in the heart, causing worry. Each of the five organs is large, making them more patient and difficult to disturb. Each of the five organs is high, enjoying elevated gestures; each of the five organs is low, enjoying humbling others. Each of the five organs is strong, without illness; each of the five organs is fragile, not leaving their sickness. Each of the five organs is upright and righteous, bringing harmony to people's hearts; each of the five organs is crooked, harboring evil intentions and being skilled at theft, cannot be made fair for others, and constantly speak words.

14: 黃帝曰：願聞六府之應。歧伯答曰：肺合大腸，大腸者，皮其應；心合小腸，小腸者，脈其應；肝合膽，膽者，筋其應；脾合胃，胃者，肉其應；腎合三焦膀胱，三焦膀胱者，腠理毫毛其應。 Yellow Emperor said: I wish to hear about the correspondence of the six ministries. Duke of Shao replied: The Lung combines with the large intestine, the large intestine being the organ of correspondence; the Heart combines with the small intestine, the small intestine being the organ of the pulse; the Liver combines with the gallbladder, the gallbladder being the organ of the tendons; the Spleen combines with the stomach, the stomach being the organ of the flesh; the Kidney combines with the three burners and bladder, the three burners and bladder being the organs of the channels, hair, and pores.

15: 黃帝曰：應之奈何？歧伯曰：肺應皮。皮厚者，大腸厚，皮薄者，大腸薄；皮緩，腹裏大者，大腸大而長；皮急者，大腸急而短；皮滑者，大腸直；皮肉不相離者，大腸結。 Yellow Emperor said: What should be done in such case? Duke of Shou replied: The lung corresponds to the skin. If the skin is thick, the large intestine is also thick; if the skin is thin, the large intestine is also thin. If the skin is relaxed and the abdomen is enlarged, the large intestine will be enlarged and long; if the skin is tense, the large intestine will be short and narrow; if the skin is slippery, the large intestine will be straight; if the skin and flesh do not separate from each other, the large intestine will form knots.

16: 心應脈，皮厚者，脈厚，脈厚者，小腸厚；皮薄者，脈薄，脈薄者，小腸薄；皮緩者，脈緩，脈緩者，小腸大而長；皮薄而脈沖小者，小腸小而短。諸陽經脈皆多紆屈者，小腸結。 The heart responds to the pulse; if the skin is thick, then the pulse is thick and those with a thick pulse have a thick small intestine. If the skin is thin, then the pulse is weak, and those with a weak pulse have a weak small intestine. If the skin is slack, then the pulse is slack and those with a slack pulse have an enlarged, elongated small intestine. If the skin is thin and the pulse is rebellious and small, then the small intestine is small and short. All of the yang channels' pulses tend to be tangled when there is a small intestine knot.

17: 脾應肉，肉䐃堅大者，胃厚；肉䐃么者，胃薄。肉䐃小而么者，胃不堅；肉膕不稱身者，胃下，胃下者，下管約不利。肉脾不堅者，胃緩；肉䐃無小裏累者，胃急。肉䐃多少裏累者，胃結，胃結者，上管約不利也。 The spleen acts on flesh, flesh that is hard and substantial makes the stomach thick; flesh that is tender makes the stomach thin. Flesh that is small and tender makes the stomach not firm; flesh that does not fill the body makes the stomach below, and the below of the stomach is not advantageous to the large intestine. The spleen without firmness makes the stomach mild; flesh without much internal accumulation makes the stomach hurry. Flesh with much internal accumulation makes the stomach form lumps, and the lumps of the stomach are not advantageous to the large intestine also.

18: 肝應爪，爪厚色黃者，膽厚；爪薄色紅者，膽薄；爪堅色青者，膽急；爪濡色赤者，膽緩；爪直色白無約者，膽直；爪惡色黑多紋者，膽結也。 The liver influences the nails. Those with thick, yellow-colored nails have a robust constitution. Those with thin, red-colored nails are frail. Those with hard, green-colored nails are anxious. Those with damp, red-colored nails are slow to act. Those with straight, white-colored nails without blemishes indicate a straightforward disposition. Those with evil-looking, black and multi-striped nails have accumulated pathogenic factors within the body

19: 腎應骨，密理厚皮者，三焦膀胱厚；麤理薄皮者，三焦膀胱薄。疏腠理者，三焦膀胱緩；皮急而無毫毛者，三焦膀胱急。毫毛美而麤者，三焦膀胱直，稀毫毛者，三焦膀胱結也。 The gallbladder, spleen, and stomach are all related to the pancreas. In cases where the tendons are strong and the mind is deep, the organs of the three burners and bladder are strong; in cases where the tendons are weak and the skin is thin, the organs of the three burners and bladder are weak. When the pores are open and the tendons are weak, the organs of the three burners and bladder become sluggish. When the skin is tight and there are no hairs, the organs of the three burners and bladder become urgent. Hairs that are beautiful and coarse indicate that the organs of the three burners and bladder are straight; hairs that are sparse indicate that the organs of the three burners and bladder are knotted.

20: 黃帝曰：厚薄美惡，皆有形，願聞其所病。歧伯答曰：視其外應，以知其內藏，則知所病矣。 Yellow Emperor said: Thick and thin are beautiful, and ugliness is also in form. I wish to hear the illness. Huzi (Huang Di's courtier) answered: By observing its outer manifestation, one can know its inner essence, thus knowing the illness.

docs.title: 禁服
docs.text:
