Zhangxi said: There is a great wind in the body, the blood vessels are weak, the weak parts lack sufficient and the strong parts have excess, light and heavy cannot be balanced, tilting to one side, unable to know east and west, unable to know south and north, constantly rising and falling, turning over and reversing, unstable, more confused than before. Yellow Emperor said: Good. How can it be taken? Zhangxi said: Write down its excesses and supplement its deficiencies, balance the yin and yang, and use acupuncture like this. It will be quick in resolving confusion. Yellow Emperor said: Good. Please keep it in the Spirits' Chamber, and dare not make a mistake.

7: 黃帝曰：余聞刺有五邪，何謂五邪？歧伯曰：病有持癰者，有容大者，有狹小者，有熱者，有寒者，是謂五邪。黃帝曰：刺五邪奈何？歧伯曰：凡刺五邪之方，不過五章，癉熱消滅，腫聚散亡，寒痺益溫，小者益陽；大者必去，請道其方。 Yellow Emperor said: I have heard that there are five evils in puncturing. What do you mean by the five evils? [The Master of the Gate of Virtue] said: There are those who have a persistent boil, those with a large swelling, those with a small swelling, those with fever, and those with cold. These are referred to as the five evils. Yellow Emperor asked: How should one deal with puncturing the five evils? [The Master of the Gate of Virtue] said: The method of puncturing the five evils does not exceed five chapters. For eliminating heat and dispelling, dispersing swellings and causing them to dissipate, warming up cold and stiffness, enlarging small ones, and reducing large ones while asking about their methods.

8: 凡刺癰邪，無迎隴，易俗移性。不得膿，脆道更行，去其鄉，不安處所乃散亡，諸陰陽過癰者，取之其輸寫之。 Anyone who is stabbed by a disease or evil will not be welcome. It is easy to become popular and change with the times. One cannot live without one's skin, and if one is forced to leave their homeland, they will eventually disperse and perish. Those who have too much yin and yang excesses should take medicine and record it.

9: 凡刺大邪，日以小，泄奪其有餘，乃益虛。剽其通，鍼其邪，肌肉親視之，毋有反其真，刺諸陽分肉間。 All acupuncture for treating major evil, should be done in small doses to prevent depletion. Once the qi is connected and the evil is pierced, observe the muscles closely, do not miss the true point, and puncture at the yang channel interstitial spaces.

10: 凡刺小邪，日以大，補其不足，乃無害。視其所在，迎之界，遠近盡至，其不得外侵而行之，乃自費，刺分肉間。 Regarding the acupuncture of minor evil qi, it gradually increases in size, supplements what is lacking, and becomes harmless. By observing its location, intercepting at the boundary, near or far without exception, it will not be allowed to invade externally, and will consume itself, piercing between the muscle layers.

11: 凡刺熱邪，越而蒼，出遊不歸，乃無病。為開通，辟門戶，使邪得出，病乃已。 All feverish ailments, if they are blue and the patient does not return home, will be cured. To open passages, clear doors and gates, allowing the evil to exit, the disease will have been resolved.

(In modern terms: All fevers that turn into a bluish color and the person does not recover quickly, will eventually subside. By treating the patient and opening up their body's pathways, the illness will improve.)

12: 凡刺寒邪，日以溫，徐往徐來，致其神。門戶已閉，氣不分，虛實得調，其氣存也。 Regarding the treatment of cold pathogenic factors: gradually warm it up day by day, proceed slowly and steadily until it is effective. By the time the door is closed (i.e., the condition has become chronic), the Qi has become stagnant and is not being dispersed; the Real and the False have been distinguished, and the pathogenic factor still remains

13: 黃帝曰：官鍼奈何？歧伯曰：刺癰者，用鈹鍼；刺大者，用鋒鍼；刺小者，用員利鍼；刺熱者，用纔鍼；刺寒者，用毫鍼也。 Yellow Emperor asked, What about the needles for officials? Huang Di replied, For piercing boils, use a needle with a hollow tip; for piercing large masses, use a needle with a sharp tip; for piercing small ones, use an acupuncture needle; for piercing those affected by heat, use a charred needle; and for piercing those affected by cold, use a fine needle.

14: 請言解論，與天地相應，與四時相副，人參天地，故可為解。下有漸洳，上生葦蒲，此所以知形氣之多少也。陰陽者，寒暑也，熱則滋雨而在上，根莖少汁，人氣在外，皮膚緩，腠理開，血氣減，汗大泄，皮淖澤。寒則地凍水冰，人氣在中，皮膚致，腠理閉，汗不出，血氣強，肉堅澀。當是之時，善行水者，不能往冰，善穿地者，不能擊凍，善用鍼者，亦不能取四厥，血脈凝結，堅搏不往來者，亦未可即柔。故行水者，必待天溫，冰釋凍解，而水可行，地可穿也。人脈猶是也。治厥者，必先熨調和其經，掌與腋，肘與腳，項與脊以調之，火氣已通，血脈乃行。然後視其病，脈淖澤者，刺而平之；堅緊者，破而散之，氣下乃止，此所謂以解結者也。 Please interpret and elucidate, corresponding with heaven and earth, and harmonizing with the four seasons, the human being is a manifestation of the solution. Below there is an incremental wash, above grows reeds and sedges, which is why we know the amount of form and qi. Yin and yang are cold and heat, warmth promotes growth and is located above, with fewer juices in roots and stems, the human being's qi is outside, the skin is supple, and the marrow opens, blood and qi decrease, sweating is excessive, skin is clammy. Cold causes the earth to freeze water into ice, the human being's qi is inside, the skin becomes tough, the marrow closes, sweating does not come out, blood and qi are strong, meat is hardened. At that time, those skilled in swimming cannot go to the ice, those skilled in walking cannot step on frozen ground, and those skilled in using needles cannot take the four extremities, blood vessels become congealed and rigid, and qi does not circulate freely. Therefore, those who walk on water must wait for the weather to warm up, for the ice to melt and thaw, so that water can flow and ground can be walked on. The human being is similar in this regard. To treat extremities, one must first regulate and harmonize their channels, holding at the wrist and elbow, at the ankle and knee, at the neck and spine, to harmonize them. Once fire qi has passed through, blood vessels will circulate. Then, depending on the illness, look at the pulse: clammy and flowing, one should use needles to disperse; tight and rigid, one should pierce and scatter, qi descending will settle, this is called resolving knots.

15: 用鍼之類，在於調氣，氣積於胃，以通營衛，各行其道。宗氣留於海，其下者，注于氣街，其上者，走於息道。故厥在於足，宗氣不下，脈中之血，凝而留止，弗之火調，弗能取之。 Using lancets of this type, regulate the qi, accumulate it in the stomach, and circulate it through the Wei channels to let each follow its own course. The original qi remains in the sea of energy, with the lower part proceeding along the qi street and the upper part traveling on the Xu channel. Therefore, the governance is located at the feet, the original qi does not descend, the blood in the vessels coagulates and stops, unable to warm or extract it.

16: 用鍼者，必先察其經絡之實虛，切而循之，按而彈之，視其應動者，乃後取之而下之。六經調者，謂之不病，雖病，謂之自已也。一經上實下虛而不通者，此必有橫絡盛加於大經，令之不通，視而寫之，此所謂解結也。 The physician who uses the lancet must first examine the truth of the patient's veins and arteries, cutting along them, pressing and probing them, observing their responses, and then extracting them. The skilled practitioner of the six canons calls this state not ill, while for those who are ill, he says it is what it is. When one meridian is full on top and empty below without communication, there must be excessive accumulation in the main meridian, leading to non-communication; observe and write this down as resolving knots.

17: 上寒下熱，先刺其項太陽，久留之，已刺則熨項與肩胛，令熱下合乃止，此所謂推而上之者也。上熱下寒，視其虛脈而陷之於經絡者，取之，氣下乃止，此所謂引而下之者也。 Above cold below heat, first pierce the back of the shoulder with the sun, and let it remain for a long time. After puncturing, press the shoulder and shoulder blades to disperse the heat, stopping when it reaches its destination. This is called pushing upwards. Above heat below cold, observe the empty pulse and sink it into the channels. Take it out, and the Qi will stop at the bottom. This is called pulling down.

Note: The original text seems to have some errors in terms of punctuation or phrasing. The translation provided above tries to convey the general meaning of the text but may not be completely accurate.

18: 大熱遍身，狂而妄見妄聞妄言，視足陽明及大絡取之，虛者補之，血而實者寫之。因其偃臥，居其頭前，以兩手四指挾按頸動脈，久持之，卷而切，推下至缺盆中，而復止如前，熱去乃止，此所謂推而散之者也。 Large heat covers the body, with madness and delusions of sight, hearing, and speech. By looking at the sole of the foot and pressing on the great vessels, filling in empty areas and writing on solid ones. Then laying it down, placing it in front of the head, using both hands to clasp and press the carotid artery, holding for a long time, then rolling, cutting, and pushing it back into the hollow, stopping again as before. The heat subsides when stopped, this is called pushing and dispersing.

19: 黃帝曰：有一脈生數十病者，或痛，或癰，或熱，或寒，或癢，或痺，或不仁，變化無窮，其故何也？歧伯曰：此皆邪氣之所生也。黃帝曰：余聞氣者，有真氣，有正氣，有邪氣。何謂真氣？歧伯曰：真氣者，所受於天，與穀氣并而充身也。正氣者，正風也，從一方來，非實風，又非虛風也。邪氣者，虛風之賊傷人也，其中人也深，不能自去。正風者，其中人也淺，合而自去，其氣來柔弱，不能勝真氣，故自去。 Yellow Emperor said: There is one pulse that has several tens of diseases, sometimes painful, sometimes swollen, sometimes feverish, sometimes cold, sometimes urinary issues, sometimes paralysis, and sometimes lacks tenderness. The manifestations are countless; what is the reason for this? The Duke of Zhou replied: All of these are due to pathogenic Qi. Yellow Emperor said: I have heard that Qi has true Qi, righteous Qi, and pathogenic Qi. What is true Qi? The Duke of Zhou replied: True Qi is what one receives from Heaven and blends with the grain Qi, nourishing the body. Righteous Qi is the correct breath that comes from one direction. It is not real or virtual wind; rather it is an energy that can be harmonized and leaves on its own accord. The energy in pathogenic Qi is a malicious harm to people, deeply rooted within them, and cannot leave by itself. Righteous Qi's energy is shallowly rooted within people, and when it is harmonized, it leaves on its own accord; its Qi is gentle and weak, unable to overcome true Qi, so it leaves.

20: 虛邪之中人也，洒晰動形，起毫毛而發腠理。其入深，內搏於骨，則為骨痺；搏於筋，則為筋攣；搏於脈中，則為血閉，不通則為癰。搏於肉，與衛氣相搏，陽勝者，則為熱，陰勝者，則為寒。寒則真氣去，去則虛，虛則寒搏於皮膚之間。其氣外發，腠理開，毫毛搖，氣往來行，則為痒。留而不去，則痺。衛氣不行，則為不仁。 A person with vacuity and evil in the interior has clear, distinct movements and hairs standing on end. If it goes deep into the bones, it is bone pain; if into the muscles, it is muscle tension; if into the blood vessels, it is blocked blood, and if not passing through, it becomes a swelling. Struggling with the flesh, it interferes with the defensive Qi, and if yang prevails, it results in heat, while if yin prevails, it results in cold. Cold causes true Qi to depart, which leads to vacuity, and vacuity allows cold to struggle between the skin and flesh. Its energy is manifested externally, with the hair standing on end, the pulse opening, and the Qi going back and forth, resulting in itching. If left untreated, it becomes pain. Blockage of defensive Qi results in lack of compassion.

21: 虛邪偏容於身半，其入深，內居榮衛，榮衛稍衰，則真氣去，邪氣獨留，發為偏枯。其邪氣淺者，脈偏痛。 The text describes a situation where an imbalance in the body's vital energy arises due to external pathogenic factors and inner deficiency. This condition starts shallowly affecting the body, particularly around the waist area, and as it progresses deeper, it impacts the honor guards (an internal organ system), which leads to the decline of genuine Qi and the presence of pathogenic Qi alone. In the latter stage, this results in a partial withering or imbalance of energy flow. When this condition is superficial, it manifests as pain in the pulse's offset or affected area

22: 虛邪之入于身也深，寒與熱相搏，久留而內著，寒勝其熱，則骨疼肉枯；熱勝其寒，則爛肉腐肌為膿，內傷骨，內傷骨為骨蝕。有所疾前筋，筋屈不得伸，邪氣居其間而不反，發為筋溜。有所結，氣歸之，衛氣留之，不得反，津液久留，合而為腸溜。久者，數歲乃成，以手按之柔，已有所結，氣歸之，津液留之，邪氣中之，凝結日以易甚，連以聚居，為昔瘤。以手按之堅，有所結，深中骨，氣因於骨，骨與氣并，日以益大，則為骨疽。有所結，中於肉，宗氣歸之，邪留而不去，有熱則化而為膿，無熱則為肉疽。凡此數氣者，其發無常處，而有常名也。 The pathology of the interior is profound, as cold and heat struggle within. Prolonged exposure leads to internal damage; cold prevailing over heat causes bones to ache and muscles to wither, while heat prevailing over cold results in muscles rotting and flesh decomposing into ulcers, damaging both bone and marrow; this ultimately leads to the bone being eaten away.

When there is an acute attack at the tendons, tendons become tense and unable to stretch. The pathogenic Qi occupies a middle position and does not disperse, resulting in tendon convulsions.

When there is a nodule or mass, Qi returns but does not disperse, and defensive Qi lingers without dispersing; bodily fluids accumulate, eventually forming an abscess. Prolonged over time, this can develop into a lump by the age of several years. When pressed with the hand, it is palpable as a nodule, Qi returns and fluid lingers, and pathogenic Qi congeals day by day, gradually massing and gathering to form a tumor.

When pressed with the hand and it feels hard, there is a nodule deep within the bone, Qi penetrates the bone, and bone and Qi coalesce, gradually increasing in size until it becomes a bone abscess. When there is a nodule within the flesh, vital Qi returns to it, pathogenic Qi lingers without dispersing, and if there is heat, it transforms into pus; if there is no heat, it becomes a flesh abscess. All such pathological conditions arise unpredictably but have constant names

docs.title: 衛氣行
docs.text:
1: 黃帝問於歧伯曰：願聞衛氣之行，出入之合，何如？歧伯曰：歲有十二月，日有十二辰，子午為經，卯酉為緯。天周二十八宿，而一面七星，四七二十八星。房昴為緯，虛張為經。是故房至畢為陽，昴至心為陰。陽主晝，陰主夜。故衛氣之行，一日一夜五十周於身，晝日行於陽二十五周，夜行於陰二十五周，周於五藏1。1. 藏 : 原作「歲」。 Yellow Emperor asked Guan Pu, I would like to hear about the movement of the guardian qi, and how its entering and exiting works. Guan Pu replied, There are twelve months in a year and twelve zodiac signs. The terms sui and xia form the meridians, and chen and wu form the equator. The sky is divided into twenty-eight lunar mansions, with one face of seven stars and forty-seven other stars. Kangcheng forms the meridian, and xuan zhang forms the terms. Therefore, when yang arrives at bai, it is yin at xin. Yang governs daytime, and yin governs nighttime. Thus, the movement of guardian qi in one day and one night spans fifty cycles. During the daytime, it travels twenty-five cycles along the yang meridian, and twenty-five cycles along the yin meridian during the nighttime. It completes fifty cycles within the five viscera.

2: 是故平旦陰盡，陽氣出於目，目張則氣上行於頭，循項下足太陽，循背下至小趾之端。其散者，別於目銳眥，下手太陽，下至手小指之間外側。其散者，別於目銳眥，下足少陽，注小趾次趾之間。以上循手少陽之分側，下至小指之間。別者以上至耳前，合於頷脈，注足陽明以下行，至跗上，入五趾之間。其散者，從耳下下手陽明，入大指之間，入掌中。其至於足也，入足心，出內踝，下行陰分，復合於目，故為一周。 Therefore, the yin energy is complete at dusk and the yang qi emerges from the eyes. When the eyes widen, the qi rises to the head, follows the governor vessel down to the great toe, follows the exceptional vessel down to the tip of the little toe. The dispersing qi separates from the acute radiance of the eyes and goes down the governor vessel to the side of the little finger's joint.

The dispersing qi separates from the acute radiance of the eyes and goes down the exceptional vessel, following the sinew channel of the small intestine to the interval between the first and second toes. In addition, it ascends to the ear lobe and merges with the chest vessel, following the foot yang linking vessel downward, reaching the ankle, entering the interval between the five toes.

The dispersing qi starts from the lower part of the ear, going down the yang linking vessel to the interval between the great toe and the palm. The qi arrives at the foot, enters the center of the foot and exits through the inner mound, descends along the yin linking vessel, returning to the eyes, thus forming a circle.

3: 是故日行一舍，人氣行一周與十分身之八；日行二舍，人氣行三周於身與十分身之六；日行三舍，人氣行於身五周與十分身之四；日行四舍，人氣行於身七周與十分身之二；日行五舍，人氣行於身九周；日行六舍，人氣行於身十周與十分身之八；日行七舍，人氣行於身十二周在身與十分身之六；日行十四舍，人氣二十五周於身有奇分與十分身之二，陽盡於陰，陰受氣矣。其始入于陰，常從足少陰注于腎，腎注于心，心注于肺，肺注于肝，肝注于脾，脾復注于腎為周。是故夜行一舍，人氣行於陰藏一周與十分藏之八，亦如陽行之二十五周，而復合於目。陰陽一日一夜，合有奇分十分身之四，與十分藏之二，是故人之所以臥起之時，有早晏者，奇分不盡故也。 Therefore, in daily life, one step equals one unit of qi within a person's body and eight units away from the body. Two steps equal three units within the body and six units away. Three steps equal five units within the body and four units away. Four steps equal seven units within the body and two units away. Five steps equal nine units within the body, and six steps equal ten units within the body and eight units away. Seven steps equal twelve units within the body and six units away. Fourteen steps equal twenty-five units within the body with a rare division and two units away, yin is complete in yang, and yin receives qi. It starts from yin and proceeds from the foot's yin minor yard to the kidney, the kidney to the heart, the heart to the lung, the lung to the liver, and the liver to the spleen, returning to the kidney to complete a cycle. Therefore, in nighttime, one step equals one unit of qi within the hidden storehouse and eight units away from the hidden storehouse, which is like twenty-five units of yang. They are united at the eyes. Yin and yang occur once day and once night, uniting with a rare division of ten units and two units away. Therefore, when people wake up or lie down, there are early and late times, and this is because the rare division is not complete.

4: 黃帝曰：衛氣之在於身也，上下往來不以期，候氣而刺之，奈何？伯高曰：分有多少，日有長短，春秋冬夏，各有分理，然後常以平旦為紀，以夜盡為始。是故一日一夜，水下百刻，二十五刻者，半日之度也，常如是毋已，日入而止，隨日之長短，各以為紀而刺之。謹候其時，病可與期，失時反候者，百病不治。故曰：刺實者，刺其來也，刺虛者，刺其去也。此言氣存亡之時，以候虛實而刺之，是故謹候氣之所在而刺之，是謂逢時。在於三陽，必候其氣在於陽而刺之，病在於三陰，必候其氣在陰分而刺之。 Yellow Emperor said: Qi resides in the body and comes and goes without restriction, waiting for the qi before needling. How should one proceed? Master Gao said: There are variations in terms of how much and how long. The seasons of spring, summer, autumn, and winter all have their own classifications. Therefore, one should always use the equinoxes as a reference, using the solstices as starting points. This is why one day equals one night, with 100 intervals in water, and 25 intervals being half a day. One should proceed accordingly without stopping, adjusting according to the length of the day, and using these as references for needling. Be careful and follow the timing precisely; illness can be anticipated by this method. If one misses the time or misjudges it, one hundred diseases cannot be cured. Thus, when needling in reality, one needs to needle according to the arrival of qi or its departure. This is discussing the time for treating life and death through waiting for the presence or absence of qi while needling. One must carefully wait for the location of qi and then needle accordingly, which means acting in accordance with the moment. One should needles at the Yang Meridian by awaiting the arrival of qi at Yang and needle it; if there is illness at the Yin Meridian, one should await the arrival of qi at Yin before needling.

5: 水下一刻，人氣在太陽；水下二刻，人氣在少陽；水下三刻，人氣在陽明；水下四刻，人氣在陰分。水下五刻，人氣在太陽；水下六刻，人氣在少陽；水下七刻，人氣在陽明；水下八刻，人氣在陰分。水下九刻，人氣在太陽；水下十刻，人氣在少陽；水下十一刻，人氣在陽明；水下十二刻，人氣在陰分。水下十三刻，人氣在太陽；水下十四刻，人氣在少陽；水下十五刻，人氣在陽明；水下十六刻，人氣在陰分。水下十七刻，人氣在太陽；水下十八刻，人氣在少陽；水下十九刻，人氣在陽明；水下二十刻，人氣在陰分。水下二十一刻，人氣在太陽；水下二十二刻，人氣在少陽；水下二十三刻，人氣在陽明；水下二十四刻，人氣在陰分。水下二十五刻，人氣在太陽，此半日之度也。從房至畢一十四舍水下五十刻，日行半度，回行一舍，水下三刻與七分刻之四。大要曰：常以日之加於宿上也，人氣在太陽，是故日行一舍，人氣行三陽行與陰分，常如是無已，天與地同紀，紛紛紛紛，終而復始，一日一夜水下百刻而盡矣。 At any given moment underwater, the Qi is at the Taiyi. At two beats, the Qi is at the Shaoyang; at three beats, the Qi is at the Yangming; at four beats, the Qi is at the Yin division. At five beats, the Qi is at Taiyi again; at six beats, the Qi is at Shaoyang; at seven beats, the Qi is at Yangming; at eight beats, the Qi is at Yin division. At nine beats, the Qi is at Taiyi again; at ten beats, the Qi is at Shaoyang; at eleven beats, the Qi is at Yangming; at twelve beats, the Qi is at Yin division. At thirteen beats, the Qi is at Taiyi again; at fourteen beats, the Qi is at Shaoyang; at fifteen beats, the Qi is at Yangming; at sixteen beats, the Qi is at Yin division. At seventeen beats, the Qi is at Taiyi again; at eighteen beats, the Qi is at Shaoyang; at nineteen beats, the Qi is at Yangming; at twenty beats, the Qi is at Yin division. At twenty-one beats, the Qi is at Taiyi again; at twenty-two beats, the Qi is at Shaoyang; at twenty-three beats, the Qi is at Yangming; at twenty-four beats, the Qi is at Yin division. At twenty-five beats, the Qi is at Taiyi again, and this marks the end of a half day.

From room to Fan, there are fourteen lodgings for water under fifty beats, with the sun traveling halfway and then returning one beat, water under three and seven divisions of beats. The main point is that by always adding the sun to the stars, the Qi at Taiyi, the day travels one beat, with the Qi moving through Yang and Yin divisions constantly like this without end. Heaven and Earth record it simultaneously, interweaving and intertwining ceaselessly until they return to their beginning, completing a day and a night underwater with 100 beats.

docs.title: 九宮八風
docs.text:
1: 大1一常以冬至之日，居葉蟄之宮四十六日，明日居天留四十六日，明日居倉門四十六日，明日居陰洛四十五日，明日居天宮四十六日，明日居玄委四十六日，明日居倉果四十六日，明日居新洛四十五日，明日復居葉蟄之宮，曰冬至矣。1. 大 : 或作「太」。《四庫全書》本作「太」。 Great One: It is customary to dwell in the Palace of Insects for sixteen days after the winter solstice. On the next day, dwell in the Palace of Clear and Radiant. On the next day, dwell in the Palace of Grain Stores. On the next day, dwell in the Palace of Yinuoluo. On the next day, dwell in the Palace of Heavenly Court. On the next day, dwell in the Palace of Mysterious Filiations. On the next day, dwell in the Palace of Granary. On the next day, dwell in the Palace of New Luo. On the next day, return to dwell in the Palace of Insects, saying Winter Solstice is today. 1. Great: May also be translated as Ta. The version in the Siku Quanshu reads Ta.

2: 太一日遊，以冬至之日，居葉蟄之宮，數所在日，從一處至九日，復返於一。常如是無已，終而復始。 On the first day, I travel. On the winter solstice day, I reside in the Palace of Leaf Flying insects. On the day when it occurs, starting from one place and lasting for nine days, returning again to one. It is always so with no end, ultimately returning to the beginning.

3: 太一移日，天必應之以風雨，以其日風雨則吉，歲美民安少病矣。先之則多雨，後之則多汗。太一在冬至之日有變，占在君；太一在春分之日有變，占在相；太一在中宮之日有變，占在吏；太一在秋分之日有變，占在將；太一在夏至之日有變，占在百姓。所謂有變者，太一居五宮之日，病風折樹木，揚沙石，各以其所主，占貴賤。因視風所從來而占之，風從其所居之鄉來為實風，主生，長養萬物；從其沖後來為虛風，傷人者也，主殺，主害者。謹候虛風而避之，故聖人日避虛邪之道，如避矢石然，邪弗能害，此之謂也。 When the Great One moves to another day, heaven will respond with wind and rain according to its day, so that when there is wind and rain, it is auspicious; there will be good weather, and people will have few diseases. If it comes beforehand, there will be much rain; if it comes afterward, there will be much sweat. The Great One changes on the day of the winter solstice and is consulted for the ruler; the Great One changes on the day of the spring equinox and is consulted for the minister; the Great One changes on the day of the middle palace and is consulted for the official; the Great One changes on the day of the autumn equinox and is consulted for the general; the Great One changes on the day of the summer solstice and is consulted for the common people. What is called a change refers to the days when the Great One dwells in the five palaces, causing illness, withering trees, raising sand and stones, each according to what they govern. By observing the direction from which the wind comes, one can determine whether it is real or virtual wind. If it comes from where it resides, it is a true wind, nurturing life and growing countless things; if it comes from its rear, it is a virtual wind that harms people, governing killing and harm. Being cautious of the virtual wind and avoiding it, the sage person avoids the evil path, like avoiding arrows in flight, so that evil cannot hurt, and this is what they mean by it.

4: 是故太一入徙立於中宮，乃朝八風，以占吉凶也。風從南方來，名曰大弱風，其傷人也，內舍於心，外在於脈，氣主熱。風從西南方來，名曰謀風，其傷人也，內舍於脾，外在於肌，其氣主為弱。風從西方來，名曰剛風，其傷人也，內舍於肺，外在於皮膚，其氣主為燥。風從西北方來，名曰折風，其傷人也，內舍於小腸，外在於手太陽脈，脈絕則溢，脈閉則結不通，善暴死。風從北方來，名曰大剛風，其傷人也，內舍於腎，外在於骨與肩背之膂筋，其氣主為寒也。風從東北方來，名曰凶風，其傷人也，內舍於大腸，外在於兩脅腋骨下及肢節。風從東方來，名曰嬰兀風，其傷人也，內舍於肝，外在於筋紐，其氣主為身濕。風從東南方來，名曰弱風，其傷人也，內舍於胃，外在肌肉，其氣主體重。此八風皆從其虛之鄉來，乃能病人。三虛相搏，則為暴病卒死。兩實一虛，病則為淋露寒熱。犯其兩濕之地，則為痿。故聖人避風，如避矢石焉。其有三虛而偏中於邪風，則為仆偏枯矣。 Therefore, the Great Ultimate enters and stands in the Middle Palace, representing the Eight Trigrams and used for divination of auspiciousness. The wind coming from the south is called the Great Yin Wind, which harms people, dwelling internally in the heart and externally in the pulse, governing heat. The wind coming from the southwest is called the Willow Wind, which harms people, dwelling internally in the spleen and externally in the muscles, governing weakness. The wind coming from the west is called the Rigid Wind, which harms people, dwelling internally in the lungs and externally in the skin, governing dryness. The wind coming from the northwest is called the Twisting Wind, which harms people, dwelling internally in the small intestine and externally in the hand yang channel, with the pulse blocked it causes drowning, and with the pulse closed it causes blockage and obstruction leading to a sudden death. The wind coming from the north is called the Great Rigid Wind, which harms people, dwelling internally in the kidneys and externally in the bones and shoulder blade tendons, governing coldness. The wind coming from the northeast is called the Disaster Wind, which harms people, dwelling internally in the large intestine and externally at the lower part of the pectoral girdle joints and limb joints. The wind coming from the east is called the Newborn Wind, which harms people, dwelling internally in the liver and externally in the tendons, governing bodily moisture. The wind coming from the southeast is called the Weak Wind, which harms people, dwelling internally in the stomach and externally in the muscles, governing corporeality. These Eight Winds all come from their deficiency regions and can harm people. When the three deficiencies struggle, it results in a violent fatal illness. When there are two realities and one deficiency, the person becomes ill with sweating and fever. If they offend the two moist areas, it leads to paralysis. Therefore, the sage avoids the wind as if avoiding arrows or rocks. If there are three deficiencies focusing on the evil wind, then the limbs become withered.

docs.title: 九鍼論
docs.text:
1: 黃帝曰：余聞九鍼於夫子，眾多博大矣，余猶不能寤，敢問九鍼焉生，何因而有名？歧伯曰：九鍼者，天地之大數也，始於一而終於九。故曰：一以法天，二以法地，三以法人，四以法時，五以法音，六以法律，七以法星，八以法風，九以法野。 Yellow Emperor said: I have heard that there are nine needles from Confucius, and they are numerous and profound. However, I still cannot sleep peacefully. I dare to ask how the nine needles came into being and why it has such a reputation? Hui Bao replied: The nine needles refer to the great number of heaven and earth, starting from one and ending at nine. Therefore, one is for the law of heaven, two is for the law of earth, three is for the law of man, four is for the law of time, five is for the law of sound, six is for the law of law, seven is for the law of stars, eight is for the law of wind, and nine is for the law of wilderness.

2: 黃帝曰：以鍼應九之數，奈何？歧伯曰：夫聖人之起天地之數也，一而九之，故以立九野。九而九之，九九八十一，以起黃鍾數焉，以鍼應數也。 Yellow Emperor said: According to the divination of the nine numbers, what do you think? Duke of Zhou said: The sacred person originated from the number of heaven and earth. One is the foundation of nine, so he established the Nine Numbers. Nine again by nine, resulting in 9981, starting the Yellow Bell numerology, which is the divination of the yarrow stalks

3: 一者，天也。天者，陽也。五藏之應天者肺，肺者，五藏六府之蓋也，皮者，肺之合也，人之陽也。故為之治鍼，必以大其頭而銳其末，令無得深入而陽氣出。 First, there is Heaven. Heaven refers to the Yang. The five organs correspond to Heaven, and the lung corresponds to the five organs and six departments. The skin is the gathering of the lung, representing the Yang of a person. Therefore, when treating acupuncture, it must be done by making the head larger and sharpening the end, so that there is no way for it to penetrate deep and let the Yang Qi out.

4: 二者，地也。人之所以應土者，肉也。故為之治鍼，必筩其身而員其末，令無得傷肉分，傷則氣得竭。 Both are earth. The reason people submit to the earth is their flesh. Therefore, when treating acupuncture needles, one must elevate their body and insert at the end, ensuring that there is no harm to the flesh. If there is damage, then qi will be exhausted.

5: 三者，人也。人之所以成生者，血脈也。故為之治鍼，必大其身而員其末，令可以按脈物陷，以致其氣，令邪氣獨出。 The three, one is man. Man's achievement of life comes from blood vessels. Therefore, in treating acupuncture, one must expand the body and fill the extremities, allowing the needles to press on the vessels to raise the Qi, driving out evil Qi.

6: 四者，時也。時者，四時八風之客於經絡之中，為瘤病者也。故為之治鍼，必筩其身而鋒其末，令可以寫熱出血，而痼病竭。 Among the four, it is time. Time refers to the four times and eight winds as guests in the channels, being patients with nodules. Therefore, when treating them with acupuncture needles, one must stand their bodies upright and sharpen their tips, allowing them to dispel heat and bleeding, so that the disease will be completely cured.

7: 五者，音也。音者，冬夏之分，分於子午，陰與陽別，寒與熱爭，兩氣相搏，合為癰膿者也。故為之治鍼，必令其末如劍鋒，可以取大膿。 Five [constellations], [representing] sound. The sound is the division between winter and summer, divided into zi and mwu, with yin and yang being distinct, cold and heat competing, two energies fighting against each other, culminating in a boil or abscess. Therefore, for the treatment of such conditions, one must make sure that the needle's tip is as sharp as a knife, so that it can drain the abscess.

8: 六者，律也。律者，調陰陽四時而合十二經脈，虛邪客於經絡而為暴痺者也。故為之治鍼，必令尖如釐，且員其銳，中身微大，以取暴氣。 Six of them are related to the (Chinese) system. The system refers to balancing yin and yang at the four times, resulting in twelve channels/meridians. In cases where pathogenic factors invade and disturb the channels/meridians, causing pain or paralysis, acupuncture treatment is necessary. Needles should be fine and sharp like a needle, and should target the affected areas precisely to remove the blocked energy.

9: 七者，星也。星者，人之七竅，邪之所客於經，而為痛痺，合於經絡者也。故為之治鍼，令尖如蚊虻喙，靜以徐往，微以久留，正氣因之，真邪俱往，出鍼而養者也。 Seven [points] are stars. Stars refer to the seven orifices of humans, where evil resides according to the classics, and causes pain and paralysis, merging with the channels. Therefore, treatment involves acupuncture, with needles pointed like a mosquito's proboscis, slowly advancing and staying for a long time, regulating Qi through it, differentiating between true and false, and cultivating after removing the needle.

10: 八者，風也。風者，人之股肱八節也。八正之虛風，八風傷人，內舍於骨解腰脊節腠理之間為深痺也。故為之治鍼，必長其身，鋒其末，可以取深邪遠痺。 Eight [points] are the wind. The wind is the eight channels of the knee and elbow. When the channels of the Eight Points are deficient, the wind harms people, causing deep pain in the muscles, tendons, and joints between the lumbar vertebrae. Therefore, for this treatment, one must pierce with an acupuncture needle, lengthen the needle, and sharpen its tip to remove deep pathogenic factors and heal the distant pain.

11: 九者，野也。野者，人之節解皮膚之間也。淫邪流溢於身，如風水之狀，而留不能過於機關大節者也。故為之治鍼，令尖如挺，其鋒微員，以取大氣之不能過於關節者也。 Nine, it means wild. Wild refers to the spaces between the joints of a person's bones and skin. Lewd and evil qi overflow the body, similar to the state of wind and water. They cannot be overcome by the larger joints. Therefore, acupuncture is used to treat them, making the needles sharp like spears, with tiny tips to target the areas where the qi cannot overcome the joints.

12: 黃帝曰：鍼之長短有數乎？歧伯曰：一曰鐵鍼者，取法於巾鍼，去末寸半，卒銳之，長一寸六分，主熱在頭身也。二曰員鍼，取法於絮鍼，筩其身而卵其鋒，長一寸六分，主治分間氣。三曰鍉鍼，取法於黍粟之銳，長三寸半，主按脈取氣，令邪出。四曰鋒鍼，取法於絮鍼，筩其身，鋒其末，長一寸六分，主癰熱出血。五曰鈹鍼，取法於劍鋒，廣二分半，長四寸，主大癰膿，兩熱爭者也。六曰員利鍼，取法於釐鍼，微大其末，反小其身，令可深內也，長一寸六分。主取癰痺者也。七曰毫鍼，取注于毫毛，長一寸六分，主寒熱痛痺在絡者也。八曰長鍼，取法於綦鍼，長七寸，主取深邪遠痺者也。九曰大鍼，取法於鋒鍼，其鋒微員，長四寸，主取大氣不出關節者也。鍼形畢矣，此九鍼大小長短法也。 Yellow Emperor said: Is there a standard for the length of acupuncture needles? Qi Bo replied: One, iron needle, patterned after the arrow, shorten by half an inch and sharpen it, with a length of one inch and six divisions, used to treat head and body heat. Two, moxa needle, patterned after the thistle needle, cover its body and place its tip on the acupoint, with a length of one inch and six divisions, used for treating between the joints qi. Three, hook needle, patterned after the sharp end of millet or wheat, with a length of three and a half inches, used for pressing the pulse and exhaling evil, expelling it. Four, knife-edge needle, patterned after the thistle needle, cover its body and sharpen its tip, with a length of one inch and six divisions, used for treating heat rash and bleeding. Five, chisel needle, patterned after the knife, with a broad tip of two and a half divisions, with a length of four inches, used for treating large heat boils and abscesses, for yin and yang contending. Six, moxa-assisted needle, patterned after the cautery needle, refine its tip and reduce its body size, making it suitable for deep insertion, with a length of one inch and six divisions, used for treating heat rash stiffness and pain. Seven, hair follicle needle, patterned after the hair follicles, with a length of one inch and six divisions, used to treat cold, heat, pain, and numbness in tendons. Eight, long needle, patterned after the silk needle, with a length of seven inches, used for treating deep evil and distant stiffness and pain. Nine, large needle, patterned after the knife-edge needle, with its tip slightly smaller, with a length of four inches, used to treat blocked qi not coming out at the joints. The forms of needles are now complete, and this is the standard for the nine types of long and short needles.

13: 黃帝曰：願聞身形，應九野，奈何？歧伯曰：請言身形之應九野也，左足應立春，其日戊寅己丑。左脅應春分，其日乙卯。左手應立夏，其日戊辰己巳。膺喉首頭應夏至，其日丙午。右手應立秋，其中戊申己末。右脅應秋分，其日辛酉。右足應立冬，其日戊戌己亥。腰尻下竅應冬至，其日壬子。六府膈下三藏應中州，其大禁，大禁太一所在之日，及諸戊己。凡此九者，善候八正所在之處。所主左右上下身體有癰腫者，欲治之，無以其所直之日潰治之，是謂天忌日也。 Yellow Emperor said: I wish to hear about the auspiciousness of the body, according to what nine situations? Huan Bo said: Please explain the auspiciousness of the body according to the nine situations. The left foot corresponds to the beginning of spring (Wood), on the day of Wuxu and Jinchen. The left elbow corresponds to the Vernal Equinox (Water), on the day of Bingchen. The left hand corresponds to summer (Fire), on the day of Wudou and Gengzi. The breast, throat, and head correspond to the summer solstice (Earth), on the day of Renren. The right hand corresponds to autumn (Metal), in the middle of the month, on the day of Xinchou. The right elbow corresponds to the Autumn Equinox (Water), on the day of Jichou. The right foot corresponds to winter (Water), on the day of Wuxu and Jixu. The lower back corresponds to the winter solstice (Fire), on the day of Rishen. All six palaces and three storage areas correspond to the Central Plains, with the main capital being where the Grand Taboo is located on days governed by Yin and Yang. These nine positions are all places of good timing for the Eight Positives. The person in charge of these left, right, up, and down parts of the body who has bumps or swellings wishes to treat them, but there is no day to directly cure them; this is called the heavenly prohibition day.

14: 形東志苦，病生於脈，治之於灸刺。形苦志東，病生於筋，治之以熨引。形東志東，病生於肉，治之以鍼石。形苦志苦，病生於咽喝，治之以甘藥。形數惊恐，筋脈不通，病生於不仁，治之以按摩謬藥。是謂形。 The text discusses the treatment of various conditions based on the patient's symptoms.

  1. If there is form (脈) pain and the symptom points to the east (形東志苦，病生於脈，治之於灸刺), it indicates a condition that causes discomfort in the form (脈) and manifests in the east. Treatment involves acupuncture and moxibustion.
  2. If there is form pain with eastward pointing (形苦志東，病生於筋，治之以熨引), it indicates a condition that causes discomfort in the form and manifests in the east, affecting the tendons. Treatment involves steaming and pulling.
  3. If there is eastward pain and eastward pointing (形東志東，病生於肉，治之以鍼石), it indicates a condition that causes discomfort in the form and manifests in the east, affecting the flesh. Treatment involves puncturing with needles or stones.
  4. If there is form (脈) pain and bitterness (形苦志苦，病生於咽喝，治之以甘藥), it indicates a condition that causes discomfort in the form and manifests as bitterness affecting the throat. Treatment involves administering sweet medicine.
  5. If there is numbers (筋) pain and shock/fear (形數惊恐，筋脈不通，病生於不仁，治之以按摩謬藥), it indicates a condition that causes discomfort in the tendons and blood vessels, leading to numbness and fear. Treatment involves massage and herbal medication.

15: 五藏氣，心主噫，肺主咳，肝主語，脾主吞，腎主欠。 Five Organs govern Qi, the heart governs the tongue, the lungs govern coughing, the liver governs speech, the spleen governs swallowing, and the kidneys govern deficiency.

16: 六府氣，膽為怒，胃為氣逆穢，大腸小腸為泄，膀胱不約為遺溺，下焦溢為水。 The six departments [organs] of Qi, courage becomes anger, the stomach becomes Qi stagnation and foulness, the large intestine and small intestine become discharge, the bladder does not bind for leakage, lower abdomen overflowing as water.

17: 五味：酸入肝，辛入肺，苦入心，甘入脾，鹹入腎，淡入胃，是謂五味。 Five Flavors: Sour enters the liver, bitter enters the heart, sweet enters the spleen, salty enters the kidneys, and bland enters the stomach.

18: 五并：精氣并肝則憂，并心則喜，并肺則悲，并腎則恐，并脾則畏，是謂五精之氣，并於藏也。 The Five Congruences: When the vital energy gathers in the liver, it causes sadness; when it gathers in the heart, it brings joy; when it gathers in the lungs, it causes sorrow; when it gathers in the kidneys, it induces fear; and when it gathers in the spleen, it provokes awe. These are the five types of vital energy that gather within the storehouse (of organs).

19: 五惡：肝惡風，心惡熱，肺惡寒，腎惡燥，脾惡濕，此五藏氣所惡也。 Evil Five: Liver Evil Wind, Heart Evil Heat, Lung Evil Cold, Kidney Evil Dryness, Spleen Evil Dampness. These are the evils affecting the Five Organs' Qi.

20: 五液：心主汗，肝主泣，肺主涕，腎主唾，脾主液，此五液所出也。 The Five Fluids: The heart governs sweat, the liver governs tears, the lung governs mucus, the kidney governs saliva, and the spleen governs fluid. These five fluids all emerge from these respective organs.

21: 五勞：久視傷血，久臥傷氣，久坐傷肉，久立傷骨，久行傷筋，此五久勞所病也。 Five labors: long-term visual strain causes blood damage, long-term lying down causes qi damage, long-term sitting causes muscle damage, long-term standing causes bone damage, and long-term walking causes tendon damage. These are the diseases caused by the five long-term labors.

22: 五走：酸走筋，辛走氣，苦走血，鹹走骨，甘走肉，是謂五走也。 Five Transformations: Sour transforms the channels, bitter transforms the Qi, pungent transforms the blood, salty transforms the bones, sweet transforms the flesh. These are the Five Transformations.

23: 五裁：病在筋，無食酸；病在氣，無食辛；病在骨，無食鹹；病在血，無食苦；病在肉，無食甘。口嗜而欲食之，不可多也，必自裁也，命曰五裁。 Five Cuts: The illness is in the tendons, so do not eat sour; the illness is in the Qi, so do not eat pungent; the illness is in the bones, so do not eat salty; the illness is in the blood, so do not eat bitter; the illness is in the flesh, so do not eat sweet. If one craves and wants to eat it, it cannot be allowed, and one must cut it off oneself. The name for this is Five Cuts.

24: 五發：陰病發於骨，陽病發於血，陰病發於肉，陽病發於冬，陰病發於夏。 Five texts: Yin diseases arise from the bones, Yang diseases arise from blood, Yin diseases arise in summer, Yang diseases arise in winter.

25: 五邪：邪入于陽，則為狂；邪入于陰，則為血痺；邪入于陽，轉則為癲疾；邪入于陰，轉則為瘖；陽入之於陰，病靜；陰出之於陽，病喜怒。 Five Evils: Evil enters the Yang, resulting in madness; evil enters the Yin, resulting in blood stagnation. Evil entering the Yang and transforming results in deaf-mutism; evil entering the Yin and transforming results in numbness. When Yang enters the Yin, the disease is quiet; when Yin exits the Yang, the disease is characterized by anger and resentment.

26: 五藏：心藏神，肺藏魄，肝藏魂，脾藏意，腎藏精志也。 Five Canons: The heart houses the spirit, the lungs house the etheric soul, the liver houses the soul, the spleen houses the mind, and the kidneys house the vital essence and willpower.

27: 五主：心主脈，肺主皮，肝主筋，脾主肌，腎主骨。 Five Organs: Heart governs the vessels, Lungs govern the skin, Liver governs the tendons, Spleen governs the muscles, Kidneys govern the bones.

28: 陽明多血多氣，太陽多血少氣，少陽多氣少血，太陰多血少氣，厥陰多血少氣，少陰多氣少血。故曰刺陽明出血氣，刺太陽出血惡氣，刺少陽出氣惡血，刺太陰出血惡氣，刺厥陰出血惡氣，刺少陰出氣惡血也。 Yang Ming has more blood and qi, Taiyang has more blood and less qi, Shaoyang has less qi and more blood, Taiyin has more blood and less qi, Baiyin has more blood and less qi, Shaoyin has less qi and more blood. Therefore it is said that by needling Yangming, one can expel blood and qi; by needling Taiyang, one can expel bad qi; by needling Shaoyang, one can expel qi and bad blood; by needling Taiyin, one can expel blood and bad qi; by needling Baiyin, one can expel blood and bad qi; by needling Shaoyin, one can expel qi and bad blood.

Note: This text is describing the theory of acupuncture according to traditional Chinese medicine, where different channels (or meridians) are associated with different qualities of energy flow in the body.

29: 足陽明太陰為裏表，少陽厥陰為表裏，太陽少陰為表裏，是謂足之陰陽也。手陽明太陰為表裏，少陽心主為表裏，太陽少陰為表裏，是謂手之陰陽也。 The text describes the Yin and Yang of the foot and hand in classical Chinese medicine. For the foot: - Sufficient Yang and Deficient Yin are internal/external, - Insufficient Yang and Deficient Yin are external/internal, - Excessive Yang and Insufficient Yin are internal/external. This is the Yin and Yang of the foot. For the hand: - Sufficient Yang and Deficient Yin are internal/external, - Insufficient Yang and Deficient Yin are external/internal, - Excessive Yang and Insufficient Yin are internal/external. This is the Yin and Yang of the hand.

docs.title: 玉版論要
docs.text:
1: 黃帝問曰：余聞揆度奇恒，所指不同，用之柰何。歧伯對曰：揆度者，度病之淺深也。奇恒者，言奇病也。請言道之至數，五色脈變，揆度奇恒，道在於一。神轉不回，回則不轉，乃失其機，至數之要，迫近以微，著之玉版，命曰合玉機。 Emperor Yellow asked, I have heard of the method of measuring the shallow or deep and distinguishing between ordinary and extraordinary diseases. How can it be used? The Duke replied, The method of measuring is for measuring the shallow or deep degree of illness, and distinguishing between ordinary and extraordinary diseases. When asking about the number, if the five colors of the pulse vary, the method of measuring and distinguishing applies. The spirit may not return or turn back and will lose its function. The essence of reaching the limit lies in approaching it subtly, engraving it onto the jade mold, which is called the Meeting of the Jade Function.

2: 容色見上下左右，各在其要。其色見淺者，湯液主治，十日已。其見深者，必齊主治，二十一日己。其見大深者，醪酒主治，百日已。色夭面脫，不治，百日盡已。脈短氣絕死，病溫虛甚死。色見上下左右，各在其要。上為逆，下為從。女子右為逆，左為從；男子左為逆，右為從。易重陽死，重陰死。 One sees the color above, below, left and right, each in its place. If one sees a light color, use hot soup as treatment and it will be cured in ten days. If one sees a deep color, it must be treated by Qu, taking twenty-one days. If one sees a very deep color, treat with fermented milk, taking a hundred days. When the color becomes rotten and peels off, it cannot be cured, after a hundred days. Pulse is short and breath is cut off, leading to death. The color above, below, left and right, each in its place. Above refers to rebellion, below refers to obedience. For females, the right refers to rebellion and the left refers to obedience; for males, the left refers to rebellion and the right refers to obedience. Easy Rebellion leads to death, Easy Yin leads to death.

3: 陰陽反他，治在權衡相奪，奇恒事也，揆度事也。搏脈痺躄，寒熱之交。脈孤為消氣，虛泄為奪血。孤為逆，虛為從。行奇恒之法，以太陰始。行所不勝曰逆，逆則死；行所勝曰從，從則活。八風四時之勝，終而復始，逆行一過，不復可數，論要畢矣。 Yin and Yang mutually oppose each other, with balance residing in their counteraction. This is a constant principle and a measure of degrees. Pulse palpitations are weak and irregular, characterized by the interplay of cold and heat. A solitary pulse indicates deficient Qi, while an empty pulse indicates bleeding. Solitariness represents reversal, and emptiness signifies following. By practicing the principles of constancy and odd-even, one can begin with the Lesser Yin. Acting contrary to what is beneficial is referred to as reversal, which leads to death; acting in accordance with what is advantageous is called following, which ensures life. The victories of the eight winds and the four seasons exemplify the cyclical nature of things. Once a cycle is completed, it starts anew. If one deviates from this pattern even once, it cannot be counted, and discussions on this subject are at an end.

docs.title: 歲露論
docs.text:
1: 黃帝問於歧伯曰：經言夏日傷暑，秋病瘧，瘧之發以時，其故何也？歧伯對曰：邪客於風府，病循膂而下，衛氣一日一夜，常大會於風府，其明日日下一節，故其日作晏，此其先客於脊背也。故每至於風府則腠理開，腠理開則邪氣入，邪氣入則病作，此所以日作尚晏也。衛氣之行風府，日下一節，二十一日下至尾底，二十二日入脊內，注于伏沖之脈，其行九日，出於缺盆之中，其氣上行，故其病稍益至。其內搏於五藏，橫連募原，其道遠，其氣深，其行遲，不能日作，故次日乃蓄積而作焉。 The Yellow Emperor asked Yu Qi: According to the classics, what is the cause of summer heat exhaustion and autumn illness? Yu Qi replied: Evil qi resides in the lung palace, and the illness descends following a persistent fever. The guardian qi disperses day and night, constantly gathering at the lung palace, and when it reaches the next degree, the day is made stagnant. This indicates that the evil qi has first lodged in the lumbar region. Whenever it arrives at the lung palace, the network vessels open up, allowing evil qi to enter. As a result, the illness worsens, which explains why the day becomes more stagnant. The guardian qi moves within the lung palace, reaching the next degree after 21 days and entering the lumbar region on the 22nd day, merging with the Chong Mai, and its energy ascends for nine days, exiting from the Ren Mai. Thus, the illness worsens further. The energy then accumulates within the five organs, spreading horizontally across the source field, but its path is distant, its qi is deep, its movement is slow, and it cannot become stagnant on a daily basis. Consequently, the following day, it collects itself before manifesting as an illness.

2: 黃帝曰：衛氣每至於風府，腠理乃發，發則邪入焉。其衛氣日下一節，則不當風府，奈何？歧伯曰：風府無常，衛氣之所應，必開其腠理，氣之所舍節，則其府也。 Yellow Emperor said: When the vital energy reaches the palace of the lungs, the orifices of the brain will open, and if they open, evil will enter. If the vital energy is deficient after a day, should it not reach the palace of the lungs? The Duke of Chou replied: The palace of the lungs is not always open; where the vital energy should be received, one must open the orifices of the brain and where the vital energy leaves its station, that is the palace.

3: 黃帝曰：善。夫風之與瘧也，相與同類，而風常在，而瘧特以時休，何也？歧伯曰：風氣留其處，瘧氣隨經絡，沉以內搏，故衛氣應，乃作也。帝曰：善。 Emperor Yellow said: Good. The wind and plague are of the same category, yet the wind is always present while the plague rests at specific times. Why is this so? The Duke said: The wind energy stays in a place, whereas the plague energy follows the meridians and channels, sinking inside to struggle, thus causing the defensive energy to respond accordingly. This is why it happens. Emperor Yellow said: Good.

4: 黃帝問於少師曰：余聞四時八風之中人也，故有寒暑，寒則皮膚急而腠理閉；暑則皮膚緩而腠理開。賊風邪氣，因得以入乎？將必須八正虛邪，乃能傷人乎？少師答曰：不然。賊風邪氣之中人也，不得以時，然必因其開也，其入深，其內極病，其病人也，卒暴。因其閉也，其入淺以留，其病也，徐以遲。 Yellow Emperor asked Laozi, saying: I have heard that people who live in the four seasons and eight winds, so there are cold and heat. When it is cold, the skin becomes tense and the orifices close; when it is hot, the skin becomes slack and the orifices open. Can the thief wind pathogenic factor enter through this? Must the eight regular and empty pathogens be able to harm people? Laozi replied, Not so. The thief wind pathogenic factor is a person who lives in the four seasons and eight winds, not according to time, but must open it, it enters deep, its internal is extremely sick, sick people die suddenly. If it closes, it enters shallowly and stays, it becomes sick.

5: 黃帝曰：有寒溫和適，腠理不開，然有卒病者，其故何也？少師答曰：帝弗知邪入乎。雖平居其腠理開閉緩急，其故常有時也。黃帝曰：可得聞乎？少師曰：人與天地相參也，與日月相應也。故月滿則海水西盛，人血氣積，肌肉充，皮膚致，毛髮堅，腠理郗，煙垢著，當是之時，雖遇賊風，其入淺不深。至其月郭空，則海水東盛，人氣血虛，其衛氣去，形獨居，肌肉減，皮膚縱，腠理開，毛髮殘，膠理薄，煙垢落，當是之時，遇賊風則其入深，其病人也，卒暴。 Yellow Emperor said: There is cold, heat, and appropriate balance. The channels do not open, but there are those who contract illnesses; why does this happen? Minister of Health replied: Your Majesty does not know the evil entering [the body]. Even if one's channels maintain a balance between opening and closing, it can still occur at certain times. Yellow Emperor said: Is this understandable? Minister of Health said: Human beings correspond with heaven and earth, and respond to the sun and moon. Thus when the moon is full, sea water flows towards the west, causing human blood and Qi to accumulate, muscles to fill, skin to form, pores to appear, hair to strengthen, and vessels to close, dust and dirt adhere; this is a time when foreign pathogens do not easily penetrate deeply. When the lunar mansion empties, sea water flows towards the east, human Qi and blood are depleted, guardian Qi retreats, one's form stands alone, muscles weaken, skin wrinkles, channels open, hair becomes sparse, vessel strength diminishes, dust and dirt fall away; this is a time when foreign pathogens can easily penetrate deeply. In such cases, the illness becomes severe and could be fatal.

6: 黃帝曰：其有卒然暴死暴病者，何也？少師答曰：三虛者，其死暴疾也；得三實者邪不能傷人也。黃帝曰：願聞三虛。少師曰：乘年之衰，逢月之空，失時之和，因為賊風所傷，是謂三虛。故論不知三虛，工反為麤。帝曰：願聞三實。少師曰：逢年之盛，遇月之滿，得時之和，雖有賊風邪氣，不能危之也。黃帝曰：善乎哉論！明乎哉道！請藏之金匱，命曰三實。然，此一夫之論也。 Yellow Emperor asked, What about those who die suddenly or suffer from serious illness? What is the cause? The Master said, It is due to the three deficiencies. Those who die of sudden illness have all three deficiencies; those who are in possession of the three realities will not be harmed by evil qi. Yellow Emperor said, I would like to hear about the three deficiencies. The Master said, Riding the decline of one's years, encountering the empty moon, missing the harmony of time, and being injured by the thief wind, this is called the three deficiencies. Therefore, those who do not understand the three deficiencies cannot be skilled in their practice. Yellow Emperor said, I would like to hear about the three realities. The Master said, Riding the fullness of one's years, encountering the full moon, obtaining the harmony of time, even with the presence of thief wind qi, they cannot endanger others. Yellow Emperor exclaimed, How marvelous is this doctrine! Please engrave this on a gold inlay and call it the Three Realities. However, this is just one man's discourse.

7: 黃帝曰：願聞歲之所以皆同病者，何因而然？少師曰：此八正之候也。黃帝曰：候之奈何？少師曰：候此者，常以冬至之日，太一立於葉蟄之宮，其至也，天必應之以風雨者矣。風雨從南方來者，為虛風，賊傷人者也。其以夜半至也，萬民皆臥而弗犯也，故其歲民少病。其以晝至者，萬民懈惰而皆中於虛風，故萬民多病。虛邪入客於骨而不發於外，至其立春，陽氣大發，腠理開，因立春之日，風從西方來，萬民又皆中於虛風，此兩邪相搏，經氣結代者矣。故諸逢其風而遇其雨者，命曰遇歲露焉，因歲之和，而少賊風者，民少病而少死。歲多賊風邪氣，寒溫不和，則民多病而死矣。 Yellow Emperor: I wish to hear about why all people suffer from the same disease at different times of the year. Younger Master said: This is a matter of the Eight Regularities. Yellow Emperor: What can be done about it? Younger Master: When this occurs, one must always wait until the winter solstice. The Great Ultimate will be established in the Palace of Insects on that day; Heaven will necessarily respond with wind and rain. Wind and rain coming from the south are empty winds that harm people. They arrive at midnight when all the myriad people are asleep and not harmed. When they arrive during the day, the myriad people are idle and all come into contact with empty winds, so the myriad people get sick. Empty evil enters the bones without manifesting externally and does not emerge until the beginning of spring, when yang qi is released in great quantity and the orifices open according to the day of the beginning of spring. Wind comes from the west at that time, and the myriad people again come into contact with empty winds; these two evils contend, causing the vital energy to accumulate and stagnate. Therefore, whenever one encounters wind and rain together, it is called an encounter with seasonal dew. Based on the harmony of the season, one can avoid evil winds. The people will have fewer diseases and fewer deaths. Many diseases are caused by evil winds, cold and warmth not being harmonious; then the myriad people suffer and die.

8: 黃帝曰：虛邪之風，其所傷貴賤何如，候之奈何？少師答曰：正月朔日，太一居天留之宮，其日西北風，不雨，人多死矣。正月朔日，平旦北風，春，民多死。正月朔日，平旦北風行，民病多者，十有三也。正月朔日，日中北風，夏，民多死。正月朔日，夕時北風，秋，民多死。終日北風，大病死者十有六。正月朔日，風從南方來，命曰旱鄉；從西方來，命曰白骨，將國有殃，人多死亡。正月朔日，風從東方來，發屋，揚沙石，國有大災也。正月朔日，風從東南方行，春有死亡。正月朔日1，天利溫不風糶賤，民不病；天寒而風，糶貴，民多病。此所謂候歲之風，殘傷人者也。二月丑不風，民多心腹病；三月戌不溫，民多寒熱；四月已不暑，民多癉病；十月申不寒，民多暴死。諸所謂風者，皆發屋，折樹木，揚沙石起毫毛，發腠理者也。1. 日 : 舊脫。 Emperor Yellow said: How does the wind of deficiency and evil harm nobles and commoners, and what about it? The disciple answered: In the winter solstice, when the Great Ultimate resides in heaven and leaves its palace, on the day of west north wind, no rain, many people die. On the winter solstice, on the morning of north wind, spring comes, and many people die. On the winter solstice, on the morning of north wind, walking, there are many sick people, one in three. In the winter solstice, at noon north wind, summer arrives, and many people die. In the winter solstice, at dusk north wind, autumn comes, and many people die. Throughout the day, north wind, six in ten will be dead. On the winter solstice, the wind comes from the south, called drought village; coming from the west, called white bones, the country is in peril, and many people die. On the winter solstice, the wind comes from the east, raises dust, sand, and stones, causing a great disaster for the country. On the winter solstice, the wind comes from the southeast, spring has deaths. On the winter solstice, the first day, heaven is warm without wind, and there are no diseases among the people; when cold and windy, it is stingy, and many people get sick. This is called waiting for the weather in a year and hurting people. In the second month, no wind, many people suffer from heart and abdomen diseases; in the third month, no heat, many people have cold and fever; in the fourth month, no heat, many people have scabies; in the tenth month, no cold, many people die violently. All so-called winds blow houses, break trees, raise sand, stones, raising every hair on their heads. 1. Day: Peeled off.

docs.title: 大惑論
docs.text:
1: 黃帝問於歧伯曰：余嘗上於清冷之台，中階而顧，匍匐而前，則惑。余私異之，竊內怪之，獨瞑獨視，安心定氣，久而不解。獨博獨眩，披髮長跪，俛而視之，後久之不已也。卒然自上，何氣使然？歧伯對曰：五藏六府之精氣，皆上注于目而為之精。精之窠為眼，骨之精為瞳子，筋之精為黑眼，血之精為絡其窠，氣之精為白眼，肌肉之精為約束，裹擷筋骨血氣之精，而與脈并為系。上屬於腦，後出於項中。故邪中於項，因逢其身之虛，其入深，則隨眼系以入于腦。入于腦則腦轉，腦轉則引目系急。目系急則目眩以轉矣。邪其精，其精所中不相比也，則精散。精散則視歧，視歧見兩物。目者，五藏六府之精也，營衛魂魄之所常營也，神氣之所生也。故神勞則魂魄散，志意亂。是故瞳子黑眼法於陰，白眼赤脈法於陽也。故陰陽合傳而精明也。目者，心使也。心者，神之舍也，故神精亂而不轉。卒然見非常處精神魂魄，散不相得，故曰惑也。 Yellow Emperor asked Guan Yu: I have once ascended a high and cool platform, stood on the middle step, looked in front and staggered, feeling dizzy. I privately and secretly observed it, closed my eyes and gazed steadily, calmly and peacefully for a long time without understanding. I was alone, staring and looking at it for a long time that did not stop. Suddenly, I came down from above, what qi made this happen? Guan Yu answered: The essence of the five viscera and six bowels is all sent up to the eyes to nourish them. The nest of essence is the eyes, the essence of bones is the pupils, the essence of sinews is the black eyes, the essence of blood is the cords of the eyes, the essence of qi is the white eyes, the essence of muscle and tendons is the binding, and the essence of arteries wraps around the bones, blood, qi, and essence. The superior resides in the brain, and comes out from the neck. Therefore, pathogenic factors are present in the neck, and by encountering its own emptiness, it enters deeply, then the eyes become bound to enter the brain. Entering the brain causes the brain to turn, turning the brain leads to tightening the eye bindings. The eye bindings become dizzy and turn, resulting in dizziness. If the pathogenic factor's essence is not harmonious within itself, then the essence scatters. Scattered essence leads to double vision, and seeing two objects. The eyes are the essence of the five viscera and six bowels, the dwelling place of defending the soul and spirit, and the source of qi. Therefore, when the mind is exhausted, the soul and spirit scatter and intentions become chaotic. This is why black pupils and red pulse methods are used in yin and yang, so when yin and yang merge, there is clarity. The eyes are the heart's use. The heart is the palace of the spirit, so when the qi and essence are disordered, it does not turn, and that is why it is called being dizzy.

2: 黃帝曰：余疑其然。余每之東苑，未曾不惑，去之則復，余唯獨為東苑勞神乎？何其異也？歧伯曰：不然也。心有所喜，神有所惡，卒然相惑，則精氣亂，視誤，故惑，神移乃復。是故間者為迷，甚者為惑。 Yellow Emperor said: I suspect it is so. I have always been puzzled by the Eastern Yard, not understanding it well; if I remove it, it returns; am I the only one who labors for the Eastern Yard? How strange that would be! Grand Preceptor replied: It is not so. There are things one likes and things one dislikes in one's heart, and if they suddenly clash, one's vital energy becomes confused, and one sees mistakes and therefore becomes puzzled; when the god moves, it returns. Therefore, those who are confused are lost, and those who are more so are even more puzzled.

3: 黃帝曰：人之善忘者，何氣使然？歧伯曰：上氣不足，下氣有餘，腸胃實而心肺虛。虛則營衛留於下，久之不以時上，故善忘也。 Yellow Emperor said: Why is it that people who are good at forgetting have such qi? Duke of Zhou said: When there is insufficient qi above and excess qi below, the stomach and intestines are full while the heart and lungs are empty. The emptiness causes the defensive qi to remain below, not ascending in time, thus leading to good forgetting.

4: 黃帝曰：人之善飢而不嗜食者，何氣使然？歧伯曰：精氣并於脾，熱氣留於胃，胃熱則消穀，穀消故善飢。胃氣逆上，則胃脘寒，故不嗜食也。 Yellow Emperor said: What kind of energy makes a person who is good at hunger but does not like to eat? Master Qi Bo replied: The vital energy converges in the spleen, and the heat energy remains in the stomach. When the stomach heat dissipates the grain, the grain disappears and one becomes good at hunger. The stomach energy flows upward, then the stomach area is cold, which is why one does not like to eat.

5: 黃帝曰：病而不得臥者，何氣使然？歧伯曰：衛氣不得入于陰，常留於陽。留於陽則陽氣滿，陽氣滿則陽蹻盛，不得入于陰則陰氣虛，故目不瞑矣。 The Yellow Emperor said: What causes a person to be unable to rest when they are sick? The Duke of Shou replied: The vital energy does not enter the yin, and always remains in the yang. When it remains in the yang, the yang vital energy is filled, and when it is filled, the yang flourishes. Since it does not enter the yin, the yin vital energy becomes weak, which is why the eyes do not close.

6: 黃帝曰：病目而不得視者，何氣使然？歧伯曰：衛氣留於陰，不得行於陽，留於陰則陰氣盛，陰氣盛則陰蹻滿，不得入于陽則陽氣虛，故目閉也。 Yellow Emperor said: If a person is sick but cannot see, what Qi causes this? Qi Bo replied: The Wei Qi resides in the Yin and does not move to the Yang. Residing in the Yin results in an abundance of Yin Qi. An abundance of Yin Qi leads to the Yin orifices being filled, and if it cannot enter the Yang, then the Yang Qi will be weakened. Thus, the eyes are closed.

7: 黃帝曰：人之多臥者，何氣使然？歧伯曰：此人腸胃大而皮膚濕，而分肉不解焉。腸胃大則衛氣留久；皮膚濕則分肉不解，其行遲。夫衛氣者，晝日常行於陽，夜行於陰，故陽氣盡則臥，陰氣盡則寤。故腸胃大，則衛氣行留久；皮膚濕，分肉不解，則行遲。留於陰也久，其氣不清，則欲瞑，故多臥矣。其腸胃小，皮膚滑以緩，分肉解利，衛氣之留於陽也久，故少瞑焉。 The Yellow Emperor said: Why do so many people sleep? Qi Bo replied: This person's stomach and intestines are large, and their skin is moist. They cannot differentiate the muscles. The large intestine and stomach cause the qi to linger for a long time; the moist skin causes the muscles not to differentiate, resulting in sluggishness. Qi that circulates in the daytime through Yang and at night through Yin will cease when the Yang qi is exhausted and sleep will come, and when the Yin qi is exhausted, one will awaken. Thus, when the intestines and stomach are large, the qi lingers for a long time; moist skin causes the muscles not to differentiate, resulting in sluggishness. When this lingers in the Yin for a long time, the qi does not become clear, causing one to be drowsy, thus many people sleep. People with smaller intestines and stomachs, smooth skin that moderates, and muscles that differentiate clearly, the qi that lingers in Yang for a long time will cause them to be less drowsy.

8: 黃帝曰：其非常經也，卒然多臥者，何氣使然？歧伯曰：邪氣留於上焦，上焦閉而不通，已食若飲湯，衛氣留久於陰而不行，故卒然多臥焉。 Yellow Emperor said: This is not a serious illness, but those who sleep frequently, what Qi allows this? Kuang Bo said: Evil Qi accumulates in the upper abdomen (Dan Zhong), the upper abdomen closes and does not communicate, already eating like drinking soup, defensive Qi accumulates for a long time in Yin and does not disperse, therefore sleep frequently.

9: 黃帝曰：善。治此諸邪，奈何？歧伯曰：先其藏府，誅其小過，後調其氣，盛者寫之，虛者補之，必先明知其形志之苦樂，定乃取之。 The Yellow Emperor said, Good. How should one regulate this perverseness? The Duke of Zhou replied: First, eliminate its root cause, exterminate its minor vices, then adjust its energy. For those who excel, record their achievements; for those who are deficient, supplement their deficiencies. One must first clearly understand its form and nature, its bitterness and pleasure, before one can truly take it.

docs.title: 癰疽
docs.text:
1: 黃帝曰：余聞腸胃受穀，上焦出氣，以溫分肉，而養骨節，通腠理。中焦出氣如露，上注谿谷，而滲孫脈，津液和調，變化而赤為血。血和則孫脈先滿溢，乃注于絡脈，皆盈，乃注于經脈，陰陽已張，因息乃行。行有經紀，周有道理，與天合同，不得休止。切而調之，從虛去實，寫則不足，疾則氣減，留則先後。從實去虛，補則有餘，血氣已調，形氣乃持。余已知血氣之平與不平，未知癰疽之所從生，成敗之時，死生之期，有遠近，何以度之，可得聞乎？ Yellow Emperor said: I have heard that the intestines and stomach receive grain, the upper cavity expels gas, warming to nourish flesh, strengthening bones and joints, and regulating sinews. The middle cavity expels gas like dew, rising to the valleys, nourishing the mother veins, harmonizing body fluids, transforming into blood, and becoming red. When the blood is in harmony, the mother veins are filled first and then distributed to the nutritive veins, yin and yang are balanced, and breathing can proceed. There are records of this process, with principles that align with heaven, and cannot be neglected.

Adjusting this process requires starting with emptiness and moving towards fullness. Writing too little will not suffice; acting too hastily may deplete qi. If one lingers, there will be a sequence of deficiencies. Conversely, starting from fullness and eliminating emptiness leads to having more than enough. When blood and qi are balanced, the body's energy can be maintained.

I know how to balance blood and qi, but I do not know where the origin of boils and carbuncles lies, nor when success or failure, life or death will occur. Are there any teachings that can shed light on this?

2: 歧伯曰：經脈留行不止，與天同度，與地合紀。故天宿失度，日月薄蝕；地經失紀，水道流溢，草萓不成，五穀不殖；徑路不通，民不往來，巷聚邑居，則別離異處。血氣猶然，請言其故。夫血脈營衛，周流不休，上應星宿，下應經數。寒邪客於經絡之中，則血泣，血泣則不通，不通則衛氣歸之，不得復反，故癰腫。寒氣化為熱，熱勝則腐肉，肉腐則為膿。膿不寫則爛筋，筋爛則傷骨，骨傷則髓消，不當骨空，不得泄寫，血枯空虛，則筋骨肌肉不相榮，經脈敗漏，熏於五藏，藏傷故死矣。 Obi said: The meridians and vessels [of the body] remain unceasing, harmonizing with heaven and earth. When the heavens are out of order, the sun and moon become faint; when the earth loses its records, rivers overflow, grass does not thrive, and crops do not sprout; roads become inaccessible, and people cannot come and go, lanes becoming densely populated areas and cities. Thus, different places become alienated. Regarding blood and qi, please explain the cause. For the blood vessels nurture and defend [the body], circulating without rest, going up to correspond with stars and constellations, and going down to correspond with meridians and numbers. Cold pathogens invade the channels of the meridians, causing the blood to weep, which in turn does not flow, and so the qi energy returns to itself, unable to reverse [the situation], thus leading to swelling and tumors. Cold turns into heat, and heat, if it prevails, rots the flesh. Rotting flesh leads to ulcers. If ulcers are not treated, tendons become weakened and damage bones, damaging bone marrow, which does not flow into the empty spaces, causing blood to dry up, leading to emptiness in muscles, sinews, and flesh, and the meridians and vessels cannot complement each other, causing the five organs to be scorched, leading to injury and resulting in death.

3: 黃帝曰：願盡聞癰疽之形，與忌曰名。歧伯曰：癰發於嗌中，名曰猛疽。猛疽不治，化為膿，膿不寫，塞咽，半日死。其化為膿者，寫則合豕膏，冷食，三日而已。 Yellow Emperor said: I wish to hear about the appearance of carbuncles and their names. Duke of Shao said: Carbuncles appear in the groin area and are called malignant boils. Malignant boils that cannot be treated turn into abscesses, untreated abscesses can obstruct the throat, leading to death within half a day. For those who have turned into abscesses, if treated, apply pig fat ointment, eat cold food, and they will recover in three days

4: 發於頸，名曰夭疽。其癰大以赤黑，不急治，則熱氣下入淵腋，前傷任脈，內熏肝肺。熏肝肺，十餘日而死矣。 Originating at the neck, it is called dantian. Its swelling is large and red-black in color. If not treated promptly, the heat will descend into the armpit, causing damage to the conception vessel, and internally scorching the liver and lungs. Scorching the liver and lungs, one will die within twenty days.

5: 陽留大發，消腦留項，名曰腦爍。其色不樂，項痛而如刺以鍼。煩心者，死不可治。 Yangliu Dafa, Xiao Nianli Qi, Mingyao Nao Ma. QixSE color bule, Jiacheng yiyanxiao. Fannaxin Zhe, Sisuo Ganqi.

6: 發於肩及臑，名曰疵癰。其狀赤黑，急治之，此令人汗出至足，不害五藏。癰發四五日，逞焫之。 Located on the shoulders and chest, it is called a blemish or rash. Its appearance is red and black, and if treated promptly, this can cause excessive sweating. However, it does not harm the internal organs. A rash appears within four to five days and eventually disappears.

7: 發於腋下赤堅者，名曰米疽。治之以砭石，欲細而長，疏砭之，塗以豕膏，六日已，勿裹之。其癰堅而不潰者，為馬刀挾癭，急治之。 If there is a hard, reddish nodule under the arm, it is called miliary tuberculosis. Treat it with chalkstone, let it be detailed and long-lasting, thinly apply chalkstone, after six days do not wrap it up. If the swelling becomes hard but does not soften, use a horse knife to squeeze the swelling and treat it urgently.

8: 發於胸，名曰井疽。其狀如大豆，三四日起，不早治，下入腹，不治，七日死矣。 Arising from the chest, it is called well-boil. Its appearance resembles that of a large bean. It emerges within three to four days and if not treated promptly, it descends into the abdomen and remains untreated, leading to death within seven days.

9: 發於膺，名曰甘疽。色青，其狀如穀實𦸈𧁾，常苦寒熱，急治之，去其寒熱，十歲死，死後出膿。 From the lung, it is called gan3qi2. It is green in color and resembles a grain swelling up, always bitterly cold and hot. If treated urgently, it removes the cold and heat, at ten years old one dies, after death there is pus.

10: 發於脅，名曰敗疵。敗疵者，女子之病也，灸之，其病大癰膿，治之，其中乃有生肉，大如赤小豆，坐陵翹草根各一升，以水一斗六升煮之，竭為取三升，則強飲厚衣，坐於釜上，令汗出至足已。 Published in The Cracks, it is called Bai Ye. Bai Ye is a woman's illness. When treated with cupping, the lesion becomes large and swollen. After treatment, there will be flesh inside the lesion, as big as a red small bean. Take one liter of the roots of Ling Xiang Cao and one liter of Jiao Cao, boil them in six liters of water, strain it to get three liters. Have the patient sit above this pot, making him sweat profusely until his feet are wet.

11: 發於股脛，名曰股脛疽。其狀不甚變，而癰膿搏骨，不急治，三十日死矣。 Located at the heel, called heel abscess. Its appearance does not change much, and the swelling pulsates against the bone. If not treated promptly, it will result in death within thirty days.

12: 發於尻，名曰銳疽。其狀赤堅大，急治之，不治，三十日死矣。 Located on the neck, it is called Sharp Carbuncle. Its appearance is red and hard, large in size, urgent treatment is necessary; if not treated, one will die within thirty days.

13: 發於股陰，名曰赤施。不急治，六十日死。在兩股之內，不治，十日而當死。 Located in the scrotum, it is called red shelf. If not treated promptly, death occurs within sixty days. If located inside the scrotum and not treated, death will occur within ten days. Note: The text seems to describe a medical condition or injury, but without further context it's difficult to determine its exact nature. It may be advisable to consult with a medical professional for advice on treatment and care.

14: 發於膝，名曰疵癰。其狀大，癰色不變，寒熱，如堅石，勿石，石之者死，須其柔，乃石之者，生。 Arising from the knee, it is called Yuan Chou. Its shape is large, the color of the Yuan Chou does not change, cold and hot like a stone, not like a stone, those who are like stones will die, there must be something soft about them, and they will survive.

15: 諸癰疽之發於節而相應者，不可治也。發於陽者，百日死；發於陰者，三十日死。 The eruptions occurring at the joints and corresponding in number [with each other] cannot be treated. If it occurs in the Yang aspect, one will die within a hundred days; if it occurs in the Yin aspect, one will die within thirty days.

16: 發於脛，名曰兔嚙，其狀赤至骨，急治之，不治害人也。 It is located on the ankle and is called rabbit's tooth. Its color is bright red to the bone. It must be treated urgently, or it will harm people.

17: 發於內踝，名曰走緩。其狀癰也，色不變，數石其輸，而止其寒熱，不死。 Originating from Nanjing, it is called Walking Calm. Its appearance is abnormal, the color does not change, it counts how many stones it passes, and stops its cold and heat, not dying.

18: 發於足上下，名曰四淫。其狀大癰，急治之，百日死。 Located on both the feet, it is called the Four Licentiousness. Its appearance is large and ugly, and if treated urgently, one will die within a hundred days

19: 發於足傍，名曰厲癰。其狀不大，初如小指，發，急治之，去其黑者；不消輒益，不治，百日死。 Located on the foot, it is called Xi Liang. Its appearance is not large, initially resembling a small finger, and if treated immediately after the black part appears, it will be cured; otherwise, if left untreated for a hundred days, it will result in death.

20: 發於足趾，名脫癰。其狀赤黑，死不治；不赤黑，不死。不衰，急斬之，不則死矣。 Appearing on the toenails, it is called a fungus. Its condition may be red or black and untreatable; if not red or black, it is not fatal. If it does not wither away, cut it out immediately, for otherwise, death will ensue.

21: 黃帝曰：夫子言癰疽，何以別之？歧伯曰：營衛稽留於經脈之中，則血泣而不行，不行則衛氣從之而不通，壅遏而不得行，故熱。大熱不止，熱勝，則肉腐，肉腐則為膿。然不能陷，骨髓不為燋枯，五藏不為傷，故命曰癰。 Yellow Emperor said: What is the distinction between boils and carbuncles? Zhi Bó replied: The wei qi accumulates in the channels of the meridians, causing the blood to stagnate and not circulate. This leads to a blockage, preventing it from flowing freely, resulting in heat. If the heat persists and becomes dominant, the flesh begins to decay, leading to abscesses. However, one cannot become critically ill; the bone marrow does not dry up nor do the internal organs get damaged, so it is called a boil.

22: 黃帝曰：何謂疽？歧伯曰：熱氣淳盛，下陷肌膚，筋髓枯，內連五藏，血氣竭，當其癰下，筋骨良肉皆無餘，故命曰疽。疽者，上之皮夭以堅，上如牛領之皮。癰者，其皮上薄以澤。此其候也。 Yellow Emperor said: What is a boil? Bóu said: The vital energy is abundant and overflowing, sinking into the muscles and skin, the tendons and marrow are dry, internally connected to the five organs, blood and vital energy are exhausted, at the point where the boil emerges, all the tendons, bones, and flesh have no remaining strength, so it is called a boil. In a boil, the skin is tightened and firm like a cow's neck, while in a furuncle (癰), the skin is thin and moisturized. This is its stage.

docs.title: 診要經終論
docs.text:
1: 黃帝問曰：診要何如。歧伯對曰：正月二月，天氣始方，地氣始發，人氣在肝。三月四月，天氣正方，地氣定發，人氣在脾。五月六月，天氣盛，地氣高，人氣在頭。七月八月，陰氣始殺，人氣在肺。九月十月，陰氣始冰，地氣始閉，人氣在心。十一月十二月，冰復，地氣合，人氣在腎。 Emperor Yellow asked, How should one diagnose? Huan Pu answered, In the second month of the first month, when the heavenly energy begins to manifest and the earthly energy emerges, the human energy is in the liver. In the third month and fourth month, when the heavenly energy is complete and the earthly energy is firmly established, the human energy is in the spleen. In the fifth month and sixth month, when the heavenly energy is abundant and the earthly energy is high, the human energy is in the head. In the seventh month and eighth month, as yin energy begins to kill, the human energy is in the lungs. In the ninth month and tenth month, as yin energy begins to freeze and the earthly energy begins to close, the human energy is in the heart. In the eleventh month and twelfth month, as the freezing repeats itself and the earthly energy merges, the human energy is in the kidneys.

2: 故春刺散俞，及與分理，血出而止，甚者傳氣，閒者環也。夏刺絡俞，見血而止，盡氣閉環，痛病必下。秋刺皮膚，循理，上下同法，神變而止。冬刺俞竅於分理，甚者直下，閒者散下。春夏秋冬，各有所刺，法其所在。 According to the seasons, there are different acupuncture methods: In spring, prick the Sanjiao, and when blood comes out, it stops. For the serious cases, pass Qi, and for the less serious, circle around. In summer, prick the Sinew Channels, see the blood and stop, exhaust all the Qi, close the circle, and painful diseases must go away. In autumn, prick the skin and follow the reason, both up and down follow the same method, spirit stops. In winter, prick the Sanjiao at the intersection of the division reason, for the serious cases, it directly goes away, and for the idle ones, it disperses away. In spring, summer, autumn, and winter, each has a place to prick, and treat according to its location.

3: 春刺夏分，脈亂氣微，入淫骨髓，病不能愈，令人不嗜食，又且少氣。春刺秋分，筋攣，逆氣環，為欬嗽，病不愈，令人時驚，又且哭。春刺冬分，邪氣著藏，令人脹，病不愈，又且欲言語。夏刺春分，病不愈，令人解墯。夏刺秋分，病不愈，令人心中欲無言，惕惕如人將補之。夏刺冬分，病不愈，令人少氣，時欲怒。秋刺春分，病不已，令人惕然欲有所為，起而忘之。秋刺夏分，病不已，令人益嗜臥，又且善㝱。秋刺冬分，病不已，令人洒洒時寒。冬刺春分，病不已，令人欲臥不能眠，眠而有見。冬刺夏分，病不愈，氣上，發為諸痺。冬刺秋分，病不已，令人善渴。 Spring acupuncture in the season of summer, the pulse is chaotic and the Qi is weak. It invades the bone marrow, causing a disease that cannot be cured, making people dislike eating and also being short of breath. Spring acupuncture in the season of autumn, the tendons twist, and the reversed Qi revolves, causing coughing and asthma, the disease does not subside, making people sometimes shocked and also weeping. Spring acupuncture in the season of winter, the evil Qi lurks and makes people bloated, the disease does not subside, also making people want to speak but unable to.

Summer acupuncture in the season of spring, the disease does not subside, making people feel as though they are about to fall down. Summer acupuncture in the season of autumn, the disease does not subside, making people have a desire to lie down and also enjoy it. Summer acupuncture in the season of winter, the disease does not subside, making people short of breath and sometimes want to be angry.

Autumn acupuncture in the season of spring, the disease is not cured, making people feel surprised and desire to do something but forget it. Autumn acupuncture in the season of summer, the disease is not cured, making people like lying down more, also enjoying it. Autumn acupuncture in the season of winter, the disease does not subside, making people thirsty.

Winter acupuncture in the season of spring, the disease does not subside, making people want to lie down but unable to sleep, sleeping and seeing things. Winter acupuncture in the season of summer, the disease is not cured, Qi rises and causes various pains. Winter acupuncture in the season of autumn, the disease does not subside, making people desire to drink water.

4: 凡刺胸腹者，必避五藏。中心者，環死；中脾者，五日死；中腎者，七日死；中肺者，五日死；中鬲者，皆為傷中，其病雖愈，不過一歲必死。刺避五藏者，知逆從也。所謂從者，鬲與脾腎之處，不知者反之。刺胸腹者，必以布憿著之，乃從單布上刺，刺之不愈，復刺。刺鍼必肅，刺腫搖鍼，經刺勿搖，此刺之道也。 Those who have been pierced in the chest or abdomen will definitely avoid the five organs. Those in the center will be surrounded by death, those in the spleen will die within five days, those in the kidneys will die within seven days, those in the lungs will die within five days, and those in the gallbladder will all be wounded in the chest; even if their illness recovers, they must die within a year. Knowing how to follow the principle when piercing the five organs, one knows whether it is reversed or not. The term follow refers to the positions of the gallbladder, spleen, and kidneys, and if one does not know, one will reverse them. When piercing the chest or abdomen, one must use a cloth with needles sewn in; one should not shake the needle when performing acupuncture, and this is the way of piercing.

5: 帝曰：願聞十二經脈之終，奈何。歧伯曰：太陽之脈，其終也戴眼反折瘈瘲，其色白，絕汗乃出，出則死矣。少陽終者，耳聾百節皆縱，目𦊷絕系，絕系一日半死，其死也，色先青白，乃死矣。陽明終者，口目動作，善驚妄言，色黃，其上下經盛，不仁，則終矣。少陰終者，面黑齒長而垢，腹脹閉，上下不通而終矣。太陰終者，腹脹閉不得息，善噫善嘔，嘔則逆，逆則面赤，不逆則上下不通，不通則面黑皮毛焦而終矣。厥陰終者，中熱嗌乾，善溺心煩，甚則舌卷卵上縮而終矣。此十二經之所敗也。 The emperor said, I hope to hear about the ending of the twelve meridians. What happens when they end? Duke Pu said: The ending of the Great Sun meridian is characterized by dizziness and vision problems, with white coloration, sweating that leads to death. The ending of the Lesser Yin meridian is marked by deafness and loss of sensation in all joints, blindness followed by coma, and death from greenish-white complexion. The ending of the Yang Ming meridian is characterized by movement of the mouth and eyes, being easily frightened and speaking nonsense, yellow coloration, and a full flow of Qi in both upper and lower meridians, but if it lacks compassion, death will follow. The ending of the Shao Yin meridian is marked by dark complexion and long teeth, with bloating of the abdomen, poor circulation in the upper and lower meridians leading to death. The ending of the Tai Yin meridian is characterized by bloating of the abdomen that does not allow breathing, being good at vomiting and hiccupping, and if there is hiccoughing, the face will turn red, if there isn't, poor circulation in the upper and lower meridians leads to dark complexion and dry skin, and ultimately death. The ending of the Ren Yin meridian is marked by an internal heat that dries up the mouth and tongue, with a tendency to drown and be bothered by the heart, which can lead to the tongue rolling up towards the yolk and death. This is what happens when the twelve meridians fail.

docs.title: 脈要精微論
docs.text:
1: 黃帝問曰：診法何如。歧伯對曰：診法常以平旦，陰氣未動，陽氣未散，飲食未進，經脈未盛，絡脈調勻，氣血未亂，故乃可診有過之脈。切脈動靜而視精明，察五色，觀五藏有餘不足，六府強弱，形之盛衰，以此參伍決死生之分。 The Yellow Emperor asked, How is the method of diagnosis? The Duke of Shou replied, Diagnosis is usually done at noon when the yin energy has not yet moved and the yang energy has not yet dispersed. Food and drink have not been taken in yet, and the channels are not full. The network vessels are in balance, and there is no confusion in the Qi and blood. Therefore, it is possible to diagnose a patient's excesses by feeling the pulse. He said, If the pulse is active or still, one must observe the clarity of the mind. Examine the five colors, observe whether the five organs have enough or lack something, assess the strength or weakness of the six departments, determine the abundance or decline of the body form, and use all these factors to distinguish between life and death.

2: 夫脈者，血之府也，長則氣治，短則氣病，數則煩心，大則病進，上盛則氣高，下盛則氣脹，代則氣衰，細則氣少，濇則心痛，渾渾革至如涌泉，病進而色弊，緜緜其去如弦絕，死。夫精明五色者，氣之華也。赤欲如白裹朱，不欲如赭；白欲如鵝羽，不欲如鹽；青欲如蒼璧之澤，不欲如藍；黃欲如羅裹雄黃，不欲如黃土；黑欲如重漆色，不欲如地蒼。五色精微象見矣，其壽不久也。夫精明者，所以視萬物，別白黑，審短長。以長為短，以白為黑，如是則精衰矣。 The pulse, or beckoning, refers to the dwelling place of blood. When it is long, the qi is regulated; when short, there is a qi disorder; when irregular, there is disturbance of the heart-spirit; when deep, disease progresses; when full on top, there is a sensation of high qi; when full below, there is a sensation of bloated qi; if intermittent, there is decline of qi; if subtle, there is insufficiency of qi; if weakened, there is pain in the heart; if chaotic, like gushing springs, disease progresses and color deteriorates, like broken strings, leading to death. The radiant purity of the five colors refers to the flowering of qi. Red desires to be white, like vermillion wrappings; yellow desires to be white, like alum; green desires to be as clear as a jade basin, not like indigo; yellow desires to be like the golden wrapping of a phoenix, not like yellow earth; black desires to be like the glossy color of lacquer, not like the blue of the sky. The five colors, radiant and subtle, have appeared, but their longevity is brief. The one who perceives and discerns myriad things, distinguishing white from black, judging long and short: if he favors the short over the long, and the black over the white, then he will decline in vitality

3: 藏者，中之守也，中盛藏滿，氣勝傷恐者，聲如從室中言，是中氣之濕也。言而微，終日乃復言者，此奪氣也。衣被不斂，言語善惡，不避親踈者，此神明之亂也。倉廩不藏者，是門戶不要也。水泉不止者，是膀胱不藏也。得守者生，失守者死。夫五藏者，身之強也，頭者精明之府，頭傾視深，精神將奪矣。背者胸中之府，背曲肩隨，府將壞矣。腰者腎之府，轉搖不能，腎將憊矣。膝者筋之府，屈伸不能，行則僂附，筋將憊矣。骨者髓之府，不能久立，行則振掉，骨將憊矣。得強則生，失強則死。 The one who keeps it is the master of the center, and when the center is full, the qi prevails over injury and fear, its voice is like speaking from inside a room, this is the dampness of the center's qi. The words are soft and subtle, all day long they change into more such words, this is losing the qi. Clothing and bedding not properly adjusted, speech good or bad, not avoiding close relatives, this is disorder of spirit and light. A warehouse without a storehouse is because the doors and windows are not closed. Springs and wells that do not stop are because the bladder is not stored. Those who have guarded it live, those who have lost it die. The five stores are the strength of the body, the head is the residence of spirit, tilting the head to look deeply, the spirit is about to be taken away. The back is the repository of the chest, bending the shoulders when the back is curved, the repository is about to deteriorate. The waist is the repository of the kidneys, unable to rotate and sway, the kidneys are about to ache.
