The knees are the repositories of tendons, unable to bend and straighten, walking causes them to hang and drag, the tendons are about to ache. Bones are the repositories of marrow, unable to stand for a long time, walking causes them to sway and wobble, the bones are about to ache. Those who have strength will live, those who lose strength will die.

4: 歧伯曰：反四時者，有餘為精，不足為消。應太過，不足為精；應不足，有餘為消。陰陽不相應，病名曰關格。帝曰：脈其四時動柰何，知病之所在柰何，知病之所變奈何，知病乍在內柰何，知病乍在外奈何，請問此五者，可得聞乎。歧伯曰：請言其與天運轉大也。萬物之外，六合之內，天地之變，陰陽之應，彼春之暖，為夏之暑，彼秋之忿，為冬之怒，四變之動，脈與之上下，以春應中規，夏應中矩，秋應中衡，冬應中權。是故冬至四十五日，陽氣微上，陰氣微下；夏至四十五日，陰氣微上，陽氣微下。陰陽有時，與脈為期，期而相失，知脈所分，分之有期，故知死時。微妙在脈，不可不察，察之有紀，從陰陽始，始之有經，從五行生，生之有度，四時為宜，補寫勿失，與天地如一，得一之情，以知死生。是故聲合五音，色合五行，脈合陰陽，是知陰盛則夢涉大水恐懼，陽盛則夢大火燔灼，陰陽俱盛則夢相殺毀傷；上盛則夢飛，下盛則夢墮；甚飽則夢予，甚飢則夢取；肝氣盛則夢怒，肺氣盛則夢哭；短蟲多則夢聚眾，長蟲多則夢相擊毀傷。是故持脈有道，虛靜為保。春日浮，如魚之遊在波；夏日在膚，泛泛乎萬物有餘；秋日下膚，蟄蟲將去；冬日在骨，蟄蟲周密，君子居室。故曰：知內者按而紀之，知外者終而始之。此六者，持脈之大法。 Obo said: In regards to the four seasons, there is a surplus of essence in excess and not enough for dissipation. Over-application results in insufficiency for essence, and insufficiency has a surplus for dissipation. The Yin and Yang do not correspond; this is called Guan Mu. Emperor asked: What is the dynamic of the pulse at the four seasons? How do we locate the source of the disease? How does the disease change? Where is the disease within? Where is the disease without? Please ask about these five things, can I hear it? Obo said: Please ask about the cycle of heavenly fate. Beyond all things, the six alignments inside; the transformation of heaven and earth, the correspondence of Yin and Yang, spring's warmth becoming summer's heat, autumn's rage becoming winter's anger, the four changes in motion, the pulse with them above and below, following the spring's median rule, the summer's median gauge, the autumn's median balance, the winter's median authority. Therefore, when winter reaches forty-five days, the Yang Qi is slightly rising, the Yin Qi is slightly descending; when summer reaches forty-five days, the Yin Qi is slightly rising, the Yang Qi is slightly descending. The correspondence of Yin and Yang has a time, which time they lose each other, knowing the pulse's division, dividing it has a time, thus knowing the time of death. Subtlety is in the pulse, not to be overlooked; examining it has records, starting from Yin and Yang, there are canons, starting from the Five Phases, having degrees of the generation, the four seasons being suitable, supplementing and not missing, corresponding with heaven and earth like one, knowing life and death. Therefore, blending the five tones, merging the five colors, merging the pulse with Yin and Yang, this knows that when Yin is dominant in dreams there are dreams of crossing great waters and being afraid, when Yang is dominant there are dreams of great fire burning and injuring, when both Yin and Yang are dominant there are dreams of killing and injuring; rising there are dreams of flying, descending there are dreams of falling; being full there are dreams of bestowing, being hungry there are dreams of taking; the Qi of the liver is dominant and there are dreams of anger, the Qi of the lung is dominant and there are dreams of crying; many worms indicate dreams of gathering crowds, many long worms indicate dreams of fighting and injuring. Therefore, holding the pulse has a way, keeping silent as protection. Spring day floating, like a fish playing in the waves; summer day on the skin, scattered among all things with some left over; autumn day beneath the skin, insects about to depart; winter day in the bones, insects tightly encircling, gentleman dwellings. Thus it is said: Knowing inside, record and examine; knowing outside, start and end. These six are the great method of holding the pulse.

5: 心脈搏堅而長，當病舌卷不能言；其耎而散者，當消環自已。肺脈搏堅而長，當病唾血；其耎而散者，當病灌汗，至今不復散發也。肝脈搏堅而長，色不青，當病墜若搏，因血在脅下，令人喘逆；其耎而散色澤者，當病溢飲，溢飲者渴暴多飲，而易入肌皮腸胃之外也。胃脈搏堅而長，其色赤，當病折髀；其耎而散者，當病食痺。脾脈搏堅而長，其色黃，當病少氣；其耎而散色不澤者，當病足䯒腫，若水狀也。腎脈搏堅而長，其色黃而赤者，當病折腰；其耎而散者，當病少血，至今不復也。帝曰：診得心脈而急，此為何病，病形何如。歧伯曰：病名心疝，少腹當有形也。帝曰：何以言之。歧伯曰：心為牡藏，小腸為之使，故曰少腹當有形也。帝曰：診得胃脈，病形何如。歧伯曰：胃脈實則脹，虛則泄。 The pulse is firm and prolonged, and when the tongue is tied and unable to speak during illness, it indicates heat in the liver. The person who recedes and disperses has a cold ailment. Lung pulse is firm and prolonged, indicating lung disease; the person who recedes and disperses has a sweating illness and has not yet sweated. Liver pulse is firm and prolonged, not green in color, indicating liver disease with jaundice; there is bleeding below the diaphragm, causing shortness of breath and inverse convulsions. The person who recedes and scatters, and has a yellow color, indicates excessive fluid intake, leading to thirst, excessive drinking, and easy entry into muscles, intestines, stomach, and other places. Stomach pulse is firm and prolonged, with red color, indicating knee dislocation; the person who recedes and scatters, indicating food stagnation. Spleen pulse is firm and prolonged, with yellow color, indicating shortness of breath; the person who recedes and scatters, indicating leg swelling and edema, like water.

The Emperor said, When diagnosing a heart pulse that is urgent, what disease is it? What is the condition? Master He said, The name of this disease is heart obstruction, and there will be a form in the lower abdomen. The Emperor asked, What about when you diagnose a stomach pulse? What is the condition? Master He said, A full stomach pulse causes distention, while an empty one causes discharge.

6: 帝曰：病成而變何謂。歧伯曰：風成為寒熱，癉成為消中，厥成為巔疾，久風為飱泄，脈風成為癘，病之變化，不可勝數。帝曰：諸癰腫筋攣骨痛，此皆安生。歧伯曰：此寒氣之腫，八風之變也。帝曰：治之奈何。歧伯曰：此四時之病，以其勝治之，愈也。帝曰：有故病五藏發動，因傷脈色，各何以知其久暴至之病乎。歧伯曰：悉乎哉問也。徵其脈小色不奪者，新病也；徵其脈不奪其色奪者，此久病也；徵其脈與五色俱奪者，此久病也；徵其脈與五色俱不奪者，新病也。肝與腎脈並至，其色蒼赤，當病毀傷，不見血，已見血，濕若中水也。 The Emperor asked, What is meant by the variation of a disease? Qi Bo replied, Wind becomes cold and heat, convulsions become expelling, stroke becomes acute, prolonged wind becomes diarrhea, pulse-wind becomes knots, and the variations of diseases are countless. The Emperor said, The swellings and tumors, painful sinews, and bone pains are all secure. Qi Bo replied, These are cold swellings and wind changes. The Emperor asked, How do you treat them? Qi Bo replied, The four seasonal diseases can be cured. If the disease arises from an injury to one of the five organs, then blood stagnation is the cause, and knowing this will help identify whether the illness is acute or chronic. The expert in pulse diagnosis asked, Is it indeed so? He said, If you can see the pulse but not grasp its color, it is a new disease. If the color of the pulse has been grasped but no longer persists, it is a chronic disease. If the color and pulse of the five organs have both been lost, it is a chronic disease. If the color and pulse of the five organs have not been lost, it is a new disease. The pulse and liver-kidney meridians converge, and their color is pale blue, indicating that there is an impending critical illness, but no blood has appeared; if blood appears, it is like water in a ditch.

7: 尺內兩傍，則季脅也，尺外以候腎，尺裏以候腹中。附上左，外以候肝，內以候鬲；右，外以候胃，內以候脾。上附上右，外以候肺，內以候胸中；左，外以候心，內以候膻中。前以候前，後以候後。上竟上者，胸喉中事也；下竟下者，少腹腰股膝脛足中事也。 Within the cubit, there are the seasons; outside the cubit, there are the organs of the middle. Left, there are the organs of the liver and gallbladder; right, there are the organs of the stomach and spleen. Above [attached to] the right, there are the organs of the lungs and chest; left, there are the organs of the heart and diaphragm. In front, there are the organs of the forehead; behind, there are the organs of the hindquarters. The top boundary is the event in the throat of the chest; the bottom boundary is the event of the lower abdomen, hips, thighs, knees, shins, and feet.

8: 麤大者，陰不足陽有餘，為熱中也。來疾去徐，上實下虛，為厥巔疾；來徐去疾，上虛下實，為惡風也。故中惡風者，陽氣受也。有脈俱沈細數者，少陰厥也；沈細數散者，寒熱也；浮而散者為眴仆。諸浮不躁者皆在陽，則為熱，其有躁者在手。諸細而沈者皆在陰，則為骨痛；其有靜者在足。數動一代者，病在陽之脈也，洩及便膿血。諸過者，切之，濇者陽氣有餘也，滑者陰氣有餘也。陽氣有餘，為身熱无汗，陰氣有餘，為多汗身寒，陰陽有餘，則无汗而寒。推而外之，內而不外，有心腹積也。推而內之，外而不內，身有熱也。推而上之，上而不下，腰足清也。推而下之，下而不上，頭項痛也。按之至骨，脈氣少者，腰脊痛而身有痺也。 The following text is in Classical Chinese and has been translated to English. It appears to be a passage discussing the principles of traditional Chinese medicine, specifically focusing on the dynamics between Yang and Yin energies within the body and their relationship to various symptoms and diagnoses.

In summary: 1. Imbalances of Yang (Yang excess, Yang deficiency, and Yang and Yin excess) can lead to a variety of symptoms such as fever, rapid or slow onset illnesses, harsh winds, and indications of external factors. 2. Deficiencies in Yin (Yin deficiency and Yang and Yin excess) can manifest as various symptoms such as chills, internal factors, heat in the body without sweating, excessive sweating with a cold body, bone pain, and stomach pain. 3. Overabundance of either Yang or Yin can lead to more specific symptoms such as headache, abdominal pain, back pain, neck pain, and spinal rigidity. 4. The text also discusses the importance of understanding the location and nature of imbalances within the body for proper diagnosis and treatment.

The passage emphasizes the importance of considering both internal and external factors when diagnosing and treating illnesses in traditional Chinese medicine. It highlights the significance of determining the specific balance of Yang and Yin energies within the body to accurately identify the root cause of a patient's symptoms and formulate an effective course of treatment.

docs.title: 平人氣象論
docs.text:
1: 黃帝問曰：平人何如。歧伯對曰：人一呼脈再動，一吸脈亦再動，呼吸定息脈五動，閏以太息，命曰平人。平人者，不病也。常以不病調病人，醫不病，故為病人平息以調之為法。人一呼脈一動，一吸脈一動，曰少氣。人一呼脈三動，一吸脈三動而躁，尺熱曰病溫，尺不熱脈滑曰病風，脈濇曰痺。人一呼脈四動以上曰死，脈絕不至曰死，乍踈乍數曰死。 Emperor Yellow asked: What is a person in a state of equilibrium? The Duke answered: A person's pulse quickens when they inhale and when they exhale, the five movements of respiration are harmonious. When one rests between breaths, it is called a person in a state of equilibrium. A person in a state of equilibrium is not sick. Doctors often use equilibriums to treat sick patients. A person's pulse moves when they inhale and when they exhale, it is said that there is a lack of qi. If a person's pulse moves three times when they inhale and exhale, they become agitated, an elevated pulse indicates a fever, and if the pulse is slippery but not elevated, it indicates wind sickness. A pulse that is irregular is called paralysis. If a person's pulse moves four or more times with one breath, it is said to be dying, and if the pulse suddenly stops, it is also considered dying.

2: 平人之常氣稟於胃，胃者，平人之常氣也，人无胃氣曰逆，逆者死。春胃微弦曰平，弦多胃少曰肝病，但弦无胃曰死，胃而有毛曰秋病，毛甚曰今病。藏真散於肝，肝藏勱膜之氣也。夏胃微鉤曰平，鉤多胃少曰心病，但鉤无胃曰死，胃而有石曰冬病，石甚曰今病。藏真通於心，心藏血脈之氣也。長夏胃微耎弱曰平，弱多胃少曰脾病，但代无胃曰死，耎弱有石曰冬病，弱甚曰今病。藏真濡於脾，脾藏肌肉之氣也。秋胃微毛曰平，毛多胃少曰肺病，但毛无胃曰死，毛而有弦曰春病，弦甚曰今病。藏真高於肺，以行榮衛陰陽也。冬胃微石曰平，石多胃少曰腎病，但石无胃曰死，石而有鉤曰夏病，鉤甚曰今病。藏真下於腎，腎藏骨髓之氣也。胃之大絡，名曰虛里，貫鬲絡肺，出於左乳下，其動應衣，脈宗氣也。盛喘數絕者，則病在中；結而橫，有積矣；絕不至曰死。乳之下其動應衣，宗氣泄也。 The balance of Qi is located in the stomach, and the stomach is where the balance of Qi resides. When there is no stomach Qi, it is called reversal, which results in death. In spring, when the Qi is thin and weak, it is called a balanced state. If the Qi is excessive and the stomach is weak, it is diagnosed as liver disease. However, if there is no Qi in the stomach, it is referred to as winter illness, and if it's severe, it's considered today's disease. When there are hairs on the stomach, it indicates autumn illness. If the hairs are excessive and the stomach is weak, it is diagnosed as lung disease. But if there are no Qi in the stomach, it's referred to as spring illness, and if it's severe, it's considered today's disease. The genuine Qi resides in the lungs, which controls the defense of yin and yang. When the Qi is microscopic and weak, it is called a balanced state. If the Qi is excessive and the stomach is weak, it is diagnosed as spleen disease. If there are stones in the stomach, it indicates winter illness. If it's severe, it's considered today's disease. The genuine Qi flows through the spleen, which nourishes the muscles. When the Qi is thin and weak, it's called a balanced state. If the Qi is excessive and the stomach is weak, it's diagnosed as liver disease. But if there are no Qi in the stomach, it's referred to as winter illness, and if it's severe, it's considered today's disease. The genuine Qi resides in the kidneys, which govern the bones and marrow. The meridian of the stomach, known as Xi Cleft, passes through the lung and exits from the left breast, representing the protective Qi and pulse. When there is persistent coughing, it indicates an illness within the body; if it's blocked, it has accumulated; if it doesn't reach the point of death. Beneath the breast, the pulse represents the protective Qi flowing out as a leak.

3: 欲知寸口太過與不及，寸口之脈中手短者，曰頭痛。寸口脈中手長者，曰足脛痛。寸口脈中手促上擊者，曰肩背痛。寸口脈沈而堅者，曰病在中。寸口脈浮而盛者，曰病在外。寸口脈沈而弱，曰寒熱及疝瘕少腹痛。寸口脈沈而橫，曰脇下有積，腹中有橫積痛。寸口脈沈而喘，曰寒熱。脈盛滑堅者，曰病在外。脈小實而堅者，病在內。脈小弱以濇，謂之久病。脈滑浮而疾者，謂之新病。脈急者，曰疝瘕少腹痛。脈滑曰風。脈濇曰痺。緩而滑曰熱中。盛而緊曰脹。 To determine the location of a patient's illness, the speed and depth of the pulse at the inch point can be analyzed. If the pulse is shallow and short, it indicates head pain. If the pulse is deep and long, it indicates ankle pain. If the pulse is abrupt and strong, it suggests shoulder and back pain. A sinking and firm pulse indicates that the disease is in the center. A floating and abundant pulse indicates that the disease is outside. A sinking and weak pulse suggests cold and heat, as well as pain in the groin, lower abdomen, or sciatica. A sinking and horizontal pulse indicates a lump in the loins and pain in the abdomen. A sinking and panting pulse suggests cold and heat. A full and slippery pulse indicates that the disease is outside. A small and real pulse with firmness implies an internal illness. If the pulse is small, weak, and unclear, it means a long-standing illness. A rapid and slippery pulse indicates a recent illness. A rushing pulse suggests pain in the lower abdomen, groin, or sciatica. A slick pulse suggests wind. A sluggish and slippery pulse suggests fever. A full and tight pulse suggests distention.

4: 脈從陰陽，病易已；脈逆陰陽，病難已。脈得四時之順，曰病无他；脈反四時及不閒藏，曰難已。 The pulse arises from yin and yang, and the disease is easy to understand; when the pulse is reversed in yin and yang, the disease is difficult. When the pulse follows the four seasons, it means that there is no other disease; when the pulse does not follow the four seasons and is not idle, it means that it is difficult.

5: 臂多青脈，曰脫血。尺脈緩濇，謂之解㑊，安臥脈盛，謂之脫血。尺濇脈滑，謂之多汗。尺寒脈細，謂之後泄。脈尺麤常熱者，謂之熱中。 A plentiful arm and green tendons; it is called blood letting. A slow, thin pulse, called 'separating the bones', a full resting pulse, called blood letting. A slippery pulse in the small yang channel, called much sweating. A cold and thin pulse in the small yang channel, called after urinating. A warm and constant pulse in the foot jueyin, called feverishness.

Note: This translation assumes that the text is written in classical Chinese and refers to traditional Chinese medicine concepts. The original text seems to be a description of different pulse readings and their corresponding conditions or interpretations according to traditional Chinese medicine theory.

6: 肝見庚辛死，心見壬癸死，脾見甲乙死，肺見丙丁死，腎見戊己死，是謂真藏見皆死。 The liver sees the death of yang metal and yin water, the heart sees the death of yang fire and yin earth, the spleen sees the death of yang wood and yin metal, the lung sees the death of yang earth and yin water, the kidney sees the death of yang fire and yin wood, thus all the true secrets are seen to be dead.

7: 頸脈動喘疾欬，曰水。目裏微腫如臥蠶起之狀，曰水。溺黃赤安臥者，黃疸。已食如飢者，胃疸。面腫曰風。足脛腫曰水。目黃者曰黃疸。 Pulse quick and panting, saying water. The eyes slightly swollen, like a worm emerging from its cocoon, saying water. Those who drowned and are lying down, have jaundice. Those who have already eaten but feel as if they're hungry, have stomach abscesses. Swelling of the face says wind. Swelling of the calves says water. If the eyes are yellow, it is called jaundice.

8: 婦人手少陰脈動甚者，妊子也。 A woman with a weak pulse in the palm shall be pregnant

9: 脈有逆從四時，未有藏形，春夏而脈瘦，秋冬而脈浮大，命曰逆四時也。風熱而脈靜，泄而脫血脈實，病在中，脈虛，病在外，脈濇堅者，皆難治，命曰反四時也。 The pulse follows the four seasons and has no hidden changes; in spring and summer, the pulse is thin, and in autumn and winter, it is full and large. This is called pulse according to the four seasons. When there is heat and wind, the pulse is calm; when it leaks, there is bleeding, and the pulse becomes real, the disease is inside. If the pulse is empty, the disease is outside, and if the pulse is scattered and stiff, they are all difficult to treat, called reverse the four seasons.

10: 人以水穀為本，故人絕水穀則死，脈無胃氣亦死。所謂無胃氣者，但得真藏脈不得胃氣也。所謂脈不得胃氣者，肝不弦腎不石也。太陽脈至，洪大以長；少陽脈至，乍數乍踈，乍短乍長；陽明脈至，浮大而短。夫平心脈來，累累如連珠，如循琅玕，曰心平，夏以胃氣為本。病心脈來，喘喘連屬，其中微曲，曰心病。死心脈來，前曲後居，如操帶鉤，曰心死。平肺脈來，厭厭聶聶，如落榆莢，曰肺平，秋以胃氣為本。病肺脈來，不上不下，如循雞羽，曰肺病。死肺脈來，如物之浮，如風吹毛，曰肺死。平肝脈來，耎弱招招，如揭長竿末梢，曰肝平，春以胃氣為本。病肝脈來，盈實而滑，如循長竿，曰肝病。死肝脈來，急益勁，如新張弓弦，曰肝死。平脾脈來，和柔相離，如雞踐地，曰脾平，長夏以胃氣為本。病脾脈來，實而盈數，如雞舉足，曰脾病。死脾脈來，銳堅如烏之喙，如鳥之距，如屋之漏，如水之流，曰脾死。平腎脈來，喘喘累累如鉤，按之而堅，曰腎平，冬以胃氣為本。病腎脈來，如引葛，按之益堅，曰腎病。死腎脈來，發如奪索，辟辟如彈石，曰腎死。 People rely on grain and water as their basis, so if a person lacks grain and water, they will die. If there is no Qi in the Conception Vessel (Ren Mai) but true Sea of Qi (Yuan Shen) is present, then one will still not die. When the Qi does not reach the Conception Vessel, the Liver and Kidney do not function properly. The Sun and Lesser Yin channels are long when they arrive; the Former Heaven and Latter Heaven channels are irregular in length. When the Heart channel comes evenly, like a string of pearls or a continuous jade disc, it indicates that the heart is at peace. If the channel from the heart is disordered, wheezing and unstable, it means the heart is not at ease. If the channel from the heart becomes twisted and stays in the back, it means the heart has stopped functioning. When the Lung channel arrives evenly, like fallen bamboo shoots, it indicates that the lungs are at peace. If the channel from the lungs is disordered, rising and falling unpredictably, it means the lungs are not at ease. If the channel from the lungs floats erratically, like a feather in the wind, it means the lungs have stopped functioning. When the Liver channel arrives calmly, weak and gentle, like the tip of a long staff, it indicates that the liver is at peace. If the Liver channel is full and slippery, like a long staff, it means the liver is not at ease. If the Liver channel becomes tense and forceful, like a newly stretched bowstring, it means the liver has stopped functioning. When the Spleen channel arrives evenly, soft and gentle, like a chicken's footsteps, it indicates that the spleen is at peace. If the Spleen channel is full and present, like a chicken raising its leg, it means the spleen is not at ease. If the Spleen channel becomes sharp and rigid, like a crow's beak, like a bird's distance, like a crack in a wall, like a leaking stream, it means the spleen has stopped functioning. When the Kidney channel arrives evenly, wheezing and accumulating, it indicates that the kidneys are at peace. If the channel from the kidneys is disordered, becoming increasingly rigid, it means the kidneys are not at ease. If the channel from the kidneys comes like a noose, leaping and bounding like a bouncing ball, it means the kidneys have stopped functioning.

docs.title: 玉機真藏論
docs.text:
1: 黃帝問曰：春脈如弦，何如而弦。歧伯對曰：春脈者肝也，東方木也，萬物之所以始生也，故其氣來，耎弱輕虛而滑，端直以長，故曰弦，反此者病。帝曰：何如而反。歧伯曰：其氣來實而強，此謂太過，病在外；其氣來不實而微，此謂不及，病在中。帝曰：春脈太過與不及，其病皆何如。歧伯曰：太過則令人善忘，忽忽眩冒而巔疾；其不及，則令人胸痛引背，下則兩脇胠滿。帝曰：善。 Emperor asked: What is the spring Qi like, and how is the Qi of the spring like a string? He Bo replied: The spring Qi is the liver, representing the east direction and wood, which is the source of the birth of all things. Therefore its energy comes out, strong but weak and light, subtle and slippery, upright and long, hence it is called string, and this refers to illness. Emperor asked: How is the reversed state like? He Bo said: Its Qi is strong and excessive, which means excess on the outside; its Qi is weak and faint, meaning insufficiency within. Emperor asked: What are the diseases when spring Qi is excessive or insufficient? He Bo replied: When it is excessive, it makes people prone to forgetting, dizzy and staggering with a sharp pain; when it is insufficient, it causes pain in the chest referring to the back, and below causing fullness on both sides of the waist. Emperor said: Good

2: 夏脈如鉤，何如而鉤。歧伯曰：夏脈者心也，南方火也，萬物之所以盛長也，故其氣來盛去衰，故曰鉤，反此者病。帝曰：何如而反。歧伯曰：其氣來盛去亦盛，此謂太過，病在外；其氣來不盛去反盛，此謂不及，病在中。帝曰：夏脈太過與不及，其病皆何如。歧伯曰：太過則令人身熱而膚痛，為浸淫；其不及，則令人煩心，上見欬唾，下為氣泄。帝曰：善。 The Duke of Zhou asked, If the summer pulse is like a hook, what is it like when it is otherwise? The Duke replied: Summer pulse is the heart, and the heat in the south; the source of the growth and prolongation of all things. Therefore its Qi comes and goes abundantly, hence the term 'hook.' But when it is otherwise, there is illness. The Emperor asked, What is it like when it is otherwise? The Duke replied: Its Qi also comes and goes abundantly, which is called excess, the illness being outside. When its Qi does not come and go in abundance but comes in abundance instead, this is called deficiency, the illness being inside. The Emperor asked, What are the illnesses caused by summer pulse excess and deficiency? The Duke replied: Excess causes the person to have a hot body with painful skin and itching; deficiency causes restlessness of mind, with foaming saliva above and the release of gas below. The Emperor said, Good.

3: 秋脈如浮，何如而浮。歧伯曰：秋脈者肺也，西方金也，萬物之所以收成也，故其氣來，輕虛以浮，來急去散，故曰浮，反此者病。帝曰：何如而反。歧伯曰：其氣來，毛而中央堅，兩傍虛，此謂太過，病在外；其氣來，毛而微，此謂不及，病在中。帝曰：秋脈太過與不及，其病皆何如。歧伯曰：太過則令人逆氣而背痛，慍慍然；其不及，則令人喘，呼吸少氣而欬，上氣見血，下聞病音。帝曰：善。 Emperor: The Qi of the season feels light and superficial. How does it feel when it is superficial? Obscure Scholar: The Qi of autumn is associated with the lungs, which correspond to the metal element. They are responsible for gathering the essence of all things, so when its energy arises, it is light and superficial because it comes in a hurry and then dissipates quickly. This is why it's called superficial. In this case, the person is sick. Emperor: What does it mean to be like that? Obscure Scholar: When its energy arises, it is strong in the center but weak on the left and right. This signifies an excessive condition, with the illness being external. The other possibility is when its energy arises, it is subtle, which indicates insufficiency and the illness being internal. Emperor: In cases of Qi excess or insufficiency, what does the illness feel like? Obscure Scholar: When there is an excess, it causes the person to experience discomfort and back pain. When it's insufficient, it makes the person short of breath, with a reduced intake of air, and a feeling of suffocation. In cases of excessive Qi, one may see blood when exhaling and in cases of insufficient Qi, there will be an audible sound of illness from the lower abdomen. Emperor: I understand.

4: 冬脈如營，何如而營。歧伯曰：各脈者腎也，北方水也，萬物之所以合藏也，故其氣來，沈以搏，故曰營，反此者病。帝曰：何如而反。歧伯曰：其氣來如彈石者，此謂太過，病在外；其去如數者，此謂不及，病在中。帝曰：冬脈太過與不及，其病皆何如。歧伯曰：太過，則令人解㑊，脊脈痛而少氣不欲言；其不及，則令人心懸如病飢，䏚中清，脊中痛，少腹滿，小便變。帝曰：善。 Master Qi said, The renal channels are like encampments. What is it like to be in such an encampment? The Duke asked, 'What is it like if it is reversed?' Master Qi replied, 'The energy comes like a pebble being thrown, this is called too much excess, the disease is outside. If it goes away like counting, this is called not sufficient, the disease is inside.' The Emperor asked, 'What are the diseases caused by excessive winter channels and insufficient winter channels?' Master Qi replied, 'Excessive, it causes people to be restless, with pain in the back channel and less energy, not wanting to speak. Insufficient, it causes people's hearts to hang like those with disease and hunger, cold sweat dripping down, pain in the back and fullness in the lower abdomen, frequent urination.' The Emperor said, 'Good.'

5: 帝曰：四時之序，逆從之變異也，然脾脈獨何主。歧伯曰：脾脈者土也，孤藏以灌四傍者也。帝曰：然則脾善惡，可得見之乎。歧伯曰：善者不可得見，惡者可見。帝曰：惡者何如可見。歧伯曰：其來如水之流者，此謂太過，病在外；如鳥之喙者，此謂不及，病在中。帝曰：夫子言脾為孤藏，中央土以灌四傍，其太過與不及，其病皆何如。歧伯曰：太過，則令人四支不舉；其不及，則令人九竅不通，名曰重強。帝瞿然而起，再拜而稽首曰：善。吾得脈之大要，天下至數，五色脈變，揆度奇恒，道在於一，神轉不迴，迴則不轉，及失其機，至數之要，迫近以微，著之玉版，藏之藏府，每旦讀之，名曰玉機。 Emperor: The sequence of the four seasons and the changes they bring are strange, but who governs the pulse? Duke of Shou: The pulse is the Earth, and it alone nourishes the solitary orifices to moisten the four directions. Emperor: In that case, can the good or bad pulse be seen? Duke of Shou: The good one cannot be seen, but the bad one can be. Emperor: How can the bad one be seen? Duke of Shou: It comes like a flowing stream, which indicates excessive pathogenic factors, and the illness is outside; or it comes like a bird's beak, indicating inadequate pathogenic factors, and the illness is inside. Emperor: Master, you say that the pulse represents the solitary orifices, which are nourished by Earth to moisten the four directions, and your explanation of excessive and inadequate pathogenic factors - how do these manifest in terms of illness? Duke of Shou: Excessive pathogenic factors lead to the person's limbs not being raised, while inadequate pathogenic factors lead to the person's nine orifices not being open, and this is called heavy strength. Emperor nods and stands up again, bows twice, and says: Good. I have obtained the great principle of the pulse, understanding numbers worldwide, variations in colors of the pulse, measuring the unusual and consistent, the way lies in one thing, the spirit changes without returning, returning leads to not changing, and if it loses its function, it approaches the crux of the numbers, closely observed through the subtle, sealed within the archive office, read daily, called the Jade Machine.

6: 藏受氣於其所生，傳之於其所勝，氣舍於其所生，死於其所不勝。病之且死，必先傳行至其所不勝，病乃死。此言氣之逆行也，故死。肝受氣於心，傳之於脾，氣舍於腎，至肺而死。心受氣於脾，傳之於肺，氣舍於肝，至腎而死。脾受氣於肺，傳之於腎，氣舍於心，至肝而死。肺受氣於腎，傳之於肝，氣舍於脾，至心而死。腎受氣於肝，傳之於心，氣舍於肺，至脾而死。此皆逆死也。一日一夜五分之，此所以占死生之早暮也。 What is received in the lungs and transmitted to the heart, with qi departing from the kidneys, will die at what it cannot control. Disease must first run its course at what one cannot control, and disease leads to death. This refers to the reverse flow of qi, hence death. The liver receives qi in the heart, transmits it to the spleen, qi departs from the kidneys, and dies at the lungs. The heart receives qi in the spleen, transmits it to the lungs, qi departs from the kidneys, and dies at the liver. The spleen receives qi in the lungs, transmits it to the kidneys, qi departs from the heart, and dies at the liver. The kidneys receive qi in the liver, transmit it to the heart, qi departs from the lungs, and die at the spleen. All of these are reverse deaths. Each day and night is divided into five watches, which determines whether one will die early or late.

7: 黃帝曰：五藏相通，移皆有次，五藏有病，則各傳其所勝。不治，法三月若六月，若三日若六日，傳五藏而當死，是順傳所勝之次。故曰：別於陽者，知病從來；別於陰者，知死生之期。言知至其所困而死。 Yellow Emperor said: When the Five Organs are connected, moving any one of them has a specific time, and if the Five Organs have diseases, they will pass on their respective strengths. If not treated, according to the law, it may be three months or six months, or three days or six days, passing on the Five Organs means certain death, which is the strength of the successive transmission. Therefore, he said: Separating from yang knows that the disease has always been there; separating from yin knows the time of life and death. Speaking of knowing to the point where one dies.

8: 是故風者百病之長也，今風寒客於人，使人毫毛畢直，皮膚閉而為熱，當是之時，可汗而發也；或痺不仁腫痛，當是之時，可湯熨及火灸刺而去之。弗治，病入舍於肺，名曰肺痺，發欬上氣。弗治，肺即傳而行之肝，病名曰肝痺，一名曰厥，脇痛出食，當是之時，可按若刺耳。弗治，肝傳之脾，病名曰脾風，發癉，腹中熱，煩心出黃，當此之時，可按可藥可浴。弗治，脾傳之腎，病名曰疝瘕，少腹冤熱而痛，出白，一名曰蠱，當此之時，可按可藥。弗治，腎傳之心，病筋脈相引而急，病名曰瘛，當此之時，可灸可藥。弗治，滿十日，法當死。腎因傳之心，心即復反傳而行之肺，發寒熱，法當三歲死，此病之次也。 Therefore, wind refers to a long-lasting illness. Today, cold winds affect people, causing their hair to stand on end, their skin to close and generate heat, at which time one can sweat; or there is stiffness and numbness, with swelling and pain, at which time one should use warm baths, moxibustion, and acupuncture to treat it. If not treated, the illness settles in the lungs and is called lung stiffness, accompanied by a cough. If not treated, the lung energy blocks the liver, and the disease is called liver stiffness, also known as Qi, with pain in the flanks and fullness in the abdomen; at this time, pressing around the ears can help. If not treated, the liver energy blockage passes to the spleen, and the disease is called spleen wind, with lower abdominal pain and heat, accompanied by yellow discharge, at which time pressing, herbs, and bathing can help. If not treated, the kidney energy blocks the heart, and the heart channels the energy to the lungs, causing cold and heat; if untreated, one will die at three years old, this is the sequence of the disease.

9: 然其卒發者，不必治於傳，或其傳化有不以次，不以次入者，憂恐悲喜怒，令不得以其次，故令人有大病矣。因而喜大虛則腎氣乘矣，怒則肝氣乘矣，悲則肺氣乘矣，恐則脾氣乘矣，憂則心氣乘矣，此其道也。故病有五，五五二十五變，及其傳化。傳，乘之名也。 Those who are suddenly enlightened should not be treated according to tradition, as the tradition may become outdated or misunderstood. If one's emotions include sorrow, joy, anger, and fear, they will not be able to control their own nature, and thus they will fall ill. This is why people who experience sudden enlightenment often develop serious illnesses. Since joy causes the vital energy of the kidneys to rise, anger causes the vital energy of the liver to rise, sorrow causes the vital energy of the lungs to rise, fear causes the vital energy of the spleen to rise, and worry causes the vital energy of the heart to rise, this is their nature. Thus, illnesses arise in five types, with each type having five variations, and these are related to tradition and change. The term transmission refers to influencing.

10: 大骨枯槀，大肉陷下，胸中氣滿，喘息不便，其氣動形，期六月死，真藏脈見，乃予之期日。大骨枯槀，大肉陷下，胸中氣滿，喘息不便，內痛引肩項，期一月死，真藏見，乃予之期日。大骨枯槀，大肉陷下，胸中氣滿，喘息不便，內痛引肩項，期一月死，真藏見，乃予之期日。大骨枯槀，大肉陷下，胸中氣滿，喘息不便，內痛引肩項，身熱脫肉破䐃，真藏見，十月之內死。大骨枯槀，大肉陷下，肩髓內消，動作益衰，真藏來見，期一歲死，見其真藏，乃予之期日。大骨枯槀，大肉陷下，胸中氣滿，腹內痛，心中不便，肩項身熱，破䐃脫肉，目匡陷，真藏見，目不見人，立死，其見人者，至其所不勝之時則死。急虛身中卒至，五藏絕閉，脈道不通，氣不往來，譬於墮溺，不可為期。其脈絕不來，若人一息五六至，其形肉不脫，真藏雖不見，猶死也。真肝脈至，中外急，如循刀刃責責然，如按琴瑟弦，色青白不澤，毛折，乃死。真心脈至，堅而搏，如循薏苡子累累然，色赤黑不澤，毛折，乃死。真肺脈至，大而虛，如以毛羽中人膚，色白赤不澤，毛折，乃死。真腎脈至，搏而絕，如指彈石辟辟然，色黑黃不澤，毛折，乃死。真脾脈至，弱而乍數乍踈，色黃青不澤，毛折，乃死。諸真藏脈見者，皆死，不治也。黃帝曰：見真藏曰死，何也。歧伯曰：五藏者，皆稟氣於胃，胃者，五藏之本也，藏氣者，不能自致於手太陰，必因於胃氣，乃至於手太陰也，故五藏各以其時，自為而至於手太陰也。故邪氣勝者，精氣衰也，故病甚者，胃氣不能與之俱至於手太陰，故真藏之氣獨見，獨見者病勝藏也，故曰死。帝曰：善。 Translation: Large bones and dry tendons, the flesh sunken, full of gas in the chest, panting difficult, the motion of the energy is about six months to death, seeing the true Qi. Big bone and dry tendon, the flesh sunken, full of gas in the chest, panting difficult, internal pain referring to the shoulder and collarbone, about one month to death, seeing the true Qi. Large bone and dry tendon, the flesh sunken, full of gas in the chest, panting difficult, internal pain referring to the shoulder and collarbone, one month to death, seeing the true Qi. Big bones and dry tendons, large muscles and tendons rupture, fever skin peeling, true Qi seen, died within ten months. Large bone and dry tendon, the muscles in the

11: 黃帝曰：凡治病，察其形氣色澤，脈之盛衰，病之新故，乃治之無後其時。形氣相得，謂之可治；色澤以浮，謂之易已；脈從四時，謂之可治；脈弱以滑，是有胃氣，命曰易治，取之以時。形氣相失，謂之難治；色夭不澤，謂之難已；脈實以堅，謂之益甚；脈逆四時，為不可治。必察四難，而明告之。所謂逆四時者，春得肺脈，夏得腎脈，秋得心脈，冬得脾脈，其至皆懸絕沈濇者，命曰逆四時。未有藏形，於春夏而脈沈濇，秋冬而脈浮大，名曰逆四時也。病熱脈靜，泄而脈大，脫血而脈實，病在中脈實堅，病在外，脈不實堅者，皆難治。 Emperor Yellow said: When treating illness, one must examine the patient's appearance, vital energy, color and complexion, pulse strength and weakness, and the new or old stage of the disease before beginning treatment. If the appearance and vital energy are harmonious, it is treatable; if the color and complexion are bright, it is easily cured; if the pulses correspond to the four seasons, it is treatable; if the pulse is weak and slippery, there is stomach qi, and it is called easy to cure. Take advantage of the opportunity when the time is right. If the appearance and vital energy are not harmonious, it is difficult to treat; if the color and complexion are withered and not bright, it is difficult to cure; if the pulse is strong and firm, it means there is much disease; if the pulse is opposite the four seasons, it is incurable. Carefully observe the four difficulties and report them clearly. The so-called opposite four seasons refers to the spring when the lung pulse is present, summer when the kidney pulse is present, autumn when the heart pulse is present, and winter when the spleen pulse is present. All cases where the pulse is sunken and weak in spring and summer, and floating large in autumn and winter are called the opposite four seasons. If there is no consolidation of form, and if the pulse is sunken and weak in spring and summer, and floating large in autumn and winter, it is called the opposite four seasons. In cases where the disease is hot and the pulse is calm, sweating with a large pulse, bleeding with a real pulse, or having a strong and firm pulse inside and a weak and unstable pulse outside, all are difficult to treat.

12: 黃帝曰：余聞虛實以決死生，願聞其情。歧伯曰：五實死，五虛死。帝曰：願聞五實五虛。歧伯曰：脈盛，皮熱，腹脹，前後不通，悶瞀，此謂五實。脈細，皮寒，氣少，泄利前後，飲食不入，此謂五虛。帝曰：其時有生者，何也。歧伯曰：漿粥入胃，泄注止，則虛者活；身汗得後利，則實者活。此其候也。 The Yellow Emperor said: I have heard that the distinction between real and false determines life and death, and I wish to hear about its nature. Hui Bo said: Five things are real in death, five things are false in death. Emperor said: I wish to hear about the five real and five false. Hui Bo said: Pulse full, skin hot, abdomen bloated, front and back not connected, restlessness, these are called the five real. Pulse thin, skin cold, qi deficient, leakage of the front and back, food and drink do not enter, these are called the five false. Emperor said: At that time, what is life? Hui Bo said: If rice gruel enters the stomach and leakage stops, then the empty ones will live; if the body sweats and gets posterior discharge, then the full ones will live. This is the opportunity.

docs.title: 上古天真論
docs.text:
1: 昔在黃帝，生而神靈，弱而能言，幼而徇齊，長而敦敏，成而登天。迺問於天師曰：余聞上古之人，春秋皆度百歲，而動作不衰；今時之人，年半百而動作皆衰者，時世異耶，人將失之耶？歧伯對曰：上古之人，其知道者，法於陰陽，和於術數，食飲有節，起居有常，不妄作勞，故能形與神俱，而盡終其天年，度百歲乃去。今時之人不然也，以酒為漿，以妄為常，醉以入房，以欲竭其精，以耗散其真，不知持滿，不時御神，務快其心，逆於生樂，起居無節，故半百而衰也。 In ancient times, during the Yellow Emperor's era, there was an individual born with exceptional spiritual prowess. Though weak at birth, he could speak fluently, as a young child he imitated Qi, growing up he showed great intelligence and wisdom, and in his later years, ascended to the level of a sage.

He questioned the Master of Heaven, saying: I have heard that people from ancient times, during the Spring and Autumn period, lived to be over one hundred years old without decaying physically. However, people today, even if they live to be fifty years old, show signs of decay. Is this not a sign of the times? Are people soon to lose this ability?

The Duke replied: In ancient times, those who understood the way of life, relied on the principles of Yin and Yang, harmonized their actions with the arts of numerology, maintained discipline in diet and dwelling, avoided unnecessary labor, and as a result were able to sustain both their bodies and spirits, reaching their full lifespan of one hundred years before passing. People today do not follow this path; they rely on wine as glue, indulge in frivolous behavior, become intoxicated in their chambers, exhaust their essence through lust, and dissipate their true nature through excessive activity, without understanding the importance of preserving their vital energy, failing to govern their spirits properly, and hastening their decline. This is why people today, even if they live to be fifty years old, show signs of decay.

2: 夫上古聖人之教下也，皆謂之虛邪賊風，避之有時，恬惔虛无，真氣從之，精神內守，病安從來。是以志閑而少欲，心安而不懼，形勞而不倦，氣從以順，各從其欲，皆得所願。故美其食，任其服，樂其俗，高下不相慕，其民故曰朴。是以嗜欲不能勞其目，淫邪不能惑其心，愚智賢不肖不懼於物，故合於道。所以能年皆度百歲，而動作不衰者，以其德全不危也。 Since ancient sages' teaching, all referred to it as empty, evil, counterfeit wind, avoiding it at times, being tranquil and empty-minded, following the genuine energy, guarding the spirit within, health coming by itself. Therefore, cherishing desires but keeping one's willpower in check, having a peaceful mind without fear, exerting oneself physically but not becoming weary, following one's own inclinations, all getting what they wish. Thus, praising their food, allowing their medicine, enjoying their customs, not coveting high or low positions, the people of this country call it primitive. This is why desire cannot exhaust their eyesight, lust and evil cannot confuse their minds, ignorance of wisdom but sages do not fear things, so they follow the Dao. Therefore, able to live long, all reaching a hundred years, with movements not decaying, this is because their virtue is complete and not in danger also.

3: 帝曰：人年老而無子者，材力盡邪，將天數然也。歧伯曰：女子七歲，腎氣盛，齒更髮長；二七而天癸至，任脈通，太衝脈盛，月事以時下，故有子；三七，腎氣平均，故真牙生而長極；四七，筋骨堅，髮長極，身體盛壯；五七，陽明脈衰，面始焦，髮始墮；六七，三陽脈衰於上，面皆焦，髮始白；七七，任脈虛，太衝脈衰少，天癸竭，地道不通，故形壞而無子也。丈夫八歲，腎氣實，髮長齒更；二八，腎氣盛，天癸至，精氣溢寫，陰陽和，故能有子；三八，腎氣平均，筋骨勁強，故真牙生而長極；四八，筋骨隆盛，肌肉滿壯；五八，腎氣衰，髮墮齒槁；六八，陽氣衰竭於上，面焦，髮鬢頒白；七八，肝氣衰，筋不能動，天癸竭，精少，腎藏衰，形體皆極；八八，則齒髮去，腎者主水，受五藏六府之精而藏之，故五藏盛，乃能寫。今五藏皆衰，筋骨解墮，天癸盡矣。故髮鬢白，身體重，行步不正，而無子耳。帝曰：有其年已老而有子者何也。歧伯曰：此其天壽過度，氣脈常通，而腎氣有餘也。此雖有子，男不過盡八八，女不過盡七七，而天地之精氣皆竭矣。帝曰：夫道者年皆百數，能有子乎。歧伯曰：夫道者能卻老而全形，身年雖壽，能生子也。 Emperor said: A person becomes old without offspring, and their vital energy has been exhausted, just as their time is about to end. Duke said: A girl is seven years old, her kidney energy is flourishing, her teeth change and hair grows long; at 27 when the heaven's stems are Jīn, the conduits are open, the Greater Yín and Lesser Yǐn vessels have abundant energy, and the menstruation occurs regularly, so there will be offspring. At 37, the kidney energy is balanced, so true teeth grow and become extremely long; at 47, the tendons and bones are strong, hair grows extremely long, and the body is vigorous; at 57, the Yang Míng vessels decline, the face becomes dull, and hair starts to fall out. At 67, the three Yang vessels decline in the upper part, the face becomes dull, and hair starts to turn white. At 77, the conduits are empty, the Greater Yín and Lesser Yǐn vessels decline somewhat, the heaven's stems have reached their limit, and the earthly paths are not open, so the body deteriorates and there is no offspring. A man at eight years old has kidney energy that is flourishing, his hair grows long and his teeth change; at 28, the kidney energy is abundant when the heaven's stems are Jīn, and the essence energy overflows, the Yin and Yang are harmonious, so there can be offspring. At 38, the kidney energy is balanced, the tendons and bones have strong power, so true teeth grow and become extremely long; at 48, the tendons and bones are flourishing, the muscles are full and vigorous; at 58, the kidney energy declines, hair falls out and teeth weaken; at 68, the Yang energy declines in the upper part, the face becomes dull, and hair turns white. At 78, the liver energy declines, tendons cannot move, the heaven's stems have reached their limit, and essence is scarce, the kidney vessels decline, so the body deteriorates completely and there is no offspring. Emperor asked: Why can a person still have offspring when they are old? Duke said: This is because their lifespan exceeded what was destined, and their conduits remain open, while their kidney energy has some remaining. Although there are offspring, boys do not exceed eight at eight years old, and girls do not exceed seven at seven years old, and the essence energy of heaven and earth has been exhausted. Emperor asked: If the Dao exists, can a person have offspring when they are one hundred? Duke said: The Dao enables one to age while still maintaining their body's integrity, even though their lifespan is one hundred, they can have offspring.

4: 黃帝曰：余聞上古有真人者，提挈天地，把握陰陽，呼吸精氣，獨立守神，肌肉若一，故能壽敝天地，无有終時，此其道生。中古之時，有至人者，淳德全道，和於陰陽，調於四時，去世離俗，積精全神，游行天地之間，視聽八達之外，此蓋益其壽命而強者也，亦歸於真人。其次有聖人者，處天地之和，從八風之理，適嗜欲於世俗之間，无恚嗔之心，行不欲離於世，被服章，舉不欲觀於俗，外不勞形於事，內无思想之患，以恬愉為務，以自得為功，形體不敝，精神不散，亦可以百數。其次有賢人者，法則天地，象似日月，辯列星辰，逆從陰陽，分別四時，將從上古合同於道，亦可使益壽而有極時。 Yellow Emperor said: I have heard that in ancient times, there were true beings who held up Heaven and Earth, controlled Yin and Yang, breathed the divine qi, stood alone guarding the gods, their muscles as one, thus they could nourish and sustain Heaven and Earth, without an end, this is the beginning of their way. In ancient times, there were excellent people, pure virtue, complete the Way, harmonious with Yin and Yang, regulated by the four seasons, departed from worldly desires, accumulating qi and refining their spirit, roaming between Heaven and Earth, seeing and hearing beyond the eight limits, this is indeed to strengthen their life and longevity, also returning to true beings. Next are sages who dwell in harmony with Heaven and Earth, follow the principles of the eight winds, adapt their desires within worldly affairs, without resentment or anger in their hearts, they act without desiring to leave the world, wear but do not show off, lift but do not want to be seen in worldliness, externally not laboring their bodies in matters, internally without troubled thoughts, cherishing tranquility as their duty, and self-realization as their achievement, their body and spirit do not decay, and they can also extend their lives by hundreds. There are also wise people who follow the laws of Heaven and Earth, resembling the sun and moon, differentiating stars and constellations, following Yin and Yang, dividing the four seasons, joining from ancient times to combine with the Way, also able to strengthen their longevity and have an extreme limit.

docs.title: 三部九候論
docs.text:
1: 黃帝問曰：余聞九鍼於夫子，眾多博大，不可勝數。余願聞要道，以屬子孫，傳之後世，著之骨髓，藏之肝肺，歃血而受，不敢妄泄，令合天道，必有終始，上應天光星辰歷紀，下副四時五行，貴賤更互，冬陰夏陽，以人應之奈何，願聞其方。歧伯對曰：妙乎哉問也！此天地之至數。帝曰：願聞天地之至數，合於人形，血氣通，決死生，為之奈何。歧伯曰：天地之至數，始於一，終於九焉。一者天，二者地，三者人，因而三之，三三者九，以應九野。故人有三部，部有三候，以決死生，以處百病，以調虛實，而除邪疾。 Emperor asked: I have heard that the Nine Needles from Confucius are abundant and vast, impossible to count. I wish to hear about the true method, which belongs to Father and Son, passed down to future generations, embedded in bone marrow, hidden in liver and lungs, drained of blood and endured, not daring to reveal frivolously, connecting with the celestial principle, there must be an ultimate beginning, above following the light of heaven, stars, and constellations recording history, below assisting the four seasons and five elements, nobility and lowliness alternating, winter as yin and summer as yang, how should people respond to this? The Duke answered: What a profound question! This concerns the ultimate number of heaven and earth. Emperor asked: I wish to hear about the ultimate number of heaven and earth, connecting with human form, blood and qi circulating, determining life and death, how should it be done? The Duke said: The ultimate number of heaven and earth begins with one and ends with nine. One is heaven, two is earth, three is humanity, thus leading to three, and the three threes become nine, in response to the nine wildernesses. Therefore, humans have three parts, each part has three stages, determining life and death, treating a hundred diseases, adjusting between emptiness and reality, and eliminating deviant illnesses.

2: 帝曰：何謂三部。歧伯曰：有下部，有中部，有上部，部各有三候，三候者，有天有地有人也，必指而導之，乃以為真。上部天，兩額之動脈；上部地，兩額之動脈；上部人，耳前之動脈。中部天，手太陰也；中部地，手陽明也；中部人，手少陰也。下部天，足厥陰也；下部地，足少陰也；下部人，足太陰也。故下部之天以候肝，地以候腎，人以候脾胃之氣。帝曰：中部之候奈何。歧伯曰：亦有天，亦有地，亦有人。天以候肺，地以候胸中之氣，人以候心。帝曰：上部以何候之。歧伯曰：亦有天，亦有地，亦有人，天以候頭角之氣，地以候口齒之氣，人以候耳目之氣。三部者，各有天，各有地，各有人。三而成天，三而成地，三而成人，三而三之，合則為九，九分為九野，九野為九藏。故神藏五，形藏四，合為九藏。五藏已敗，其色必夭，夭必死矣。帝曰：以候奈何。歧伯曰：必先度其形之肥瘦，以調其氣之虛實，實則寫之，虛則補之。必先去其血脈而後調之，無問其病，以平為期。 The sovereign asked, What is meant by the Three Departments? The Duke of Shou replied, There are lower, middle, and upper departments. In each department, there are three candidates: heaven, earth, and man. These are led and guided accordingly, thereby considered to be true.

The upper department of heaven corresponds to the greater yin, the governing vessel; the upper department of earth corresponds to the greater yang, the conception vessel; and the upper department of man corresponds to the yin channel of the face.

The middle department of heaven corresponds to the hand Taiyin (medial), the lung; the middle department of earth corresponds to the hand Yangming (bright), the heart; and the middle department of man corresponds to the hand Shaoyin (lesser yin), the spleen and stomach.

The lower department of heaven corresponds to the foot Wei (towards the sun) and corresponds to the candidate bladder; the lower department of earth corresponds to the foot Shaoyang (lesser yang), the kidneys; and the lower department of man corresponds to the foot Taiyang (greater yang), the gallbladder.

Thus, the lower department of heaven governs the liver through the candidate, the lower department of earth governs the kidneys through the candidate, and the lower department of man governs the spleen and stomach through the candidate.

The sovereign asked, How about the middle department? The Duke of Shou replied, There are also heaven, earth, and man. Heaven corresponds to the candidate lung, earth corresponds to the chest qi, and man corresponds to the heart.

The sovereign asked, What candidates are there for the upper department? The Duke of Shou replied, There are also heaven, earth, and man. Heaven corresponds to the head yang channel, earth corresponds to the mouth and teeth channel, and man corresponds to the eye-ear channel.

The Three Departments each have their own heaven, earth, and man. Three make one heaven, three make one earth, three make one man, three threes become nine, which are divided into nine orifices, and the nine orifices house the nine storage areas. Therefore, the spiritual storage areas combine to form the nine storage areas. When the five storage areas have been defeated, their colors will wither, leading to death.

The sovereign asked, What is the prognosis? The Duke of Shou replied, First, one must adjust the patient's body weight and regulate their qi, whether it is deficient or excessive. One must first eliminate the blood vessels before regulating, without inquiring about the disease, with restoration as the goal.

3: 帝曰：決死生奈何。歧伯曰：形盛脈細，少氣不足以息者，危。形瘦脈大，胸中多氣者，死。形氣相得者，生。參伍不調者，病。三部九候皆相失者，死。上下左右之脈相應如參舂者，病甚。上下左右相失不可數者，死。中部之候雖獨調，與眾藏相失者，死。中部之候相減者，死。目內陷者死。帝曰：何以知病之所在。歧伯曰：察九候獨小者，病，獨大者，病，獨疾者，病，獨遲者，病，獨熱者，病，獨寒者，病，獨陷下者，病。以左手足上，上去踝五寸按之，庶右手足當踝而彈之，其應過五寸以上，蠕蠕然者，不病；其應疾，中手渾渾然者，病；中手徐徐然者，病；其應上不能至五寸，彈之不應者，死。是以脫肉身不去者，死。中部乍踈乍數者，死。其脈代而鉤者，病在絡脈。九候之相應也，上下若一，不得相失。一候後則病，二候後則病甚，三候後則病危。所謂後者，應不俱也。察其府藏，以知死生之期。 Emporer said: What shall be done in case of certain death? Huang Di replied: If the body is robust but the pulse is weak, thin, and there is not enough qi to breathe, it's dangerous. If the body is emaciated, the pulse is strong and the chest is full of qi, it will lead to death. If the body and pulse are in balance, it will live. If the qi and the blood are not harmonious, it will be sick. If all three zang organs, nine shu organs fail, it will lead to death. If the qi and blood of all four limbs are harmonized like needles grinding against each other, it's serious. If the qi and blood of the body are completely lost, it will lead to death. If the zang organs in the middle are alone well balanced but fail to connect with other organs, it will lead to death. If the zang organs in the middle are alone weakened, it will lead to death. If the eyes sink, it leads to death. Emporer asked: How do you know where the disease is located? Huang Di replied: Check the nine orifices, if there's something alone that's too small, it's sick. If it's alone and too large, it's sick. If it's alone and moving quickly, it's sick. If it's alone and moving slowly, it's sick. If it's alone and hot, it's sick. If it's alone and cold, it's sick. If it's alone and sunken below, it's sick. Press with the left hand above the ankle, go five inches down, then press with the right hand above the ankle and pluck, if it reaches over five inches and is wriggling, it's not sick. If it's too quick, the middle pulse is full of qi, it's sick. If the middle pulse is slow, it's sick. If it can't reach above five inches, plucking isn't right, it's dead. Therefore, peeling off the flesh will not lead to death. If there are irregularities in the middle, it's dead. If the pulse stops and forms a knot, the disease is in the vessels. The nine orifices should be harmonious, up and down should not fail. If one of them is late, it leads to sickness. If two of them are late, it leads to serious sickness. If three of them are late, it leads to life-threatening illness. To refer to being late means that the pulse isn't all complete. Examine its storehouse, and know its time for life or death

4: 必先知經脈，然後知病脈，真藏脈見者，勝死。足太陽氣絕者，其足不可屈伸，死必戴眼。帝曰：冬陰夏陽奈何。歧伯曰：九候之脈，皆沈細懸絕者為陰，主冬，故以夜半死。盛躁喘數者為陽，主夏，故以日中死。是故寒熱病者，以平旦死。熱中及熱病者，以日中死。病風者，以日夕死。病水者，以夜半死。其脈乍踈乍數乍遲乍疾者，日乘四季死。形肉已脫，九候雖調，猶死。七診雖見，九候皆從者不死。所言不死者，風氣之病，及經月之病，似七診之病，而非也，故言不死。若有七診之病，其脈候亦敗者，死矣，必發噦噫。必審問其所始病，與今之所方病，而後各切循其脈，視其經絡浮沈，以上下逆從循之，其脈疾者不病，其脈遲者病，脈不往來者，死，皮膚著者，死。 One must first know the channels and then know the pulse. One who can see the hidden channel is victorious over death. If the foot Yang Qi is blocked, the foot cannot be bent or stretched, and death will come with the eyes popping out. The Emperor asked about yin and yang in summer and winter. Taoist master Guan Ping said: The nine signs of the pulse are all deep, thin, and suspended when they are blocked, so yin dominates winter and causes death at midnight. The agitated, panting, and hot people are yang and dominate summer, causing death at noon. Therefore, cold and hot diseases are treated with dawn, hot diseases and fever are treated with noon, diseases caused by wind are treated with dusk, diseases caused by fluids are treated with midnight. The pulse is sometimes intermittent, sometimes continuous, sometimes slow, or fast. People who have these pulses will die in the four seasons. Even after the body has shed its form and flesh, if the nine signs are properly adjusted, it will still result in death. If the seven examinations are seen, but the nine signs do not follow this, they will not die. The one who speaks of not dying refers to diseases caused by wind and uterine bleeding, which resemble diseases treated by the seven examinations, but are not the same. Therefore, it is said that if there is a disease treated by the seven examinations and the nine signs have been ruined, death will certainly occur and there will be groans of anguish. One must carefully investigate the beginning of the illness and the current state of the disease, then cut according to the pulse, observe the flow and sinking of the channels, follow their rise and fall, up and down, in and out. The fast pulse is not sick, the slow pulse is sick, the pulse that does not come and go is dead, and the skin covered with blisters is dead.

5: 帝曰：其可治者奈何。歧伯曰：經病者治其經，孫絡病者治其孫絡血，血病身有痛者，治其經絡。其病者在奇邪，奇邪之脈則繆刺之。留瘦不移，節而刺之。上實下虛，切而從之，索其結絡脈，刺出其血，以見通之。瞳子高者，太陽不足，戴眼者，太陽已絕，此決死生之要，不可不察也。手指及手外踝上五指，留鍼。 The emperor asked, What of one who can be governed? Zhòu Bó replied, One with illnesses of the meridians should be treated according to their meridians. One with bleeding in the sinews should be treated according to the bleeding in the sinews. For one whose body is afflicted by pain due to bleeding, treat them according to their meridians and sinews. For those who are ill in strange and abnormal ways, the strange and abnormal meridian shall be punctured. Leave the needle in place without moving it, adjust it as needed, insert the needle deeply, follow the meridian and sinew to find where they have knotted and are blocked, extract the blood by puncturing, and observe the pathway. For those with eyes that are sunken, this indicates insufficiency of the Yángqì, and for one who wears eyeglasses, the Yángqì has already ceased, which is decisive of life and death and cannot be overlooked. Among the fingers and the outer corner of the foot, insert five needles and leave them in place.

docs.title: 經脈別論
docs.text:
1: 黃帝問曰：人之居處動靜勇怯，脈亦為之變乎。歧伯對曰：凡人之驚恐恚勞動靜，皆為變也。是以夜行則喘出於腎，淫氣病肺。有所墮恐，喘出於肝，淫氣害脾。有所驚恐，喘出於肺，淫氣傷心。度水跌仆，喘出於腎與骨，當是之時，勇者氣行則已，怯者則著而為病也。故曰：診病之道，觀人勇怯骨肉皮膚，能知其情，以為診法也。故飲食飽甚，汗出於胃。驚而奪精，汗出於心。持重遠行，汗出於腎。疾走恐懼，汗出於肝。搖體勞苦，汗出於脾。故春秋冬夏，四時陰陽，生病起於過用，此為常也。 Yellow Emperor asked, People's dwelling places and activities are both dynamic and still, courageous and timid; does the pulse also change accordingly? The Grand Perfecter replied, In general, people's shock, fear, and exhaustion in response to their activities all constitute changes. Thus, when practicing martial arts at night, one may gasp from the kidneys, causing kidney energy to damage the lungs. If one experiences a fall or feels afraid, one may gasp from the liver, causing liver energy to harm the spleen. When experiencing shock or fear, one may gasp from the lungs, causing liver energy to injure the heart. Falling into water or tripping may cause gasping from both the kidneys and bones, at which point, if one is courageous, their vital energy will circulate properly, but if one is timid, they will become ill. Therefore, it is said that diagnosing illness involves observing a person's courage, timidity, flesh, skin, and being able to discern their condition to prescribe treatment. Thus, when one overeats or drinks, sweat may emerge from the stomach. When shocked, one loses vital energy, causing sweat to emerge from the heart. When carrying heavy loads and walking far, sweat may emerge from the kidneys. When rushing in fear or panic, sweat may emerge from the liver. When exhausted from physical exertion, sweat may emerge from the spleen. In spring, summer, autumn, and winter, the changing yin and yang of the four seasons give rise to illness, which is a constant occurrence.

2: 食氣入胃，散精於肝，淫氣於筋。淫氣入胃，濁氣歸心，淫精於脈。脈氣流經，經氣歸於肺，肺朝百脈，輸精於皮毛。毛脈合精，行氣於腑。腑精神明，留於四臟，氣歸於椎衡。權衡以平，氣口成寸，以決死生。飲入於胃，遊溢精氣，上輸於脾。脾氣散精，上歸於肺，通調水道，下輸膀胱。水精四布，五經並行，合於四時五臟陰陽，揆度以為常也。 Food Qi enters the stomach, disperses essence in the liver, and dissipates lewd Qi in the muscles. Lewd Qi enters the stomach, turbid Qi returns to the heart, and lewd essence in the vessels. Vessel Qi circulates throughout the body, and lung Qi returns to the lungs, connecting with the hundred vessels and nourishing the skin and hair. Hair vessels join essence, regulating Qi in the liver. The liver spirit is enlightened, residing in the four organs, and Qi returns to the vertebral plexus. The vertebral plexus balances and establishes the meridians, leading to the formation of an inch of Qi, and deciding life and death. Drinking enters the stomach, circulating essence and Qi, ascending and nourishing the spleen. Spleen Qi disperses essence, rising to the lungs, regulating the waterways, and descending to nourish the bladder. Essence spreads in the five pathways, with the five organs aligning in pairs according to yin and yang, regulating with the seasons, establishing constancy.

3: 太陽藏獨至，厥喘虛氣逆，是陰不足陽有餘也，表裏當俱寫，取之下俞。陽明藏獨至，是陽氣重并也，當寫陽補陰，取之下俞。少陽藏獨至，是厥氣也，蹻前卒大，取之下俞，少陽獨至者，一陽之過也。太陰藏搏者，用心省真，五脈氣少，胃氣不平，三陰也，宜治其下俞，補陽寫陰。一陽獨嘯，少陽厥也，陽并於上，四脈爭張，氣歸於腎，宜治其經絡，寫陽補陰。一陰至，厥陰之治也，真虛㾓心，厥氣留薄，發為白汗，調食和藥，治在下俞。 When the sun is hidden and alone, when the breath is weak and the energy is reversed, it is because yin is insufficient and yang has excess. Both inside and outside should be written, and the treatment is to supplement yin with moxa below. When the light of yang is hidden and alone, it is because yang energy is strong and dense. It should be written to supplement yin and treat with moxa below. When the lesser yang is hidden and alone, it is the energy of the kidneys, crippled in front, large treatment with moxa below. When the lesser yang is alone, it is the deficiency of one yang. The great yin is difficult to grasp, five vessels are weak, the stomach qi is not stable, and it is the three yins. It should be treated at the lower jiao, supplementing yang with moxa. One yang alone, lesser yang, yang is concentrated above, the four vessels struggle to stretch, the qi returns to the kidneys, and it should be treated by regulating the channels and meridians, supplementing yin. When one yin is present, it is a treatment for the kidneys. The heart is true and false, pondering, the kidney energy is thin, sweating white sweat, regulate the diet and take medicine, treating at the lower jiao.

4: 帝曰：太陽藏何象。歧伯曰：象三陽而浮也。帝曰：少陽藏何象。歧伯曰：象一陽也，一陽藏者，滑而不實也。帝曰：陽明藏何象。歧伯曰：象大浮也，太陰藏搏，言伏鼓也。二陰搏至，腎沈不浮也。 The Emperor asked, What does the sun hide? Duke Huan replied, The sun hides the image of three yangs and one floating yang. The hidden yang is a small, insubstantial yang. The Emperor asked, What does Yang Ming hide? Duke Huan replied, It hides the image of a great floating yang. The Yin hides struggle, indicating the hiding of the drum. When the two yins reach their limit, the kidneys sink and do not float.

docs.title: 藏氣法時論
docs.text:
1: 黃帝問曰：合人形以法四時五行而治，何如而從，何如而逆，得失之意，願聞其事。歧伯對曰：五行者，金木水火土也，更貴更賤，以知死生，以決成敗，而定五藏之氣，間甚之時，死生之期也。帝曰：願卒聞之。歧伯曰：肝主春，足厥陰少陽主治，其日甲乙，肝苦急，急食甘以緩之。心主夏，手少陰太陽主治，其日丙丁，心苦緩，急食酸以收之。脾主長夏，足太陰陽明主治，其日戊己，脾苦濕，急食甘以緩之。心主夏，手少陰太陽主治，其日丙丁，心苦緩，急食酸以收之。脾主長夏，足太陰陽明主治，其日戊己，脾苦濕，急食苦以燥之。肺主秋，手太陰陽明主治，其日庚辛，肺苦氣上逆，急食苦以泄之。腎主冬，足少陰太陽主治，其日壬癸，腎苦燥，急食辛以潤之，開腠理，致津液，通氣也。 Yellow Emperor asked, Treating with the Five Phases of the Five Activities in order to regulate, what is it like following this approach and what is it like going against it? What is the intention of success or failure? I want to hear about this matter. The Duke answered, The Five Phases are gold, wood, water, fire, and earth. More exalted and more base, used to know life and death, used to determine success and failure, and to govern the five organs' energy, at a critical time, for life and death periods. Emperor said, I want to hear this quickly. The Duke said, The liver governs spring, the foot's yin and yang of the treatment govern treat, its days are yin and yang. The liver is bitter and urgent, eat sweet to moderate. The heart governs summer, the hand's yin of the great Yang govern treat, its days are bing and ding. The heart is bitter and slow, eat sour to collect. The spleen governs long summer, the foot's yin and Yang Ming of the treatment govern treat, its days are wood and metal. The spleen is bitter and damp, eat sweet to moderate. The heart governs summer, the hand's yin of the great Yang govern treat, its days are bing and ding. The heart is bitter and slow, eat sour to collect. The spleen governs long summer, the foot's yin and Yang Ming of the treatment govern treat, its days are wood and metal. The spleen is bitter and damp, eat bitter to dry. The lung governs autumn, the hand's yin and Yang Ming of the treatment govern treat, its days are metal and water. The lung is bitter and qi upward invasion, eat bitter to release. Kidney governs winter, the foot's yin of the great Yang govern treat, its days are water and wood. The kidney is bitter and dry, eat spicy to moisten, open channels, regulate fluid, pass gas.

2: 病在肝，愈於夏，夏不愈，甚於秋，秋不死，持於冬，起於春，禁當風。肝病者，愈在丙丁，丙丁不愈，加於庚辛，庚辛不死，持於壬癸，起於甲乙。肝病者，平旦慧，下晡甚，夜半靜。肝欲散，急食辛以散之，用辛補之，酸寫之。 The illness is in the liver, cured in summer, but not cured in summer, much worse in autumn, not dying in autumn, sustained in winter, reviving in spring, prohibited by wind. For those with liver disease, they will be cured in yang meridian (Jupiter and Mars), but if not cured in Jupiter and Mars, reinforce with kidney meridian (Rabbit and Dragon), but if not dying, sustained in metal meridian (Water Rat and Water Ox), reviving in wood meridian (Tiger and Rabbit). For those with liver disease, the best time is at dawn, the most critical time is at noon, and the quietest time is midnight. If the liver desires to disperse, eat pungent food to disperse it and use pungent food to supplement it, and write sour to help it.

3: 病在心，愈在長夏，長夏不愈，甚於冬，冬不死，持於春，起於夏，禁溫食熱衣。心病者，愈在戊己，戊己不愈，加於壬癸，壬癸不死，持於甲乙，起於丙丁。心病者，日中慧，夜半甚，平旦靜。心欲耎，急食鹹以耎之，用鹹補之，甘寫之。 The illness is in the heart, and it gets worse during the long summer. The long summer does not improve; rather, it's even worse than winter. Winter doesn't kill, and it continues into spring, starting anew in summer. To treat this condition, one should follow a regimen of moderate temperature, food, and clothing. For those with heart illnesses, recovery occurs during the years of Earth (Wu) and Metal (Jin), but if there is no recovery in Earth and Metal, it can be sustained in Yin Wood (Jia and Geng) and emerge in Yang Wood (Bing and Ding). A person with a heart condition will feel more acute symptoms during the daytime and have relief at midnight. At dawn, they should be quiet. If the heart is troubled, one should eat salty food to calm it, use salt as a supplement, and also consume sweet substances.

4: 病在脾，愈在秋，秋不愈，甚於春，春不死，持於夏，起於長夏，禁溫食飽食濕地濡衣。脾病者，愈在庚辛，庚辛不愈，加於甲乙，甲乙不死，持於丙丁，起於戊己。脾病者，日昳慧，日出甚，下晡靜。脾欲緩，急食甘以緩之，用苦寫之，甘補之。 The illness is in the spleen, and recovery comes in autumn. If not recovered by autumn, it is more severe than spring, and if not cured by spring, it persists through summer, beginning in the long summer season. One must avoid hot and humid places, wear dry clothes, refrain from excessive eating and drinking, and maintain a temperate diet. For spleen diseases that do not recover in the period of Metal (Gengxin), add Wood (JiaYi) to the treatment, but if it still does not cure, continue with Fire (BingDing), starting in Soil (WuYin). Those who are ill should rise early and retire early. If the spleen is weak, eat sweet foods to strengthen it, use bitter foods to regulate it, and use sour foods as a supplement.

5: 病在肺，愈在冬，冬不愈，甚於夏，夏不死，持於長夏，起於秋，禁寒飲食寒衣。肺病者，愈在壬癸，壬癸不愈，加於丙丁，丙丁不死，持於戊己，起於庚辛。肺病者，下晡慧，日中甚，夜半靜。肺欲收，急食酸以收之，用酸補之，辛寫之。 Lung disease, recovery in winter, if not recovered in winter, even worse than summer, and if not cured in summer, persists into the long summer, beginning in autumn. Treatment: prohibit cold drinks, food, and clothing. For lung disease, recovery in the years of Ren and Geng, if not cured in Ren and Geng, add the years of Bing and Ding, if not fatal, persist in Wu and Jia, starting in Geng and Xin. Lung patients should wake up early, be especially clear-headed during the day, and be quiet at midnight. To stop lung disease, eat sour food urgently to stop it, use sour foods to supplement it, and use herbs that promote digestion.

6: 病在腎，愈在春，春不愈，甚於長夏，長夏不死，持於秋，起於冬，禁犯焠㶼熱食溫炙衣。腎病者，愈在甲乙，甲乙不愈，甚於戊己，戊己不死，持於庚辛，起於壬癸。腎病者，夜半慧，四季甚，下晡靜。腎欲堅，急食苦以堅之，用苦補之，鹹寫之。 The text translated to English: Kidney disease, recovery in spring, if not recovered in spring, it is more difficult than summer, if not dead in summer, it persists into autumn and begins in winter. Punish those who commit crimes of fire and heat, food, clothing. For kidney disease patients, recover in the yin months (Jia Yi), if not recovered in Jia Yi, it is more difficult in the metal months (Wu Xu), if not dead in Wu Xu, it persists into the water months (Geng Xin), and begins in the wood months (Ren Gui). Kidney disease patients are wise at midnight, difficult to cure in all seasons, and should wake up early. For kidney disease, eat bitter food urgently to strengthen it, use bitter medicine as a supplement, and write salt with it

7: 夫邪氣之客於身也，以勝相加，至其所生而愈，至其所不勝而甚，至於所生而持，自得其位而起。必先定五藏之脈，乃可言間甚之時，死生之期也。 When evil qi enters the body, it increases by conquering the surface and becomes more severe when it is generated. When it becomes strong enough to be held, one will naturally attain its position and arise. Before being able to control the five viscera's meridians, one cannot speak of a critical time between life and death.

8: 肝病者，兩脇下痛引少腹，令人善怒，虛則目䀮䀮無所見，耳無所聞，善恐如人將捕之，取其經，厥陰與少陽，氣逆，則頭痛耳聾不聰頰腫。取血者。 For patients with liver disease, pain in the lower flanks refers to the lower abdomen, causing anger and irritability. When it is deficient, the eyes cannot see and the ears cannot hear. They are easily frightened, as if someone is about to capture them. By taking the meridians, rein in the yin of the liver and the Yang of the stomach, with Qi reversal, there will be headache, deafness, dullness of the face, and swelling.

9: 心病者，胸中痛，脇支滿，脇下痛，膺背肩甲間痛，兩臂內痛，虛則胸腹大，脇下與腰相引而痛，取其經者，少陰太陽，舌下血者。其變病，刺郄中血者。 For a patient with heart disease, there is pain in the chest, fullness in the flanks, lower abdominal pain, soreness between the shoulder blades and shoulders, inner arm pain. If it is empty, the chest and abdomen become enlarged, the lower abdomen and back are painful when pulled together. When seeking the meridian, it is related to the kidney Yang and red tongue with blood at the bottom. The transformation of disease is caused by bleeding in the Zangqiu point.

10: 脾病者，身重善肌肉痿，足不收，行善瘈，腳下痛，虛則腹滿腸鳴，飱泄食不化，取其經，太陰陽明少陰血者。 For those with spleen disease, the body is heavy and has weak muscles, the feet do not recover, walking is difficult and painful, the soles of the feet hurt, when empty, the abdomen is full, the intestines are rumbling, food is not digested, their channels are the Yin and Yang of the Spleen with a deficiency of Yin blood.

11: 肺病者，喘欬逆氣，肩背痛，汗出尻陰股膝髀腨胻足皆痛，虛則少氣不能報息，耳聾嗌乾，取其經，太陰足太陽之外厥陰內血者。 The patient with lung disease experiences wheezing, shortness of breath, and difficulty in breathing. They may also experience pain in the shoulders and back, excessive sweating, and pain in the hip joints, buttocks, thighs, waist, and feet. If the condition worsens, they may not be able to produce enough vital energy to maintain respiration, leading to deafness or tinnitus. The meridian associated with this condition is the Lung Meridian, which connects to the Large Intestine Meridian through the exterior and interior Yin channels, affecting internal blood flow.

12: 腎病者，腹大脛腫，喘欬身重，寢汗出憎風，虛則胸中痛，大腹小腹痛，清厥意不樂，取其經，少陰太陽血者。 For patients with liver disease, the abdomen is distended and the legs are swollen; they pant and feel heavy, have difficulty sleeping due to night sweats and a dislike of wind; when deficient, there is pain in the center of the chest; both the large intestine and small intestine hurt, the clear yang fails to delight the mind, regulate their qi and take their meridians, nourish the yin of the spleen and stomach.

13: 肝色青，宜食甘，粳米、牛肉、棗、葵皆甘。心色赤，宜食酸，小豆、犬肉、李、韭皆酸。肺色白，宜食苦，麥、羊肉、杏、薤皆苦。脾色黃，宜食鹹，大豆、豕肉、栗、藿皆鹹。腎色黑，宜食辛，黃黍、雞肉、桃、蔥皆辛。辛散，酸收，甘緩，苦堅，鹹耎。毒藥攻邪，五穀為養，五果為助，五畜為益，五菜為充，氣味合而服之，以補精益氣。此五者。有辛酸甘苦鹹，各有所利，或散或收，或緩或急，或堅或耎，四時五藏，病隨五味所宜也。 The colors of the organs indicate what flavors one should consume to maintain balance.

Liver color: Green, eat sweet foods such as glutinous rice, beef, jujubes, and chrysanthemum, all of which are sweet. Heart color: Red, eat sour foods like soybeans, dog meat, loquats, and chives, all of which are sour. Lungs color: White, eat bitter foods such as barley, mutton, apricot kernels, and licorice, all of which are bitter. Spleen color: Yellow, eat salty foods like soybeans, pork, chestnuts, and astragalus, all of which are salty. Kidneys color: Black, eat spicy foods such as millet, chicken meat, peaches, and garlic, all of which are spicy.

The properties of these flavors are dispersing, gathering, calming, strengthening, and clearing. Toxic drugs attack evil; grains nourish; fruits aid; animals benefit; vegetables fill; combining the proper tastes in one's diet will help to replenish essence and vital energy.

These five elements have their specific properties, which are beneficial in different ways. They can be dispersing or gathering, calming or urgent, firm or purgative, according to the seasons and the organs involved. Disease can be treated according to these flavors.

docs.title: 宣明五氣
docs.text:
1: 味所入；酸入肝，辛入肺，苦入心，鹹入腎，甘入脾，是謂五入。 The flavors enter accordingly; sour enters the liver, bitter enters the heart, salty enters the kidneys, sweet enters the spleen, and pungent enters the lungs. This is called the Five Enter.

2: 氣所病：心為噫，肺為欬，肝為語，脾為吞，腎為欠為嚏，胃為氣逆為噦為恐，大腸小腸為泄，下焦溢為水，膀胱不利為癃，不約為遺溺，膽為怒，是謂五病。 Diseases of Qi: The heart is manifested as sighing, the lungs as groaning, the liver as speech, the spleen as swallowing, the kidneys as shivering, the stomach as nausea from reversed qi, the large intestine and small intestine as diarrhea, the lower abdomen as overflow of water, the bladder as difficult urination, convulsions as not being bound, the gallbladder as anger, these are the five diseases.

3: 精所并：精氣并於心則喜，并於肺則悲，并於肝則憂，并於脾則畏，并於腎則恐，是謂五并，虛而相并者也。 The text translates to: The gathering of the spirit (精): when it gathers in the heart, there is joy; when it gathers in the lungs, there is sorrow; when it gathers in the liver, there is worry; when it gathers in the spleen, there is fear; when it gathers in the kidneys, there is terror. These are the five gatherings, and they occur when the spirit is empty.

4: 藏所惡：心惡熱，肺惡寒，肝惡風，脾惡濕，腎惡燥，是謂五惡。 The text in literary Chinese can be translated to English as: Evil of the hidden: heart evil heat, lung evil cold, liver evil wind, spleen evil dampness, kidney evil dryness, are called the five evils.

5: 藏化液：心為汗，肺為涕，肝為淚，脾為涎，腎為唾，是謂五液。 Literary Chinese Translation: The heart is sweat, the lungs are tears, the liver is mucus, the spleen is saliva, and the kidneys are sputum. These are called the five fluids. English Translation: The heart is sweat, the lungs are tears, the liver is phlegm, the spleen is saliva, and the kidneys are sputum. These are known as the five essences.

6: 味所禁：辛走氣，氣病無多食辛；鹹走血，血病無多食鹹；苦走骨，骨病無多食苦；甘走肉，肉病無多食甘；酸走筋，筋病無多食酸；是謂五禁，無令多食。 In accordance with one's taste: bitter moves Qi, Qi diseases are not common in those who eat much bitter; salty moves blood, blood diseases are not common in those who eat much salty; acrid moves bones, bone diseases are not common in those who eat much acrid; sweet moves flesh, flesh diseases are not common in those who eat much sweet; sour moves tendons, tendon diseases are not common in those who eat much sour; this is called the Five Prohibitions, do not let people eat too much.

7: 病所發：陰病發於骨，陽病發於血，陰病發於肉，陽病發於冬，陰病發於夏，是謂五發。 According to the text: The disease arises from the Yin (internal organs and their functions), while Yang (external factors such as weather or pathogens) affects the blood, the Yin manifests in summer, while the Yang appears in winter. Thus are described the five manifestations of disease

8: 邪所亂：邪入於陽則狂，邪入於陰則痺，搏陽則為巔疾，搏陰則為瘖，陽入之陰則靜，陰出之陽則怒，是謂五亂。 Wickedness Disorder: Evil enters the Yang and causes madness, evil enters the Yin and causes paralysis, struggling with Yang leads to severe pain, struggling with Yin leads to rigidity. When Yang invades the Yin, it becomes quiet, when Yin emerges from Yang, it becomes angry. This is known as the Five Disorders

9: 邪所見：春得秋脈，夏得冬脈，長夏得春脈，秋得夏脈，冬得長夏脈，名曰陰出之陽，病善怒不治，是謂五邪，皆同命，死不治。 Evil observations: Obtaining the pulse of autumn in spring, the pulse of summer in summer, a long summer obtaining the pulse of spring, obtaining the pulse of autumn in summer, obtaining the pulse of winter in long summer; called yin producing yang, diseases of anger are not curable; these are the five evils, all the same disease, untreatable and dying.

10: 藏所藏：心藏神，肺藏魄，肝藏魂，脾藏意，腎藏志，是謂五藏所藏。 Hidden within: The heart houses the spirit, the lungs house the soul, the liver houses the soul essence, the spleen houses the mind, and the kidneys house the willpower; this is what is referred to as the five internal organs.

Note that the translation provided uses more traditional terminology for the internal organs and their functions. The text refers to the heart housing the spirit, lungs housing the soul, liver housing the soul essence, spleen housing the mind, and kidneys housing the willpower, which are part of traditional Chinese medicine's concept of the five internal organs (五藏).

11: 藏所主：心主脈，肺主皮，肝主筋，脾主肉，腎主骨，是謂五主。 The Cave Master: The heart governs the vessels, the lungs govern the skin, the liver governs the tendons, the spleen governs the flesh, and the kidneys govern the bones. This is known as the five organs.

12: 勞所傷：久視傷血，久臥傷氣，久坐傷肉，久立傷骨，久行傷筋，是謂五勞所傷。 Labor-induced injury: Prolonged visual strain leads to blood damage; prolonged bed rest results in qi damage; prolonged sitting causes muscle damage; prolonged standing causes bone damage; prolonged walking causes sinew damage. These are the five types of injuries caused by labor.

13: 脈應象：肝脈絃，心脈鉤，脾脈代，肺脈毛，腎脈石，是謂五藏之脈。 Pulse Characteristics: The liver pulse is like silk, the heart pulse is like a claw, the spleen pulse is like coins, the lung pulse is like fur, and the kidney pulse is like stone. These are the pulse characteristics of the five organs.

docs.title: 血氣形志
docs.text:
1: 夫人之常數，太陽常多血少氣，少陽常少血多氣，陽明常多氣多血，少陰常少血多氣，厥陰常多血少氣，太陰常多氣少血，此天之常數。足太陽與少陰為表裏，少陽與厥陰為表裏，陽明與太陰為表裏，是為足陰陽也。手太陽與少陰為表裏，少陽與心主為表裏，陽明與太陰為表裏，是為手之陰陽也。今知手足陰陽所苦，凡治病必先去其血，乃去其所苦，伺之所欲，然後寫有餘，補不足。 The constant nature of women, the sun is often bloody and less qi; lesser yang is less bloody and more qi, jueyin is often deficient in blood but more in qi, baxian is often deficient in blood but abundant in qi, and the kidneys are always deficient in blood but rich in qi. The foot zang and fu organs represent yin and yang externally; the zang of lesser yang and the fu of the kidney are external; the zang of yangming and the fu of the spleen are external; the hand zang and fu organs represent yin and yang externally; the zang of lesser yang and the fu of the heart are external; the zang of jueyin and the fu of the lungs are external. Now, knowing that the hands and feet are treated for their respective yin and yang deficiencies, in treating diseases one must first remove the blood, thereby removing the source of the imbalance, and then replenish what is lacking to achieve balance.

2: 欲知背俞，先度其兩乳間，中折之，更以他草度去半已，即以兩隅相拄也，乃舉以度其背，令其一隅居上，齊脊大椎，兩隅在下，當其下隅者，肺之俞也。得下一度，心之俞也。復下一度，左角肝之俞也，右角脾之俞也。復下一度，腎之俞也。是謂五藏之俞，灸刺之度也。 To understand the position of the lung meridian, first locate the two nipples and find the midpoint between them. Then, fold one side over the other and use your finger to measure about halfway from the fold. The lung meridian is located at the intersection point where you stop touching. After mastering this, you can raise a hand to measure its position, with the lung meridian on top, the kidney meridian at the bottom, and both sides connecting at the lower end. The left side corresponds to the lung meridian, the right side corresponds to the spleen meridian. Further down is the kidney meridian. This describes the position of the five organs' meridians through acupuncture and moxibustion measurements.

3: 形樂志苦，病生於脈，治之以灸刺。形樂志樂，病生於肉，治之以鍼石。形苦志樂，病生於筋，治之以熨引。形苦志苦，病生於咽嗌，治之以百藥。形數驚恐，經絡不通，病生於不仁，治之以按摩醪藥。是謂五形志也。 The Formulas for Treating the Five Constitutional Patterns:

  1. Form Rebellious and Difficult, disease arising at the pulse, treated with acupuncture and moxibustion.
  2. Form Joyful and Ease, disease arising in the flesh, treated with cupping and piercing.
  3. Form Painful and Joyful, disease arising in the tendons, treated with friction and pulling.
  4. Form Rebellious and Difficult, disease arising at the throat, treated with a hundred medicines.
  5. Form Numerous and Terrified, blockage of the channels and collaterals, disease arising in the area of the heart, treated with massage and aromatic medicine.

These are the five constitutional patterns.

4: 刺陽明出血氣，刺太陽，出血惡氣，刺少陽，出氣惡血，刺太陰，出氣惡血，刺少陰，出氣惡血，刺厥陰，出血惡氣也。 Piercing the sun with a clear vision, one can see the true essence of things. Piercing the Yang Sun brings forth pure energy, piercing the Yin Sun releases impure energy, and piercing the Yin and Yang extremes results in clear vision as well

docs.title: 寶命全形論
docs.text:
1: 黃帝問曰：天覆地載，萬物悉備，莫貴於人，人以天地之氣生，四時之法成，君王眾庶，盡欲全形，形之疾病，莫知其情，留淫日深，著於骨髓，心私慮之。余欲鍼除其疾病，為之奈何。歧伯對曰：夫鹽之味鹹者，其氣令器津泄；絃絕者，其音嘶敗；木敷者，其葉發；病深者，其聲噦。人有此三者，是謂壞府，毒藥無治，短鍼無取，此皆絕皮傷肉，血氣爭黑。 Yellow Emperor asked: The heavens and earth are complete, all things are prepared, nothing is more precious than humans. People are born from the qi of heaven and earth, the laws of the four seasons are established, rulers among the multitude, wanting to preserve their physical form, the diseases of the body, nothing knows their nature, accumulating lust for many days, lodging in the bone marrow, worrying about the heart. I want to remove the disease with acupuncture, what should I do? Hua Xi answered: The flavor of salt is salty, its qi regulates the vessel and excretes sweat; the string is broken, its sound becomes weak; the wood is sealed, its leaves grow. When a person has these three things, it is called a ruined palace, poisonous drugs cannot be treated, short needles cannot be grasped, all are cutting the skin and injuring the flesh, blood qi struggle and black.

2: 帝曰：余念其痛，心為之亂惑，反甚，其病，不可更代，百姓聞之，以為殘賊，為之柰何。歧伯曰：夫人生於地，懸命於天，天地合氣，命之曰人。人能應四時者，天地為之父母；知萬物者，謂之天子。天有陰陽，人有十二節；天有寒暑，人有虛實。能經天地陰陽之化者，不失四時；知十二節之理者，聖智不能欺也；能存八動之變，五勝更立；能達虛實之數者，獨出獨入，呿吟至微，秋毫在目。 The emperor said: I think of my pain and my heart is in chaos, it is quite severe. His illness cannot be passed on to another, if the common people hear of this, they will consider it a disaster, what should be done? Duke Zhou replied: Man is born of earth and hangs upon heaven. When earth and heaven unite their breaths, it is called man. If a person responds to the four seasons, heaven and earth are his parents; if one knows all things, he is called the Son of Heaven. There are yin and yang in heaven, and there are ten vital points in man. There are cold and heat in heaven, and there are reality and emptiness in man. If one can harmonize with the changes of heaven and earth, then one will not miss the four seasons; if one knows the principles of the twelve points, saints cannot be deceived; if one can endure the eight changes, five victories will arise; if one can grasp the numbers of reality and emptiness, one will be unique and enter alone, sighing and murmuring in extreme weakness, like a hair left in the eye.

3: 帝曰：人生有形，不離陰陽，天地合氣，別為九野，分為四時，月有小大，日有短長，萬物並至，不可勝量，虛實呿吟，敢問其方。歧伯曰：木得金而伐，火得水而滅，土得木而達，金得火而缺，水得土而絕，萬物盡然，不可勝竭。故鍼有懸布天下者五，黔首共餘食，莫知之也。一曰治神，二曰知養身，三曰知毒藥為真，四曰制砭石小大，五曰知府藏血氣之診。五法俱立，各有所先。今末世之刺也，虛者實之，滿者泄之，此皆眾工所共知也。若夫法天則地，隨應而動，和之者若響，隨之者若影，道無鬼神，獨來獨往。 The emperor said: Human life has form and does not depart from yin and yang. Heaven and Earth unite their qi, divide into nine regions, and differentiate into four seasons. The moon has small and large phases, and the sun has short and long days. All things reach perfection and cannot be fully enumerated. It is like a ghost singing, daring to ask its method. Duke of Zhou said: Wood obtains metal but cuts it down; fire obtains water and extinguishes it; earth obtains wood and flourishes; metal obtains fire and lacks it; water obtains soil and ends it; all things are complete and cannot be exhausted. Therefore, among the five needles that hang from heaven to earth, there is one for the marquis of the left arch, one for the duke of the right arch, and one for the lord of the central arch - these three are not known. The first [needle] is for regulating spirits, the second is for nourishing the body, the third is for knowing real medicine from poisonous ones, the fourth is for adjusting jade stones large and small, and the fifth is for knowing the location of blood and qi flow in the palace. Each of these five methods has its own area of expertise. Today's needle practitioners imitate the ancients; they virtualize what is real and release what is full - this is all known by ordinary people. If one follows the law of heaven and earth, it moves according to its nature, resonating like an echo and following like a shadow. There are no ghosts or gods that come and go independently.

4: 帝曰：願聞其道。歧伯曰：凡刺之真，必先治神，五藏已定，九候已備，後乃存鍼，眾脈不見，眾凶弗聞，外肉相得，無以形先，可玩往來，乃施於人。人有虛實，五虛勿近，五實勿遠，至其當發，間不容𣊇。手動若務，鍼耀而勻，靜意視義，觀適之變，是謂冥冥，莫知其形，見其烏烏，見其稷稷，從見其飛，不知其誰，伏如橫弩，起如發機。帝曰：何如而虛，何如而實。歧伯曰：刺虛者須其實，刺實者須其虛，經氣已至，慎守勿失，深淺在志，遠近若一，如臨深淵，手如握虎，神無營於眾物。 The Emperor said: I wish to hear of its method.
