The Liver moves cold to the Heart, causing madness. The Heart moves cold to the Lungs, and the Lungs waste away. Wasting of the lungs is characterized by coughing up phlegm and blood, and this cannot be treated. The Lung moves cold to the Kidney, causing an excess of water. In cases of excess water, pressing the abdomen does not alleviate the pain. Water qi resides in the large intestine, moving quickly it causes a rumbling sound like a drum being beaten, and this is a disease involving water.

2: 脾移熱於肝，則為驚衂。肝移熱於心，則死。心移熱於肺，傳為鬲消。肺移熱於腎，傳為柔痓。腎移熱於脾，傳為虛，腸澼死，不可治。 If the spleen's heat moves to the liver, it results in a severe case of jaundice. If the liver's heat moves to the heart, one will die. If the heart's heat moves to the lung, it leads to excessive coughing. If the lung's heat moves to the kidney, it results in impotence, and if the kidney's heat moves to the spleen, it leads to emptiness, and the intestines will rot and become incurable.

3: 胞移熱於膀胱，則癃溺血。膀胱移熱於小腸，鬲腸不便，上為口麋。小腸移熱於大腸，為虙瘕為沈。大腸移熱於胃，善食而瘦入謂之食亦。胃移熱於膽，亦曰食亦。膽移熱於腦，則辛頞鼻淵，鼻淵者，濁涕下不止也，傳為衂衊瞑目，故得之氣厥也。 If the heat moves to the bladder, one will drown in blood. If the heat moves to the small intestine, the large intestine becomes obstructed and ascends to the throat. If the heat moves to the large intestine, one suffers from diarrhea. If the heat moves to the stomach, one can eat well but still lose weight, thus such eating is referred to as food too. If the heat moves to the gallbladder, it is also called food. If the heat moves to the brain, one will have a bitter taste in the nose and the nose will pour a foul discharge that does not stop, leading to clouded eyes and a dimming of sight, resulting in a deficiency of vital energy.

docs.title: 欬論
docs.text:
1: 黃帝問曰：肺之令人欬，何也。歧伯對曰：五藏六府，皆令人欬，非獨肺也。帝曰：願聞其狀。歧伯曰：皮毛者，肺之合也，皮毛先受邪氣，邪氣以從其合也。其寒飲食入胃，從肺脈上至於肺，則肺寒，肺寒則外內合，邪因而客之，則為肺欬。五藏各以其時受病，非其時，各傳以與之。人與天地相參，故五藏各以治，時感於寒，則受病，微則為欬，甚者為泄為痛。乘秋則肺先受邪，乘春則肝先受之，乘夏則心先受之，乘至陰則脾先受之，乘冬則腎先受之。 Emperor asked: What is it about the lungs that makes people sneeze? The Duke answered: All the five organs and six sense organs can cause people to sneeze, it's not just the lungs. Emperor said: I would like to hear more about this. The Duke said: The skin and hair are what the lungs control. The skin and hair are the first to be affected by pathogenic qi, and the pathogenic qi follows their control. When cold drinks or food enter the stomach, they travel along the lung channel to the lungs, causing the lungs to become cold. Cold lungs cause internal and external control to merge, and the pathogenic factor attacks the body, resulting in a lung sneeze. Each of the five organs is affected by disease at different times, and none of them are unaffected. People and heaven harmonize with each other, so the five organs each have their ways of treatment. When it's cold, they are susceptible to disease, mild cases result in sneezing, while severe cases lead to leaking or pain. Riding autumn, the lungs are the first to be affected by pathogenic factors, riding spring causes the liver to be first affected, riding summer causes the heart to be first affected, riding yin results in the spleen being the first affected, and riding winter leads to the kidneys being the first affected.

2: 帝曰：何以異之。歧伯曰：肺欬之狀，欬而喘息有音，甚則唾血。心欬之狀，欬則心痛。喉中介介如梗狀，甚則咽腫喉痺。肝欬之狀，欬則兩脇下痛，甚則不可以轉，轉則兩胠下滿。脾欬之狀，欬則右脇下痛陰陰引肩背，甚則不可以動，動則欬劇。腎欬之狀，欬則腰背相引而痛，甚則欬涎。 The emperor asked, What is the peculiarity of this? The marquis replied, The state of the lung is characterized by coughing and wheezing with a hoarse voice. Severe cases involve spitting blood. The state of the heart is characterized by chest pain upon coughing. In the throat, there is an obstructed feeling like choking, which in severe cases causes enlargement of the throat and soreness of the neck. The state of the liver is characterized by pain in the flanks upon coughing, with severe cases making it impossible to turn and, when turning, causing pain in the lower abdomen. The state of the spleen is characterized by right-flank pain upon coughing, which then radiates to the groin and makes the shoulders and back sore. In severe cases, movement is impossible and coughing becomes more pronounced. The state of the kidney is characterized by lower back pain that extends to the abdomen upon coughing, with severe cases involving excessive spitting.

3: 帝曰：六府之欬柰何，安所受病。歧伯曰：五藏之久欬，乃移於六府，脾欬不已，則胃受之，胃欬之狀，欬而嘔，嘔甚則長蟲出。肝欬不已，則膽受之，膽欬之狀，欬嘔膽汁，肺欬不已，則大腸受之，大腸欬狀，欬而遺失。心欬不已，則小腸受之，小腸欬狀，欬而失氣，氣與欬俱失。腎欬不已，則膀胱受之，膀胱欬狀，欬而遺溺。久欬不已，則三焦受之，三焦欬狀，欬而腹滿，不欲食飲，此皆聚於胃，關於肺，使人多涕唾而面浮腫氣逆也。 The emperor asked: What is the meaning of the six palaces? How can it be treated? The Duke said: When there is a prolonged disturbance in the Five Organs, it moves to the six palaces. If the spleen is not relieved, it affects the stomach; when the stomach is disturbed, it causes nausea and vomiting. If this persists, worms will appear. If the liver is not relieved, it affects the gallbladder; when the gallbladder is disturbed, it causes qi to rise up and there will be bile secretion. If the lungs are not relieved, it affects the large intestine; when the large intestine is disturbed, there will be involuntary loss of feces. If the heart is not relieved, it affects the small intestine; when the small intestine is disturbed, there will be shortness of breath and loss of vital energy. If the kidneys are not relieved, it affects the bladder; when the bladder is disturbed, there will be incontinence. When there is a prolonged disturbance, it affects the triple burner; when the triple burner is disturbed, there will be abdominal fullness and no desire to eat or drink. All these symptoms accumulate in the stomach and obstruct the lungs, causing excessive secretion of tears and swelling of the face due to qi turning upwards.

4: 帝曰：治之柰何。歧伯曰：治藏者，治其俞，治府者，治其合。浮腫者，治其經。帝曰：善。 The emperor asked: How should one govern? Duke of Zhou replied: To govern the people, govern their rituals; to govern the household, govern its members. To govern the floating and bloated, govern their meridians. The emperor said: Good

docs.title: 舉痛論
docs.text:
1: 黃帝問曰：余聞善言天者，必有驗於人；善言古者，必有合於今；善言人者，必有厭於己。如此，則道不惑而要數極，所謂明也。今余問於夫子，令言而可知，視而可見，捫而可得，令驗於己而發蒙解惑，可得而聞乎。歧伯再拜稽首對曰：何道之問也。 The Yellow Emperor asked: I have heard that the words of the sage who speaks of heaven are verified in people; the words of the ancient sage are applicable to today; and the words of a human sage must be weary of oneself. If so, then the Way is not confused and has a clear extreme, which is called clarity. Now, I ask Master Zhou about this: let me explain it so that it can be understood, see it so that it can be seen, cultivate it so that it can be obtained, let it be verified in oneself and illuminate confusion, obtain it and hear about it. Huan He bowed twice, knelt down, and said, What is the meaning of asking about the Way?

2: 帝曰：願聞人之五藏卒痛，何氣使然。歧伯對曰：經脈流行不止，環周不休，寒氣入經而稽遲，泣而不行，客於脈外則血少，客於脈中則氣不通，故卒然而痛。 The emperor said, I wish to hear the reason why a person's five viscera suffer from acute pain. The Duke of Tang replied, The channels and network vessels are not at rest, and the cold Qi invades the channels, causing the person to cry but unable to stand. If the disorder is outside the channels, there will be insufficient blood; if it is within the channels, the Qi will not circulate freely, leading to acute pain.

3: 帝曰：其痛或卒然而止者，或痛甚不休者，或痛甚不可按者，或按之而痛止者，或按之無益者，或喘動應手者，或心與背相引而痛者，或脇肋與少腹相引而痛者，或腹痛引陰股者，或痛宿昔而成積者，或卒然痛死不知人，有少閒復生者，或痛而嘔者，或腹痛而後泄者，或痛而閉不通者，凡此諸痛，各不同形，別之柰何。 The emperor said: Some pains may suddenly stop, some pains are too severe to rest, some pains cannot be pressed, or pressing alleviates the pain, or pressing is of no benefit, or gasping and extending a hand, or pain with the heart and back pulling each other, or the side ribs and lower abdomen pulling each other causing pain, or pain in the abdomen referring to the yin channel, some pains that were sudden but became chronic, or pains that suddenly cause death without knowing the person, are there any who recover a little, or pains that cause vomiting, or pain in the abdomen that then causes diarrhea, or pain that causes difficulty breathing, all these different types of pain, how can they be distinguished?

4: 歧伯曰：寒氣客於脈外，則脈寒，脈寒則縮踡，縮踡則脈絀急，則外引小絡，故卒然而痛，得炅則痛立止，因重中於寒，則痛久矣。寒氣客於經脈之中，與炅氣相薄，則脈滿，滿則痛而不可按也。寒氣稽留，炅氣從上，則脈充大而血氣亂，故痛甚不可按也。寒氣客於腸胃之閒，膜原之下，血不得散，小絡急引故痛，按之則血氣散，故按之痛止。寒氣客於俠脊之脈，則深按之不能及，故按之無益也。寒氣客於衝脈，衝脈起於關元，隨腹直上，寒氣客則脈不通，脈不通則氣因之，故喘動應手矣。寒氣客於背俞之脈則脈泣，脈泣則血虛，血虛則痛，其俞注於心，故相引而痛，按之則熱氣至，熱氣至則痛止矣。寒氣客於厥陰之脈，厥陰之脈者，絡陰器繫於肝，寒氣客於脈中，則血泣脈急，故脇肋與少腹相引痛矣。厥氣客於陰股，寒氣上及少腹，血泣在下相引，故腹痛引陰股。寒氣客於小腸膜原之間，絡血之中，血泣不得注於大經，血氣稽留不得行，故宿昔而成積矣。寒氣客於五藏，厥逆上泄，陰氣竭，陽氣未入，故卒然痛死不知人，氣復反，則生矣。寒氣客於腸胃，厥逆上出，故痛而嘔也。寒氣客於小腸，小腸不得成聚，故後泄腹痛矣。熱氣留於小腸，腸中痛，癉熱焦渴，則堅乾不得出，故痛而閉不通矣。帝曰：所謂言而可知者也。 Master said: When the cold Qi is outside the pulse, the pulse is cold, and when the pulse is cold, it contracts and tightens, causing the pulse to be urgent and leading to external referral of the small vessels. Thus, there is sudden pain. When warmed, the pain stops, because heating is more effective in this case. Cold Qi residing within the channels is thinner than fire Qi, resulting in a full pulse, which hurts but cannot be pressed, and when cold Qi ascends from above, the pulse is large and disorderly, causing great pain that cannot be pressed. When cold Qi resides in the intestines, the ligament of the mucosa does not allow blood to disperse, causing small vessel referral pain; pressing it causes blood to disperse, stopping the pain. Cold Qi residing at the lumbar vertebrae causes a deep pulse that cannot be reached, making pressing ineffective. Cold Qi residing in the Chong channel, originating from the Ren channel and ascending along the middle line, results in an obstructed pulse when cold Qi is present, causing breathing difficulty and shortness of breath. When cold Qi resides at the Bladder channel, the pulse weeps, indicating blood deficiency, which causes pain when it is pulled together by the Bladder; pressing leads to the arrival of fire Qi, stopping the pain. Cold Qi residing in the liver channel causes the reining Qi to be obstructed at the kidneys. Kidney yin is depleted, but yang Qi has not yet entered, causing sudden death without anyone knowing. Reversal of Qi leads to life again. Cold Qi residing in the intestines causes reining Qi to rise, resulting in pain with vomiting. Cold Qi residing in the small intestine causes it not to gather, resulting in diarrhea and lower abdominal pain. When fire Qi remains in the small intestine, there is pain in the intestines, fever, and scorched thirst, leading to constipation and an inability to release them, causing pain and closure without flow. All that is said can be understood.

5: 視而可見，柰何。歧伯曰：五藏六府，固盡有部，視其五色，黃赤為熱，白為寒，青黑為痛，此所謂視而可見者也。帝曰：捫而可得，柰何。歧伯曰：視其主病之脈堅而血，及陷下者，皆可捫而得也。 Upon seeing, it is clear. How much more so? The Duke of Zhou said: The Five Canons and Six Palaces are indeed complete with their respective divisions. Upon looking at the five colors, yellow and red are hot, white is cold, green and black are painful; this is what is meant by upon seeing it can be known. The Emperor said: If one can obtain them by touching, how much more so? The Duke of Zhou said: By looking at the master's disease pulse and finding it tight and blood-filled, as well as sunken below, these can all be obtained through touch.

6: 帝曰：善。余知百病生於氣也，怒則氣上，喜則氣緩，悲則氣消，恐則氣下，寒則氣收，炅則氣泄，驚則氣亂，勞則氣耗，思則氣結，九氣不同，何病之生。歧伯曰：怒則氣逆，甚則嘔血及飱泄，故氣上矣。喜則氣和志達，榮衛通利，故氣緩矣。悲則心系急，肺布葉舉，而上焦不通，榮衛不散，熱氣在中，故氣消矣。恐則精卻，卻則上焦閉，閉則氣還，還則下焦脹，故氣不行矣。寒則腠理閉，氣不行，故氣收矣。炅則腠理開，榮衛通汗大泄，故氣泄。驚則心無所倚，神無所歸，慮無所定，故氣亂矣。勞則喘息汗出，外內皆越，故氣耗矣。思則心有所存，神有所歸，正氣留而不行，故氣結矣。 Emperor said: Good. I know that all diseases arise from Qi, anger causes Qi to rise, joy causes Qi to become calm, sorrow causes Qi to dissipate, fear causes Qi to descend, cold causes Qi to contract, heat causes Qi to discharge, shock causes Qi to be disordered, labor causes Qi to deplete, and thought causes Qi to congeal. Qi has nine different manifestations; how can diseases arise?

Marquis Wen said: When angry, Qi rises up excessively, causing vomiting of blood and purging of the bowels, so it is Qi that rises. When joyful, Qi becomes harmonious and spirit moves smoothly, causing the defense qi to flow freely through the channels, so it is Qi that becomes calm. When sorrowful, the heart is bound tightly, the lungs spread out their leaves and raise them up, yet the middle jiao does not communicate, and the defensive qi does not scatter, so it is Qi that dissipates. When afraid, the vital essence scatters, causing the middle jiao to close, and when closed, the Qi returns and causes the lower jiao to distend, so it is Qi that does not circulate. Cold causes the networks and vessels to contract, preventing Qi from circulating, so it is Qi that contracts. When heated, the networks and vessels open, causing the defense qi to sweat profusely, so it is Qi that discharges. When shocked, the heart has nowhere to rely on, the spirit has nowhere to return, the mind has no place to settle, so it is Qi that becomes disordered. When working hard, there is panting and sweating, both internally and externally are out of balance, so it is Qi that depletes. When thinking, the heart has a place to store, the spirit has a place to return, the genuine qi remains but does not circulate, so it is Qi that congeals

docs.title: 生氣通天論
docs.text:
1: 黃帝曰：夫自古通天者生之本，本於陰陽天地之間，六合之內，其氣九州九竅五藏十二節，皆通乎天氣。其生五，其氣三，數犯此者，則邪氣傷人，此壽命之本也。蒼天之氣清淨，則志意治，順之則陽氣固，雖有賊邪，弗能害也，此因時之序。故聖人傳精神，服天氣，而通神明。失之則內閉九竅，外壅肌肉，衛氣散解，此謂自傷，氣之削也。 Yellow Emperor said: The foundation of connecting with heaven is from ancient times. It comes from the space between yin and yang, within the six harmonies, nine zones and five layers, and twelve channels. Their qi connects to the celestial qi. When there are five openings and three layers, often falling into this, evil qi harms people, which is the basis of life and death. The pure and clear qi of the sky regulates intention and follows it, leading to the strengthening of yang qi, even if there are external evil influences, they cannot harm. This is due to the appropriate order of the times. Therefore, sages transmit spirit and serve celestial qi in order to connect with the divine light. Failing this, nine apertures close internally, exterior muscles harden, guarding and dispersing qi, which is called self-harm and the decline of qi.

2: 陽氣者若天與日，失其所，則折壽而不彰，故天運當以日光明。是故陽因而上，衛外者也。因於寒，欲如運樞，起居如驚，神氣乃浮。因於暑，汗煩則喘喝，靜則多言，體若燔炭，汗出而散。因於濕，首如裹，濕熱不攘，大筋緛短，小筋弛長，緛短為拘，弛長為痿。因於氣，為腫，四維相代，陽氣乃竭。 If one is like the sun and heaven, losing their place will result in a bent life that does not shine brightly. Therefore, celestial stems correspond to solar illumination. Hence, the Yang Qi ascends above, and pertains to the outlying area (i.e., the periphery of the body). Because of Cold, one wishes to be like an axis, arising and settling as if startled; the spirit energy rises. Because of Heat, sweat vexes and causes panting and hoarse speech; in silence, it results in much speaking; the body is like scorched charcoal with sweat being released to disperse. Because of Dampness, the head is like a swaddling cloth, damp heat does not distinguish boundaries, large sinews are tightened and shortened, small sinews are loosened and lengthened; tightening and shortening leads to rigidity, while loosening and lengthening lead to weakness. Because of Qi, there is distention, with the four limbs taking turns in being distended; Yang Qi is depleted.

3: 陽氣者，煩勞則張，精絕辟積，於夏使人煎厥。目盲不可以視，耳閉不可以聽，潰潰乎若壞都，汨汨乎不可止。陽氣者，大怒則形氣絕，而血菀於上，使人薄厥。有傷於筋縱，其若不容，汗出偏沮，使人偏枯。汗出見濕，乃生痤疿。高梁之變，足生大丁，受如持虛。勞汗當風，寒薄為皻，鬱乃痤。 Persons with excessive Yang Qi, when fatigued or overworked, their Essence is depleted and accumulated, causing them to be scorched in summer. Their eyesight cannot see, and they cannot hear with their ears, and saliva drools uncontrollably, like the ruins of a city. When Yang Qi becomes enraged, one's physical condition is disrupted, causing blood to flow upward, leading to dizziness. There are injuries to the tendons that cannot be tolerated; sweating occurs on one side, leading to emaciation in one part. Sweat is visible and generates boils and swelling. High fever leads to the formation of large blisters, which are as difficult to hold as emptiness. Laborous sweating in cold weather causes chills, while depression leads to boils

4: 陽氣者，精則養神，柔則養筋。開闔不得，寒氣從之，乃生大僂。陷脈為瘻，留連肉腠。俞氣化薄，傳為善畏，及為驚駭。營氣不從，逆於肉理，乃生癰腫。魄汗未盡，形弱而氣爍，穴俞以閉，發為風瘧。故風者，百病之始也，清靜則肉腠閉拒，雖有大風苛毒，弗之能害，此因時之序也。故病久則傳化，上下不并，良醫弗為。故陽畜積病死，而陽氣當隔，隔者當寫，不亟正治，粗乃敗之。 The person with Yang Qi cultivates the spirit through refinement and nurtures the muscles through softness. If one cannot open or close, cold Qi will invade, leading to the formation of large swellings. Blood stagnation is like a piglet stuck in a drainpipe, leaving behind tendons and sinews. Yang Qi transforms into thinness, spreading fear and shock. If the energy does not circulate properly, it goes against the flesh's principles and causes boils and tumors. Before the soul sweat has evaporated, one's form is weak and energy is depleted, closing the acupuncture points leads to wind sickness. Therefore, wind is the source of all diseases; when calm and clear, the flesh and sinews close and reject even harsh winds and toxic poisons. If a disease persists, it will change forms and not parallel up and down, making it difficult for skilled doctors to treat. Thus, Yang Qi accumulates diseases leading to death, while Yang Qi must be separated; separation must be written, without delay in proper treatment, leading to failure

5: 故陽氣者，一日而主外，平旦人氣生，日中而陽氣隆，日西而陽氣已虛，氣門乃閉。是故暮而收拒，無擾筋骨，無見霧露，反此三時，形乃困薄。 Individuals with a yang nature: by midday they are in charge, and the qi of the people is generated at night. The qi of yang becomes strong at noon, but as the sun sets, the yang qi has already become depleted, and the gate of qi is closed. Therefore, at dusk, one should gather and withdraw, have no disturbance to sinews and bones, not see mist and dew, and in contrast to these three times, the form will be weak and thin.

6: 歧伯曰：陰者，藏精而起亟也，陽者，衛外而為固也。陰不勝其陽，則脈流薄疾，并乃狂。陽不勝其陰，則五藏氣爭，九竅不通。是以聖人陳陰陽，筋脈和同，骨髓堅固，氣血皆從。如是，則內外調和，邪不能害，耳目聰明，氣立如故。 The Yu Bode said: The Yin is the one that stores its essence and acts in a hurry, while the Yang is the one that defends outside and stands firm. If Yin does not overcome Yang, then the pulse will flow thinly and rapidly, leading to madness. If Yang does not overcome Yin, then the five organs struggle for Qi, and the nine orifices do not communicate. Thus, the sage person establishes Yin and Yang, coordinates tendons and vessels, and makes bone marrow strong and firm, allowing Qi and blood to flow well. In this way, the inner and outer are harmonized, evil cannot harm, and hearing and sight are acute, Qi stands tall as before.

7: 風客淫氣，精乃亡，邪傷肝也。因而飽食，筋脈橫解，腸澼為痔。因而大飲，則氣逆。因而強力，腎氣乃傷，高骨乃壞。凡陰陽之要，陽密乃固，兩者不和，若春無秋，若冬無夏，因而和之，是謂聖度。故陽強不能密，陰氣乃絕，陰平陽秘，精神乃治，陰陽離決，精氣乃絕，因於露風，乃生寒熱。 The winds of the wayward roam and disperse, souls perish, the path of the demonic damages the liver. Hence indulgence in food leads to the sinews' dispersion, causing the intestines to form fistulas. Thus great drinking results in reversed Qi. Thus exerting oneself causes kidney Qi to be injured and bones to decay. In all matters of yin and yang, yang being sealed is key; if the two do not harmonize, it is like spring without autumn or winter without summer. Hence to harmonize them, this is called sheng du. Therefore, when yang is strong but cannot be sealed, yin Qi will vanish; yin is leveled and yang concealed, spirit will be treated, yin and yang separate, and Qi of spirit will vanish due to exposure to cold wind, thus giving rise to cold and heat.

8: 是以春傷於風，邪氣留連，乃為洞泄。夏傷於暑，秋為痎瘧。秋傷於濕，上逆而欬，發為痿厥。冬傷於寒，春必溫病。四時之氣，更傷五藏。 Therefore, the harm caused by the spring wind gives rise to a cold condition; the pathogenic qi lingers and results in an excretion. In summer, harm from heat leads to rash; in autumn, it causes prickly heat. Harm from dampness in autumn causes headache with dizziness, leading to limb weakness. Harm from cold in winter necessarily brings onspring fever. The seasonal pathogenic qi further harms the five organs.

9: 陰之所生，本在五味，陰之五宮，傷在五味。是故味過於酸，肝氣以津，脾氣乃絕。味過於鹹，大骨氣勞，短肌，心氣抑。味過於甘，心氣喘滿，色黑腎氣不衡。味過於苦，脾氣不濡，胃氣乃厚。味過於辛，筋脈沮弛，精神乃央，是故謹和五味，骨正筋柔，氣血以流，湊理以密，如是，則骨氣以精，謹道如法，長有天命。 The flavors that arise from yin are rooted in the five tastes, and the yin of the five orifices resides within the five tastes. Therefore, if the taste is excessively sour, liver qi will dominate with fluids, spleen qi will be exhausted. If the taste is overly salty, bone qi will labor, muscles will be short, heart qi will be repressed. If the taste is too sweet, heart qi will pant heavily, complexion will be black and kidney qi will not regulate. If the taste is excessively bitter, spleen qi will not moisten, stomach qi will become thick. If the taste is overly pungent, channels and vessels will collapse, spirit will be dispersed. Therefore, carefully harmonize the five tastes, so that bones will be upright and muscles pliable, qi and blood will circulate, essences will be subtle, practice the way according to law, and one can enjoy longevity by following heaven's decrees

docs.title: 腹中論
docs.text:
1: 黃帝問曰：有病心腹滿，旦食則不能暮食，此為何病。歧伯對曰：名為鼓脹。帝曰：治之柰何。歧伯曰：治之以雞矢醴一劑知二劑已。帝曰：其時有復發者何也。歧伯曰：此飲食不節，故時有病也。雖然其病且已，時故當病，氣聚於腹也。 Emperor asked: One has a full heart and abdomen, and cannot eat in the morning if they eat at night. What kind of disease is this? Hua Bo replied: It is called gǔ xīn. Emperor asked: How do you treat it? Hua Bo said: Treat with one to two doses of chicken needle medicine. Emperor asked: If there is a recurrence later, what is the reason? Hua Bo said: This is due to the lack of regulation of food and drink, which can cause disease at that time. Although the disease has improved for now, it will be sick again because the Qi is concentrated in the abdomen.

2: 帝曰：有病胸脇支滿者，妨於食，病至則先聞腥臊臭，出清液，先唾血，四支清，目眩，時時前後血，病名為何。何以得之。歧伯曰：病名血枯。此得之年少時，有所大脫血，若醉入房中，氣竭肝傷，故月事衰少不來也。帝曰：治之柰何，復以何術。歧伯曰：以四烏鰂骨一藘茹二物并合之，丸以雀卵，大如小豆，以五丸為後飯，飲以鮑魚汁，利腸中及傷肝也。 Emperor asked: There is a person with fullness and pain in the chest and sides, hindering them from eating. When the disease worsens, they first hear the smell of rancid meat and foul odors, exude clear fluids, spit blood, have cold limbs, become dizzy, and sometimes have blood in front and behind. What is this disease called? Why did they get it?

Bo Yi replied: The disease is called Xue Ku (Blood Dryness). It occurs during youth when there is excessive bleeding, such as when one is drunk and enters a bedroom, exhausting the lung qi and damaging the liver. This results in menstruation becoming insufficient or absent.

Emperor asked: How do we treat this? What methods should be used?

Bo Yi replied: Take four black bones of crows, soak them with two medicinal materials, mix them into small pellets the size of a millet seed. Take five of these pellets as an after-dinner snack, and drink broth made from shrimp. This will regulate the intestines and heal damaged liver qi.

3: 帝曰：病有少腹盛，上下左右皆有根，此為何病，可治不歧伯曰：病名曰伏梁。帝曰：伏梁何因而得之。歧伯曰：裹大膿血，居腸胃之外，不可治，治之，每切按之致死。帝曰：何以然。歧伯曰：此下則因陰必下膿血，上則迫胃脘生鬲，俠胃脘內癰。此久病也難治。居齊上為逆，居齊下為從，勿動亟奪，論在刺法中。帝曰：人有身體髀股䯒皆腫，環齊而痛，是為何病。歧伯曰：病名伏梁，此風根也。其氣溢於大腸而著於肓，肓之原在齊下，故環齊而痛也。不可動之，動之為水溺濇之病。 Emperor: This disease has a shallow root and manifests in all four directions. What is this disease, and can it be treated? Hui Bo replied: The name of the disease is Fu Ling. Emperor: How does one contract the Fu Ling disease? Hui Bo answered: It occurs from wrapping the intestines with blood, residing outside the stomach and intestines, and cannot be treated. If treated, pressing it will inevitably lead to death. Emperor: Why is that so? Hui Bo replied: Below, it is caused by yin deficiency causing intestinal bleeding; above, it is due to pressure on the diaphragm and spleen, causing ulcers in the diaphragm and spleen. This is a long-standing disease difficult to treat. As for someone living in Qi who is upstairs as a rebel and downstairs as a follower, do not act hastily or seize urgently; discuss it in the context of acupuncture law. Emperor: When people have hip and knee joint pain, their bodies are swollen and surrounded by pain, what disease is this? Hui Bo replied: The disease is called Fu Ling, and it is a wind-related illness. Its energy overflowed in the large intestine and settled on the tendons, and the roots of the tendons are below. Therefore, it surrounds the hip and causes pain. Do not move it, as moving it will cause water drowning disease.

4: 帝曰：夫子數言熱中消中，不可服高梁芳草石藥，石藥發瘨，芳草發狂。夫熱中消中者皆富貴人也，今禁高梁，是不合其心，禁芳草石藥，是病不愈，願聞其說。歧伯曰：夫芳草之氣美，石藥之氣悍，二者其氣急疾堅勁，故非緩心和人，不可以服此二者。帝曰：不可以服此二者，何以然。歧伯曰：夫熱氣慓悍，藥氣亦然，二者相遇恐內傷脾。脾者土也而惡木，服此藥者，至甲乙日更論。 The Emperor said: Master Zhū says that, in treating fever, one should not use high-ranking medicinal herbs such as flowers, grasses, and stones. Stones produce toxins, while flowers induce madness. The fever patients are usually wealthy and powerful individuals. Prohibiting the use of high-ranking herbs is against their wishes; prohibiting the use of flower and stone medicines will not cure them. I would like to hear your opinion on this matter. Lord Bi said: The virtues of flower and stone medicines are potent and swift, but they are not suitable for those who need to calm their hearts and harmonize with others. The Emperor asked: Why are they not suitable? Lord Bi replied: Because the fever energy is fierce and uncontrollable, the energy of the medicines is also like this. Combining them may cause internal damage to the spleen. The spleen represents earth and dislikes wood. Those who take these medicines will have more discussions on the day of jia and yi.

5: 帝曰：善。有病膺腫頸痛胸滿腹脹此為何病，何以得之。歧伯曰：名厥逆。帝曰：治之柰何。歧伯曰：灸之則瘖，石之則狂，須其氣并，乃可治也。帝曰：何以然。歧伯曰：陽氣重上，有餘於上，灸之則陽氣入陰，入則瘖，石之則陽氣虛，虛則狂，須其氣并而治之，可使全也。 The emperor asked, What is this illness that causes one to have the diseases of fever, swollen neck, throat pain, a full chest and distended abdomen? The Duke of Zhou replied, It is called 'Extreme Yin'. The emperor asked, How do I treat it? The Duke of Zhou said, Apply acupuncture to expel the illness, and apply moxibustion to regulate the body. When the energies are balanced, the patient can be treated completely.

6: 帝曰：善。何以知懷子之且生也。歧伯曰：身有病而無邪脈也。 The emperor said: Good. How do I know there is a fetus and it is growing? Duke Zhou said: There is a physical condition without any sign of evil qi in the body.

7: 帝曰：病熱而有所痛者，何也。歧伯曰：病熱者，陽脈也，以三陽之動也，人迎一盛少陽，二盛太陽，三盛陽明，入陰也，夫陽入於陰，故病在頭與腹，乃䐜脹而頭痛也。帝曰：善。 The Emperor asked: What about those who are sick with fever and pain? Hui Bao replied: The fever is due to the Yang Meridian, which is caused by the movement of three Yangs - one of Shao Yang, two of Tai Yang, and three of Yang Ming. They enter the Yin, so the illness is located in the head and abdomen, resulting in a distended feeling and headache. The Emperor said: Good

docs.title: 刺腰痛
docs.text:
1: 足太陽脈，令人腰痛，引項脊尻背如重狀；刺其郄中太陽正經出血，春無見血。少陽令人腰痛，如以鍼刺其皮中，循循然不可以俛仰，不可以顧。刺少陽成骨之端出血，成骨在膝外廉之骨獨起者，夏無見血。陽明令人腰痛，不可以顧顧如有見者，善悲；刺陽明於䯒前三痏，上下和之出血。秋無見血，足少陰令人腰痛，痛引脊內廉；刺少陰於內踝上二痏，春無見血，出血太多，不可復也。厥陰之脈，令人腰痛，腰中如張弓弩弦；刺厥陰之脈，在腨踵魚腹之外，循之累累然，乃刺之，其病令人善言，默默然不慧，刺之三痏。解脈令人腰痛，痛引肩，目䀮䀮然，時遺溲；刺解脈，在膝筋肉分閒郄外廉之橫脈出血，血變而止。解脈令人腰痛如引帶，常如折腰狀，善恐，刺解脈，在郄中結絡如黍米，刺之血射以黑，見赤血而已。同陰之脈，令人腰痛，痛如小錘居其中，怫然腫；刺同陰之脈，在外踝上絕骨之端，為三痏。陽維之脈，令人腰痛，痛上怫然腫，刺陽維之脈，脈與太陽合腨下間，去地一尺所。衡絡之脈，令人腰痛，不可以俛仰，仰則恐仆，得之舉重傷腰，衡絡絕，惡血歸之；刺之在郄陽筋之間，上郄數寸，衡居為二痏出血。會陰之脈，令人腰痛，痛上漯漯然汗出，汗乾令人欲飲，飲已欲走。刺直陽之脈，上三痏在蹻上郄下五寸橫居，視其盛者出血。飛陽之脈，令人腰痛，痛上拂拂然，甚則悲以恐；刺飛陽之脈，在內踝上五寸，少陰之前，與陰維之會。昌陽之脈，令人腰痛，痛引膺，目䀮䀮然，甚則反折，舌卷不能言；刺內筋為二痏，在內踝上大筋前，太陰後上踝二寸所。散脈令人腰痛而熱，熱甚生煩，腰下如有橫木居其中，甚則遺溲，刺散脈，在膝前骨肉分間，絡外廉束脈為三痏。肉里之脈，令人腰痛，不可以欬，欬則筋縮急，刺肉里之脈為二痏，在太陽之外，少陽絕骨之後。 Foot Too Yang channel, causing lower back pain that refers to the shoulder blades and makes one feel heavy; puncture the Shu-point of the Too Yang channel at the Yuan level, and there will be bleeding without seeing blood in spring. The Shao Yin causes lower back pain, similar to inserting an awl through the skin; when one leans forward or looks back, there is no relief. Puncture the Shao Yin at the Sinew Channel point on the inner side of the knee, and in spring there will be bleeding without seeing blood. The Yang Ming causes lower back pain, preventing one from looking back as if looking at something; puncture the Yang Ming at the Lung channel point of the first three Jing-well points, connect the blood and bleed. In autumn, the foot Too Yin channel causes lower back pain that refers to the inside of the lumbar region; puncture the Too Yin at the point two cun above the inner ankle bone, in spring there will be excessive bleeding, which cannot be stopped. The Kidney Yin channel causes lower back pain, like a tight bowstring; puncture the Kidney Yin channel, outside the Lower Sea of Qi and Shu points of the Bladder, accumulate them and then puncture, after which the disease will cause one to speak eloquently but with confusion. Puncture the Luo-connecting channel, causing lower back pain that refers to the shoulder, with blurred vision; puncture the Luo-connecting channel at the Bladder channel point on the crease of the knee, connect the blood and stop it from bleeding. The Luo-connecting channel causes lower back pain as if dragging something, always feeling like the waist is bent, causing fear; puncture the Luo-connecting channel, in the area of the sinew and muscle between the Shu points of the Governing Vessel and the Conception Vessel, connect the blood and stop it from bleeding. The same Yin channel causes lower back pain, like a small axe inside; puncture the Same Yin channel at the point above the outer ankle where the bone ends, for three cun. The Yang Wei channel causes lower back pain, with the pain above feeling tight and swollen; puncture the Yang Wei channel, between the Too Yang channel and the Bladder channel, one foot's distance away. The Conception Vessel channel causes lower back pain, preventing one from looking up as if afraid; puncture the Conception Vessel at the point of the sinew channel on the inner side of the knee, connect the blood and stop it from bleeding. The Willow (Flying) Yang channel causes lower back pain, with pain above feeling like brushing something; puncture the Flying Yang channel at the point five cun above the Shu points of the Too Yin channel and the Shao Yin channel. The Pure Yang channel of the Stomach causes lower back pain, referring to the chest and making one feel like bending over; puncture the Interior sinew channels for two cun, at the point in front of the inner knee where the Shao Yin meets the Yang Wei channel. Scattered (Qi) channel causes lower back pain with fever, and excessive heat causing irritability; with a feeling as if there is a horizontal board inside the lower back, and in severe cases, there will be excessive bleeding due to injury. Puncture the scattered (Qi) channel at the point between the sinew channels of the Stomach and Spleen, connect the blood and stop it from bleeding. The muscle channel causes lower back pain, preventing one from looking up; puncture the muscle channel for two cun, outside the Too Yang channel and the Shao Yin channel.

2: 腰痛俠脊而痛至頭几几然，目䀮䀮欲僵仆；刺足太陽郄中出血，腰痛上寒，刺足太陽陽明；上熱，刺足厥陰。不可以俛仰，刺足少陽。中熱而喘，刺足少陰，刺郄中出血。腰痛上寒不可顧，刺足陽明；上熱，刺足太陰，中熱而喘，刺足少陰。大便難刺足少陰。少腹滿，刺足厥陰。如折不可以俛仰不可舉，刺足太陽。引脊內廉，刺足少陰。腰痛引少腹控䏚，不可以仰，刺腰尻交者，兩髁胂上。以月生死為痏數，發鍼立已，左取右，右取左。 Acute lower back pain with radiating pain to the head, vision blurring and wanting to stiffen; bleeding after needling at the Yongquan point, lower back pain becoming cold, needle at the Yongquan and Yangming points. Feverishness, needle at the Weiguan point. Not to be treated in a supine position, needle at the ShaoYang point. Short of breath while feeling feverish, needle at the ShaoYin point and Xuejin point. Difficulty passing feces, needle at the ShaoYin point. Bloated lower abdomen, needle at the Weiguan point. If unable to straighten due to lower back pain, needle at the Yangming point. Feverishness, needle at the Taiyin point. Short of breath while feeling feverish, needle at the ShaoYin point. Difficulty passing feces, needle at the ShaoYin point. Unable to straighten and not allowed to recline, needle at the Yangming point. Guide the Du channel internally and needle at the ShaoYin point. Lower back pain radiating to the lower abdomen, not allowed to recline, needle at the intersection of the Bladder and Governor Vessel channels, and both the Huaivo and Pangguangshu points. Count by the lunar calendar for treatment number, stand up after moxibustion, left hand takes right and vice versa.

docs.title: 風論
docs.text:
1: 黃帝問曰：風之傷人也，或為寒熱，或為熱中，或為寒中，或為癘風，或為偏枯，或為風也；其病各異，其名不同，或內至五藏六府，不知其解，願聞其說。歧伯對曰：風氣藏於皮膚之閒，內不得通，外不得泄；風者，善行而數變，腠理開則洒然寒，閉則熱而悶，其寒也，則衰食飲，其熱也，則消肌肉，故使人怢慄而不能食，名曰寒熱。風氣與陽明入胃循脈而上至目內眥，其人肥則風氣不得外泄，則為熱中而目黃；人瘦，則外泄而寒，則為寒中而泣出。風氣與太陽俱入行諸脈俞，散於分肉之閒，與衛氣相干，其道不利，故使肌肉憤䐜而有瘍；衛氣有所凝而不行，故其肉有不仁也。癘者有榮氣熱胕，其氣不清，故使其鼻柱壞而色敗，皮膚瘍潰。風寒客於脈而不去，名曰癘風，或名曰寒熱。 Yellow Emperor asked: Wind can harm people, and it can be due to cold-heat, heat alone, cold alone, or wind stroke, or dryness, or just wind. The diseases are different and have different names. Sometimes it affects the five organs and six palaces, and one does not know how to treat it. I hope to hear your explanation.

The Duke answered: Wind energy is stored in the skin's slackness, and it cannot be dispersed internally or externally. Wind is changeable and often causes chills and sweating. If it is cold, one loses strength and appetite; if it is hot, the muscles weaken, causing the person to tremble and unable to eat - this is called cold-heat.

Wind energy and Yang Ming enter the stomach and spleen, ascending through the meridians to the eye's surface. If a person is fat, wind energy cannot be released externally, leading to heat in the eyes; if a person is thin, wind is released externally, causing cold in the eyes and tearing.

Wind energy and Yang Qi both enter and circulate through the meridians, dispersing into the muscle's slackness and interfering with defensive Qi. If the pathway is not smooth, it causes muscle spasms and sores; if defensive Qi congeals and does not move, the muscles become unyielding.

Strokes are caused by excessive heat and unclear Qi, damaging the nasal bridge and causing the skin to degenerate. Wind-cold lingers in the meridians and does not leave, known as wind-cold or cold-heat.

2: 以春甲乙傷於風者為肝風；以夏丙丁傷於風者為心風；以以季夏戊己傷於邪者為脾風；秋庚辛中於邪者為肺風；以冬壬癸中於邪者為腎風。風中五藏六府之俞亦為藏府之風，各入其門戶所中，則為偏風。風氣循風府而上，則為腦風；風入係頭，則為目風眼寒；飲酒中風，則為漏風；入房汗出中風，則為內風；新沐中風則為首風；久風入中，則為腸風飱泄；外在腠理，則為泄風。故風者，百病之長也，至其變化，乃為他病也，無常方，然致有風氣也。 Those harmed by spring's wind are afflicted with liver wind; those harmed by summer's wind are afflicted with heart wind; those harmed in the period of midsummer, by metallic influences, are afflicted with spleen wind; in autumn, within the phase of adverse influences, those afflicted are said to have lung wind; and in winter, within the phase of adverse influences, those afflicted are said to have kidney wind. Wind affecting the five viscera and six bowels is also called viscera-bowel wind, each entering its gate, resulting in localized or offsetting wind. If wind Qi ascends through the wind palace, it is brain wind; if it enters the head, it is eye wind and eye cold; when drinking, it is leak wind; when inside a room and sweating, it is interior wind; after bathing, it is neck wind; if prolonged, it becomes intestinal wind with diarrhea; outside in the hairy regions, it is a wind of discharge. Thus, wind is the root of myriad diseases. When its transformations become varied and diverse, they may be called epidemic diseases, with no constant treatment, yet they all involve wind Qi.

3: 帝曰：五藏風之形狀不同者何，願聞其診及其病能。歧伯曰：肺風之狀，多汗惡風，色皏然白，時欬短氣，晝日則差，暮則甚，診在眉上，其色白；心風之狀，多汗惡風，焦絕善怒嚇，赤色，病甚則言不可快，診在口，其色赤；肝風之狀，多汗惡風，善悲色微蒼，嗌乾善怒，時憎女子，診在目下，其色青；脾風之狀，多汗惡風，身體怠墯，四支不欲動，色薄微黃，不嗜食，診在鼻上，其色黃；腎風之狀，多汗惡風，面痝然浮腫，脊痛不能正立，其色炱，隱曲不利，診在肌上，其色黑，胃風之狀，頸多汗惡風，食飲不下，鬲塞不通，腹善滿，失衣則䐜脹，食寒則泄，診形瘦而腹大；首風之狀頭面多汗惡風當先風一日，則病甚頭痛不可，以出內至其風日，則病少愈；漏風之狀，或多汗，常不可單衣，食則汗出，甚則身汗，喘息惡風，衣常濡，口乾善渴，不能勞事；泄風之狀，多汗，汗出泄衣上，口中乾上漬，其風不能勞事，身體盡痛則寒。帝曰：善。 Emperor: What are the different manifestations of the Five Winds, and I wish to hear about their diagnosis and treatment. Taiyi said: The Lung wind manifestation has excessive sweating and aversion to cold wind, with a pale and white complexion, coughing with short breath during the day, worsening at night, diagnose it on the forehead, and its color is white. The Heart wind manifestation has excessive sweating and aversion to cold wind, becomes angry easily with a red complexion, speech becomes difficult when sick, diagnose it on the mouth, and its color is red. The Liver wind manifestation has excessive sweating and aversion to cold wind, prone to sadness with a light blue complexion, becomes angry easily dislikes women, diagnose it in the eyes, and its color is green. The Spleen wind manifestation has excessive sweating and aversion to cold wind, body weak and unwilling to move limbs, pale and yellowish complexion, dislikes food, diagnose it on the nose, and its color is yellow. Kidney wind manifestation has excessive sweating and aversion to cold wind, facial swelling and abdominal distension, back pain unable to stand straight, its color is purple, curvature not beneficial, diagnose it on the flesh, and its color is black. Stomach wind manifestation has neck with excessive sweating and aversion to cold wind, difficulty swallowing food and drink, stomach full, unbuttoning clothes results in vomiting, cold leads to diarrhea, diagnose it with a thin appearance but abdomen swollen. Wind on the head and face manifestation has excess sweating and aversion to cold wind, with the first symptoms appearing in the head and face, if sick, headache is unbearable, with the progression of the disease, it becomes less severe. Leak wind manifestation may have excessive sweating, often unable to wear clothes, sweats when eating, worsens severely with a pale complexion, always damp clothes, mouth dry and thirsty, unable to do strenuous work. Discharge wind manifestation has excessive sweating, discharge of sweat and discharge on clothing, salty taste in the mouth, unable to do strenuous work, body hurts severely when cold. Emperor: Good.

docs.title: 痺論
docs.text:
1: 黃帝問曰：痺之安生。歧伯對曰：風寒濕三氣雜至，合而為痺也。其風氣勝者為行痺，寒氣勝者為痛痺，濕氣勝者為著痺也。帝曰：其有五者，何也。歧伯曰：以冬遇此者為骨痺，以春遇此者為筋痺，以夏遇此者為脈痺，以至陰遇此者為肌痺，以秋遇此者為皮痺。帝曰：內舍五藏六府，何氣使然。歧伯曰：五藏皆有合病，久而不去者，內舍於其合也。故骨痺不已，復感於邪，內舍於腎；筋痺不已，復感於邪內舍於肝；脈痺不已，復感於邪內舍於心；肌痺不已，復感於邪內舍於脾；皮痺不已，復感於邪，內舍於肺，所謂痺者，各以其時，重感於風寒濕之氣也。 Yellow Emperor asked: What is the cause of paralysis? [Taiwan] Bo said: It is due to the combination of three types of Qi - wind, cold and damp. If wind Qi predominates, it causes limb paralysis; if cold Qi predominates, it causes painful paralysis; if damp Qi predominates, it causes swollen paralysis. Yellow Emperor asked: Are there five types of this? [Taiwan] Bo said: In the winter, it is bone paralysis; in the spring, it is muscle paralysis; in the summer, it is tendon paralysis; in the autumn, it is skin paralysis. Yellow Emperor asked: The internal organs have six divisions; what Qi causes this? [Taiwan] Bo said: All internal organs have a condition of merging diseases, which persists and does not go away. Therefore, bone paralysis does not subside, and is affected by external pathogens, it merges in the kidney; muscle paralysis does not subside, and is affected by external pathogens, it merges in the liver; tendon paralysis does not sub

2: 凡痺之客五藏者，肺痺者，煩滿喘而嘔；心痺者，脈不通，煩則心下鼓，暴上氣而喘，嗌乾善噫，厥氣上則恐；肝痺者，夜臥則驚，多飲數小便，上為引如懷；腎痺者，善脹，尻以代踵，脊以代頭；脾痺者，四支解墯，發欬嘔汁，上為大塞；腸痺者，數飲而出不得，中氣喘爭，時發飱泄；胞痺者，少腹膀胱，按之內痛，若沃以湯，澀於小便，上為清涕。 All cases of organ stagnation: - Lung stagnation causes wheezing, shortness of breath, and nausea. - Heart stagnation leads to irregular pulse, palpitations, shortness of breath, coughing, and fear. - Liver stagnation results in nighttime awakenings with fright, excessive urination, and symptoms similar to carrying a child. - Kidney stagnation causes bloating, walking with difficulty like someone pulling on the hips, and neck stiffness. - Spleen stagnation results in weak limbs, hiccups, nausea, and difficulty swallowing. - Stomach stagnation leads to frequent drinking without being able to relieve oneself, shortness of breath, and occasional diarrhea. - Uterus stagnation causes lower abdominal pain and bloating, pressing on the abdomen induces pain, discharging watery fluid when applying heat, and clear vaginal discharge.

3: 陰氣者，靜則神藏，躁則消亡。飲食自倍，腸胃乃傷。淫氣喘息，痺聚在肺；淫氣憂思，痺聚在心；淫氣遺溺，痺聚在腎；淫氣乏竭，痺聚在肝；淫氣肌絕，痺聚在脾。諸痺不已，亦益內也，其風氣勝者，其人易已也。帝曰：痺，其時有死者，或疼久者，或易已者，其故何也。歧伯曰：其入藏者死，其留連筋骨閒者疼久，其留皮膚閒者易已。 The person with yin (internal) energy, when quiet, the spirit is hidden, and when agitated, it perishes. Excessive food and drink harm the stomach and intestines. Dissipated qi (vital energy) causes shortness of breath, accumulating in the lungs; dissipated qi causing worry, accumulating in the heart; dissipated qi leading to drowning, accumulating in the kidneys; dissipated qi causing weakness, accumulating in the liver; and dissipated qi causing muscle atrophy, accumulating in the spleen. The accumulations do not stop, and it also harms internally, with the dominant winds and qi leading to harm in people. The Emperor said: In the case of accumulation, there are those who die, those who suffer for a long time, and those who are easily harmed. What is the reason for this? Zhi Bo said: Those who enter and hide (the qi) die; those who linger on the tendons and bones suffer for a long time; and those who linger on the skin and flesh are easily harmed.

4: 帝曰：其客於六府者何也。歧伯曰：此亦其食飲居處，為其病本也。六府亦各有俞，風寒濕氣中其俞，而食飲應之，循俞而入，各舍其府也。帝曰：以鍼治之，柰何。歧伯曰：五藏有俞，六府有合，循脈之分，各有所發，各隨其過，則病瘳也。 The Emperor asked, What are the six ministries? The Duke of Zhou replied, This refers to their food and drink and their place of residence, which are the origins of their diseases. Each of the six ministries has its own affinity, and when affected by wind, cold, or dampness, they act according to their affinity and take refuge in their respective ministries. The Emperor asked, How would you treat it with a lancet? The Duke of Zhou replied, The Five Canisters have affinities, and the six ministries have correspondences. By following the pulse divisions, each has its own manifestation, following its path, and then the disease will resolve.

5: 帝曰：榮衛之氣，亦令人痺乎。歧伯曰：榮者水穀之精氣也，和調於五藏，灑陳於六府，乃能入於脈也；故循脈上下，貫五藏絡六府也。衛者水穀之悍氣也，其氣慓疾滑利，不能入於脈也；故循皮膚之中，分肉之閒，熏於肓膜，散於胸腹，逆其氣則病，從其氣則愈。不與風寒濕氣合，故不為痺。帝曰：善。痺或痛，或不痛或不仁，或寒，或熱，或燥，或濕，其故何也。歧伯曰：痛者，寒氣多也，有寒故痛也。其不痛不仁者，病久入深，榮衛之行濇，經絡時踈，故不通，皮膚不營，故為不仁。其寒者，陽氣少，陰氣多，與病相益，故寒也；其熱者，陽氣多，陰氣少，病氣勝陽遭陰，故為痺熱。其多汗而濡者，此其逢濕甚也，陽氣少，陰氣盛，兩氣相感，故汗出而濡也。帝曰：夫痺之為病，不痛何也。歧伯曰：痺在於骨則重，在於脈則血凝而不流，在於筋則屈不伸，在於肉則不仁，在於皮則寒，故具此五者，則不痛也。凡痺之類，逢寒則蟲，逢熱則縱。帝曰：善。 Emperor said: The Qi of glory is also lethargic for people. Master Of Gi said: Glory refers to the Qi of grains, regulated in the Five Zang and poured into the Six Fu, which can enter the Meridians. Therefore, by following the Meridians up and down and penetrating the Five Zang and Six Fu. Glory is the fierce Qi of grains, with its Qi agile, swift, slippery, and unable to enter the Meridians. So, by circulating within the skin and flesh, dispersing in the muscles, fumigating on the Lung and Stomach, opposite the Qi will cause disease, following the Qi will cure. If it does not merge with the Wind, Cold, Dampness Qi, it will not be lethargic.

Emperor asked: Why is there pain or no pain, or numbness in some cases? Master Of Gi said: Pain indicates that Cold Qi is abundant, and therefore causes pain. Numbness without pain or sensitivity is due to the disease becoming deep-seated, and the disordered flow of Qi and blood at the meridians and collaterals. The skin does not nourish properly, resulting in insensitivity. Cold indicates that Yang Qi is deficient and Yin Qi is abundant, which benefit each other, causing cold. Heat indicates that Yang Qi is abundant and Yin Qi is deficient, and the pathogenic factor attacks Yang or Yin, causing numbness and heat. Sweating and becoming damp indicates meeting excessive Dampness, with Yang Qi deficient and Yin Qi abundant, causing the two Qis to feel each other, resulting in sweating and becoming damp.

Emperor asked: What causes numbness without pain? Master Of Gi said: Numbness resides in the bones, making it heavy; numbness resides in the meridians, making blood congeal and not flow; numbness resides in the tendons, making them unable to bend and stretch; numbness resides in the flesh, causing insensitivity; so if all five of these are present, there is no pain. All cases of numbness have different treatments: encountering Cold will cause constriction, encountering Heat will cause stretching.

Emperor said: Good. Why do some types of numbness hurt and others do not? Master Of Gi said: Numbness is in the bones, making it heavy; numbness resides in the meridians, causing blood to congeal and not flow; numbness resides in the tendons, making them unable to bend and stretch; numbness resides in the flesh, causing insensitivity; so if all five of these are present, there is no pain. All cases of numbness have different treatments: encountering Cold will cause constriction, encountering Heat will cause stretching. Emperor said: Good

docs.title: 痿論
docs.text:
1: 黃帝問曰：五藏使人痿，何也。歧伯對曰：肺主身之皮毛，心主身之血脈，肝主身之筋膜，脾主身之肌肉，腎主身之骨髓。故肺熱葉焦，則皮毛虛弱，急薄著則生痿躄也；心氣熱，則下脈厥而上，上則下脈虛，虛則生脈痿，樞折挈，脛縱而不任地也；肝氣熱，則膽泄口苦筋膜乾，筋膜乾則筋急而攣，發為筋痿；脾氣熱，則胃乾而渴，肌肉不仁，發為肉痿；腎氣熱，則腰脊不舉，骨枯而髓減，發為骨痿。 Yellow Emperor asked, The Five Organs cause impotence, why is that? The Grand Officer replied, The Lung governs the skin and hair of the body, the Heart governs the blood vessels of the body, the Liver governs the tendons and membranes of the body, the Spleen governs the muscle tissue of the body, and the Kidney governs the bone marrow of the body. Therefore, when Lung is heated, the skin and hair become weak, and if they are not properly nourished, it leads to impotence and involuntary discharge; when Heart's Qi is heated, the blood vessels below become deficient while those above become excessive, leading to deficiency of blood vessels below, which results in weak pulse, causing impotence, limp erections, and inability to stand upright; when Liver's Qi is heated, the Gallbladder leaks, causing bitterness, drying up of tendons and membranes, resulting in stiff and spasmodic muscles, leading to impotence; when Spleen's Qi is heated, the Stomach becomes dry and one experiences thirst, muscle tissue not being nourished properly leads to muscle weakness, causing atrophy of muscle tissue; when Kidney's Qi is heated, the backbone does not support properly, bones become brittle and marrow decreases, resulting in impotence due to weak bones.

2: 帝曰：何以得之。歧伯曰：肺者藏之長也，為心之蓋也；有所失亡，所求不得，則發肺鳴，鳴則肺熱葉焦，故曰：五藏因肺熱葉焦，發為痿躄，此之謂也。悲哀太甚，則胞絡絕，胞絡絕，則陽氣內動，發則心下崩數溲血也。故《本病》曰：大經空虛，發為肌痺，傳為脈痿。思想無窮，所願不得，意淫於外，入房太甚，宗筋弛縱，發為筋痿，及為白淫。故《下經》曰：筋痿者，生於肝使內也。有漸於濕以水為事，若有所留居處相濕，肌肉濡漬，痺而不仁，發為肉痿。故《下經》曰：肉痿者，得之濕地也。有所遠行勞倦，逢大熱而渴，渴則陽氣內伐，內伐則熱舍於腎，腎者，水藏也，今水不勝火，則骨枯而髓虛，故足不任身，發為骨痿。故《下經》曰，骨痿者，生於大熱也。帝曰：何以別之。歧伯曰：肺熱者，色白而毛敗；心熱者，色赤而絡脈溢，肝熱者，色蒼而爪枯；脾熱者，色黃而肉蠕動；腎熱者，色黑而齒槁。 The Emperor asked, How can it be obtained? The Duke of Tang replied: The lungs are the storehouse of Qi and serve as a cover for the heart; when there is something lost or missing and one cannot obtain what they seek, the lungs will emit a sound, and once there is a sound, the lungs will heat and burn the leaves, thus causing it to be called 'five storehouses due to lung heat and burning of the leaves.' It is said: when grief is too great, the channels will stop, and once the channels have stopped, the Yang Qi will move internally, leading to palpitations and bleeding below the heart. Therefore, in the treatise on Originating Diseases, it is said: 'Great vacuity leads to muscle paralysis, and this is called the disease.' Contemplation without end results in desires not being fulfilled, and one's intentions become excessive outside, leading to a dwelling place that is too wet. The muscles become flaccid and unable to tendon reflex, resulting in muscle weakness. Therefore, in the treatise on Diseases of the Extremities, it is said: 'Muscle weakness comes from a damp environment.' When one engages in distant travel and becomes tired, encountering great heat while thirsty, the Yang Qi retreats internally, causing the heat to reside in the kidneys, which are the water storehouse. If water cannot withstand fire, then bones will dry up and marrow will be depleted, resulting in weakness of the limbs. Therefore, in the treatise on Diseases of the Extremities, it is said: 'Bone weakness comes from great heat.' The Emperor asked, How can they be distinguished? The Duke of Tang replied: Lung heat manifests as a pale complexion and hair falling; heart heat manifests as a reddish complexion with overflowing channels and vessels; liver heat manifests as a blue-green complexion with nails becoming dry; spleen heat manifests as a yellow complexion with muscle tremors; kidney heat manifests as a dark complexion with teeth becoming worn.

3: 帝曰：如夫子言可矣，論言治痿者獨取陽明何也。歧伯曰：陽明者，五藏六府之海，主閏宗筋，宗筋主束骨而利機關也。衝脈者經脈之海也，主滲灌谿谷，與陽明合於宗筋，陰陽揔宗筋之會，會於氣街，而陽明為之長，皆屬於帶脈，而絡於督脈。故陽明虛則宗筋縱，帶脈不引，故足痿不用也。帝曰：治之柰何。歧伯曰：各補其滎而通其俞，調其虛實，和其逆順，筋脈骨肉，各以其時受月，則病已矣。帝曰：善。 Emperor said: If Master's words are true, how can one take the Yangming for treating paralysis? Hui Bo said: The Yangming is the sea of the Five Zang and Six Fu organs, which governs the Yuan Shen and Gu Qi, and the Yuan Shen governs binding the bones and nourishing the Jing Luo vessels. The Jing vessels are the sea of the Conception Vessel, which governs the Gui and Luo rivers, and merge with the Yangming at the Yuan Shen, where the Yin and Yang meet the Yuan Shen, meeting at the Qi Street. In this case, the Yangming provides length, and all belong to the Conception Vessel, and are governed by the Governor Vessel. Therefore, if the Yangming is deficient, the Yuan Shen is disordered, the Conception Vessel does not guide, and thus the paralysis occurs. Emperor asked: How can it be treated? Hui Bo said: Each organ should be supplemented and opened accordingly, regulate its excess and deficiency, harmonize its ascending and descending, sinews, vessels, bones, and flesh should each be governed by their respective time to receive the moon phase, then the illness will resolve. Emperor said: Good.

docs.title: 厥論
docs.text:
1: 黃帝問曰：厥之寒熱者何也。歧伯對曰：陽氣衰於下，則為寒厥；陰氣衰於下，則為熱厥。帝曰：熱厥之為熱也，必起於足下者，何也。歧伯曰：陽氣起於足五指之表，陰脈者，集於足下而聚於足心，故陽氣勝，則足下熱也。帝曰：寒厥之為寒也，必從五指而上於膝者，何也。歧伯曰：陰氣起於五指之裏，集於膝下而聚於膝上，故陰氣勝，則從五指至膝上寒，其寒也，不從外，皆從內也。帝曰：寒厥何失而然也。歧伯曰：前陰者，宗筋之所聚，太陰陽明之所合也。春夏則陽氣多而陰氣少，秋冬則陰氣盛而陽氣衰，此人者質壯，以秋冬奪於所用，下氣上爭不能復，精氣溢下，邪氣因從之而上也；氣因於中，陽氣衰，不能滲營其經絡，陽氣日損，陰氣獨在，故手足為之寒也。帝曰：熱厥何如而然也。歧伯曰：酒入於胃，則絡脈滿而經脈虛；脾主為胃行其津液者也，陰氣虛，則陽氣入，陽氣入，則胃不和，胃不和，則精氣竭，精氣竭，則不營其四支也。此人必數醉若飽以入房，氣聚於脾中不得散，酒氣與穀氣相薄，熱盛於中，故熱徧於身內熱而溺赤也。夫酒氣盛而慓悍，腎氣有衰，陽氣獨勝，故手足為之熱也。帝曰：厥或令人腹滿，或令人暴不知人，或至半日遠至一日乃知人者，何也。歧伯曰：陰氣盛於上則下虛，下虛則腹脹滿；陽氣盛於上，則下氣重上而邪氣逆，逆則陽氣亂，陽氣亂則不知人也。 Emperor asked: What is the cause of cold and fever? Hua Tuo replied: When yang qi declines below, it leads to a cold condition; when yin qi declines below, it leads to a feverish condition. Emperor asked: If the fever condition is due to the foot, what is the reason for this? Hua Tuo said: Yang qi arises from the tips of the five fingers and yin qi gathers at the soles and accumulates in the heart of the foot; therefore, if yin qi prevails, there will be heat at the foot. Emperor asked: What is the cause of cold condition? Hua Tuo said: The yin qi arises from the tips of the five fingers and gathers at the knees and accumulates at the knee cap; hence, if yin qi prevails, there will be cold from the tips of the five fingers to the knees. Emperor asked: Why do cold and fever conditions result in failure? Hua Tuo said: The front yin is where the governing vessels gather and the Taiyang Yingming merge. In spring and summer, there is an abundance of yang qi and a lack of yin qi; in autumn and winter, yin qi flourishes while yang qi declines. This person possesses strength, but due to autumn and winter, it takes away what they need, causing the qi to struggle upwards and not be able to recover, leading to the depletion of essence and allowing pathogenic qi to arise from within. The qi is weakened, yang qi cannot nourish its channels and networks, yang qi gradually decreases, yin qi remains alone, and thus the hands and feet become cold. Emperor asked: What is the nature of fever condition? Hua Tuo said: When food enters the stomach, the network and transporting vessels are filled while the meridian vessels are empty; the spleen governs the stomach's transformation of fluids, yin qi is lacking, leading to yang qi intruding. Yang qi intruding leads to an unbalanced stomach, causing essence qi to be exhausted, essence qi being exhausted leads to failure of nourishing the four limbs, this person will drink excessively as if fully sated and go to bed, causing the qi to gather in the spleen without dispersing, the qi of alcohol and grain mingle, leading to fever within the body and appearing red and flushed. The qi of alcohol is abundant but causes the essence of the kidneys to decline, allowing yang qi to prevail, resulting in heat in the hands and feet. Emperor asked: Can cold and fever conditions cause someone to be bloated and not know who they are? Hua Tuo said: When yin qi prevails above, it leads to deficiency below, causing the abdomen to distend; when yang qi prevails above, the qi rises incorrectly, and pathogenic qi rebels, leading to confusion of yang qi, resulting in not knowing who they are.

2: 帝曰：善。願聞六經脈之厥狀病能也。歧伯曰：巨陽之厥，則腫首頭重，足不能行，發為眴仆；陽明之厥，則癲疾欲走呼，腹滿不得臥面赤而熱，妄見而妄言；少陽之厥，則暴聾頰腫而熱，脇痛，䯒不可以運；太陰之厥，則腹滿䐜脹後不利不欲食，食則嘔不得臥；少陰之厥，則口乾溺赤，腹滿心痛；厥陰之厥，則少腹腫痛，腹脹涇溲不利，好臥屈膝，陰縮腫䯒內熱，盛則寫之，虛則補之，不盛不虛，以經取之。太陰厥逆，䯒急攣，心痛引腹，治主病者，少陰厥逆，虛滿嘔變，下泄清，治主病者；厥陰厥逆，攣腰痛，虛滿前閉譫言，治主病者；三陰俱逆，不得前後，使人手足寒，三日死。太陽厥逆，僵仆嘔血善衂，治主病者；少陽厥逆，機關不利，機關不利者，腰不可以行，項不可以顧，發腸癰不可治驚者死，陽明厥逆喘欬身熱，善驚衂嘔血。手太陰厥逆，虛滿而欬，善嘔沫治主病者；手心主少陰厥逆，心痛引喉身熱死不可治。手太陽厥逆，耳聾泣出，項不可以顧，腰不可以俛仰，治主病者；手陽明少陽厥逆，發喉痺，嗌腫痓，治主病者。 Emperor said: Good. I wish to hear about the six classic meridians and their pathological disorders. The Duke of Shao replied: When there is a blockage in the Jue Yang meridian, there is swelling of the head and neck, difficulty walking, stiffness of the limbs; when there is a blockage in the Yang Ming meridian, one has blurred vision and hearing, feels restless and calls out, abdominal distention with redness and fever, sees hallucinations and speaks nonsense; when there is a blockage in the Shao Yang meridian, one has deafness and facial swelling with redness and fever, pain in the flanks, jaundice that cannot be discharged; when there is a blockage in the Tai Yin meridian, the abdomen is distended and bloated, constipation, does not want to eat, turns red with fever, sees hallucinations and speaks nonsense, with the genitals swollen and internal heat, if full it should be drained, if empty it should be supplemented, if neither full nor empty, it should be treated according to the Classic; when there is a blockage in the Shao Yin meridian, the lower abdomen is distended and painful, with bloody stool and constipation, likes to lie down with knees bent, the genitals are swollen and have internal heat, if full it should be drained, if empty it should be supplemented, if neither full nor empty, it should be treated according to the Classic; when both Shao Yin meridians are inverted, one cannot go forward or backward, causing the hands and feet to feel cold, and death occurs within three days. When there is a blockage in the Tai Yang meridian, the patient is rigid with vomiting of blood, and it is the primary disorder to be treated; when there is a blockage in the Shao Yang meridian, the channels are not smooth, leading to difficulty walking, the neck cannot be turned, abdominal distention without treatment, shock and vomiting of blood lead to death, when there is a blockage in the Yang Ming meridian, one has shortness of breath, panting, fever with redness of the body, shock easily leads to vomiting of blood. When there is a blockage in the hand Tai Yin meridian, there are emptiness and panting, and it is suitable for treating the primary disorder; when there is a blockage in the hand Shao Yin meridian, there is pain in the heart and redness of the throat, leading to death that cannot be treated; when there is a blockage in the hand Tai Yang meridian, deafness and tears overflowing, the neck cannot be turned, it is suitable for treating the primary disorder; when there is a blockage in the hand Yang Ming and Shao Yang meridians, the throat is paralyzed, the tongue and gums are swollen with ulcers, it is suitable for treating the primary disorder.

docs.title: 病能論
docs.text:
1: 黃帝問曰：人病胃脘癰者，診當何如。歧伯對曰：診此者，當候胃脈，其脈當沈細，沈細者氣逆，逆者，人迎甚盛，甚盛則熱，人迎者胃脈也，逆而盛，則熱聚於胃口而不行，故胃脘為癰也。 Emperor Yellow asked: How should one diagnose a person with abdominal pain and jaundice? Master Qi replied: To diagnose this condition, one must examine the pulse at the lower abdomen. The pulse should be shallow and weak. Weakness indicates that qi is flowing in reverse, causing the symptoms to be quite pronounced. When these symptoms are intense, heat accumulates in the stomach region and does not disperse properly, resulting in jaundice. Thus, the name abdominal pain and jaundice.

2: 帝曰：善。人有臥而有所不安者何也。歧伯曰：藏有所傷，及精有所之寄則安，故人不能懸其病也。 The Emperor said: Good. What kind of person is someone who lies down but feels uneasy? Duke Zhou said: When there is something hidden that hurts and the vitality has a place to rest, then one can be at ease, so people cannot simply hang their illnesses

3: 帝曰：人之不得偃臥者，何也。岐伯曰：肺者，藏之蓋也，肺氣盛則脈大，脈大則不得偃臥，論在奇恒陰陽中。 The Emperor asked: Why can't some people lie down and rest? Qi Bo replied: The lungs are the container for the vital energy. When the lung energy is abundant, the pulse becomes strong, causing difficulty in lying down or resting, and this relates to the discussion of the odd and even principles of yin and yang

4: 帝曰：有病厥者，診右脈沈而緊，左脈浮而遲，不然病主安在。歧伯曰：冬診之右脈固當沈緊，此應四時，左脈浮而遲，此逆四時。在左當主病在腎，頗關在肺，當腰痛也。帝曰：何以言之。歧伯曰：少陰脈貫腎絡肺，今得肺脈，腎為之病，故腎為腰痛之病也。 The emperor asked: A patient with a severe illness, examining the right radix and finding it sunken and tense while the left radix is floating and slow - if this is not the case, where is the disease located?

Huang Di responded: In winter, the right radix should be sunken and tense; this is consistent with the four seasons. The left radix floats and is slow - this is contrary to the four seasons. If it is on the left side, then the disease is located in the kidneys; if it is on the right side, it may relate to the lungs, and it could be a case of lower back pain.

The emperor asked: How do you know this? Huang Di replied: The yang ming vessel passes through both the kidneys and lungs. With an examination of the lung radix, there is disease in the kidneys, hence the kidney is related to lower back pain.

5: 帝曰：善。有病頸癰者，或石治之，或鍼灸治之，而皆已，其真安在。歧伯曰：此同名異等者也。夫癰氣之息者，宜以鍼開除去之；夫氣盛血聚者，宜石而寫之。此所謂同病異治也。 Emperor: Good. For someone with a sore throat and tonsillitis, one may treat it with stones or acupuncture and moxibustion, but in all cases the true nature of the disease remains unknown. Duke Mu said: This is an example of same name, different treatment. In the case of a condition caused by stagnation of qi, acupuncture should be used to open and remove it; in the case of an abundance of qi and blood, stones should be used for cupping therapy. This is called treating the same disease with different methods

6: 帝曰：有病怒狂者此病安生。歧伯曰：生於陽也，帝曰：陽何以使人狂。歧伯曰：陽氣者因暴折而難決，故善怒也，病名曰陽厥。帝曰：何以知之。歧伯曰：陽明者常動，巨陽少陽不動，不動而動大疾，此其候也。帝曰：治之柰何。歧伯曰：奪其食即已。夫食入於陰，長氣於陽，故奪其食即已。使之服以生鐵洛為飲，夫生鐵洛者，下氣疾也。 The Emperor said, What about someone who is ill and angry? Tongbo said, Such a person is born under the influence of Yang. The Emperor asked, How does Yang cause this? Tongbo replied, Yang qi is easily agitated and difficult to control after being jarred, which makes people prone to anger. This condition is known as Yang excess. The Emperor asked, How do you know this? Tongbo said, The brilliance of Yang constantly changes, but the large Yang and small Yang remain unchanged. They move quickly when they are not supposed to, which indicates the presence of this condition. The Emperor asked, What is the cure? Tongbo replied, Withhold their food, and it will be cured. Food enters through Yin, nourishes Yang, so withholding their food will cure them. Have them drink a decoction of Genihulu, as this herb calms the qi rapidly.

7: 帝曰：善。有病身熱解墯，汗出如浴，惡風少氣，此為何病。歧伯曰：病名曰酒風。帝曰：治之奈何。歧伯曰：以澤瀉朮各十分，麋銜五分，合以三指撮為後飯。 The Emperor said: Good. There is a disease with fever and sweating like taking a bath, weak breathing due to bad wind, what kind of disease is this? Duke Huan said: The name of the disease is wine wind. The Emperor asked: How to treat it? Duke Huan said: Take 10 parts of Zexie and 10 parts of Mu Tong, mix them with 5 parts of Ge Gen. Boil in water, then strain the decoction into a bowl as dinner.

8: 所謂深之細者，其中手如鍼也，摩之切之，聚者堅也；博者大也。上經者，言氣之通天也，下經者，言病之變化也，金匱者，決死生也，揆度者，切度之也，奇恒者，言奇病也。所謂奇者，使奇病不得以四時死也，恒者得以四時死也。所謂揆者，方切求之也，言切求其脈理也，度者得其病處，以四時度之也。 Regarding the subtle and profound, its touch is as sharp as a needle, delicate and precise, and firm when assembled; it is broad. Mastering the classics refers to understanding the flow of qi throughout heaven, while mastering the lower classics refers to understanding the changes in disease. Golden needles decide between life and death, while regulating the depth of insertion decides the degree of illness. The constant ones refer to managing strange diseases so that they do not lead to death during the four seasons, while odd ones are able to cause death at the four seasons. Regarding the odd, it prevents strange diseases from causing death during the four seasons; regarding the constant, one can cause death at the four seasons. Regarding regulating, it is a matter of seeking the precise depth, understanding the subtlety of the meridians, and accurately locating the disease before regulating it according to the four seasons.

docs.title: 奇病論
docs.text:
1: 黃帝問曰：人有重身，九月而瘖，此為何也。歧伯對曰：胞之絡脈絕也。帝曰：何以言之。歧伯曰：胞絡者繫於腎，少陰之脈，貫腎繫舌本，故不能言。帝曰：治之奈何。歧伯曰：無治也，當十月復。刺法曰：無損不足，益有餘，以成其疹，然後調之。所謂無損不足者，身羸瘦，無用鑱石也；無益其有餘者，腹中有形而泄之，泄之則精出而病獨擅中，故曰疹成也。 Emperor Yellow asked, A person has a heavy body and becomes sick in the ninth month. What is the reason for this? The Duke answered, It is due to the disruption of the fetal cord. Emperor Yellow asked, How can it be described? The Duke said, The fetal cord attaches to the kidney, the source of the yin essence, passing through the kidney and connecting to the tongue. Therefore, one cannot speak. Emperor Yellow asked, What is the treatment for this? The Duke said, There is no cure; it will resolve by itself in the tenth month. Acupuncture says, It is a condition without damage or excess. Treatment consists of promoting the body's natural healing abilities by reinforcing the deficiency and allowing the rash to develop fully before addressing it. The term 'without damage or excess' refers to a weakened body that does not require the use of jade stones. In this case, there is an internal mass within the abdomen that is expelled, leading to the expulsion of essence and the disease becoming entrenched in the body, causing the rash.

2: 帝曰：病脇下滿氣逆，二三歲不已，是為何病。歧伯曰：病名曰息積，此不妨於食，不可灸刺，積為導引服藥，藥不能獨治也。 The Emperor said: This illness causes a fullness and reversal below the ribs, lasting for days in children aged two or three. What is this disease called? Minister Qi replied: The disease is called Accumulation. It does not hinder eating, and should not be treated with acupuncture or moxibustion. Accumulation is a guide for administering medicine, and the medicine cannot cure the condition alone.

Translation: Emperor: What kind of disease causes fullness and reversal below the ribs in children aged two or three that lasts for days? Minister Qi: It's called Accumulation. It doesn't affect eating and should not be treated with acupuncture or moxibustion. Accumulation is a guide for administering medicine, but it cannot cure the condition alone.

3: 帝曰：人有身體髀股䯒皆腫，環齊而痛是為何病。歧伯曰：病名曰伏梁，此風根也，其氣溢於大腸，而著於肓，肓之原在齊下，故環齊而痛也。不可動之，動之，為水溺濇之病也。 The emperor asked: People have bodily hip joints that swell and are painful, and they are all around the area, so why is it due to which disease? Hua Bo responded: The name of the disease is Fu Ling. This is a Wind pathogen, and its Qi rises to the large intestine, causing it to attach to the muscles. The root of the muscles is at the lower part of the back, so that's why there is pain around the area. It should not be moved, but if moved, it becomes a disease of water drowning.

4: 帝曰：人有尺脈數甚，筋急而見，此為何病。歧伯曰：此所謂疹筋，是人腹必急，白色黑色見，則病甚。 The Emperor said: A person's pulse has various sizes, and when the sinews are tense, it is visible. What kind of disease is this? Hui-Bo replied: This is called Jin Jing, a condition where the abdomen is urgent, and white or black colors are seen; in such cases, the illness is severe.

5: 帝曰：人有病頭痛以數歲不已，此安得之，名為何病。歧伯曰：當有所犯大寒，內至骨髓，髓者以腦為主，腦逆故令頭痛，齒亦痛。病名曰厥逆。帝曰：善。 The Emperor said: A person has a headache and pain that does not cease with age, what is this called? The Duke of Zhou replied: There must be an attack of great cold, spreading inside to the bone marrow. Bone marrow, which serves as the root for the brain, causes the headache because it is twisted. Teeth also hurt. This disease is called severe twist. The Emperor said: Good.

6: 帝曰：有病口甘者，病名為何，何以得之。歧伯曰：此五氣之溢也，名曰脾癉。夫五味入口，藏於胃，脾為之行其精氣，津液在脾，故令人口甘也；此肥美之所發也，此人必數食甘美而多肥也，肥者令人內熱，甘者令人中滿，故其氣上溢，轉為消渴。治之以蘭，除陳氣也。 Emperor: What is the disease of someone who likes to eat bitter things? What is it called, and how does one get it? Duke of Zhou: This is an excess of the Five Qi, known as the spleen. When the five flavors enter the mouth, they are stored in the stomach. The spleen moves the vital energy, and fluids reside in the spleen, thereby causing a person's mouth to taste bitter. This is the source of being overweight and enjoying sweet things; such people have eaten many sweet and rich foods, leading them to become overweight. Being overweight causes internal heat, and sweetness causes a feeling of fullness. As a result, their vital energy rises in excess, leading to thirst. Treatment involves using orchid (蘭) to disperse stagnant qi.

7: 帝曰：有病口苦，取陽陵泉，口苦者病名為何，何以得之。歧伯曰：病名曰膽癉。夫肝者中之將也，取決於膽，咽為之使。此人者，數謀慮不決，故膽虛氣上溢，而口為之苦。治之以膽募俞，治在陰陽十二官相使中。 Emperor: There is a person with a painful sore throat. They have taken water from Yangling Spring, yet the pain in their throat persists. What is this person's condition called, and how did they contract it? Minister Qi replied: The condition is called gallbladder confluence. The liver sends out a message, and the gallbladder responds by concentrating it. This person has been pondering and worrying for some time without making any decisions, which has caused their gallbladder to become deficient in Qi, causing it to rise upwards, resulting in throat pain. The treatment is to strengthen the gallbladder with Gui Piao, and the remedy lies in the communication between the Yin and Yang of the Twelve Organ Networks.

8: 帝曰：有癃者，一日數十溲，此不足也；身熱如炭，頸膺如格，人迎躁盛，喘息氣逆，此有餘也，太陰脈微細如髮者，此不足也。其病安在，名為何病。歧伯曰：病在太陰，其盛在胃頗在肺，病名曰厥，死不治。此所謂得五有餘二不足也。帝曰：何謂五有餘，二不足。歧伯曰：所謂五有餘者五病之氣有餘也；二不足者，亦病氣之不足也。今外得五有餘內得二不足，此其身不表不裏，亦正死明矣。 The emperor said: Someone has symptoms where they are ill for a day or two with fever, and this is not enough. The body temperature is high like charcoal, the neck muscles feel like sandbags, the person has a strong smell coming from them, and their breathing is heavy and shallow, showing that they have excess energy. The small yin pulse is weak and faint, which is not enough. Where are they sick and what is this illness called?

Huo Bo said: They are sick with small yin, the excess energy is in the stomach and slightly in the lungs. This disease is called qi and is fatal if untreated. This is what is meant by having five excesses and two deficiencies.

The emperor asked: What are the five excesses and two deficiencies? Huo Bo said: The five excesses refer to having excess energy in the five diseases, while the two deficiencies refer to a lack of energy in the diseases. If someone has both the five excesses inside and the two deficiencies outside, it means their body is not expressing what's going on within them, and this clearly signifies death.

9: 帝曰：人生而有病巔疾者，病名曰何，安所得之。歧伯曰：病名為胎病，此得之在母腹中時，其母有所大驚，氣上而不下，精氣并居，故令子發為巔疾也。 The Emperor asked: Of those born, who are afflicted with diseases and disorders, what are they called, and how did they come to have them? Duke Mu replied: They are called 'uterine diseases.' These are acquired when the mother is greatly surprised while pregnant. Her vital energy ascends and does not descend; her essence and vital energy both gather, causing the child to be born with diseases and disorders.

10: 帝曰：有病痝然如有水狀，切其脈大緊，身無痛者，形不瘦不能食，食少，名為何病。歧伯曰：病生在腎，名為腎風。腎風而不能食善驚，驚已，心氣痿者死。帝曰：善。 The Emperor asked: There is a disease where one's body becomes limp like a corpse, but there is no pain when the pulse is taken. The person cannot gain weight nor can they eat, and they eat little; what is this disease called? Duke of Shou replied: The disease originates from the kidney, and it is called kidney wind. If one has kidney wind and cannot eat well, and it becomes an emergency, then if the vital energy of the heart weakens, death will ensue. The Emperor said: Very good.

docs.title: 大奇論
docs.text:
1: 肝滿腎滿肺滿皆實，即為腫。肺之雍喘而兩胠滿，肝雍兩胠滿，臥則驚，不得小便；腎雍腳下至少腹滿，脛有大小，髀䯒大跛，易偏枯。 The liver and kidneys are both full, resulting in swelling. The lungs become wheezy, causing the abdomen to be distended, the liver also causes the abdomen to be distended, lying down brings about surprise, one cannot urinate; the kidneys become swollen to the soles of the feet, the ankles have large and small protrusions, the hips are painful and stiff, walking is difficult and there may be withering.

2: 心脈滿大，癇瘛筋攣。肝脈小急，癇瘛筋攣。肝脈騖暴，有所驚駭，脈不至若瘖，不治自已。腎脈小急，肝脈小急，心脈小急，不鼓皆為瘕。腎肝并沈為石水，并浮為風水，并虛為死，并小絃欲驚。 Great force in the pulse, trembling and spasms. Liver pulse is small and rapid, trembling and spasms. Liver pulse suddenly violent, with shock and awe, the pulse does not reach the extent of palpitation, self-cures without treatment. Kidney pulse small and rapid, liver pulse small and rapid, heart pulse small and rapid, all lacking fullness are called pallor. Kidney and liver combined sink as stone water, combined float as wind water, combined empty as death, and combined thin desire to shock.

3: 腎脈大急沈，肝脈大急沈，皆為疝，心脈搏滑急為心疝。肺脈沈搏為肺疝。三陽急為瘕，三陰急為疝，二陰急為癇厥，二陽急為驚。 The liver pulse is large and rapid, and it is deficient; the kidney pulse is also large and rapid, indicating urinary incontinence. The heart pulse is irregular and rapid, indicating heart palpitations. The lung pulse is deep and irregular, indicating lung disease. When the yang pulses are rapid, it indicates consumption (or wasting). When the yin pulses are rapid, it indicates convulsions or stroke.

4: 脾脈外鼓，沈為腸澼，久自已，肝脈小緩為腸澼易治。腎脈小搏，沈為腸澼，下血血溫身熱者死。心肝澼亦下血，二藏同病者可治。其脈小沈濇為腸澼，其身熱者死，熱見七日死。 The pulse on the left side of the abdomen is weak, the bladder is sinking, and it has been like this for a long time. The liver pulse is slightly delayed, causing the bladder to sink easily and can be treated. The kidney pulse is faint, causing the bladder to sink and internal bleeding leading to death. If both heart and liver are involved in the sinking of the bladder, they can be treated together. A weak pulse with slight sinking in the abdomen causes the bladder to sink and the patient's body temperature becomes high. The fever lasts for seven days and leads to death.

5: 胃脈沈鼓濇胃外鼓大，心脈小堅急，皆鬲偏枯。男子發左，女子發右，不瘖舌轉，可治，三十日起。其從者瘖，三歲起。年不滿二十者，三歲死。 The stomach pulse is weak and faint, the outer pulse is large and throbbing. The heart pulse is small, tight, and urgent, all showing signs of being out of balance. Male patients have a left-sided pulse, while female patients have a right-sided pulse. If the tongue is not smooth and changes color, it can be treated, starting on the third day. For those who follow this treatment, if they have rashness, it starts on the third day. For children under two years old, they will die on the third day

6: 脈至而搏，血衂身熱者死，脈來懸鉤浮為常脈。脈至如喘名曰暴厥，暴厥者，不知與人言。脈至如數，使人暴驚，三四日自已。 When the pulse arrives, it struggles; when the blood congeals and the body is hot, death ensues. When the pulse comes, it hangs and floats like a common pulse. When the pulse arrives like gasping, it is called violent apoplexy, and those suffering from it cannot communicate with others. When the pulse arrives like counting, it startles people and lasts for three or four days.

7: 脈至浮合，浮合如數，一息十至以上，是經氣予不足也，微見九十日死，脈至如火薪然，是心精之予奪也，草乾而死；脈至如散葉，是肝氣予虛也，木葉落而死；脈至如省客，省客者，脈塞而鼓，是腎氣予不足也，懸去棗華而死；脈至如丸泥是胃精予不足也，榆莢落而死；脈至如橫格，是膽氣予不足也，禾熟而死；脈至如弦縷，是胞精予不足也，病善言，下霜而死，不言可治；脈至如交漆，交漆者，左右傍至也，微見三十日死；脈至如涌泉浮鼓，肌中太陽氣予不足也，少氣味，韭英而死。脈至如頹土之狀，按之不得，是肌氣予不足也，五色先見黑白壘發死；脈至如懸雍，懸雍者浮，揣切之益大，是十二俞之予不足也，水凝而死；脈至如偃刀，偃刀者，浮之小急，按之堅大急，五藏菀熟，寒熱獨并於腎也，如此其人不得坐，立春而死，脈至如丸滑不直手，不直手者，按之不可得也，是大腸氣予不足也，棗葉生而死；脈至如華者，令人善恐，不欲坐臥，行立常聽，是小腸氣予不足也，季秋而死。 The pulse is described as being in various states, leading to different deaths. - Pulse at the state of floating together, like numbers, one breath of ten counts, it indicates insufficient Qi from the channels; a hint of death in ninety days. The person dies when the grass dries up. - Pulse at the state of scattered leaves, indicates deficient liver Qi; the leaves fall and the person dies. - Pulse at the state of stalls, the stall being when the pulse is blocked but the armpits pound; insufficient kidney Qi; the peach blossoms wither and the person dies. - Pulse at the state of baked clay, indicates deficient stomach Qi; the jiuweed withers and the person dies. - Pulse at the state of planks, indicates deficient gallbladder Qi; the wheat ripens and the person dies. - Pulse at the state of twisted strings, indicates deficient uterine Qi; the patient's speech is good but has a white discharge and dies. - Pulse at the state of lacquered joinery, means that the left and right are about to happen; hint of death in thirty days. - Pulse at the state of gushing springs and pounding, it's the Yang Qi from the muscles insufficient; shortness of breath, mugwort flowers bloom and the person dies. - Pulse at the state of rotten earth, press it and it doesn't sink in, indicates insufficient muscle Qi; five colors appear earlier than black and white, hint of death seen in black and white. - Pulse at the state of suspended jade, hangs but is not stable, indicates insufficient Qi of the twelve meridians; water condenses and the person dies. - Pulse at the state of lying sword, means floating in a small urgency, pressing it is strong and urgent, the five viscera are ripe, cold and heat are mixed only in the kidney, like this the person cannot sit, stands in spring and dies. Pulse at the state of curved but not straight hands, indicates insufficient large intestine Qi; peach blossoms bloom and the person dies. - Pulse at the state of flowers, makes people feel fearful, do not want to sit or lie down, walking standing always listens, indicates deficient small intestine Qi; autumn hint seen, dies in autumn.

docs.title: 脈解
docs.text:
1: 太陽所謂腫腰脽痛者，正月太陽寅，寅，太陽也，正月陽氣出在上，而陰氣盛，陽未得自次也，故腫腰脽痛也。病偏虛為跛者，正月陽氣凍解地氣而出也，所謂偏虛者冬寒頗有不足者，故偏虛為跛也。所謂強上引背者，陽氣大上而爭故強上也。所謂耳鳴者，陽氣萬物盛上而躍，故耳鳴也。所謂甚則狂巔疾者，陽盡在上，而陰氣從下，下虛上實，故狂巔疾也。所謂浮為聾者，皆在氣也。所謂入中為瘖者，陽盛已衰，故為瘖也。內奪而厥，則為瘖俳，此腎虛也。少陰不至者，厥也。 Regarding those with pain in the waist and loins due to the sun, it is the first month of the sun [cycle], and during the sun's cycle, when the sun [cycle] begins, solar qi is abundant above while yin qi is not yet self-manifesting; thus there is waist and loin pain. If the disease is vacuity and affects the foot, it is because solar qi has dissolved earth qi as it emerges in the first month, and vacuity diseases are more common in winter. Therefore, vacuity results in a limping gait. The case of strong upward-pulling and bending of the back is due to an excess of solar qi contending [with yin qi] above, resulting in strong upward-pulling and bending of the back. Tinnitus, meaning that solar qi is abundant in all things and leaping, results in tinnitus. The case of wild and raving restlessness is due to solar qi being fully present above while yin qi ascends from below; with emptiness below and fullness above, this results in wild and raving restlessness. Floating leading to deafness is all due to qi. Entering the center leads to stiffness, which occurs when solar qi has reached its peak and then declines, resulting in stiffness. Internal theft results in collapse, leading to stiffness; this is a deficiency of the kidney [organ]. Inadequate nourishment from the kidneys results in collapse, manifesting as stiffness and numbness; this is due to deficient yin.

2: 少陽所謂心脇痛者，言少陽盛也，盛者心之所表也。九月陽氣盡而陰氣盛，故心脇痛也，所謂不可反側者，陰氣藏物也，物藏則不動，故不可反側也。所謂甚則躍者，九月萬物盡衰，草木畢落而墮，則氣去陽而之陰，氣盛而陽之下長，故謂躍。 Of those who are said to have heart and flank pain due to Shao Yang, this refers to the excess of Shao Yang. The excess is what the heart expresses. In September, yang qi is exhausted and yin qi is abundant, so there is heart and flank pain, which means that one cannot turn over. Yin qi governs storage, and when it stores something, it does not move, thus one cannot turn over. When it reaches the extreme and leaps, in September all things have waned and grass and trees have fallen, so the yang has dissipated and the yin has accumulated, causing it to grow below the yang, hence it is said to leap

3: 陽明所謂洒洒振寒者，陽明者，午也，五月盛陽之陰也，陽盛而陰氣加之，故洒洒振寒也。所謂脛腫而股不收者，是五月盛陽之陰也，陽者衰於五月，而一陰氣上，與陽始爭，故脛腫而股不收也。所謂上喘而為水者，陰氣下而復上，上則邪客於藏府間，故為水也。所謂胸痛少氣者，水氣在藏府也，水者，陰氣也，陰氣在中，故胸痛少氣也。所謂甚則厥惡人與火，聞木音則惕然而驚者，陽氣與陰氣相薄，水火相惡，故惕然而驚也。所謂欲獨閉戶牖而處者，陰陽相薄也，陽盡而陰盛，故欲獨閉戶牖而居。所謂病至則欲乘高而歌，棄衣而走者，陰陽復爭，而外并於陽，故使之棄衣而走也。所謂客孫脈則頭痛鼻鼽腹腫者，陽明并於上，上者，則其孫絡太陰也，故頭痛鼻鼽腹腫也。 On the Yangming theory of chilling and warmth: Yangming refers to the refreshing and warming energy. Yangming is the energy in the middle hour (noon) of the fifth solar term, which is when the yang energy is at its peak. When the yang energy is strong and the yin energy arrives, it causes a refreshing and cooling sensation.

On the condition of knee swelling but thighs not receding: This is also related to the yin energy in the fifth solar term when the yang energy starts to decline. As the yang energy wanes in the fifth solar term, the yin energy surges upwards and competes with the yang energy, causing knee swelling and thighs that do not recede.

On the condition of shortness of breath and feeling of suffocation: The yin energy has descended but then rises again, causing disruption in the lower abdomen where vital organs are located, leading to shortness of breath and a feeling of suffocation.

On the condition of chest pain and weakness: The yin energy is present in the lower abdomen, where vital organs are located, and hence the chest pain and weakness.

On the phenomenon of being shocked and frightened by sudden loud noises: The yang and yin energies are out of balance, and water and fire are at odds with each other, causing one to be startled and frightened by sudden loud noises.

On the condition of wanting to be alone and closing oneself off: The yin and yang energies are out of balance, and when the yang energy is depleted and the yin energy is in excess, it leads to a desire for solitude and closure.

On the condition of wanting to sing and climb high during illness: The yin and yang energies are competing, with the external force leaning towards the yang energy, leading to the desire to sing and climb high during illness.

On the phenomenon of Toung-Chi (client's grandson) pulse and headache, nasal congestion, and abdominal distension: The Yangming energy is present in the upper body, where the grandson pulse is located. The presence of the grandson pulse indicates an imbalance of yin and yang energies, leading to headache, nasal congestion, and abdominal distension.
