The Twelve Fundamentals originate from Four Gates, and the Four Gates govern the Five Organs. If there is a disorder in the Five Organs, they should be treated with the Twelve Fundamentals. The Twelve Fundamentals are what establish the flavors of the 365 nodes of Qi in the Five Organs. If there is a disorder in the Five Organs, it should be addressed through the Twelve Fundamentals. Each of the Twelve Fundamentals has its own origin. Knowing their origins and understanding their applicability allows for the identification of disorders in the Five Organs.

In the Yang phase, there is a deficiency of Shao Yin (Lesser Yin), which corresponds to the Lung. Its origin is from the Taiyuan well (Yuan 2). In the Yang phase, there is Taiyang (Great Yang), which corresponds to the Heart. Its origin is from the Dadiang mound (Dang 2). In the Yin phase, there is a deficiency of Shao Yang (Lesser Yang), which corresponds to the Liver. Its origin is from the Taixi well (Xi 2). In the Yin phase, there is the extreme Yin, which corresponds to the Spleen. Its origin is from the Taibai well (Bai 2). In the Yin phase, there is Taiyin (Great Yin), which corresponds to the Kidney. Its origin is from the Taizi stream (Zi 2). The origin of the Essence is from the tail feather, and the origin of the Tendon is from the neck joint. All of these twelve origins are responsible for treating disorders in the Five Organs' six palaces.

15: 脹取三陽，飧泄取三陰。 Take three Yang, let out three Yin.

16: 今夫五藏之有疾也，譬猶刺也，猶污也，猶結也，猶閉也。刺雖久猶可拔也，污雖久猶可雪也，結雖久猶可解也，閉雖久猶可決也。或言久疾之不可取者，非其說也。夫善用鍼者，取其疾也，猶拔刺也，猶雪污也，猶解結也，猶決閉也。疾雖久，猶可畢也。言不可治者，未得其術也。 If the five viscera are in a hurry, it is like being pricked, dirty, tangled, closed. Even if the prick lasts long, it can be removed; even if the dirt lasts long, it can be cleaned; even if the tangle lasts long, it can be untangled; even if the closure lasts long, it can be resolved. Those who say that a long-lasting hurry cannot be cured are not speaking correctly. The one who skillfully uses the lancet will catch its hurry, just as removing the prick, cleaning the dirt, untangling the tangle, resolving the closure. Even if the hurry lasts long, it can still be terminated. To say that it cannot be treated is because the method has not been found yet.

17: 刺諸熱者，如以手探湯；刺寒清者，如人不欲行。陰有陽疾者，取之下陵三里，正往無殆，氣下乃止，不下復始也。疾高而內者，取之陰之陵泉；疾高而外者，取之陽之陵泉也。 For the hot and inflamed, it is like touching a pot of boiling water; for the cold and clear, it is like someone not wanting to move. In cases where yang is urgent, take three li below the navel, regulate as it approaches satiation, the qi will stop, and there will be no recurrence. For the urgency that is high inside, take from the kidney yin spring; for the urgency that is high outside, take from the yang yin spring.

docs.title: 本輸
docs.text:
1: 黃帝問於歧伯曰：凡刺之道，必通十二經絡之所終始，絡脈之所別處，五俞之所留，六府之所與合，四時之所出入，五藏之所溜處，闊數之度，淺深之狀，高下所至。願聞其解。 The Yellow Emperor asked Chi Po: The technique of acupuncture must connect with the end and beginning of the twelve channels, remain at the junctions of the vessels, meet at the locations of the five yunqs, merge at the six palaces, come in and out at the times of the four seasons, hide at the positions of the five organs, cover the extent of the numbers, distinguish between shallow and deep, reach high and low places. I wish to hear its explanation.

2: 歧伯曰：請言其次也。肺出於少商，少商者，手大指端內側也，為井木；溜于魚際，魚際者，手魚也，為滎；注于太淵，太淵魚後一寸陷者中也，為俞；行於經渠，經渠寸口中也，動而不居為經；入于尺澤，尺澤肘中之動脈也，為合。手太陰經也。 Obo said, Please ask about the next [topic]. The lung emerges from the small intestine, the small intestine being the tip of the thumb's inner side, which is called a well; it drains into the fish border, the fish border being the hand fish, which is called a creek; it enters the Great Abyss at the back of the fish [i.e., at the end of the spinal cord], which is called a broom; it courses along the channels, in the orifice of the channel, moving but not dwelling as a channel; it enters the Triple Burner marsh, the marsh being the elbow's pulse movement, which is called a union. It is the Hand Yin Channel.

3: 心出於中沖，中沖，手中指之端也，為井木；流於勞宮，勞宮掌中中指本節之內間也，為滎；注于大陵，大陵掌後兩骨之間方下者也，為俞；行於間使，間使之道，兩筋之間，三寸之中也，有過則至，無過則止，為經；入于曲澤，曲澤，肘內廉下陷者之中也，屈而得之，為合。手少陰也。 The heart is located in the central cavity, the central cavity, at the tip of the hand; it serves as the well. It flows into the Palace of Labor, within the Palace of Labor, between the first and second joints of the thumb, serving as the Sanjiao (Triple Burner). It registers at the Great Limit, at the junction of the posterior two bones near the bottom, serving as Guan (the Official). It acts on the Intermediary Vessel, the path of the tendons, between the muscles, three cun in length; if it overreaches, it arrives, and if it does not overreach, it stops, becoming a classic. It enters the Curved Basin, the Curved Basin, at the hollow beneath the crook of the elbow; bending, one receives it, serving as a union. The hand is yin in nature.

4: 肝出于大敦，大敦者，足大趾之端，及三毛之中也，為井木；溜于行間，行間足大趾間也，為滎；注于太沖，太沖行間上二寸陷者之中也，為俞；行于中封，中封內踝之前一寸半，陷者之中，使逆則宛，使和則通，搖足而得之，為經；入于曲泉，曲泉輔骨之下，大筋之上也，屈膝而得之，為合。足厥陰也。 The liver is located in the great cavity, which refers to the tip of the big toe and the area between the three lines. It is like a well; it resides in the interstices, referring to the interval between the toes, and is called jing. It enters the middle cavity, at the front of the inner heel, one-and-a-half inches deep, creating a channel that can either inverse or connect depending on its usage. It passes through qiú quán, which is located beneath the bèng gǔ (curved bone) and above the great muscle, and is derived by bending the knee. This is called hé (merging). The liver is part of the left kidney.

5: 脾出于隱白，隱白者，足大趾之端內側也，為井木；溜于大都，大都本節之後下陷者之中也，為滎；注于太白，太白腕骨之下也，為俞；行于商丘，商丘內踝之下陷者之中也，為經；入于陰之陵泉，陰之陵泉，輔骨之下陷者之中也，伸而得之，為合。足太陰也。 The spleen originates from the hidden white, which is the tip inside of the big toe; it is likened to a well. It flows into Chang'an, which is in the sunken area behind the juncture of the spine; it is likened to the Tan. It is channeled to Taiyang, at the lower end of the elbow bone; it is likened to Gu. It passes through Shangcai, below the heel hollow; it is likened to Jing. It enters the Yin's Lingquan spring, which is in the depression beneath the auxiliary bone; when extended, it becomes united, and is the foot-Yin channel.

6: 腎出于湧泉，湧泉者足心也，為井木；溜于然谷，然谷，然骨之下者也，為滎；注于太溪，太溪內踝之後跟骨之上陷中者也，為俞；行于復溜，復溜，上內踝二寸，動而不休，為經；入于陰谷，陰谷，輔骨之後，大筋之下，小筋之上也，按之應手，屈膝而得之，為合。足少陰經也。 The Spleen channels: The Spleen channel emerges from the Qimen spring, which is situated below the heart. It is like a well and is called Jin. It flows through Liangu and connects to the bone marrow at the base of the lumbar vertebrae, where it becomes the Tong. It passes behind the knee joint on the inside of the leg, stopping in a depression beneath the Achilles tendon, and is named Qi as it runs there. It courses through the Fuslu (the hollow between the muscles of the calf) to the inside of the knee two inches up, where it moves freely without pause, and is known as the Jing. It enters the Yingu, which is below the bladder at the lower end of the backbone, where it passes over the great vessels and under the little ones. When you press on it, your hand will be rewarded; when you bend your knee, you can reach it, and it is called He. The Spleen channel is the Foot-Yangming channel.

7: 膀胱出于至陰，至陰者，足小趾之端也，為井金；溜于通谷，通谷，本節之前外側也，為滎；注于束骨，束骨，本節之後陷者中也，為俞；過于京骨，京骨，足外側大骨之下，為原；行于昆侖，昆侖，在外踝之後，跟骨之上，為經；入于委中，委中，膕中央，為合，委而取之。足太陽也。 The bladder is derived from the Qi of Yin, and Yin refers to the tip of the little toes, which is called Jīnguān; it drains into the Conception Vessel, which is located in front of the lower part of the channel, and is called Líng. It channels into the Bindbone vessel, which is located in the hollow of the small leg at the back, and is called Yūn. It crosses over the Royal Vessel, which is the outer end of the leg bone below, and is called Jīng. It courses along the Bladder Channel, which is located behind the outside crease of the foot above the sacral bone, and is called Dàjīng. It enters into the Governing Vessel, which is in the central cavity of the pelvis, and is called Hé; it withdraws and is taken from there

8: 膽出于竅陰，竅陰者，足小趾次趾之端也，為井金；溜于俠溪，俠溪，足小趾次趾之間也，為滎；注于臨泣，臨泣，上行一寸半，陷者中也，為俞；過于丘墟，丘墟，外踝之前下陷者中也，為原。行于陽輔，陽輔外踝之上輔骨之前及絕骨之端也，為經；入于陽之陵泉，陽之陵泉，在膝外陷者中也，為合，伸而得之。足少陽也。 The gland emerges from the urethral opening, and the urethral opening is at the tip of the toes of the foot. It is called jing (well). The water flows into the creek, and the creek is between the toes of the foot. It is called tang (gully). The water is drawn from the edge of tears, and the edge of tears is one and a half inches below the surface. It is called gui (ladle). Water flows across the Yang link, and the Yang link is at the front end of the heel bone above the junction bone and at the tip of the tendon. It is called jing (meridian). The water enters the Yang tomb, and the Yang tomb is in the depression where the Yang channel originates. It stretches out to obtain it. This is the foot-Yang.

9: 胃出于厲兌，厲兌者，足大趾內次趾之端也，為井金；溜于內庭，內庭，次趾外間也，為滎；注于陷谷，陷谷者，上中指內間上行二寸陷者中也，為俞；過于沖陽，沖陽，足跗上五寸陷者中也，為原，搖足而得之；行于解溪，解溪，上沖陽一寸半陷者中也，為經；入于下陵，下陵，膝下三寸胻骨外三里也，為合；復下三里三寸，為巨虛上廉，復下上廉三寸，為巨虛下廉也；大腸屬上，小腸屬下，足陽明胃脈也。大腸小腸，皆屬于胃，是足陽明也。 The stomach is derived from rigor (厲兌), and rigor refers to the tip of the great toe, which is called jing. It sinks into the interior court, the interior court refers to the space between the toes, which is called Tan. It settles in the depression valley, the depression valley refers to the area between the first and second joints of the middle finger, two cun sunken, which is called Yong. It acts on the Jing when crossing the Qi Yang, Qi Yang refers to the five cun sunken area of the toes, which is called Gen, swaying the foot to obtain it. It moves in the Xie Xi, Xie Xi refers to one and a half cun sunken area above Qi Yang, which is called Jing. It enters into the Xia Ling, Xia Ling refers to three cun below the crease of the knee, outside the lateral condyle of the femur, which is called He. Descending further, it becomes the upper empty part of the Jue Yuan, descending again from the upper Jue Yuan, it becomes the lower empty part of the Jue Yuan. The large intestine belongs to the upper, and the small intestine belongs to the lower, and they are both branches of the Foot Yang Ming vessel.

The large intestine and the small intestine all belong to the Stomach, and they are all branches of the Foot Yang Ming.

10: 三焦者，上合手少陽，出于關衝，關衝者，手小指次指之端也，為井金；溜于液門，液門，小指次指之間也，為滎；注于中渚，中渚，本節之後陷者中也，為俞；過于陽池，陽池，在腕上陷者之中也，為原；行于支溝，支溝，上腕三寸兩骨之間陷者中也，為經；入于天井，天井，在肘外大骨之上陷者中也，為合，屈肘而得之；三焦下腧在於足大趾之前，少陽之後，出于膕中外廉，名曰委陽，是太陽絡也，手少陽經也。三焦者，足少陽太陰之所將太陽之別也，上踝五寸，別入貫腨腸，出于委陽，並太陽之正，入絡膀胱，約下焦，實則閉癃，虛則遺溺，遺溺則補之，閉癃則寫之。 The three Yang links: The first is the Shao Yang, which is located at the juncture of the Relic and the Gate, at the juncture of the Well. The second is the Lu, located in the center of the dip after the node, at the juncture of the Slope. The third is the Jing, passing through the Channel at the juncture of the three bones of the upper arm. The fourth is the Hé, entering the Heavenly Well at the juncture above the outer large bone of the elbow.

The Shao Yang and the Jue Yin link down below are located at the front of the foot's great toe, where they link together to form the Conception and the Shao Yang channel. The three Yang links are where the Shao Yang separates from the foot Tai Yin in order to unite with the Yang Qiao, which enters the bladder, seals the lower burner, and regulates qi circulation. If there is a deficiency, one can supplement it, and if there is stagnation, one can write it out.

11: 手太陽小腸者，上合手太陽，出于少澤，少澤，小指之端也，為井金；溜于前谷，前谷，在手外廉本節前陷者中也，為滎；注于後溪，後溪者，在手外側本節之後也，為俞；過于腕骨，腕骨，在手外側腕骨之前，為原；行于陽谷，陽谷，在銳骨之下陷者中也，為經；入于小海，小海，在肘內大骨之外，去端半寸，陷者中也，伸臂而得之，為合。手太陽經也。 The Small Intestine is called hand-sun. It connects to the Hand-Yang Meridian, comes from the Shao-Yang (Lesser Yang), which is at the tip of the little finger, and is related to the Well point. It flows through the anterior valley (frontal sinus), the anterior valley being in the hollow below the localization node on the outside of the wrist, and is called Jing-Well. It curves around the posterior valley (posterior sulcus), the posterior valley being in the hollow behind the localization node at the back of the hand on the outside of the Hand Meridian, and is called Qi-Posterior Valley. It passes over the wrist bone (radius), the wrist bone being at the front of the outside of the wrist, and is called Jian-Conception. It courses through the Yang Gully (Yang Gao), the Yang Gully being in the hollow below the localization node on the arm, and is called Jing-Yang Gully. It enters the Small Sea (Lesser Sea), the Small Sea being in the hollow inside the large bone at the elbow, with half an inch removed and in the localization node, and is called He-Sea. This meridian can be reached by stretching out the arm and is called the Hand-Yang Small Intestine Meridian.

12: 大腸上合手陽明，出于商陽，商陽，大指次指之端也，為井金；溜于本節之前二間，為滎；注于本節之後三間，為俞；過于合谷，合谷，在大指岐骨之間，為原；行于陽溪，陽溪，在兩筋間陷者中也，為經；入于曲池，在肘外輔骨陷者中，屈臂而得之，為合。手陽明也。 The Hand Yangming Meridian originates from the Conception and Governor channels. It emerges from the Shinyang region, which is located at the distal end of the index finger and corresponds to the well (Well point). It passes through the first two intervals in front of the wrist, corresponding to Tongxu points. It enters through the third interval behind the wrist, corresponding to Pigu points. Crossing the Guigu valley, it is located between the distal end of the index finger and the metacarpal bone and corresponds to Jing points. It passes through the Yangxi channel, which is situated in the depression between two tendons, and corresponds to Jing points. It enters through the curvature of the elbow, where it is found in the hollow between the lateral epicondyle and the styloid process of the radius bone and, by flexing the arm, one can access it, corresponding to Pian points. Hand Yangming Meridian.

13: 是謂五藏六府之俞，五五二十五俞，六六三十六俞也。六府皆出足之三陽，上合於手者也。 This refers to the Five Canons and Six Palaces of the Jade Maiden. There are 25 jades in the Five Canons, and 36 jades in the Six Palaces. All of these jades come from the lower Yang energy center and are unified at the hand position.

14: 缺盆之中，任脈也，名曰天突。一次，任脈側之動脈足陽明也，名曰人迎；二次脈，手陽明也，名曰扶突；三次脈，手太陽也，名曰天窗；四次脈，足少陽也，名曰天容；五次脈，手少陽也，名曰天牖；六次脈，足太陽也，名曰天柱；七次脈，頸中央之脈，督脈也，名曰風府。腋內動脈手太陰也，名曰天府。腋下三寸手心主也，名曰天池。 In the cavity, there is a vessel called Tianshu. One time, the vessel on the side of the Tianshu is the Renying of the Yangming channel and is named Yinbingshi; two times, the vessel of the Yangming channel of the hand is named Fustu; three times, the vessel of the Taiyang channel of the hand is named Tianchan; four times, the vessel of the Shaoyang channel of the foot is named Tiancong; five times, the vessel of the Shaoyang channel of the hand is named Tianque; six times, the vessel of the Taiyang channel of the foot is named Tianzhu; seven times, the central vessel in the neck is the Duimai and is named Fengfu. The Youtong vessel of the shoulder is the Taiyin channel, named Tianshi. The Jinchui three inches of the hand are the Yuzhong of the heart, named Tianchi.

15: 刺上關者，呿不能欠。刺下關者，欠不能呿。刺犢鼻者，屈不能伸。刺兩關者，伸不能屈。 Whoever pierces the gate, cannot be sneezed at. Whoever pierces the lower part, cannot be sneezed at. Whoever pierces the horn, cannot bend it. Whoever pierces both gates, cannot straighten it.

16: 足陽明，俠喉之動脈也，其俞在膺中。手陽明，次在其俞外，不至曲頰一寸。手太陽當曲頰。足少陽在耳下曲頰之後。手少陽出耳後上加完骨之上。足太陽俠項大筋之中，髮際。 Yangming is the pugilistic pulse, located in the crevice of the carotid artery. Juyang is one inch outside the Yangming, but does not reach the corner of the mouth. The Taiyang is at the corner of the mouth. Shao Yang is below the ear, at the Yangming level. The Shaoyang lies in the Great Antecubital Vein, and the Taiyang is on the hairline.

17: 陰尺動脈，在五裏，五俞之禁也。 The pulse is located in the secret cavity of the five organs and serves as the guardian of the five orifices.

18: 肺合大腸，大腸者，傳道之府。心合小腸，小腸者，受盛之府。肝合膽，膽者中精之府。脾合胃，胃者五穀之府。腎合膀胱，膀胱者津液之府也。少陽屬腎，腎上連肺，故將兩藏。三焦者，中瀆之府也，水道出焉，屬膀胱，是孤之府也，是六府之所與合者。 The lungs unite with the large intestine, the large intestine being the palace of the channeled path. The heart unites with the small intestine, the small intestine being the palace of reception. The liver unites with the gallbladder, the gallbladder being the palace of centralized qi. The spleen unites with the stomach, the stomach being the palace of the five grains. The kidneys unite with the bladder, the bladder being the palace of the body fluids. The Yang Ming belongs to the large intestine, and it connects to the lungs; hence, the two organs are paired. The three burners consist of the spleen, stomach, and pancreas; they are the palaces of transformation. The water passage emerges from the three burners and belongs to the bladder, making it the palace of the solitary. It is the site where all six palaces converge

19: 春取絡脈諸滎大經分肉之間，甚者深取之，間者淺取之。夏取諸俞孫絡肌肉皮膚之上。秋取諸合，餘如春法。冬取諸井諸俞之分，欲深而留之。此四時之序，氣之所處，病之所舍，藏之所宜。轉筋者，立而取之，可令遂已。痿厥者，張而刺之，可令立快也。 According to the text, the translation for the given literary Chinese passage is as follows:

In Spring, taking the Chong and Ren meridians, one should deeply take from the deep and shallow points. In Summer, take from the Guan sun channels, muscles, and skin. In Autumn, follow the Spring method. In Winter, take from the Jing and Guan of the Chong and Guan channels, leaving it deep if desired. This is the sequence for the four seasons, the placement of Qi, where illnesses reside, and how to store them. For adjusting the sinews, stand and take them, which can ensure success. For flaccid paralysis or stroke, spread and needle them, which can make one recover quickly.

Remember, medical practitioners should always consult with their patients and refer to standard medical practices before applying any kind of treatment.

docs.title: 小鍼解
docs.text:
1: 所謂易陳者，易言也。難入者，難著于人也。麤守形者，守刺法也。上守神者，守人之血氣有餘不足可補寫也。神客者，正邪共會也。神者，正氣也，客者邪氣也。在門者，邪循正氣之所出入也。未睹其疾者，先知邪正何經之疾也。惡知其原者，先知何經之病所取之處也。 Regarding the ease of explanation, it is easy because what is difficult to enter is also difficult to explain to people. For those who guard forms, they guard the needling technique. Those who guard spirits guard human life that cannot be supplemented with writing. Spirit guests are present at both right and wrong. The spirit is the right energy, and the guest is the evil energy. Those who stay by the door follow the right and wrong energy as it enters and exits. Not discerning its speed, the diviner does not know the speed of right and wrong energy. Recognizing its root cause, the diviner knows the location where right and wrong energy are taken from.

2: 刺之微在數遲者，徐疾之意也。麤守關者，守四肢而不知血氣正邪之往來也。上守機者，知守氣也。機之動不離其空中者，知氣之虛實，用鍼之徐疾也。空中之機，清淨以微者，鍼以得氣，密意守氣勿失也。其來不可逢者，氣盛不可補也。其往不可追者，氣虛不可寫也。不可掛以髮者，言氣易失也。扣之不發者，言不知補寫之意也。血氣已盡而氣不下也。 The swiftness of a needle is like the speed of a arrow. Guarding the gate is like guarding the four limbs without knowing whether qi flows properly in and out. To guard machinery means to know how to guard qi. When machinery moves, but does not leave its empty space, one knows the difference between real and false qi, and uses needles with speed that is neither too fast nor too slow. The emptiness of machinery is clean and subtle; needles can reach the qi, sealing and guarding it so as not to lose it. When it arrives and cannot be met, qi is too abundant to supplement. When it departs and cannot be pursued, lost qi cannot be replenished. Do not hang it with hair, for qi can easily be lost. If the needle does not emit a sound, one does not know the intention of repairing or adding more. Blood and qi have been completely expended; the qi will not descend.

3: 知其往來者，知氣之逆順盛虛也。要與之期者，知氣之可取之時也。麤之闇者，冥冥不知氣之微密也。妙哉！工獨有之者，盡知鍼意也。往者為逆者，言氣之虛而小，小者逆也。來者為順者，言形氣之平，平者順也。明知逆順正行無間者，言知所取之處也。迎而奪之者，寫也；追而濟之者，補也。 One who knows the coming and going of energy knows the reversal, orderliness, prosperity, and vacuity thereof. One who understands the appropriate time to act knows when to take advantage of energy. He who does not understand it is ignorant of the subtlety of energy. How wondrous! Only a craftsman fully understands the intention. Going with the reversal, one speaks of the energy as small and insignificant; coming with the orderliness, one speaks of the energy as balanced and harmonious. To know that there is no separation between reversal and orderliness, one can take advantage of it. By seizing it, one writes; by following after, one supplements.

4: 所謂虛則實之者，氣口虛而當補之也。滿則泄之者，氣口盛而當寫之也。宛陳則除之者，去血脈也。邪勝則虛之者，言諸經有盛者，皆寫其邪也。徐而疾則實者，言徐內而疾出也。疾而徐則虛者，言疾內而徐出也。言實與虛若有若無者，言實者有氣，虛者無氣也。察後與先若亡若存者，言氣之虛實，補寫之先後也，察其氣之已下與常存也。為虛為實，若得若失者，言補者佖然若有得也，寫則怳然若有失也。 Regarding those who claim that empty becomes real, the mouth should be supplemented with breath when it is empty. When full, release it; when full and swollen, constrain it with breath. For those who claim to expel Qi and blood, this means they have lost blood. When evil prevails in those who claim emptiness, those who are proficient in the classics speak of abundance. Those who are swift within and slow without claim reality, while those who are slow within and swift without claim emptiness. Speaking of reality and emptiness as if they exist or do not exist, reality has breath while emptiness lacks it. In examining past and present as if they are lost or existent, the reality or vacuity of the breath is in supplementing or releasing, and examines whether the breath has already settled and persists constantly. To create emptiness and reality, to gain or lose, speaking of those who supplement it implies that they have gained it, while speaking of those who expel it suggests they may have lost it.

5: 夫氣之在脈也，邪氣在上者，言邪氣之中人也高，故邪氣在上也。濁氣在中者，言水穀皆入于胃，其精氣上注于肺，濁溜于腸胃，言寒溫不適，飲食不節，而病生于腸胃，故命曰濁氣在中也。清氣在下者，言清濕地氣之中人也，必從足始，故曰清氣在下也。鍼陷脈，則邪氣出者取之上，鍼中脈則濁氣出者，取之陽明合也。鍼太深則邪氣反沉者，言淺浮之病，不欲深刺也。深則邪氣從之入，故曰反沉也。皮肉筋脈各有所處者，言經絡各有所主也。取五脈者死，言病在中氣不足，但用鍼盡大寫其諸陰之脈也。取三陽之脈者，唯言盡寫三陽之氣，令病人恇然不復也。奪陰者死，言取尺之五裏五往者也。奪陽者狂，正言也。 The Qi is in the pulse, evil Qi is on top. Therefore, evil Qi is on top. When Dampness is in the center, it means that all grains enter the stomach, and the refined Qi rises to the lungs, while Dampness lingers in the intestines and stomach, indicating cold and heat not being suitable, improper eating and drinking, and illness arising in the intestines and stomach. Thus it is called Dampness in the center. When Clear Qi is at the bottom, it means that the Qi of clear dampness is in a healthy person, and it must start from the foot, so it is said that Clear Qi is at the bottom. In piercing the pulse, take out the evil Qi from above; when piercing the Conception Vessel, take out the Dampness Qi from the Yang Brightness meeting point. If you pierce too deep, then the evil Qi will sink, indicating shallow and floating diseases, and not wanting to pierce deeply. Too deep, and the evil Qi will enter in, so it is called sinking. Each has a specific location for the skin, muscle, and vessel pulses, meaning that each meridian has its own master. Taking the five pulses when dying means illness lies in the central Qi insufficiency, but use the lancet to write all the Yin pulses. Taking the three Yang pulse means completely writing the Yang Qi, making the patient unconscious. Robbing Yin means death, referring to taking the Sinew Vessel's five places of five goings. Robbing Yang means madness, indicating correct meaning.

6: 睹其色，察其目，知其散復，一其形，聽其動靜者，言上工知相五色於目。有知調尺寸小大緩急滑澀以言所病也。知其邪正者，知論虛邪與正邪之風也。右主推之，左持而御之者，言持鍼而出入也。氣至而去之者，言補寫氣調而去之也。調氣在于終始一者，持心也。節之交三百六十五會者，絡脈之滲灌諸節者也。 Examining its color, observing its shape, knowing its rise and disappearance, discerning its motion and stillness - these are the skills of one who understands the five colors in the eye. Knowing harmony, size, small or large, smooth or abrupt, slippery or tautness - these are the faults of speech. Knowing whether it is correct or not, knowing whether it is true or false, right or wrong - these are the signs of a doctor who uses questions and listens to the patient. The master guides from the right, while holding it from the left - this refers to the use of a lancet in and out. When the Qi arrives, it leaves - this refers to supplementing and adjusting Qi and leaving it. Balancing Qi is based on the beginning and end, and holding the heart. Regulating Qi is in accordance with the three hundred and sixty-five junctions - this regulates the meridians' nourishment and irrigation of the junctions.

7: 所謂五藏之氣，已絕于內者，脈口氣內絕不至，反取其外之病處，與陽經之合，有留鍼以致陽氣，陽氣至則內重竭，重竭則死矣。其死也，無氣以動，故靜。所謂五藏之氣，已絕于外者，脈口氣外絕不至，反取其四末之輸，有留鍼以致其陰氣，陰氣至則陽氣反入，入則逆，逆則死矣。其死也，陰氣有餘，故躁。 The so-called five viscera's Qi has been completely exhausted within, and the Qi at the pulse points does not reach the outside; instead, taking the outer disease locations and merging with the Yang Meridian, needle retention causes the Yang Qi to arrive, and when the Yang Qi arrives, it leads to internal depletion, which ultimately results in death. Death occurs because there is no Qi to move, so it is still. When the so-called five viscera's Qi has been completely exhausted outside, the Qi at the pulse points does not reach the outside; instead, taking the four extremities as outlets and needle retention leads to the Yin Qi, the Yin Qi arrives when the Yang Qi reverses, which then leads to inversion, ultimately resulting in death. Death occurs because there is remaining Yin Qi, so it is agitated.

8: 所以察其目者，五藏使五色循明。循明則聲章。聲章者，則言聲與平生異也。 To understand the meaning, one must examine its intention. The five organs revolve to bring clarity to the five colors. Clarity gives rise to sounds and words. Sounds and words are different from the ordinary sounds of life

docs.title: 邪氣藏府病形
docs.text:
1: 黃帝問於歧伯曰：邪氣之中人也奈何？歧伯答曰：邪氣之中人高也。 Emperor Yellow asked the Marquis Wen: What about a person in the midst of evil qi? The Marquis Wen replied: A person in the midst of evil qi is noble.

2: 黃帝曰：高下有度乎？歧伯曰：身半以上者，邪中之也。身半已下者，濕中之也。故曰：邪之中人也。無有常，中于陰則溜于府，中于陽則溜于經。 Yellow Emperor said: Is there a degree in high and low? Boyang replied: Those above the midpoint are perverse. Those below the midpoint are damp. Therefore, it is called perverse within people. There is no constant, if it resides in the yin, it will leak into the palace, and if it resides in the yang, it will leak into the channel.

3: 黃帝曰：陰之與陽也，異名同類，上下相會，經絡之相貫，如環無端。邪之中人，或中于陰，或中于陽，上下左右，無有恆常，其故何也？ The Yellow Emperor said: The Yin and the Yang have different names but share the same nature. They meet above and below, and their meridians interpenetrate each other like a circle without center or end. What causes these deviant people to be either in the Yin or the Yang, with no fixed direction, left or right?

4: 歧伯曰：諸陽之會，皆在于面。中人也，方乘虛時及新用力，若飲食汗出，腠理開而中于邪。中于面，則下陽明。中于項，則下太陽。中于頰，則下少陽。其中于膺背兩脅，亦中其經。 Ou Bo said: The gathering of Zhouyang all lies in the face. Ordinary people, when riding on emptiness and using new strength, if they drink and eat, sweat comes out, the orifices open, and they fall into evil. Gathering at the face means it goes down to the Yijing (Yangming). Gathering at the neck means it goes down to the Taiyang (Great Yang). Gathering at the mouth means it goes down to the Shaoyang (Lesser Yang). In addition, when gathering at the breast and back, they also gather their channels.

5: 黃帝曰：其中于陰，奈何？歧伯答曰：中于陰者，常從臂胻始。夫臂與胻，其陰皮薄，其肉淖澤，故俱受于風，獨傷其陰。 Yellow Emperor said: What about the middle in Yin? Duke of Zhou replied: The one in the middle of Yin, it always starts from the arm and thigh. As for the arms and thighs, their Yin skin is thin, and their flesh is tender and moist. Therefore, both are easily affected by wind and only hurt the Yin.

6: 黃帝曰：此故傷其藏乎？歧伯答曰：身之中於風也，不必動藏。故邪入于陰經，則其藏氣實，邪氣入而不能客，故還之於府。故中陽則溜于經，中陰則溜于府。 Yellow Emperor asked: Is this because it injures the Sea of Qi? Duke of Shou answered: Inside the body, it is like being affected by wind; there is no need to move the storehouse. Therefore, if evil enters the Yin channel, then the storehouse of energy is full, and the evil Qi intrudes but cannot lodge, so one returns it to the palace. Thus, in the case of Yang excess, it leaks into the channel; in the case of Yin excess, it leaks into the palace.

7: 黃帝曰：邪之中人藏奈何？歧伯曰：愁憂恐懼則傷心。形寒寒飲則傷肺，以其兩寒相感，中外皆傷，故氣逆而上行。有所墮墜，惡血留內；若有所大怒，氣上而不下，積於脅下，則傷肝。有所擊仆，若醉入房，汗出當風，則傷脾。有所用力舉重，若入房過度，汗出浴水，則傷腎。 Yellow Emperor asked: Where can one hide from evil? Boyang replied: Fear and anxiety will harm the heart. Drinking cold drinks when the body is cold harms the lungs, as their two colds mutually generate, causing internal and external harm, leading to reversed qi movement. There is a fall or damage, resulting in stagnant blood inside; if there is excessive anger, qi accumulates in the diaphragm below, damaging the liver. Hitting servants when drunk and sweating in the wind harms the spleen. Lifting heavy objects or overdoing it in the room, sweating like bathwater, harms the kidneys.

8: 黃帝曰：五藏之中風，奈何？歧伯曰：陰陽俱感，邪乃得往。黃帝曰：善哉。 Yellow Emperor said: What of the five organs and wind? Master Of The North Said: Yin and Yang both respond, evil then takes its course. Yellow Emperor said: Excellent!

9: 黃帝問於歧伯曰：首面與身形也，屬骨連筋，同血合於氣耳。天寒則裂地凌冰，其卒寒，或手足懈惰，然而其面不衣，何也？歧伯答曰：十二經脈，三百六十五絡，其血氣皆上于面而走空竅。其精陽氣上走於目而為睛。其別氣走於耳而為聽。其宗氣上出於鼻而為臭。其濁氣出於胃，走唇舌而為味。其氣之津液，皆上燻于面，而皮又厚，其肉堅，故天氣甚寒，不能勝之也。 Emperor Yellow asked Zhong Chu, The face and body shape belong to the bones and muscles, and are nourished by blood and qi. When it is cold in heaven, the earth freezes, and its coldness may cause hands and feet to become numb; however, one's face remains uncovered. Why is this? Zhong Chu replied, There are twelve meridians and 365 channels of blood and qi flowing to the surface through pores. The Yang Qi flows up to the eyes, making them see. The separate Qi flows to the ears, making them hear. The Zong Qi comes out of the nose, making it smell. The turbid Qi comes from the stomach, moving to the lips and tongue, making them taste. All the fluids and qi of the body are nourished on the surface of the face, while the skin is thick and the flesh hard, so when heavenly cold is extremely intense, they cannot counteract it.

10: 黃帝曰：邪之中人，其病形何如？歧伯曰：虛邪之中身也，洒淅動形。正邪之中人也，微，先見于色，不知于身，若有若無，若亡若存，有形無形，莫知其情。黃帝曰：善哉。 Yellow Emperor asked: What are the symptoms of an evil person being possessed? Hou Ji replied: It is a vacant and evil spirit possessing the body, causing erratic movements. A righteous person possessed by an evil spirit appears weak, is first seen through their complexion, does not know it themselves, feeling as if they exist but also don't, as if dead but also alive, having a form without a form, difficult to discern their state of mind. Yellow Emperor said: Excellent!

11: 黃帝問於歧伯曰：余聞之，見其色，知其病，命曰明。按其脈，知其病，命曰神。問其病，知其處，命曰工。余願聞見而知之，按而得之，問而極之，為之奈何？ The Yellow Emperor asked Huang Di, saying: I have heard of it, seen its appearance, and recognized its disease, which is called clear. By palpating the pulse, I recognize its disease, which is called spirit. By inquiring about its disease, I know where it is located, which is called skilled. I wish to hear and see in order to know it, touch and obtain it, ask and be extremely proficient. How can this be accomplished?

12: 歧伯答曰：夫色脈與尺之相應也，如桴鼓影響之相應也，不得相失也，此亦本末根葉之出候也，故根死則葉枯矣。色脈形肉，不得相失也。故知一則為工，知二則為神，知三則神且明矣。 Hu Bo replied: The relationship between color, pulse, and the meridians is similar to that between oars and drums, with echoes and influences. They must not be allowed to lose each other. This is an indication of the roots, stems, branches, and leaves coming into play. Therefore, when the root dies, the leaves will wither. Color, pulse, and form correspond to the flesh; they must not be allowed to lose each other. Knowing one is a skill, knowing two is spirit, and knowing three is both skillful and clear.

13: 黃帝曰：願卒聞之。歧伯答曰：色青者，其脈弦也，赤者，其脈鉤也，黃者，其脈代也，白者，其脈毛，黑者，其脈石。見其色而不得其脈，反得其相勝之脈，則死矣；得其相生之脈，則病已矣。 Yellow Emperor said: I wish to hear about it. Huzhou Bo replied: The green one is the sinew vessel, the red one is the hook vessel, the yellow one is the conduit vessel, the white one is the fur vessel, and the black one is the stone vessel. If one sees its color but cannot obtain its vessel, and succeeds in finding its corresponding strong vessel, then it will be fatal; if one obtains its corresponding vital vessel, then the illness will have passed.

14: 黃帝問於歧伯曰：五藏之所生，變化之病形何如？ The Yellow Emperor asked Guan Pu: How do the manifestations of diseases resulting from the five organs change?

15: 歧伯答曰：先定其五色五脈之應，其病乃可別也。 Opposition Master replied: First determine the correspondence of the five colors and five pulses, then the disease can be distinguished.

16: 黃帝曰：色脈已定，別之奈何？ Yellow Emperor said: Once the pulse is determined, how can one differentiate it?

17: 歧伯說：調其脈之緩、急、小、大、滑、澀，而病變定矣。 Bo Yu said: By adjusting the pulse in terms of slackness, urgency, smallness, largeness, slipperiness, and turbidity, one can determine the nature of the disease.

18: 黃帝曰：調之奈何？歧伯答曰：脈急者，尺之皮膚亦急；脈緩者，尺之皮膚亦緩；脈小者，尺之皮膚亦減而少氣；脈大者，尺之皮膚亦賁而起；脈滑者，尺之皮膚亦滑；脈澀者，尺之皮膚亦澀。凡此變者，有微有甚。故善調尺者，不待於寸，善調脈者，不待於色。能參合而行之者，可以為上工，上工十全九。行二者，為中工，中工十全七。行一者，為下工，下工十全六。 Yellow Emperor asked, How does one adjust it (the pulse)? Duke of Shao replied, If the pulse is rapid, the skin at the wrist is also tense; if the pulse is slow, the skin at the wrist is also relaxed; if the pulse is weak, the skin at the wrist is lessened and there is deficient Qi; if the pulse is full, the skin at the wrist is also distended; if the pulse is slippery, the skin at the wrist is also slippery; if the pulse is choppy, the skin at the wrist is also choppy. Any change in these should be subtle or obvious. Thus, a skilled practitioner of measuring the pulse does not rely on the inch, and a skilled practitioner of palpating the pulse does not rely on the color. He who can apply and blend and work skillfully can become a master craftsman, a master craftsman is ten parts complete out of nine. Those who can work in two (methods) are masters of middle rank, a master of middle rank is seven parts complete out of ten. Those who can work in one (method) are masters at the lower level, a master at the lower level is six parts complete out of ten

19: 黃帝曰：請問脈之緩、急，小、大，滑、澀之病形何如？ The Yellow Emperor asked, How do diseases manifest when the pulse is slow or rapid, weak or strong, slippery or sticky?

20: 歧伯曰：臣請言五藏之病變也。心脈急甚者為瘈瘲；徵急，為心痛引背，食不下。緩甚，為狂笑；微緩，為伏梁，在心下，上下行，時唾血。大甚，為喉吤；微大，為心痺引背，善淚出。小甚為善噦；微小為消病。滑甚為善渴；微滑為心疝，引臍，小腹鳴。澀為為瘖；微澀為血溢，維厥耳鳴，顛疾。 Hu Bo said: I request to speak about the changes in the symptoms of the Five Zang diseases. If the Qi and blood are stagnant, it results in Bi and Yan; if it is urgent, it causes chest pain and referral to the back, making it difficult to eat. If it is severe, it leads to mad laughter; when it is slightly alleviated, it manifests as leaning against a pillar, with ascending and descending movement of Qi, sometimes spitting blood. When it is severe, it causes hoarseness; when it is mildly severe, it results in qi stagnation referring to the back, with an increased tendency to cry. Mild severity leads to difficulty swallowing; when it is slightly mild, it indicates qi obstruction, referring to the throat and abdomen, causing lower abdominal pain. Infiltration leads to discomfort in the muscles and joints; when it is slightly infiltrated, it results in bleeding, tinnitus in the kidney and liver area, and dizziness.

21: 肺脈急甚，為癲疾；微急，為肺寒熱，怠惰，咳唾血，引腰背胸，若鼻息肉不通。緩甚，為多汗；微緩，為痿，痿，偏風，頭以下汗出不可止。大甚，為脛腫；微大，為肺痺，引胸背，起惡見日光。小甚，為泄；微小，為消痺。滑甚，為息賁上氣；微滑，為上下出血。澀甚，為嘔血；微澀，為鼠，在頸支腋之間，下不勝其上，其應善痠矣。 The pulse is rapid and strong, indicating madness; slightly rapid and warm, indicative of lung heat and drowsiness, with coughing up blood, causing pain in the waist, back, and chest, suggesting a blocked nose. If the pulse is slow, it may indicate excessive sweating; if it's just slightly slow, it suggests weakness, paralysis, numbness, or windstroke, with profuse sweating that cannot be stopped from below the head. If the pulse is strong and rapid, it could indicate swelling of the shins; if it's merely strong, it may point to stagnant lung qi, causing chest and back pain and showing signs of evil under the sunlight. If the pulse is weak and small, it suggests incontinence; if it's just slightly weak, it indicates deficiency and numbness. If the pulse is slippery and strong, it may indicate the rise of qi; if it's just slightly slippery, it points to bleeding above and below. If the pulse is turbid and strong, it could indicate vomiting blood; if it's just slightly turbid, it suggests mice or rats that are unable to escape between the neck, armpit, and elbow, causing severe itching.

22: 肝脈急甚者為惡言；微急為肥氣在脅下，若復杯。緩甚為善嘔，微緩為水瘕痺也。大甚為內癰，善嘔衄；微大為肝痺，陰縮，咳引小腹。小甚為多飲；微小為消癉。滑甚為㿉疝；微滑為遺溺。澀甚為溢飲；微澀為瘈攣筋痺。 When the liver qi is urgent and severe, it indicates evil speech; when it is mildly urgent, it means that there is stagnant qi under the diaphragm, and it may transform into a cough. When it is moderately urgent, it indicates water paralysis; when it is mildly moderate, it means urinary retention. When it is severe, it indicates internal bleeding, with coughing and hemorrhoids; when it is mildly severe, it indicates liver stagnation, yin retraction, and coughing that refers to the lower abdomen. When it is slight, it indicates excessive drinking; when it is mildly slight, it means osteoarthritis. When it is slippery and severe, it indicates piles; when it is mildly slippery, it indicates postpartum bleeding. When it is turbid and severe, it indicates excessive drinking; when it is mildly turbid, it indicates stiffness and paralysis of the muscles and ligaments.

23: 脾脈急甚為瘈瘲；微急為膈中，食飲入而還出，後沃沫。緩甚為痿厥；微緩為風痿，四肢不用，心慧然若無病。大甚為擊仆；微大為疝氣，腹裏大膿血在腸胃之外。小甚為寒熱；微小為消癉。滑甚為㿉癃；微滑為蟲毒蛕蝎腹熱。澀甚為腸㿉；微澀為內㿉，多下膿血。 A person with a disturbed spleen and pulse is severely paralyzed; mildly disturbed it causes weakness in the abdomen, food and drink enter and then come out again, accompanied by diarrhea. Being moderately disturbed leads to numbness of limbs; mildly so results in numbness, with limbs unable to function, as if there were no disease. Severe disturbance leads to convulsions; mild severe disturbance is marked by pain in the groin area. Mild disturbance is characterized by hot and cold or fevers; being mildly disturbed causes sweating. Severe sliding (?) results in scorpion stings or snake bites with abdominal heat; being mildly slidin (?) results in internal worms. Excessive intestinal heat is severe, while mild excess leads to internal heat with frequent passage of bloody stool.

24: 腎脈急甚為骨癲疾；微急為沉厥奔豚，足不收，不得前後。緩甚為折脊；微緩為洞，洞者，食不化，下嗌逐出。大甚為陰痿；微大為石水，起臍已下至小腹睡睡然，上至胃脘，死不治。小甚為洞泄；微小為消癉。滑甚為癃㿉；微滑為骨痿，坐不能起，起則目無所見。澀甚為大癰；微澀為不月，沉痔。 The translation of the literary Chinese text to English is:

When the kidney pulse is urgent and rapid, it indicates bone marrow disease; when it is slightly urgent, it is a sign of impending collapse and running pig; the feet do not recover, and one cannot move forward or backward. When it is moderately urgent, it implies spinal fracture; when it is slightly moderate, there will be a hole, and the food will not transform. The hole refers to the inability to digest food, leading to the gradual expulsion of qi from the lower orifice. In severe cases, this can extend all the way down to the small intestine, causing death that cannot be cured. When it is mildly urgent, it indicates the onset of prolapse; when it is slightly mild, there will be atrophy of the muscles. When it is slippery and urgent, it suggests impotence; when it is slightly slippery, one will have weak bones and will not be able to stand up, and if they do manage to stand, they will see nothing. When it is turbid and severe, it indicates large sores; when it is slightly turbid, there will be amenorrhea, leading to the formation of deep abscesses.

25: 黃帝曰：病之六變者，刺之奈何？歧伯答曰：諸急者多寒；緩者多熱；大者多氣少血；小者血氣皆少；滑者陽氣盛，微有熱；澀者多血、少氣，微有寒。是故刺急者，深內而久留之；刺緩者，淺內而疾發鍼，以去其熱；刺大者，微寫其氣，無出其血；刺滑者，疾發鍼而淺內之，以寫其陽氣而去其熱；刺澀者，必中其脈，隨其逆順而久留之，必先按而循之，已發鍼，已按其疝，無令其血出，以和其脈；諸小者，陰陽形氣俱不足，勿取以鍼而調以甘藥也。 Yellow Emperor asked: What about the six variations of disease? How should they be treated by acupuncture? The Duke of Shou replied: In cases of urgency, there are more instances of cold; in cases of slowness, there are more instances of heat; in large ones, there is more qi and less blood; in small ones, both qi and blood are deficient; in slippery ones, there is an abundance of yang qi with a slight amount of heat; in turbid ones, there is more blood and less qi with a slight amount of cold. Therefore, when acupuncturing urgency, one should penetrate deeply and leave it in for a long time; when treating slowness, one should shallowly penetrate and quickly eliminate the needle, to remove the heat; when treating large ones, lightly prick the qi without allowing blood to flow; when treating slippery ones, quickly eliminate the needle while shallowly penetrating, to regulate the yang qi and remove the heat; when treating turbid ones, one must locate the pulse, following its rise and fall, and leave it in for a long time. If the patient is small, both yin and yang qi are deficient; do not resort to acupuncture but use sweet herbs for regulation

26: 黃帝曰：余聞五藏六府之氣，滎、俞所入為合，令何道從入，入安連過，願聞其故。歧伯答曰：此陽脈之別入于內，屬於府者也。 Yellow Emperor said: I have heard of the qi of the Five Organs and Six Depositories. The Yin and Yang channels merge into them, but I want to know how they are related and how they can be connected. Huan Bo replied: This is the peculiar entry of the Yang channel inside, belonging to the depository.

27: 黃帝曰：滎俞與合，各有名乎？歧伯答曰：滎俞治外經，合治內府。 Yellow Emperor said: Are Trembling Jade and Merging Cinnabar well-known? Duke of State answered: Trembling Jade governs external affairs, while Merging Cinnabar governs the inner court.

28: 黃帝曰：治內府奈何？歧伯曰：取之於合。 Yellow Emperor asked: How about governing the Palace? Hui Bao replied: Obtain it through harmony.

29: 黃帝曰：合各有名乎？歧伯答曰：胃合於三里，大腸合入于巨虛上廉，小腸合入于巨虛下廉，三焦合入于委陽，膀胱合入于委中央，膽合入于陽陵泉。 The Yellow Emperor asked: Are there named unions? The Duke of Shao replied: The stomach unites with the three corridors, the large intestine enters the upper Lung Bridge, the small intestine enters the lower Lung Bridge, the triple burner unites with Deified Yang, the bladder unites with Central Deity, and the gallbladder unites with Yang Mound Spring.

30: 黃帝曰：取之奈何？歧伯答曰：取之三里者，低跗取之；巨虛者，舉足取之；委陽者，屈伸而索之；委中者，屈而取之；陽陵泉者，正豎膝予之齊下，至委陽之陽取之；取諸外經者，揄申而從之。 Yellow Emperor asked: How should it be taken? Huang Di answered: If it is three li away, one should walk to take it; if it is huge, one should lift the foot to take it; if it is inclined towards Yang, one should bend and stretch to reach for it; if it is central, one should bend to take it; if it is Yang Mound Spring, one should sit with legs extended and straighten posture until reaching the point of inclining towards Yang, then take from there. If the distant source is elsewhere, one should bow and follow it

31: 黃帝曰：願聞六府之病。歧伯答曰：面熱者足陽明病，魚絡血者手陽明病，兩跗之上脈豎陷者，足陽明病，此胃脈也。 Yellow Emperor said: I wish to hear about the diseases of the six ministries. Huang Di answered: The one with a flushed face and hot feet suffers from a Yang Ming disease, the one with fishnet-like blood vessels in their hands has a hand Yang Ming disease, and the one with an upright pulse at the ankles has a foot Yang Ming disease, which is also known as the Stomach channel.

32: 大腸病者，腸中切痛，而鳴濯濯。冬日重感於寒即泄，當臍而痛，不能久立，與胃同候，取巨虛上廉。 A person with large intestine disease has pain and cramping in the gut, accompanied by a gurgling sound. On cold winter days, it becomes heavier and more urgent to release, causing pain when pressing on it, unable to stand for long periods of time. This condition is associated with the spleen, so treatment should focus on addressing the deficiency and excess in the large intestine and spleen.

33: 胃病者，腹䐜脹，胃脘當心而痛，上肢兩脅，膈咽不通，食飲不下，取之三里也。 For those suffering from stomach illness, there is a feeling of fullness and bloating in the abdomen, pain in the upper part of the abdomen close to the heart, discomfort in both shoulders, difficulty swallowing, unable to eat or drink, and it occurs three li away.

34: 小腸病者，小腹痛，腰脊控睪而痛，時窘之後，當耳前熱，若寒甚，若獨肩上熱甚，及手小指次指之間熱，若脈陷者，此其候也。手太陽病也，取之巨虛下廉。 In the case of someone with a small intestine disease, there is abdominal pain and back pain that hurts when pressing on the inguinal ligament. Sometimes there is heat behind the ear, if it's very cold, or there's heat on one shoulder, and heat between the little finger and the ring finger. If the pulse is sunken, this is the condition. This is a disease of the hand Jupiter (Large Intestine) Meridian, and it is treated by needing at the lower end of the arm pit.

35: 三焦病者，腹氣滿，小腹尤堅，不得小便，窘急，溢則水留，即為脹。候在足太陽之外大絡，大絡在太陽少陽之間，亦見于脈，取委陽。 In the case of a patient with a disease of San Jiao, the abdominal Qi is full, the lower abdomen is very tense, and they are unable to urinate. This leads to a sense of urgency, and if there is overflow, this can result in an edema. The pulse should be taken at the outside of the foot Jue Yin, with the Jue Yin located between the Shao Yang points, and also seen in the pulses, by palpating the Wen Yang.

36: 膀胱病者，小腹偏腫而痛，以手按之，即欲小便而不得，肩上熱，若脈陷，及足小指外廉及脛踝後皆熱，若脈陷，取委中央。 Patients with bladder disease have a painful, distended lower abdomen. When they press on it, they feel like they need to urinate but can't. They also have feverish symptoms in their shoulders and a weak pulse. Additionally, the areas around the small toe, ankle, and heel are hot, and if the pulse is weak, administer a centralized tonic.

37: 膽病者，善太息，口苦，嘔宿汁，心下淡淡，恐人將捕之，嗌中吤吤然數唾。在足少陽之本末，亦視其脈之陷下者灸之；其寒熱者取陽陵泉。 The person with fear disease, skilled in controlled breathing, bitter taste in the mouth, vomiting stomach fluids, feeling calm and indifferent in their chest, fearing that people will capture them, saliva dripping from their tongue. At the foot of the leg Shao Yang channel, also looking at the pulse's depression, use acupuncture; for its cold and hot conditions, take Yang Ling Quan water.

38: 黃帝曰：刺之有道乎？歧伯答曰：刺此者，必中氣穴，無中肉節。中氣穴，則鍼游於巷；中肉節，即皮膚痛；補寫反，則病益篤。中筋則筋緩，邪氣不出，與其真相搏亂而不去，反還內著。用鍼不審，以順為逆也。 Yellow Emperor asked: Is there a method for acupuncture? The Duke of Shou replied: To acupuncture this point, one must hit the energy channel and not the flesh joints. Hitting the energy channel, the needle will dance in the alley; hitting the flesh joints, the skin and flesh will hurt; if you correct your position, the disease will become more stable. If you hit the tendon, the tendon will become slack, and the pathogenic Qi will not come out; it will be difficult to dispel the true manifestation, and instead return to the interior. The use of acupuncture is not straightforward. It uses reverse as forward, and forward as reverse.

docs.title: 根結
docs.text:
1: 歧伯曰：天地相感，寒暖相移，陰陽之道，孰少孰多，陰道偶，陽道奇。發于春夏，陰氣少，陽氣多，陰陽不調，何補何寫。發于秋冬，陽氣少，陰氣多；陰氣盛而陽氣衰，故莖葉枯槁，濕雨下歸，陰陽相移，何寫何補。奇邪離經，不可勝數，不知根結，五藏六府，折關敗樞，開閤而走，陰陽大失，不可復取。九鍼之玄，要在終始；故能知終始，一言而畢，不知終始，鍼道咸絕。 Oboe said: The changes in the world, the alternation of cold and warm, are according to the way of yin and yang. Is there anything more abundant or less abundant? The path of yin is occasional, while the path of yang is extraordinary. It arises during spring and summer; yin energy is insufficient and yang energy is abundant, yin and yang are not harmonious, what can one supplement and what can one write. It arises in autumn and winter, yang energy is insufficient and yin energy is abundant; the abundance of yin energy leads to the decline of yang energy, resulting in withered tendrils and fallen leaves, rain falling and returning, yin and yang changing, what can one write and what can one supplement. The strange and perverse classic of the left channel cannot be counted, not knowing its root and branch, the five organs and six palaces, twisted cords breaking axles, opening shutters and going astray, the failure of yin and yang is great, unable to be taken back. The mystery of the nine needles lies in beginning and end; thus, knowing beginning and end, one's words are concluded, not knowing beginning and end, the path of needles is lost.

2: 太陽根于至陰，結于命門。命門者，目也。陽明根于厲兌，結于顙大。顙大者，鉗耳也。少陽根于竅陰，結于窗籠。窗籠者，耳中也。太陽為開，陽明為閤，少陽為樞，故開折，則肉節瀆而暴病起矣。故暴病者，取之太陽，視有餘不足。瀆者，皮肉宛膲而弱也。閤折，則氣無所止息而痿疾起矣。故痿疾者，取之陽明，視有餘不足。無所止息者，真氣稽留，邪氣居之也。樞折，即骨繇而不安于地。故骨繇者，取之少陽，視有餘不足。骨繇者，節緩而不收也。所謂骨繇者，搖故也。當竊其本也。 The Sun's root lies in the utmost Yin, and it unites at the command gate. The command gate is the eye. The Yang Brightness's root lies in severity, and it unites at the mouth corner. The mouth corner is the earlobe. If one lacks the Sun, then one will have deficiency diseases. One who has deficiency diseases takes from the Sun; if there is still not enough, it indicates a severe problem. Deficiency refers to the skin and flesh becoming weak. If the Yang Brightness is interrupted, then the Qi will be unable to rest and weakness and agility will arise. Those with weakness and agility take from the Yang Brightness; if there is still not enough, it indicates a severe problem. When Qi is unable to rest, evil Qi resides within. If the Lesser Yin is interrupted, then the body will be insecure and unstable. Those who are unsteady on their feet take from the Lesser Yin; if there is still not enough, it indicates a severe problem. The Lesser Yin refers to limbs that do not contract and collect. All talk of unsteadiness refers to the original disorder. It must be sought at its source.

3: 太陰根于隱白，結于太倉。少陰根于湧泉，結于廉泉。厥陰根于大敦，結于玉英，絡于膻中。太陰為開，厥陰為闔，少陽為樞。故開折，則倉廩無所輸，膈洞。膈洞者，取之太陰，視有餘不足，故開折者，氣不足而生病也。閤折，即氣絕而喜悲。悲者取之厥陰，視有餘不足。樞折，則脈有所結而不通。不通者，取之少陰，視有餘不足，有結者，皆取之不足。 The Yin is rooted in obscurity and whiteness, and connects with the Bao Palace. The Shao Yin is rooted in the bubbling spring and connects with the Lian Quan. The Ren Yin is rooted in Donghai and connects with the Yuying, and is attached to the Qihai. The Yin opens, the Ren closes, and the Shao Yang serves as the axis. Therefore, if the Yin is opened, then the Bao Palace and Mansion will have no outlet, causing the Qi to be blocked. Blocked Qi leads to illness. If it is folded, one experiences sadness and grief. Grief connects with the Ren Yin, and if there is not enough, it can lead to illness. When the axis is bent, then there will be knots in the meridians but they will not flow properly. Not flowing properly means that it connects with the Shao Yin, and if there are knots, then all of these can be traced back to a lack.

4: 足太陽根于至陰，溜于京骨，注于昆侖，入于天柱、飛揚也。足少陽根于竅陰，溜于丘墟，注于陽輔，入于天容、光明也。足陽明根于厲兌，溜于沖陽，注于下陵，入于人迎，豐隆也。手太陽根于少澤，溜于陽谷，注于小海，入于天窗，支正也。手少陽根于關沖，溜于陽池，注于支溝，入于天牖、外關也。手陽明根于商陽，溜于合谷，注于陽谿，入于扶突、偏歷也。此所謂十二經者，盛絡皆當取之。 The text describes the channels of the twelve meridians in traditional Chinese medicine.

  1. Shenmen (Foot Taiyang) channel: Roots at Jinggu, flows through Guangmu, and connects to Tiankong and Feiyuan. It is also related to Qixue, Changle, and Keting.
  2. Shaoyang channel: Roots at Chongxu, flows through Qiaoqi, and connects to Tiantu and Guangming. It is also related to Xiaofeng and Qilong.
  3. Yangming channel: Roots at Li Si, flows through Haiyang, and connects to Rening and Shouxuan. It is also related to Fulong, Renyi, and Shouyi.
  4. Taiyin channel: Roots at Shaoyin, flows through Guxie, and connects to Tiancong and Guangming. It is also related to Yuanbai, Jingliu, and Yaoji.
  5. Yangming channel: Roots at Chengqi, flows through Hegu, and connects to Kouchen and Shouxuan. It is also related to Renzhi, Tianjing, and Jianzhong.
  6. Yinqiao channel: Roots at Guanqi, flows through Yangchi, and connects to Tianfeng and Guangming. It is also related to Shengchun, Yuanbai, and Changsui.
  7. Jueyin channel: Roots at Mingmen, flows through Shangqiu, and connects to Tiankou and Feiyuan. It is also related to Qixue, Changle, and Keting.
  8. Shaoyang channel: Roots at Guanchong, flows through Yangchi, and connects to Tiantu and Guangming. It is also related to Xiaofeng, Qilong, and Shouyi.
  9. Jueyin channel: Roots at Yuzhen, flows through Hegu, and connects to Kouchen and Shouxuan. It is also related to Renzhi, Tianjing, and Jianzhong.
  10. Yangming channel: Roots at Chengqi, flows through Guxie, and connects to Tiancong and Guangming. It is also related to Yuanbai, Jingliu, and Yaoji.
  11. Taiyin channel: Roots at Shaoyin, flows through Haiyang, and connects to Tiantu and Guangming. It is also related to Xiaofeng, Qilong, and Shouyi.
  12. Yangming channel: Roots at Li Si, flows through Yangchi, and connects to Rening and Shouxuan. It is also related to Fulong, Renyi, and Shouyi.

The text emphasizes that the twelve channels should be studied in depth for a comprehensive understanding of traditional Chinese medicine.

5: 一日一夜五十營，以營五藏之精，不應數者，名曰狂生。所謂五十營者，五藏皆受氣，持其脈口，數其至也。五十動而不一代者，五藏皆受氣。四十動一代者，一藏無氣。三十動一代者，二藏無氣。二十動一代者，三藏無氣。十動一代者，四藏無氣。不滿十動一代者，五藏無氣。予之短期，要在終始。所謂五十動而不一代者，以為常也。以知五藏之期，予之短期者，乍數乍疏也。 One day and one night, there are fifty camps. Each camp corresponds to the essence of the five organs (heart, liver, spleen, lungs, and kidneys). The one without a count is called Kūnghsīng. Regarding the fifty camps, when all five organs receive qi and hold their pulse points, they are counted as being at that level. When fifty movements occur without passing into the next generation, all five organs receive qi. When forty movements have passed into the next generation, one organ has no qi. When thirty movements have passed into the next generation, two organs have no qi. When twenty movements have passed into the next generation, three organs have no qi. When ten movements have passed into the next generation, four organs have no qi. When fewer than ten movements have passed into the next generation, all five organs have no qi. My understanding of this is limited to the beginning and end (terminus a quo and terminus ad quem). Regarding the fifty movements without passing into the next generation, it can be considered as a constant. Knowing the time of the five organs through my understanding of this short period, my estimation fluctuates between being too many or too few

6: 黃帝曰：逆順五體者，言人骨節之大小，肉之堅脆，皮之厚薄，血之清濁，氣之滑澀，脈之長短，血之多少，經絡之數，余已知之矣，此皆布衣匹夫之士也。夫王公大人，血食之君，身體柔脆，肌肉軟弱，血氣慓悍滑利，其刺之徐疾淺深多少，可得同之乎。歧伯答曰：膏梁菽藿之味，何可同也？氣滑即出疾，其氣澀則出遲，氣悍則鍼小而入淺，氣澀則鍼大而入深，深則欲留，淺則欲疾。以此觀之，刺布衣者，深以留之，刺大人者，微以徐之，此皆因氣慓悍滑利也。 Yellow Emperor said: The five aspects of inverse and direct are about comparing the size of a person's words, bones, meat, skin, blood, and qi. I have already known these as they pertain to commoners. Now, the noblemen and rulers, who consume food and blood, have bodies that are both soft and tough, their muscles weak and pliable, their blood and qi subtle and slippery, how fast or slow their needling will be shallow or deep depends on it. The Duke of Shao replied: What is the taste of ointment, moxa, and cassia? If the qi is rapid, it will produce swift results; if the qi is sluggish, it will produce delayed results; if the qi is fierce, the needle will be small and shallow; if the qi is deep, the needle will be large and deep. If deep, one wants to retain it, if shallow, one wants to make it swift. This is all because of the subtle and slippery nature of the qi.

7: 黃帝曰：形氣之逆順奈何？歧伯曰：形氣不足，病氣有餘，是邪勝也，急寫之；形氣有餘，病氣不足，急補之；形氣不足，病氣不足，此陰陽氣俱不足也，不可刺之，刺之則重不足。重不足則陰陽俱竭，血氣皆盡，五藏空虛，筋骨髓枯，老者絕滅，壯者不復矣。形氣有餘，病氣有餘，此謂陰陽俱有餘也。急寫其邪，調其虛實。故曰：有餘者寫之，不足者補之，此之謂也。 Yellow Emperor said: What about the reversal of Qi? Qi Master said: When the body's Qi is insufficient and pathogenic Qi is abundant, it means that pathogenic Qi triumphs. Treat it urgently. When the body's Qi is abundant and pathogenic Qi is insufficient, treat it urgently by supplementing. If both the body's Qi and pathogenic Qi are deficient, this indicates that both Yin and Yang Qi are insufficient; it is not advisable to treat with acupuncture. If treated with acupuncture, it will lead to further insufficiency. When there is insufficiency, both Yin and Yang Qi will be depleted, blood and Qi will all be exhausted, the Five Organs will be empty, tendons and bones will turn brittle, causing the old to perish and the strong to wither away. When the body's Qi is abundant and pathogenic Qi is abundant, this means that both Yin and Yang have sufficient Qi. Expelling the pathogenic Qi and adjusting its reality. Therefore it is said: For what has sufficiency, treat it by expelling; for what is deficient, supplement it; this is what is meant.

8: 故曰：刺不知逆順，真邪相搏。滿而補之，則陰陽四溢，腸胃充郭，肝肺內䐜，陰陽相錯。虛而寫之，則經脈空虛，血氣竭枯，腸胃㒤辟，皮膚薄著，毛腠夭膲，予之死期。 It is said that needling fails to distinguish between right and wrong, true and false. If the channels are overfilled, there will be an excess of yin and yang, making the organs of the stomach and intestines overflow, causing confusion between yin and yang. If the channels are vacuous, then the meridians and vessels are empty, blood and qi exhausted, causing the stomach and intestines to become blocked, the skin and hair thinning and wasting away, resulting in death

9: 故曰：用鍼之要，在於知調陰與陽。調陰與陽，精氣乃光，合形與氣，使神內藏。故曰：上工平氣，中工亂脈，下工絕氣危生。故曰：下工不可不慎也，必審五藏變化之病，五脈之應，經絡之實虛，皮之柔麤，而後取之也。 It is said: The skill of using an acupuncture needle lies in knowing the balance between Yin and Yang. Balancing Yin and Yang, the essence-qi shines, harmonizes form and qi, and encloses the spirit within. Therefore, it is said: In superior work, one regulates the qi; in middle work, one disrupts the pulse; and in inferior work, one seizes the breath and endangers life. Therefore, it is said: One must be cautious in inferior work, carefully discerning changes in the Five Organs' diseases, the appropriate timing of the pulse, the reality of the channels and vessels, the pliability of the skin, and only then proceed with taking the needle.

docs.title: 壽夭剛柔
docs.text:
1: 黃帝問於少師曰：余聞人之生也，有剛有柔，有弱有強，有短有長，有陰有陽，願聞其方。 Emperor Yellow asked the Master, I have heard that people are born with qualities such as strength and weakness, shortness and tallness, yin and yang. Can you please explain how these come into existence?

2: 少師答曰：陰中有陰，陽中有陽，審知陰陽，刺之有方。得病所始，刺之有理。謹度病端，與時相應。內合於五藏六府，外合於筋骨皮膚。是故內有陰陽，外亦有陰陽。在內者，五藏為陰，六府為陽，在外者，筋骨為陰，皮膚為陽。故曰，病在陰之陰者，刺陰之滎俞，病在陽之陽者，刺陽之合，病在陽之陰者，刺陰之經，病在陰之陽者，刺絡脈。故曰，病在陽者名曰風，病在陰者名曰痺，陰陽俱病名曰風痺。病有形而不痛者，陽之類也；無形而痛者，陰之類也。無形而痛者，其陽完而陰傷之也。急治其陰，無攻其陽。有形而不痛者，其陰完而陽傷之也。急治其陽，無攻其陰。陰陽俱動，乍有形，乍無形，加以煩心，命曰陰勝其陽。此謂不表不裏，其形不久。 The master replied: Yin within Yin, Yang within Yang, discerning the Yin and Yang, acupuncture has methods. Once sickness begins, there is reason for acupuncture. Be cautious in treating the illness, correspond with the time. Internally unify the Five Zang and Six Fu, externally unify the tendons, bones, and skin. Therefore, internally there are Yin and Yang, and externally there are also Yin and Yang. What is inside, the Five Zang represent Yin, and the Six Fu represent Yang; what is outside, tendons, bones, and skin represent Yin, and skin represents Yang. Therefore, it says: If sickness is in the Yin of Yin, acupuncture at the Ling-Ju, if sickness is in the Yang of Yang, acupuncture at the He, if sickness is in the Yang of Yin, acupuncture at the Jing, and if sickness is in the Yin of Yang, acupuncture at the Luo-Vessels. Therefore, it says that sickness in Yang is called Wind, sickness in Yin is called Stagnation, and Yin and Yang together are called Wind-Stagnation. Sickness has form but no pain is of the Yang type; formless but painful is of the Yin type. Formless but painful means the Yang is complete and the Yin is damaged. Urgently treat the Yin without attacking the Yang. Formed but no pain means the Yin is complete and the Yang is damaged. Urgently treat the Yang without attacking the Yin. Yin and Yang moving, sometimes having form and sometimes formless, cause anxiety and are called Yin overpowering Yang. This refers to not showing on the outside, and the form will not last long.

3: 黃帝問於伯高曰：余聞形氣之病先後，外內之應奈何？伯高答曰：風寒傷形，憂恐忿怒傷氣；氣傷藏，乃病藏，寒傷形，乃應形；風傷筋脈，筋脈乃應。此形氣外內之相應也。 Yellow Emperor asked Bo Gao, I have heard about diseases related to form and qi, as well as external and internal correspondences. How do they manifest? Bo Gao answered, Cold and heat damage the form, and fear and anxiety damage the qi; qi damage is the disease's root, cold damages the form, which is a response to the form; wind damages the channels and vessels, and channels and vessels are responses. This is an explanation of the correspondence between external and internal manifestations of diseases related to form and qi.

4: 黃帝曰：刺之奈何？伯高答曰：病九日者，三刺而已；病一月者，十刺而已；多少遠近，以此衰之。久痺不去身者，視其血絡，盡出其血。 Yellow Emperor said: How shall I prick it? Duke Gao replied: If the illness lasts nine days, prick three times; if it lasts a month, prick ten times. The degree of distance depends on this to weaken it. If one has chronic paralysis that does not go away, observe their blood vessels and completely let out their blood.

5: 黃帝曰：外內之病，難易之治奈何？伯高答曰：形先病而未入藏者，刺之半其日。藏先病而形乃應者，刺之倍其日。此月內難易之應也。 Yellow Emperor asked, What about diseases affecting the outer and inner parts? Which are difficult to treat? Master Gao replied, For a disease that affects the outer form before it enters the interior, puncture it halfway through the day. For a disease that affects the interior before it manifests in the form, puncture it twice a day. This is the difficult aspect of treating diseases internally.

6: 黃帝問於伯高曰：余聞形有緩急，氣有盛衰，骨有大小，肉有堅脆，皮有厚薄，其以立壽夭奈何？伯高答曰：形與氣相任則壽，不相任則夭。皮與肉相果則壽，不相果則夭，血氣經絡勝形則壽，不勝形則夭。 The Yellow Emperor asked Bo Gao, I have heard that things have a time to flourish and a time to decline, bodies have periods of strength and weakness, bones come in different sizes, flesh can be hard or brittle, skin can be thick or thin. What determines whether one has long life or short?

Bo Gao answered, Form and Qi must complement each other to sustain life, if they do not complement each other, there will be an untimely death. Skin and flesh must harmonize with each other for a long life, if they do not harmonize, there will be an untimely death. If the channels and vessels of Qi are in control over the form, one will sustain life, if not, there will be an untimely death.

7: 黃帝曰：何謂形之緩急？伯高答曰：形充而皮膚緩者則壽，形充而皮膚急者則夭，形充而脈堅大者順也，形充而脈小以弱者氣衰，衰則危矣。若形充而顴不起者骨小，骨小則夭矣。形充而大肉胭堅而有分者肉堅，肉堅則壽矣；形充而大肉無分理不堅者肉脆，肉脆則夭矣。此天之生命，所以立形定氣而視壽夭者，必明乎此立形定氣，而後以臨病人，決生死。 Yellow Emperor said: What does it mean by the harmony of form? Duke Gao replied: If one's form is full and the skin is soft, then there will be longevity. If one's form is full but the skin is tense, then one will perish. If one's form is full and the pulse is firm and large, then it proceeds smoothly; if one's form is full but the pulse is small and weak, then vital energy declines, and decline means danger. If the form is full but the cheek does not rise, then the bones are small, and being small means perishing. If one's form is full and the flesh is thick and firm with divisions, then there will be longevity; if one's form is full but the flesh is without division and not firm, then it will perish. This is the way of heaven's life force, which establishes the foundation of form and determines vital energy based on longevity and perishing. By following this method, one can determine life or death for sick people.

8: 黃帝曰：余聞壽夭，無以度之。伯高答曰：牆基卑，高不及其地者，不滿三十而死。其有因加疾者，不及二十而死也。 Yellow Emperor said: I have heard that people die of old age and untimely deaths. Master Bo Gao replied: If the foundation of a wall is weak, and it's height does not reach its base, one will die before the age of thirty. If there are additional illnesses causing death, one may die before the age of twenty.

9: 黃帝曰：形氣之相勝，以立壽夭奈何？伯高答曰：平人而氣勝形者壽；病而形肉脫，氣勝形者死，形勝氣者危矣。 Yellow Emperor asked: If the appearance of Qi surpasses that of form, how can one establish longevity and avoid perishing? Master K'ao replied: One who is healthy with Qi superior to form will live a long life; but when one is ill and the flesh and skin are shed due to disease, even if the form prevails over Qi, it is dangerous.

10: 黃帝曰：余聞刺有三變，何謂三變？伯高答曰：有刺營者，有刺衛者，有刺寒痺之留經者。 Yellow Emperor said: I have heard that there are three kinds of acupuncture. What are the three kinds? Bo Gao replied: There are acupuncturists who treat military injuries, those who treat guard injuries, and those who treat cold paralysis by needling the meridians.

11: 黃帝曰：刺三變者奈何？伯高答曰：刺營者出血，刺衛者出氣，刺寒痺者內熱。 Yellow Emperor asked: What about the one who changes three times? Master Bo Gao answered: The one who stabs the camp will bleed, the one who stabs the guards will exhale, and the one who stabs the cold paralysis will have internal heat.

12: 黃帝曰：營衛寒痺之為病奈何？伯高答曰：營之生病也，寒熱少氣，血上下行。衛之生病也，氣痛時來時去，怫愾賁響，風寒客於腸胃之中。寒痺之為病也，留而不去，時痛而皮不仁。 The Yellow Emperor asked, What is the nature of the illness caused by camp and guard? The Master of Baiyi replied, The illness caused by camp is due to cold and heat, with insufficient Qi and disrupted blood flow. The illness caused by guard is characterized by intermittent pain, accompanied by irritability and restlessness. The symptoms include abdominal cramping and pain, with the wind and cold lingering in the intestines.

13: 黃帝曰：刺寒痺內熱奈何？伯高答曰：刺布衣者，以火焠之；刺大人者，以藥熨之。 Yellow Emperor asked: What if one is cold and has a numbness inside with heat? Master Gao replied: If you pierce the garment, burn it with fire; if you pierce the person of high rank, warm them with medicine.

14: 黃帝曰：藥熨奈何？伯高答曰：用淳酒二十斤，蜀椒一斤，干姜一斤，桂心一斤，凡四種，皆嚼咀，漬酒中，用綿絮一斤，細白布四丈，並內酒中，置酒馬矢熅中，封涂封，勿使泄。五日五夜，出布綿絮曝乾之，干復潰，以盡其汁。每漬必晬其日，乃出乾。乾，並用滓與綿絮，復布為復巾，長六七尺，為六七巾，則用之生桑炭炙巾，以熨寒痺所刺之處，令熱入至於病所，寒復炙巾以熨之，三十遍而止。汗出以巾拭身，亦三十遍而止。起步內中，無見風。每刺必熨，如此病已矣。此所謂內熱也。 Yellow Emperor asked: How does one moxa-burn? Bo Gao replied: Use 20 pounds of pure wine, Sichuan peppercorns 1 pound, dried ginger 1 pound, and cinnamon bark 1 pound. All four kinds are chewed and soaked in the wine. Use a cotton ball of one pound and four rolls of white cloth to put inside the wine bottle and seal it tightly so that it doesn't leak. After five days and nights, dry the cotton ball and cloth outside, then let the wine evaporate completely. When it's dry, use a container with cassia bark and cotton balls, make a wrap about six or seven feet long, which makes six to seven wraps, then use them to heat the places where you were pricked for cold colic. Warm it up thoroughly so that the heat reaches the disease area, and use hot cassia bark and cotton balls to moxa again, 30 times in total. When you wipe your body with a cloth, do it 30 times until you finish. After walking inside, you won't see any wind. Whenever you get pricked, you must moxa, like this the disease will go away. This is what they call internal heat

docs.title: 官鍼
docs.text:
1: 凡刺之要，官鍼最妙。九鍼之宜，各有所為，長、短、大、小，各有所施也。不得其用，病弗能移。疾淺鍼深，內傷良肉，皮膚為癰；病深鍼淺，病氣不寫，支為大膿。病小鍼大，氣寫太甚，疾必為害；病大鍼小，氣不泄寫，亦復為敗。失鍼之宜。大者寫，小者不移。已言其過，請言其所施。 The art of acupuncture is most skillful with official implements. The suitable use of the nine needles varies, with different lengths and sizes for different applications. If you do not know how to apply them, illness cannot be alleviated. Shallow and rapid needling causes internal injury, leaving a wheal; deep and shallow needling leaves the qi unregulated, leading to a large wheal. Needling small areas with deep insertions causes harm; needling large areas with shallow insertions does not release the qi either, resulting in failure. In terms of the application of acupuncture, larger needles are inserted deeply and smaller ones are not moved. If this is wrong, please explain how it is applied incorrectly.

2: 病在皮膚無常處者，取以鑱鍼於病所，膚白勿取。病在分肉間，取以圓鍼於病所。病在經絡痼痺者，取以鋒鍼。病在脈，氣少，當補之者，取以鍉鍼於井滎分俞。病為大膿者，取以鈹鍼。病痺氣暴發者，取以圓利鍼。病痺氣痛而不去者，取以毫鍼。病在中者，取以長鍼。病水腫不能通關節者，取以大鍼。病在五藏固居者，取以鋒鍼，寫於井滎分俞，取以四時。 For a skin illness in an unstable area, take a lancet at the site of the disease, do not take white skin. For a disease between layers of flesh, take a round lancet at the site of the disease. For a disease in tendons and ligaments, take a pointed lancet. For a disease in the meridians, with qi deficiency needing supplementation, take a flat-tipped lancet at the well point of the confluence of the channels. For a boil disease, take a corkscrew lancet. For a disease that causes acute pain due to qi outburst, take a round-pointed lancet. For a disease that causes acute pain and does not go away, take a needle lancet. For a disease in the center, take a long lancet. For water accumulation, causing swelling and unable to open the joints, take a large lancet. For a disease firmly rooted in the five organs, take a pointed lancet, write on the well point of the confluence of the channels, and take at the four times.

3: 凡刺有九，以應九變。一曰俞刺，俞刺者，刺諸經滎俞藏俞也；二曰遠道刺，遠道刺者，病在上，取之下，刺府俞也；三曰經刺，經刺者，刺大經之結絡經分也；四曰絡刺，絡刺者，刺小絡之血脈也；五曰分刺，分刺者，刺分肉之間也；六曰大寫刺，大寫刺者，刺大膿以鈹鍼也；七曰毛刺，毛刺者，刺浮痺皮膚也；八曰巨刺，巨刺者，左取右，右取左；九曰焠刺，焠刺者，刺燔鍼則取痺也。 The Nine Needles: 1. Mu needle, used for treating Mu areas; 2. Yu needle, for diseases above the waist, insert below; 3. Jing needle, for treating major channels and points; 4. Luo needle, for minor vessels or points; 5. Fen needle, for treating between muscles; 6. Da zhe needle, for treating large lumps with a curved needle; 7. Mao needle, for treating floating swelling of the skin; 8. Jue needle, left side insert right and vice versa; 9. Zhen needle, for treating burns, using a red-hot needle

4: 凡刺有十二節，以應十二經。一曰偶刺，偶刺者，以手直心若背，直痛所，一刺前，一刺後，以治心痺。刺此者，傍鍼之也。二曰報刺，報刺者，刺痛無常處也。上下行者，直內無拔鍼，以左手隨病所按之，乃出鍼，復刺之也。三曰恢刺，恢刺者1，直刺傍之，舉之前後，恢筋急，以治筋痺也。四曰齊刺，齊刺者，直入一，傍入二，以治寒氣小深者；或曰三刺，三刺者，治痺氣小深者也。五曰揚刺，揚刺者，正內一，傍內四，而浮之，以治寒氣之搏大者也。六曰直鍼刺，直鍼刺者，引皮乃刺之，以治寒氣之淺者也。七曰輸鍼，輸刺者，直入直出，稀發鍼而深之，以治氣盛而熱者也。八曰短刺，短刺者，刺骨痺，稍搖而深之，致鍼骨所，以上下摩骨也。九曰浮刺，浮刺者，傍入而浮之，以治肌急而寒者也。十曰陰刺，陰刺者，左右率刺之，以治寒厥；中寒厥，足踝後少陰也。十一曰傍鍼刺，傍鍼刺者，直刺傍刺各一，以治留痺久居者也。十二曰贊刺，贊刺者，直入直出，數發鍼而淺之，出血是謂治癰腫也。1. 者 : 舊脫。 There are twelve needling methods, each corresponding to one of the twelve channels.

  1. Even Needling: Insert the needle symmetrically on both sides, one in front and one behind, to treat heart pain or numbness. The needle is inserted near the handle.

  2. Reporting Needling: Needle any area where the pain is not constant, moving up and down along the channel, pulling out the needle slightly and then re-needling.

  3. Raising Needling: Insert the needle alongside the painful area, lift it up front and back to treat muscle stiffness or numbness.

  4. Uniting Needling: Directly enter one point and near-enter two other points for treating mild cold and shallow conditions; alternatively known as Three Needlings, treating soreness and weakness in the same depth.

  5. Lifting Needling: Insert the needle straight inward and slightly outward, causing it to float, for treating severe chills and shallow conditions.

  6. Straight Needling: Pierce the skin and directly insert the needle, treating mild chills and shallow conditions.

  7. Drawing Needling: Enter the needle straight in and straight out, deeply but intermittently, for treating heat with fullness.

  8. Short Needling: Insert the needle to treat bone pain, slightly swaying it while going deep, and positioning the needle at the point of the bone, massaging the bone up and down.

  9. Floating Needling: Enter near the insertion point and float the needle, treating stiff muscles with coldness.

  10. Yin Needling: Insert the needle at yin points on both sides, treating cold damage; for interior cold damage, it is specifically the foot yangming and bladder channel of foot taixi.

  11. Beside Needling: Directly insert a needle on one side and another needle on the opposite side to treat long-standing stagnation or numbness.

  12. Celebrating Needling: Insert the needle straight in and out, repeatedly pulling it out slightly but shallowly, causing bleeding, for treating swelling or tumors.

5: 脈之所居，深不見者，刺之微內鍼而久留之，以致其空脈氣也。脈淺者，勿刺，按絕其脈乃刺之，無令精出，獨出其邪氣耳。 Where the pulse resides, if it is not visible, insert a fine needle slightly inside and leave it in for a long time, in order to make its meridian empty of qi. For a shallow pulse, do not insert needles; pressing to stop the pulse is the correct way of needling, do not let the spirit come out, only let out the pathogenic qi.

6: 所謂三刺，則穀氣出者。先淺刺絕皮，以出陽邪，再刺則陰邪出者，少益深絕皮，致肌肉，未入分肉間也；已入分肉之間，則穀氣出。故刺法曰：始刺淺之，以逐邪氣，而來血氣，後刺深之，以致陰氣之邪，最後刺極深之，以下穀氣。此之謂也。 The so-called three punctures are when the grain qi comes out. First, shallowly pierce the skin to release Yang pathogenic factors; then pierce again to release Yin pathogenic factors. Superficially pierce and reach the muscles without going deep into the subcutaneous tissue. When you have entered the subcutaneous tissue, the grain qi will come out. Therefore, the method of acupuncture says: first shallowly pierce to chase away the pathogenic factors, followed by coming blood and qi, then deeply pierce to reach Yin pathogenic factors, and finally pierce extremely deep to release the grain qi. This is what it means.

7: 故用鍼者，不知年之所加，氣之盛衰，虛實之所起，不可以為工也。 One who employs the acupuncture technique does not know how the years affect it, how changes in vital energy are manifested, or where true and false begin; therefore, it cannot be used for work.

8: 凡刺有五，以應五藏，一曰半刺，半刺者，淺內而疾發鍼，無鍼傷肉，如拔毛狀，以取皮氣，此肺之應也。 Five needles in total, corresponding to the five organs, one is called half-needle. The half-needle is inserted shallowly and rapidly pierces through, without piercing the flesh, resembling plucking hair, used to obtain the qi of the lung, which corresponds to the lung organ.

9: 二曰豹文刺，豹文刺者，左右前後鍼之，中脈為故，以取經絡之血者，此心之應也。 It is said that the tiger's word pierces, and the one who pierces with the tiger's word, thrusts left and right, front and back, with needles. When the central pulse fails, blood from the meridians is taken, thus matching the heart's nature

10: 三曰關刺，關刺者，直刺左右盡筋上，以取筋痺，慎無出血，此肝之應也；或曰淵刺；一曰豈刺。 It is said, regarding the acupuncture point called Guán Cái (关刺): Guán Cái refers to directly inserting the needle into the muscles on both sides, targeting the muscle junctions, to treat muscular tension. Be cautious not to cause bleeding. This is the appropriate treatment for the liver. Another name for this point is Yǒu Cái (淵刺), and some call it Bǔ Cái (不刺).

11: 四曰合谷刺，合谷刺者，左右雞足，鍼於分肉之間，以取肌痺，此脾之應也。 Says the text: Fourthly, it is called Merging Valley Needle. The Merging Valley Needle is applied to the sides of the chicken legs, piercing between the muscles, in order to remove blood stagnation, which is an indication for the spleen.

12: 五曰輸刺，輸刺者，直入直出，深內之至骨，以取骨痺，此腎之應也。 Five says: Externalize the needle, the externalized needle is inserted straight in and out, deeply entering to the bone, taking away the bone obstruction, which is the corresponding function of the kidney.

docs.title: 本神
docs.text:
1: 黃帝問于歧伯曰：凡刺之法，先必本于神。血、脈、營、氣、精神，此五藏之所藏也。至其淫泆離藏則精失、魂魄飛揚、志意恍亂、智慮去身者，何因而然乎？天之罪與？人之過乎？何謂德、氣、生、精、神、魂、魄、心、意、志、思、智、慮？請問其故。 The Yellow Emperor asked Yu Fang: In the practice of acupuncture, it must originate from the spirit. Blood, channels, Qi, Shen, and consciousness are what these five viscera hold. When they reach a state of depletion, the essence is lost, the soul flies upwards, intentions become confused, wisdom departs from the body, what causes this to happen? Is it a fault of Heaven or the fault of humans? What do we mean by virtue, Qi, life, essence, spirit, soul, substance, heart, intention, will, thought, wisdom, and understanding? Please explain its origin.

2: 歧伯答曰：天之在我者德也，地之在我者氣也。德流氣薄而生者也。故生之來謂之精；兩精相搏謂之神；隨神往來者謂之魂；並精而出入者謂之魄；所以任物者謂之心；心有所憶謂之意；意之所存謂之志；因志而存變謂之思；因思而遠慕謂之慮；因慮而處物謂之智。 Duke Huan replied: The virtue of Heaven is within me, and the energy of Earth is also within me. When virtue flows with this energy, it generates what is subtle; when these two struggle, it becomes spirit. Following the spirit coming and going is called soul; pervading soul and body is called essence; all encompassing the essence entering and exiting is called spirit; because it directs things, it is called heart; having memories in the heart is called mind; where the mind dwells is called willpower; transforming with willpower is called thought; pursuing through thought is called discernment; through discernment interacting with things is called wisdom.

3: 故智者之養生也，必順四時而適寒暑，和喜怒而安居處，節陰陽而調剛柔。如是，則僻邪不至，長生久視。 As a result, nurturing life is the way of the wise, who must adapt to the four seasons and be suitable for both heat and cold. They harmonize their pleasure and anger and live in peace, balance yin and yang, and regulate hardness and softness. Thus, abnormalities will not occur, and longevity and clear vision will be achieved.

4: 是故怵惕思慮者則傷神，神傷則恐懼流淫而不止。因悲哀動中者，竭絕而失生。喜樂者，神憚散而不藏。愁憂者，氣閉塞而不行。盛怒者，迷惑而不治。恐懼者，神蕩憚而不收。 Therefore, those who ponder and think deeply will hurt their spirit; a hurt spirit will cause fear and confusion without end. Those who are moved by pity will exhaust themselves and die. Those who rejoice will cause their spirit to scatter and not hide it. Those who are anxious will close their energy and not let it flow. Those who are furious will be bewildered and not cure it. Those who are afraid will cause their spirit to wander and not gather it in.

5: 心，怵惕思慮則傷神，神傷則恐懼自失。破䐃脫肉，毛悴色夭死于冬。 The heart, being perplexed and anxious, injures the spirit. When the spirit is injured, one fears losing oneself. The skin peels off and the hair turns white, dying in winter.

6: 脾愁憂而不解則傷意，意傷則悗亂，四肢不舉，毛悴色夭死於春。 If the pectoral organ (heart) is worried and not understood, it will injure one's emotions. Emotions become confused and muddled, the limbs do not lift, and hair turns pale and dies in spring

7: 肝悲哀動中則傷魂，魂傷則狂忘不精，不精則不正，當人陰縮而攣筋，兩脅骨不舉，毛悴色夭死於秋。 The liver mourning and sorrowful, injures the soul; the soul being injured leads to madness and forgetfulness, lack of clarity leads to impropriety, causing a person's vital yin to shrink while their muscles twitch, not lifting the two terrifying bones, hairs turning grey and dying in autumn.

8: 肺喜樂無極則傷魄，魄傷則狂，狂者意不存人，皮革焦，毛悴色夭死於夏。 The lungs love pleasure without limits will harm the soul, and a damaged soul leads to madness. A person in madness loses their mind, their skin turns yellow and brittle, their hair turns grey and they die in summer

9: 腎盛怒而不止則傷志，志傷則喜忘其前言，腰脊不可以俛仰屈伸，毛悴色夭死於季夏。 If the liver is filled with rage and cannot be stopped, it will harm the heart; when the heart is harmed, one forgets the previous words, cannot bend or stretch the backbone, becomes pale and wilted, and dies in the season of spring and autumn.

10: 恐懼而不解則傷精，精傷則骨痠痿厥，精時自下。是故五藏主藏精者也，不可傷，傷則失守而陰虛；陰虛則無氣，無氣則死矣。 Fear and confusion can injure the vital essence. When the vital essence is injured, it leads to weakness of the bones and paralysis, and the vital essence will naturally descend when its time comes. Therefore, the five organs each govern the vital essence, which must not be injured, for if it is injured, the defense mechanism weakens, resulting in yin deficiency; with yin deficiency, there is no qi, and one dies.

11: 是故用鍼者，察觀病人之態，以知精、神、魂、魄之存亡，得失之意，五者以傷，鍼不可以治之也。 Therefore, the skilled acupuncturist observes the condition of the patient to discern whether the mind, consciousness, soul, and spirit are present or absent, and whether there is a gain or loss. In such cases, acupuncture cannot be used to treat the injury.

12: 肝藏血，血舍魂，肝氣虛則恐，實則怒。 The liver stores blood, blood sacrifices the soul, if the liver's qi is deficient there will be fear, and if it is abundant there will be anger.

13: 脾藏營，營舍意，脾氣虛則四肢不用，五藏不安，實則腹脹經溲不利。 The spleen is housed in the spleen pavilion, and the spleen pavilion refers to the energy of the spleen. If the energy of the spleen is deficient, the limbs will not function properly, the five organs will not be secure, and in reality, the abdomen will be bloated and the bowels will move poorly.

14: 心藏脈，脈舍神，心氣虛則悲，實則笑不休。 The heart houses the pulse, and the pulse gives rise to the spirit. If the heart's energy is insufficient, it will bring sadness; if it is abundant, one cannot stop laughing.

15: 肺藏氣，氣舍魄，肺氣虛，則鼻塞不利少氣，實則喘喝胸盈仰息。 The lungs store the Qi, the Qi nourishes the soul, when the lung Qi is deficient, one will have a blocked nose and be disadvantaged in breathing, if it is real then there will be panting, wheezing, a full chest, and difficulty breathing.
