16: 腎藏精，精舍志，腎氣虛則厥，實則脹。五藏不安。必審五藏之病形，以知其氣之虛實，謹而調之也。 The essence of the kidney, essence treasuring aspiration, kidney qi being deficient results in lethargy, kidney qi being abundant results in distention. The five organs are not at ease. One must carefully examine the signs of the five organs to know the state of their qi, and proceed with caution in treating them

docs.title: 靈蘭秘典論
docs.text:
1: 黃帝問曰：願聞十二藏之相使，貴賤何如。歧伯對曰：悉乎哉問也，請遂言之。心者，君主之官也，神明出焉。肺者，相傅之官，治節出焉。肝者，將軍之官，謀慮出焉。膽者，中正之官，決斷出焉。膻中者，臣使之官，喜樂出焉。脾胃者，倉廩之官，五味出焉。大腸者，傳道之官，變化出焉。小腸者，受盛之官，化物出焉。腎者，作強之官，伎巧出焉。三焦者，決瀆之官，水道出焉。膀胱者，州都之官，津液藏焉，氣化則能出矣。 Yellow Emperor asked: I would like to hear about the functions of the twelve organs, high and low. The Grand Preceptor replied: Indeed, this is a comprehensive inquiry, please allow me to explain. The heart is the ruler's office, from which spirit arises. The lung is the minister's office, responsible for regulating the pulse. The liver is the general's office, where strategy and planning emerge. The spleen is the central authority's office, making decisions. The urinary bladder is the official in charge of pleasure and enjoyment, from which laughter arises. The pancreas is the office responsible for managing grains and five flavors. The large intestine is the office that transmits the teachings, from which transformation emerges. The small intestine is the office that receives offerings, from which the transformation of things arises. The kidney is the office of strength-making, where agility and skill arise. The three burners are the offices of discernment and differentiation, from which the waterway arises. The gallbladder is the prefectural office, where fluids and essences are stored, and when they are transformed, they can be emitted.

2: 凡此十二官者，不得相失也。故主明則下安，以此養生則壽，歿世不殆，以為天下則大昌。主不明則十二官危，使道閉塞而不通，形乃大傷，以此養生則殃，以為天下者，其宗大危，戒之戒之。 Of these twelve offices, none shall be lost. Therefore, when the ruler is enlightened, he will govern well and nurture life, which leads to long life, and the world will not perish; this being so, great prosperity will ensue. If the ruler is not enlightened, the twelve offices are in danger, and the Way will close and become blocked, causing great harm to life, and if this happens, the foundation of the world is in grave danger. Be warned! Be warned!

3: 至道在微，變化無窮，孰知其原；窘乎哉，消者瞿瞿，孰知其要；閔閔之當，孰者為良。恍惚之數，生於毫氂，毫氂之數，起於度量，千之萬之，可以益大，推之大之，其形乃制。黃帝曰：善哉，余聞精光之道，大聖之業，而宣明大道，非齋戒擇吉日，不敢受也。黃帝乃擇吉日良兆，而藏靈蘭之室，以傳保焉。 Where the way is subtle, changes are infinite, who knows its origin? It is difficult indeed. Those who vanish do so quietly, who knows their purpose? In the midst of ambiguity, who is to be trusted? The many uncertainties arising from the tip of a needle, originate from measurement, ten thousandths of a degree can be further increased, and if pushed further, its form will be shaped. The Yellow Emperor said: Excellent! I have heard of the profound way and great works of the sages, but they do not declare the way, nor do they dare to prescribe auspicious days. The Yellow Emperor chose an auspicious day and hid the Spirit Room of the Jade Maiden in order to preserve it.

docs.title: 終始
docs.text:
1: 凡刺之道，畢於終始，明知終始，五藏為紀，陰陽定矣。陰者主藏，陽者主府，陽受氣於四末，陰受氣於五藏，故寫者迎之，補者隨之，知迎知隨，氣可令和，和氣之方，必通陰陽。五藏為陰，六府為陽，傳之後世，以血為盟。敬之者昌，慢之者亡。無道行私，必得夭殃。 Regarding the needle art, it comes to an end and a beginning, knowing its end and beginning, the five organs serve as records, and yin and yang are established. The yin governs the organs, while the yang governs the palace. Yin receives qi at the four extremities, and yang receives qi at the five organs; therefore, the writer approaches it and the supplementer follows it. Knowing how to approach and knowing how to follow, one can regulate the qi, and the method of regulating qi depends on the harmony of yin and yang. The five organs represent yin, and the six palaces represent yang. This was transmitted for future generations and sealed with blood. Those who revered it prospered, while those who disparaged it perished. Without a path, practicing in secret will inevitably lead to ruin.

2: 謹奉天道，請言終始。終始者，經脈為紀。持其脈口人迎，以知陰陽有餘不足，平與不平，天道畢矣。所謂平人者不病，不病者，脈口人迎應四時也，上下相應而俱往來也，六經之脈不結動也，本末之寒溫之相守司也。形肉血氣必相稱也，是謂平人。少氣者，脈口人迎俱少，而不稱尺寸也。如是者，則陰陽俱不足，補陽則陰竭，寫陰則陽脫。如是者，可將以甘藥，不可飲以至劑，如此者弗灸。不巳者因而寫之，則五藏氣壞矣。 Respecting the Way of Heaven, attending to speech from beginning to end. The one who attends from beginning to end is recorded in the classics as a memorial. Holding the pulse and asking people to greet it, one can know whether there is excess or deficiency of yin and yang, whether it is balanced or unbalanced, and the Way of Heaven is finished. What is meant by a balanced person is that he does not fall ill; when there is no illness, one's pulse and greeting are in harmony with the four seasons, both going to and fro, and the six channels do not move. The pulse reflects the correspondence between yin and yang's extremes, the balance of cold and heat. The body's form, flesh, blood, and qi must correspond and be harmonious; this is what is meant by a balanced person. If there is insufficient qi, the pulse and greeting will also be insufficient, not measuring their dimensions. When this happens, both yin and yang are deficient, supplementing yang will deplete yin, and writing yin will cause yang to disappear. Such a situation should be treated with sweet wormwood; one cannot drink it as an emetic, lest one blister from the moxa stick. Not moxa-ing on the day of Jupiter will cause damage to the five viscera's qi.

3: 人迎一盛，病在足少陽，一盛而躁，病在手少陽。人迎二盛，病在足太陽，二盛而躁，病在手太陽，人迎三盛，病在足陽明，三盛而躁，病在手陽明。人迎四盛，且大且數，名曰溢陽，溢陽為外格。 When a person has a Dampness-Heat attack, it is called Yang Ming. When Dampness-Heat is in the foot's Shao Yang channel, there will be agitation and pain in the hand's Shao Yang channel. If the condition worsens, it is called Jue Yin, which belongs to the exterior. For a person having a Dampness-Heat attack, it is called Yang Ming. When Dampness-Heat is in the foot's Tai Yang channel, there will be agitation and pain in the hand's Tai Yang channel. If the condition worsens further, it is called Tai Yin, which belongs to the exterior

4: 脈口一盛，病在足厥陰；厥陰一盛而躁，在手心主。脈口二盛，病在足少陰；二盛而躁，在手少陰。脈口三盛，病在足太陰；三盛而躁，在手太陰。脈口四盛，且大且數者，名曰溢陰。溢陰為內關，內關不通，死不治。人迎與太陰脈口俱盛四倍以上，名曰關格。關格者，與之短期。 In the following text, the terms 脈口 and 盛 refer to a point in the pulse where it is full or swollen. The term 病在 means the disease is located at, and 而躁 refers to a restless or agitated pulse. The term 溢陰 refers to an excess of yin energy, while 關格 indicates a blockage in the flow of Qi (pronounced chee) energy, which can lead to serious consequences if not treated promptly.

5: 人迎一盛，寫足少陽而補足厥陰，二寫一補，日一取之，必切而驗之，疏取之，上氣和乃止。人迎二盛，寫足太陽補足少陰，二寫一補，二日一取之，必切而驗之，疏取之，上氣和乃止。人迎三盛，寫足陽明而補足太陰，二寫一補，日二取之，必切而驗之，疏取之，上氣和乃止。 One batch: write yang and supplement yin, two writings and one supplement, take once a day, cut and check it, take out the sediment, rise gas is harmonious and stops. Two batches: write yang of great yang and supplement yin, two writings and one supplement, take once a day, cut and check it, take out the sediment, rise gas is harmonious and stops. Three batches: write yang and brightness and supplement great yin, two writings and one supplement, take twice a day, cut and check it, take out the sediment, rise gas is harmonious and stops.

6: 脈口一盛，寫足厥陰而補足少陽，二補一寫，日一取之，必切而驗之，疏而取，上氣和乃止。脈口二盛，寫足少陰而補足太陽，二補一寫，二日一取之，必切而驗之，疏取之，上氣和乃止。脈口三盛，寫足太陰而補足陽明，二補一寫，日二取之，必切而驗之，疏而取之，上氣和乃止。所以日二取之者，太、陽主胃，大富於穀氣，故可日二取之也。 When the pulse is full and round, write the foot yin and supplement the foot taiyang, with both being one. Take it once a day, cutting and verifying it, taking it lightly, and the ascending qi will be harmonious and cease. When the pulse is full and double round, write the foot shao yin and supplement the foot taiyang, both being one. Take it twice a day, cutting and verifying it, taking it lightly, and the ascending qi will be harmonious and cease. When the pulse is full and triple round, write the foot taiyang and supplement the foot jingming, both being one. Take it once every two days, cutting and verifying it, taking it lightly, and the ascending qi will be harmonious and cease. Therefore, those who take it twice a day are governed by taiyin and shangqi, abundant in grain qi, so they can take it twice a day.

7: 人迎與脈口俱盛三倍以上，命曰陰陽俱溢，如是者不開，則血脈閉塞，氣無所行，流淫於中，五藏內傷。如此者，因而灸之，則變易而為他病矣。 When the pulse at both wrists is full and abundant, threefold or more, and the name is Yin and Yang overflowing, if this person does not open (the body), the blood vessels will be blocked, the Qi will have no place to go, causing leakage and dysfunction in the internal organs. If such a case arises, acupuncture can be used, and the condition may change into another illness altogether.

8: 凡刺之道，氣調而止，補陰寫陽，音氣益彰，耳目聰明。反此者，血氣不行。 Anyone who practices acupuncture must be skillful in regulating the qi, complementing yin and writing yang, making the sounds and Qi more prominent, and having sharp ears and eyes. If not, the blood and qi will not flow properly

9: 所謂氣至而有效者，寫則益虛，虛者，脈大如其故而不堅也；堅如其故者，適雖言故，病未去也。補則益實，實者，脈大如其故而益堅也；夫如其故而不堅者，適雖言快，病未去也。故補則實、寫則虛，痛雖不隨鍼，病必衰去。必先通十二經脈之所生病，而後可得傳於終始矣。故陰陽不相移，虛實不相傾，取之其經。 Regarding those who are skilled in Qi and effective, if they write prescriptions, these will be more vacuous; the vacuous, their pulse is large but not firm, while the firm as per usual, the speech is appropriate but the disease has not yet departed. If one supplements, then there is more substance; the substantial, their pulse is large and firm, but they are still far from recovery. Therefore, supplementation leads to reality and writing leads to vacuity, even though there is pain that does not follow the needle, the disease must decline. One must first establish the connection between the twelve channels and the illness before it can be transmitted to life and death. Thus, yin and yang should not be interchangeable, and vacuity and substance should not be tilted; one should take this to heart when treating disease.

10: 凡刺之屬，三刺至穀氣，邪僻妄合，陰陽易居，逆順相反，沉浮異處，四時不得，稽留淫泆須鍼而去。故一刺則陽邪出，再刺則陰邪出，三刺則穀氣至，穀氣至而止。所謂穀氣至者，已補而實，已寫而虛，故以知穀氣至也。邪氣獨去者，陰與陽未能調而病知愈也。故曰：補則實，寫則虛，痛雖不隨鍼，病必衰去矣。 Any practitioners of acupuncture, when the three needles are located at the grain spirit, if there is a mix-up between right and wrong, yin and yang being out of balance, opposite directions, then this should be corrected. Therefore, one needle leads to an excess of yang pathogen, two needles lead to an excess of yin pathogen, three needles lead to the arrival of grain spirit, and once the spirit arrives it stops there. The term arrival of the grain spirit refers to something being filled and real, something written down as being empty and void, therefore we can tell when the grain spirit has arrived. When the pathogenic qi leaves on its own, yin and yang have not yet been balanced and the disease is known to be getting better. Therefore it is said: filling leads to reality, writing leads to emptiness, although there may still be pain, the illness will surely decline and disappear.

11: 陰盛而陽虛，先補其陽，後寫其陰而和之。陰虛而陽盛，先補其陰，後寫其陽而和之。 When yin is abundant and yang is deficient, first supplement the yang, then regulate the yin to bring harmony. When yang is abundant and yin is deficient, first supplement the yin, then regulate the yang to bring harmony.

12: 三脈動於足大趾之間，必審其實虛，虛而寫之，是謂重虛。重虛病益甚。凡刺此者，以指按之，脈動而實且疾者疾寫之，虛而徐者則補之。反此者，病益甚。其動也，陽明在上，厥陰在中，少陰在下。 The three pulses are at the middle of the sole of the foot. It is necessary to discern whether they are strong or weak, and if weak, write them down as heavy weakness. The disease becomes more severe. Whoever inserts a needle here must press with the finger, feeling the pulse to be both strong and rapid; one should then quickly write it down. If it is weak and slow, one should reinforce it. In case of failure, the disease worsens. Its movement is such that the Yang Ming is above, the Yin Shu is in the center, and the Shao Yin is below.

13: 膺俞中膺，背俞中背，肩膊虛者，取之上。 Holding the jade disc in the center, holding the handles at the back, with hollow shoulders, take it up above.

14: 重舌，刺舌柱以鈹鍼也。 Re-tongue, pierce the tongue plate with a needle also.

15: 手屈而不伸者，其病在筋，伸而不屈者，其病在骨，在骨守骨，在筋守筋。 If one's hand cannot bend but is not stiff, the disease lies in the tendons. If one's hand can bend but cannot straighten, the disease lies in the bones. Guard the bones and guard the tendons.

16: 補須一方實，深取之，稀按其痏，以極出其邪氣。一方虛，淺刺之，以養其脈，疾按其痏，無使邪氣得入。邪氣來也緊而疾，穀氣來也徐而和。脈實者深刺之，以泄其氣；脈虛者，淺刺之，使精氣無寫出，以養其脈，獨出其邪氣。 One method is to supplement when necessary, plunge deeply and lightly touch the tongue, using extremes to expel its pathogenic qi. Another method is for those who are deficient, make a shallow puncture and nourish the pulse, pressing lightly on the tongue so that the pathogenic qi does not enter. Pathogenic qi comes quickly and rapidly while true qi comes slowly and harmoniously. For those with a real pulse, plunge deeply to release its qi; for those who are deficient, make a shallow puncture, allowing the essence qi to remain undisturbed so as to nourish the pulse and expel only the pathogenic qi

17: 刺諸痛者，其脈皆實。 For those experiencing pain, all pulse readings will be genuine.

18: 故曰：從腰以上者，手太陰陽明皆主之；從腰以下者，足太陰陽明皆主之。 It is said: For that which is above the waist, both the Taiyang and Shaoyang channels govern the hands; for that which is below the waist, both the Taiyang and Shaoyang channels govern the feet.

19: 病在上者下取之；病在下者高取之；病在頭者取之足；病在腰者取之膕。 If the ailment is located above, take from below; if the ailment is located below, take from above; if the ailment is in the head, take from the foot; if the ailment is in the waist, take from the hip.

20: 病生於頭者，頭重；生於手者，臂重；生於足者，足重。治病者，先刺其病所從生者也。 If the illness originates in the head, it causes heaviness of the head; if it originates in the hand, it causes weakness in the arm; if it originates in the foot, it causes weakness in the leg. When treating the disease, first treat the area where the disease began.

21: 春氣在毛，夏氣在皮膚，秋氣在分肉，冬氣在筋骨。刺此病者，各以其時為齊。故刺肥人者，以1秋冬之齊，刺瘦人者，以春夏之齊。1. 以 : 舊脫。 The vital qi is in the pores, summer qi in the skin, autumn qi in the muscles, and winter qi in the bones. When treating disease with acupuncture, one must adjust according to the season. Therefore, when acupuncturing an obese person, use the balance of autumn and winter, and when acupuncturing a thin person, use the balance of spring and summer. 1. Using: removing old skin

22: 病痛者，陰也，痛而以手按之不得者，陰也，深刺之。病在上者，陽也。病在下者，陰也。癢者，陽也，淺刺之。 For a person in pain, it is yin. If the pain cannot be relieved by pressing with the hand, it is yin. Deeper acupuncture is needed. If the illness is located above, it is yang. If the illness is located below, it is yin. A cold is yang and shall be treated with shallow acupuncture.

23: 病先起陰者，先治其陰，而後治其陽；病先起陽者，先治其陽，而後治其陰。 If the disease first arises from yin, treat the yin first and then treat the yang; if the disease first arises from yang, treat the yang first and then treat the yin.

24: 刺熱厥者，留鍼反為寒；刺寒厥者，留鍼反為熱。刺熱厥者，二陰一陽；刺寒厥者，二陽一陰。所謂二陰者，二刺陰也；一陽者，一刺陽也。 For the person with fever, use cold needles and convert them to warm; for the person with cold, use cold needles and convert them to hot. For the person with fever, it is Yin two and Yang one; for the person with cold, it is Yang two and Yin one. As for the two Yins, it means two needle Yin; one Yang means one needle Yang

25: 久病者，邪氣入深。刺此病者，深內而久留之，間日而復刺之，必先調其左右，去其血脈，刺道畢矣。 For those who have been ill for a long time, the pathogenic qi has penetrated deep within. When treating such patients, pierce deeply and let the needles stay for a long time, intermittently needling over several days, one must first regulate the left and right (channels), clear the blood vessels, and complete the needle placement.

26: 凡刺之法，必察其形氣。形肉未脫，少氣而脈又躁，躁厥者，必為繆刺之，散氣可收，聚氣可布。 In the matter of acupuncture, one must examine the form and qi. When the body has not yet been disrobed, and the qi is insufficient but the pulse is agitated, if it is deficient on one side, it is necessary to use revision acupuncture; regulate the qi and disperse it, and gather the qi and distribute it.

27: 深居靜處，占神往來，閉戶塞牖，魂魄不散，專意一神，精氣之分，毋聞人聲，以收其精，必一其神，令志在鍼。 Dwell in a quiet and secluded place, keep track of the movements of the spirit, close and seal the doors, keep your soul undivided, focus your mind fully, divide your vital energy, do not hear human voices, collect your energy to focus it completely, direct your willpower like an awl.

28: 淺而留之，微而浮之，以移其神，氣至乃休。 Shallow and subtle, it moves; minute and delicate, it floats; thus it influences the minds of men. When its power has reached completion, it ceases to exist.

29: 男內女外，堅拒勿出，謹守勿內，是謂得氣。 The phrase 男內女外，堅拒勿出，謹守勿內，是謂得氣 can be translated to English as: Men inside, women outside; firmly reject going out, cautiously guard against going in; this is what it means to have Qi (energy).

30: 凡刺之禁：新內勿刺，新刺勿內；已醉勿刺，已刺勿醉；新怒勿刺，已刺勿怒；新勞勿刺，已刺勿勞；已飽勿刺，已刺勿飽；已飢勿刺，已刺勿飢；已渴勿刺，已刺勿渴；大驚大恐，必定其氣乃刺之。乘車來者，臥而休之，如食頃乃刺之。出行來者，坐而休之，如行千里頃乃刺之。凡此十二禁者，其脈亂氣散，逆其營衛，經氣不次，因而刺之，則陽病入于陰，陰病出為陽，則邪氣復生。麤工勿察，是謂伐身，形體淫泆，乃消腦髓，津液不化，脫其五味，是謂失氣也。 The prohibitions of acupuncture: Do not acupuncture the new, do not acupuncture the old; do not acupuncture when drunk, do not acupuncture when angry; do not acupuncture when tired, do not acupuncture when full; do not acupuncture when hungry, do not acupuncture when thirsty; do not acupuncture when thirsty, do not acupuncture when dry. Fear and dread must regulate the qi; when riding in a vehicle, rest, and then acupuncture after eating; when traveling, sit and rest, then acupuncture after a journey of a thousand miles. All these twelve prohibitions govern the pulse, disperse the qi, and follow the defensive qi and channel qi. By needling at such times, yang diseases enter the yin, and yin diseases manifest as yang, thus reviving the pathogenic qi. Superficial needling should not be used; this is akin to chopping down one's body, corrupting the form, polluting the brain and marrow, causing the fluids to fail to transform, and losing one's qi.

31: 太陽之脈，其終也。戴眼，反折，瘈瘲，其色白，絕皮乃絕汗，絕汗則終矣。 The pulse of the sun, it is finished. Wearing glasses, bending, limping, its color is white, cutting off the skin results in cutting off perspiration, and when perspiration is cut off, it is finished.

32: 少陽終者，耳聾，百節盡縱，目系絕，目系絕，一日半則死矣。其死也，色青白，乃死。 A person afflicted with the ailment of Shao Yang will become deaf, lose control over their limbs, go blind, and be unable to see. Such a person will die within one to two days. Their death will be marked by a change in color to green or white.

33: 陽明終者，口目動作，喜驚、妄言、色黃；其上下之經盛而不行，則終矣。 When the Yangming period comes to an end, there is movement of the mouth and eyes, joy, surprise, nonsense, and yellowing of complexion. If the superior and inferior channels are filled but not functioning, then it is at an end.

34: 少陰終者，面黑，齒長而垢，腹脹閉塞，上下不通而終矣。 The individual of insufficient yin, has a dark face, long and crooked teeth, bloated abdomen that is closed up, upper and lower parts not connected, and so he dies.

35: 厥陰終者，中熱溢干，喜溺，心煩，甚則舌卷，卵上縮而終矣。 The yin phase is over, the heat surges and dries up, enjoying an excess, causing restlessness, sometimes leading to tongue rolling, and ending with the eggs shrinking and dying.

36: 太陰終者，腹脹閉，不得息，氣噫，善嘔，嘔則逆，逆則面赤，不逆則上下不通，上下不通則面黑，皮毛憔而終矣。 The person who has too much yin will be bloated, unable to breathe, gasping for air, and prone to vomiting. If the vomiting occurs, there will be a red face; if it does not occur, the upper and lower parts will not connect, leading to a black face and hair falling out until death ensues

docs.title: 經脈
docs.text:
1: 雷公問於黃帝曰：「禁脈」之言，凡刺之理，經脈為始，營其所行，制其度量，內次五藏，外別六府，願盡聞其道。 Master Lái asked Emperor Yellow: Regulating the pulse is a topic, in which the theory of needling pertains. The pulse originates the pathway, charts its course, measures it, arranges its internal divisions (the Five Organs) and its external areas (the Six Departments), wishing to hear about its way.

2: 黃帝曰：人始生，先成精，精成而腦髓生，骨為幹，脈為營，筋為剛，肉為牆，皮膚堅而毛髮長，穀入于胃，脈道以通，血氣乃行。 The Yellow Emperor said: When a person is first born, they are initially pure. This purity leads to the development of their brain and spinal cord. Their bones serve as the framework, their vessels serve as their territory, their tendons provide strength, their flesh serves as the walls, their skin is firm while their hair and fur grow long. Their grains enter the stomach, their channels circulate throughout, and blood and qi function properly.

3: 雷公曰：願卒聞經脈之始生。黃帝曰：經脈者，所以能決死生、處百病、調虛實，不可不通。 Lei Gong said: I wish to hear about the origins of the meridians. Huang Di said: The meridians are what allow us to determine life and death, treat a hundred diseases, and regulate real and fake, and cannot be ignored.

4: 肺手太陰之脈，起於中焦，下絡大腸，還循胃口，上膈屬肺，從肺系橫出腋下，下循臑內，行少陰心主之前，下肘中，循臂內上骨下廉，入寸口，上魚，循魚際，出大指之端；其支者，從腕後直出次指內廉出其端。 The lung channel's conception vessel pulse, originating from the middle burner, passes through the large intestine, ascends along the stomach opening, connects to the lung, exits horizontally from the axilla, descends inside the muscle, proceeds along the small intestine channel, reaches the heart governor's front, descends at the elbow's center, follows the arm's interior along the bone and shin, enters the foot's portal, ascends along the flexor tendon, follows the Achilles tendon, exits at the tip of the great toe; its connecting vessel is from the wrist back, straight out to the side of the ring finger's base.

5: 是動則病肺脹滿，膨脹而喘咳，缺盆中痛，甚則交兩手而瞀，此為臂厥。是主肺所生病者，咳上氣，喘渴，煩心，胸滿，臑臂內前廉痛厥，掌中熱。氣盛有餘，則肩背痛，風寒汗出中風，小便數而欠。氣虛則肩背痛，寒，少氣不足以息，溺色變。為此諸病，盛則寫之，虛則補之，熱則疾之，寒則留之，陷下則灸之，不盛不虛，以經取之。盛者，寸口大三倍於人迎，虛者，則寸口反小於人迎也。 The text describes the symptoms and treatment of a disease affecting the lung, characterized by fullness, wheezing, coughing, pain in the lower abdomen, and other related issues. It also provides instructions for diagnosing and treating the condition based on whether it is excessive or deficient, hot or cold, and whether it has sunk down or not. The text concludes with details about how the pulse at a specific acupuncture point should appear under different circumstances.

Translation:

A disease of lung Qi stagnation presents with fullness and pain, causing bloating and wheezing, accompanied by coughing. There is pain in the lower abdomen, and in severe cases, the patient may clutch their chest and gasp for breath, manifesting as Qi stagnation. This condition affects those with lung disorders. The patient experiences coughing up Qi, shortness of breath, restlessness, fullness in the chest, pain in the inner aspect of the arm, and heat in the palm. If there is an excess of Qi, there will be pain in the shoulders and back, sweating due to wind-heat, and frequent urination with dribbling. If Qi is deficient, there will be pain in the shoulders and back, coldness, and insufficient Qi to dispel pathogens, leading to a changed appearance.

To treat these various illnesses, first determine if they are excessive or deficient, hot or cold, and whether they have sunk down. If there is an excess, the pulse at a specific acupuncture point will be large, three times the size of a normal pulse. If there is a deficiency, the pulse will be smaller than normal. The treatment approach varies depending on whether it is excessive or deficient, hot or cold, and whether it has sunk down or not.

6: 大腸手陽明之脈，起於大指次指之端，循指上廉，出合谷兩骨之間，上入兩筋之中，循臂上廉，入肘外廉，上臑外前廉，上肩，出髃骨之前廉，上出於柱骨之會上，下入缺盆，絡肺，下膈，屬大腸。其支者，從缺盆上頸，貫頰，入下齒中，還出挾口，交人中，左之右，右之左，上挾鼻孔。 The Large Intestine Channel of the Yang Ming meridian begins at the root of the index finger, ascends along the back of the index finger, emerges between the two bones in the crease of the wrist, enters the muscle and rises to the surface, passing over the outer aspect of the elbow, up to the outer aspect of the shoulder, emerging from the front of the mastoid process, exiting at the junction of the axis bone, descending into the hollow of the inguinal ligament, connecting with the lungs, moving downward, it connects with the Conception Vessel and nourishes the large intestine. Its branch (the Channel of the Yang Ming) starts from the inguinal ligament, ascends to the back of the neck, passes through the mouth, exits the throat, crosses in front of the nostrils, left over right, right over left, and ascends to the nasal opening.

7: 是動則病齒痛，頸腫。是主津液所生病者，目黃，口乾，鼽衄，喉痺，肩前臑痛，大指次指痛不用，氣有餘則當脈所過者熱腫；虛則寒慄不復。為此諸病，盛則寫之，虛則補之，熱則疾之，寒則留之，陷下則灸之，不盛不虛，以經取之。盛者，人迎大三倍於寸口；虛者，人迎反小於寸口也。 If the condition is caused by movement, there will be toothache and neck swelling. The patient suffers from a disease associated with the production of body fluids and exhibits symptoms such as yellow eyes, dry mouth, nosebleeds, a sore throat, pain in the shoulder blade, and pain in the second and third fingers that are difficult to use. If there is an excess of Qi, the pulse will be rapid at specific points along the meridian, accompanied by heat and swelling; if there is deficiency, there will be chills and no recovery.

For these symptoms, if there is an excess or a deficiency, write down the prescription; if there is heat or cold, act accordingly; if there is stagnation, use acupuncture; and if there is nonexcess or deficiency, apply the meridian points according to the classics. In cases of excess, the patient will be greeted by the Lung, Large Intestine, and Stomach meridians three times as large as the Conception Vessel at the point; in cases of deficiency, the patient will be greeted by the Conception Vessel, which is smaller than the point on the Conception Vessel.

8: 胃足陽明之脈，起於鼻之交頞中，旁納太陽之脈，下循鼻外，入上齒中，還出挾口環唇，下交承漿，卻循頤後下廉，出大迎，循頰車，上耳前，過客主人，循髮際，至額顱；其支者，從大迎前下人迎，循喉嚨，入缺盆，下膈，屬胃，絡脾；其直者，從缺盆下乳內廉，下挾臍，入氣沖中；其支者，起於胃口，下循腹裏，下至氣沖中而合，以下髀關，抵伏兔，下膝臏中，下循脛外廉，下足跗，入中指內間；其支者，下廉三寸而別下入中趾外間；其支者，別跗上，入大趾間出其端。 The Pulse: Yangming, also called the Governing Vessel, begins at the intersection of the nostrils. It runs alongside the Great Vessel, descending externally along the nose, entering the upper gum between the lips, emerging below the cheekbone, passing in front of the ear, crossing the temple, and ending at the hairline; its branch is called Jueyin, which originates from the juncture just below the Great Vessel's external end, descends along the throat, enters the hollow under the breast, connecting to the stomach, uniting with the spleen; its direct branch starts from the hollow beneath the breast and descends along the inguinal region, entering the bladder hole, connecting to the diaphragm, relating to the stomach, nourishing the spleen; its branch begins at the end of the stomach, descending through the abdomen, reaching the bladder hole, and merging there, then proceeding down the outer edge of the shin, below the little toe, entering the middle space between the toes; its branch originates from below the ankle, enters the big toe's outer corner and exits.

9: 是動則病洒洒振寒，善呻，數欠，顏黑，病至則惡人與火，聞木聲則惕然而惊，心欲動，獨閉戶塞牖而處。甚則欲上高而歌，棄衣而走，賁嚮腹脹，是為骭厥。是主血所生病者，狂瘧溫淫，汗出，鼽衄，口喎，唇胗，頸腫，喉痺，大腹水腫，膝臏腫痛，循膺乳、氣沖、股、伏兔、骭外廉、足跗上皆痛，中趾不用，氣盛則身以前皆熱，其有餘於胃，則消穀善飢，溺色黃；氣不足則身以前皆寒慄，胃中寒則脹滿。為此諸病，盛則寫之，虛則補之，熱則疾之，寒則留之，陷下則灸之，不盛不虛，以經取之。盛者，人迎大三倍於寸口，虛者，人迎反小於寸口也。 The disease caused by excessive movement is characterized by trembling, shivering, and a pale complexion. As the disease worsens, the patient becomes hostile and uncooperative, jumps at the sound of footsteps, and their heart palpitates. They close themselves in a dark room. In severe cases, they want to climb high and sing, discard their clothes and run around, experiencing abdominal pain and distension, this is called jia yi. This disease is caused by excessive bleeding and is characterized by madness, fever, sweating, bloody discharge, a hoarse voice, swollen lips, sore throat, goiter, and difficulty swallowing. Patients also experience abdominal swelling, knee pain, lower back pain, swelling and pain in the hui, lao, qi, kou, and chen regions, pain in the ankle joints, aching soles of the feet, and the big toe is unable to bear weight. If there is an excess of this condition, patients may have excessive hunger and yellow complexion, or if there is not enough Qi, they will feel cold and tremble, with distension in the abdomen. For these diseases, when there is an excess, you should write down the symptoms, when there is a deficiency, you should supplement it, when there is heat, you should release it, and when there is cold, you should retain it. If the disease sinks down, you should use acupuncture. If there is neither excess nor deficiency, you should treat according to the classical texts. When there is an excess, the patient will present symptoms three times greater than at the guan (governor) vessel point, and when there is a deficiency, the patient will present symptoms smaller than at the guan vessel point.

10: 脾足太陰之脈，起於大趾之端，循趾內側白肉際，過核骨後，上內踝前廉，上踹內，循脛骨後，交出厥陰之前，上膝股內前廉，入腹，屬脾，絡胃，上膈，挾咽，連吞本，散舌下；其支者，復從胃，別上膈、注心中。 The conception vessel, starting at the center of the foot where the spleen and kidney yin meet, follows the inner white side of the big toe, crossing the exocrine bone behind, ascends to the inner crook in front, goes along the back of the shankbone, connects with the beginning of the penile vessel outside the pubic arch, enters the abdomen, belongs to the spleen, nourishes the stomach, lifts the throat, links the origin of swallowing, disperses below the tongue; its connecting vessel, again comes from the stomach, separates upward to regulate the heart.

11: 是動則病舌本強，食則嘔，胃脘痛，腹脹，善噫，得後與氣，則快然如衰，身體皆重。是主脾所生病者，舌本痛，體不能動搖，食不下，煩心，心下急痛，溏瘕泄，水閉，黃疸，不能臥，強立，股膝內腫厥，足大趾不用。為此諸病，盛則寫之，虛則補之，熱則疾之，寒則留之，陷下則灸之，不盛不虛，以經取之。盛者，寸口大三倍於人迎，虛者，寸口反小於人迎。 This passage discusses the diagnosis and treatment of various illnesses in traditional Chinese medicine, based on the condition of the patient's tongue.

Translation: When there is movement (of the body), it is due to illness of the sinew; when eating, there is vomiting, pain in the abdomen, distension in the belly, burping, and quick recovery after defecation, and the body feels heavy. This pertains to patients with illnesses caused by the spleen. The tongue is painful, the body cannot move freely, and food does not descend. The mind is restless, there is pain below the heart, there is discharge of pus, urinary retention, jaundice, hemorrhoids, and an inability to lie down. When standing, there is swelling and numbness in the groin and knees, and the toes cannot be lifted.

For these illnesses, if they are predominant, write them down; if they are deficient, supplement them; if they are warm, disperse them; if they are cold, retain them; if they have sunken, use acupuncture; if they do not fit any of the above, use the classics. For the predominant ones, the pulse at the right spring (location) is three times larger than that of a normal person; for the deficient ones, it is smaller than that of a normal person.

12: 心手少陰之脈，起於心中，出屬心系，下膈，絡小腸；其支者，從心系，上挾咽，系目系；其直者，復從心系卻上肺，下出腋下，下循臑內後廉，行太陰心主之後，下肘內，循臂內後廉，抵掌後銳骨之端，入掌內後廉，循小指之內，出其端。 The heart meridian of the spleen and stomach starts at the center of the chest, belonging to the heart channel. It goes down to the abdomen and connects with the small intestine. Its branch goes from the heart channel up to the throat, connecting with the governor vessel; its direct course goes from the heart channel but up to the lung, exiting at the inframammary crease, descending along the inner rear crest of the oblique muscles, following the sinewy conduit of the small intestine, and entering the rear of the wrist's sharp end. It goes along the inner part of the little finger and exits at its tip.

13: 是動則病嗌干，心痛，渴而欲飲，是為臂厥。是主心所生病者，目黃，脅痛，臑臂內後廉痛厥，掌中熱痛。為此諸病，盛則寫之，虛則補之，熱則疾之，寒則留之，陷下則灸之，不盛不虛，以經取之。盛者，寸口大再倍於人迎，虛者，寸口反小於人迎也。 If there is movement and pain in the tongue, heart palpitations, chest pain, thirst, and a desire to drink, it is due to a weakness of the arm. This pertains to patients with diseases of the heart. The symptoms include yellow eyes, pain behind the navel, pain in the inside of the elbow, pain in the palm, and pain when grasping something. For these diseases, if there is an excess, write about it; if there is a deficiency, supplement it; if there is heat, disperse it; if there is cold, retain it; if it sinks down, use acupuncture; do not have an excess without a deficiency, and take from the meridians according to the Classic of Medicine. If there is an excess, the pulse at the Influential point (LU-1) will be large, double that of a normal person; if there is a deficiency, it will be small compared to a normal person's pulse.

14: 小腸手太陽之脈，起於小指之端，循手外側，上腕，出踝中，直上循臂骨下廉，出肘內側兩筋之間，上循臑外後廉，出肩解，繞肩胛，交肩上，入缺盆，絡心，循咽，下膈，抵胃，屬小腸；其支者，從缺盆循頸上頰，至目銳眥，卻入耳中；其支者，別頰上䪼，抵鼻，至目內眥，斜絡於顴。 The small intestine channel of the foot Yang Ming begins at the tip of the little finger, follows the outer side of the hand, ascends to the wrist, exits from the crook of the elbow, moves along the outside of the upper arm, exits from the shoulder hollow, encircles the collarbone, crosses the shoulder joint, enters the pit between the two shoulder muscles, connects the heart, follows the throat, descends to the diaphragm, opposes the stomach, belongs to the small intestine. Its connecting point is from the pit of the stomach along the top of the neck to the sharp end of the eye and enters the ear canal. The other connecting point diverges from the upper part of the forehead, opposes the nose, reaches the inner corner of the eye, slantwise connects at the cheekbone.

15: 是動則病嗌痛，頷腫，不可以顧，肩似拔，臑似折。是主液所生病者，耳聾、目黃，頰腫，頸、頷、肩、臑、肘、臂外後廉痛。為此諸病，盛則寫之，虛則補之，熱則疾之，寒則留之，陷下則灸之，不盛不虛，以經取之。盛者，人迎大再倍於寸口，虛者，人迎反小於寸口也。 The patient has symptoms of qi stagnation and blood stasis, such as pain in the tongue, swollen throat, difficulty swallowing, shoulder pain similar to pulling, elbow pain similar to bending. The chief manifestations of this disease are tinnitus, deafness, yellow eyes, swelling of the cheek, neck, throat, shoulders, elbows, forearms, and numbness on the outer side of the limbs. For these diseases, one should prescribe according to their predominance; if abundant, record it in the case history, if deficient, supplement it. If there is heat, treat it urgently; if cold, let it be. If it sinks downward, use acupuncture and moxibustion. Do not simply rely on the meridians; take the pulse. When abundant, the pulse at the wrist will be twice as strong as that at the heart position, and when deficient, it will be smaller than that at the heart position.

16: 膀胱足太陽之脈，起於目內眥，上額，交巔；其支者，從巔至耳上角；其直者，從巔入絡腦，還出別下項，循肩髆內，挾脊，抵腰中，入循膂，絡腎，屬膀胱；其支者，從腰中下挾脊，貫臀，入膕中；其支者，從髆內左右，別下，貫胛，挾脊內，過髀樞，循髀外，從後廉，下合膕中，以下貫踹內，出外踝之後，循京骨，至小趾外側。 The pulse of the Chong (Renishing) is located at the interior gate of the eyes, and runs up to the forehead and the vertex; its branch proceeds from the vertex to the top of the ear. Its direct flow goes from the vertex into the network vessel, exits from another lower abdomen, follows the lumbar region, presses on the loin, and arrives at a point in the middle of the back that loops with the sinew vessel, connects with the kidney, and belongs to the Chong. Its branch proceeds from the middle of the back down to the lumber region, penetrates the buttocks, enters the urinary bladder, presses on the inside of the lumbar region, passes the knee joint, loops around the outside of the thigh, from the pubic tuberosity downward merges with the urinary bladder's interior, exits outward from the heel, and follows the shin bone to the little toe's outer edge.

17: 是動則病沖頭痛，目似脫，項如拔，脊痛，腰似折，髀不可以曲，膕如結，踹如裂，是為踝厥。是主筋所生病者，痔、瘧、狂、癲疾、頭𩕄項痛，目黃、淚出，鼽衄，項、背、腰、尻、膕踹、腳皆痛，小趾不用。為此諸病，盛則寫之，虛則補之，熱則疾之，寒則留之，陷下則灸之，不盛不虛，以經取之。盛者，人迎大再倍於寸口，虛者，人迎反小於寸口也。 The condition is caused by overexertion, and presents with headache, dizziness, stiffness in the neck, back pain, painful hips that cannot be flexed, knees that feel like they are locked, and ankles that feel like they are split. This is called Gua disease. It affects those who have illnesses of the sinews, such as boils, furuncles, madness, mania, headaches, aching necks, yellow and watery eyes, nasal discharge, stiffness in the neck, back, hips, waist, knees, ankles, and toes that all hurt, and small toe weakness. For this condition, if it is excessive, write it; if it is deficient, tonify it; if there is heat, expel it; if there is cold, retain it; if it sinks downward, use moxibustion; if it neither excesses nor deficiencies, use acupuncture according to the classics. Excess is when the patient faces the practitioner at a distance twice that of the Cun point, and deficiency is when the patient faces the practitioner at a distance smaller than the Cun point.

18: 腎足少陰之脈，起於小趾之下，邪走足心，出於然谷之下，循內踝之後，別入跟中，以上踹內，出膕內廉，上股內後廉，貫脊，屬腎，絡膀胱；其直者，從腎上貫肝膈，入肺中，循喉嚨，挾舌本；其支者，從肺出絡心，注胸中。 The pulse of the Spleen and Kidney Yang is situated at the bottom of the small toe. If pathogenic factors travel to the heart, it comes out from the groove below, following the inner calf, not entering the heel, rising above the pubic tubercle, coming out before the inguinal ligament, penetrating the groin and entering the kidney region, passing through the spine. It belongs to the Spleen and nourishes the Bladder. Its direct path is from the Spleen, passing through the Liver and Stomach, entering the Lung, following the throat and grasping the root of the tongue. Its branch path is from the Lung, descending to nourish the Heart, lodging in the chest.

19: 是動則病飢不欲食，面如漆柴，咳唾則有血，喝喝而喘，坐而欲起，目𥆨𥆨如無所見，心如懸若飢狀。氣不足則善恐，心惕惕如人將捕之，是為骨厥。是主腎所生病者，口熱，舌乾，咽腫，上氣，嗌乾及痛，煩心，心痛，黃疸，腸澼，脊股內後廉痛，痿厥，嗜臥，足下熱而痛。為此諸病，盛則寫之，虛則補之，熱則疾之，寒則留之，陷下則灸之，不盛不虛，以經取之。灸則強食生肉，緩帶披發，大杖重履而步。盛者，寸口大再倍於人迎，虛者，寸口反小於人迎也。 When there is movement, it becomes illness due to hunger and lack of appetite, with a pale face like lacquer on tinder. When coughing up sputum, there is blood. Panting after drinking, sitting and wanting to get up, the eyes roll around like seeing nothing, and the heart feels suspended as if in a state of hunger. Insufficient Qi causes one to be easily frightened, with the mind being alert, like someone about to be caught, which is known as Jade Tear. This governs diseases generated by the Kidney, marked by a red tongue, a dry throat, swollen lymph nodes, a sensation of stuffiness in the chest, a dry and painful tongue, restlessness, heart pain, jaundice, abdominal bloating, lower back and inner thigh pain, impotence, liking to lie down, and hot and painful soles of the feet. For these diseases, if there is excess, regulate it; if deficient, supplement it; if there is heat, disperse it; if cold, retain it; if sunken in, apply acupuncture; if not excess or deficiency, use the Meridians. When applying acupuncture, the size of the opening at the Conception Vessel should be doubled in those with excess and half that in those with deficiency.

20: 心主手厥陰心包絡之脈，起於胸中，出屬心包絡，下膈，歷絡三焦；其支者，循胸出脅，下腋三寸，上抵腋下，循臑內，行太陰、少陰之間，入肘中，下臂，行兩筋之間，入掌中，循中指，出其端；其支者，別掌中，循小指次指，出其端。 The radial artery is the pulse taken at the wrist. It is derived from the brachial artery, which branches off from the axillary artery (a continuation of the subclavian artery). The branching is part of the process of forming the three Yang meridians of the hand: the Large Intestine, the Lung, and the Pericardium.

21: 是動則病手心熱，臂肘攣急，腋腫，甚則胸脅支滿，心中憺憺大動，面赤，目黃，喜笑不休。是主脈所生病者，煩心，心痛，掌中熱。為此諸病，盛則寫之，虛則補之，熱則疾之，寒則留之，陷下則灸之，不盛不虛，以經取之。盛者，寸口大一倍於人迎，虛者，寸口反小於人迎也。 The condition is due to a hyperactivity of the liver, manifested by redness of the palms, sweating, urgent and painful movements of the arms, swelling in the armpits, such that the chest feels supported, filled, and the heart is beating violently. The face turns red and the eyes yellow; they laugh uncontrollably. For this condition, if it predominates (i.e., the liver), then write it down. If it's deficient, then supplement. If there's heat, use an expeditious treatment. If there's cold, retain it. If it sinks downward, then use cupping therapy. If it isn't predominant or deficient, use the meridian and apply the classical text. When it predominates, the inch point is larger than a person's embrace; when it's deficient, the inch point is smaller than a person's embrace.

22: 三焦手少陽之脈，起於小指次指之端，上出兩指之間，循手表腕，出臂外兩骨之間，上貫肘，循臑外，上肩，而交出足少陽之後，入缺盆，布膻中，散落心包，下膈，循屬三焦；其支者，從膻中上出缺盆，上項系耳後，直上出耳上角，以屈下頰至䪼，其支者，從耳後入耳中，出走耳前，過客主人前，交頰，至目銳眥。 The three Yang Meridians: The Shao Yang meridian is the Lesser Yang meridian. It begins on the radial aspect of the third metacarpal joint, ascends between the first and second metacarpals, runs along the wrist, exits the outside of the two ulnae, passes through the elbow, follows the outer border of the scapula, ascends to the shoulder, and connects with the foot's lesser Yang channel, enters the hollow at the pubic bone, disseminates over the heart's pack, descends the abdomen, and follows the Spleen's three channels. Its branch is from the pubic bone up and out of the hollow, ascends to the level of the collarbone, connects at the ear's posterior, directly exits the ear's summit, extends down to the corner of the mouth, and its branch is from the ear's posterior entering the ear's interior, exiting the front of the walking earlobe, crossing in front of the ruler's nose, connecting at the chin, reaching the sharpness of the eyes.

23: 是動則病耳聾渾渾焞焞，嗌腫，喉痺。是主氣所生病者，汗出，目銳眥痛，頰痛，耳後、肩、臑、肘、臂外皆痛，小指次指不用。為此諸病，盛則寫之，虛則補之，熱則疾之，寒則留之，陷下則灸之，不盛不虛，以經取之。盛者，人迎大一倍於寸口，虛者，人迎反小於寸口也。 The text states that certain conditions arise from the movement of qi, such as deafness and dizziness. This is a disease caused by qi imbalance. Symptoms include sweating, sharp pain in the eyes, facial pain, pain in the ears, shoulders, chest, elbows, forearms, and the sides of the small and index fingers. The treatment approach involves regulating the balance between excess and deficiency, using acupuncture for sinking conditions, and adapting techniques based on whether the condition is due to heat or cold. If the qi is in excess or deficient, the treatment will be adjusted according to the principles of the meridians. When there is an excess of qi, it manifests as a person standing upright with their hands outstretched at the Large Intestine (Lung) position, and when there is a deficiency, it manifests as their hands being pulled in close to the body, smaller than the Inception (Conception) position.

24: 膽足少陽之脈，起於目銳眥，上抵頭角下耳後，循頸行手少陽之前，至肩上卻交出手少陽之後，入缺盆；其支者，從耳後入耳中，出走耳前，至目銳眥後；其支者，別銳眥，下大迎，合於手少陽，抵於䪼下，加頰車，下頸，合缺盆，以下胸中，貫膈，絡肝，屬膽，循脅裏，出氣沖，繞毛際，橫入髀厭中；其直者，從缺盆下腋，循胸，過季脅下合髀厭中，以下循髀陽，出膝外廉，下外輔骨之前，直下抵絕骨之端，下出外踝之前，循足跗上，入小趾次趾之間；其支者，別跗上，入大指之間，循大指歧骨內，出其端，還貫爪甲，出三毛。 The Dujue (Duyu) point is located on the Shao Yang meridian, starting at the bright and clear location of the eye, rising to the top of the ear lobe, following the front of the neck and extending to the hand of the Shao Yang. The supporting (branch) line originates from the back of the ear, enters the center of the ear, exits in front of the bright and clear part of the eye; its connecting (line) originates from the bright and clear location of the eye, descends below the large opening, merges with the Shao Yang of the hand, opposes the Hundred Convergences, adds the cheekbone, descends the throat, merges at the missing basin, traverses the chest within, pierces the Chong, connects the liver, belongs to the Gallbladder, follows the inside of the Guan, exits the Stomach Well, encircles the hairline, horizontally enters the hollow of the hip, and merges into the Huaigo channel; its direct (path) originates from the missing basin below the armpit, follows the chest, crosses the Guan below the seasonal gate and merges into the Hip Well channel, then descends following the Yangu, exiting outside the front of the Pubic Tubercle, down to the front of the auxiliary bone, directly below the tip of the heel, then exits at the front of the little toe. Its supporting (path) originates from the heel top, enters between the great toe's proximal phalanx, loops along the proximal phalanx of the great toe, and exits its tip, still connecting the claws and exiting at the three hairs

25: 是動則病口苦，善太息，心脅痛，不能轉側，甚則面微有塵，體無膏澤，足外反熱，是為陽厥。是主骨所生病者，頭痛，頷痛，目銳眥痛，缺盆中腫痛，腋下腫，馬刀俠癭，汗出振寒，瘧，胸、脅、肋、髀、膝外至脛、絕骨、外踝前及諸節皆痛，小趾次趾不用。為此諸病，盛則寫之，虛則補之，熱則疾之，寒則留之，陷下則灸之，不盛不虛，以經取之。盛者，人迎大一倍於寸口，虛者，人迎反小於寸口也。 The text is written in literary Chinese, which is a type of classical Chinese used in ancient texts and literature. The translation of this particular passage into English would be:

Symptoms arise due to the movement, pain at the mouth, shallow breathing, unable to turn over, sometimes with a little dirt on the face, body without sweat, feet hot outside, this is called Yang deficiency. It governs diseases arising from bones, headache, jaw pain, eye pain, pubic pain due to swelling, groin swelling, hip pain, knee pain, ankle pain, heel pain, toe pain, not being able to use the toes. If these diseases are abundant, record them; if they are scarce, supplement them; if there is heat, resolve it; if there is cold, retain it; if sinking, use cupping; if not abundant nor deficient, rely on the meridians. Abundance refers to the person standing facing the great yin (or a position where the large intestine point is 1 cun larger than the governing vessel point), and deficiency refers to the person standing facing the small yang (or a position where the governing vessel point is smaller than the large intestine point).

26: 肝足厥陰之脈，起於大趾叢毛之際，上循足跗上廉，去內踝一寸，上踝八寸，交出太陰之後，上膕內廉，循股陰，入毛中，過陰器，抵小腹，挾胃，屬肝，絡膽，上貫膈，布脅肋，循喉嚨之後，上入頏顙，連目系，上出額，與督脈會於巔；其支者，從目系下頰裏，環唇內；其支者，復從肝，別貫膈，上注肺。 The radialis minor pulse, which governs the kidney and influences the yin, arises at the intersection of the thick hair on the great toe. It rises along the inner side of the foot to the ankle joint, then ascends eight cun (approximately 12 cm or 4.7 inches) beyond it to reach the junction of the conception vessel and the governing vessel. Rising inside the inguinal ring, it follows the yin hollow of the thigh, enters the hairy region, passes in front of the genitals, strikes the small abdomen, embraces the stomach, belongs to the liver, unites with the gallbladder, ascends through the uterus, spreads over the costal margins, and follows the back of the throat. Then it enters the chin and joins with the governor vessel at the apex; its branches extend downward from the junction of the governing and conception vessels to encompass the eyes and ascend again to the lips. Another branch departs from the liver, separates from the conduit vessel, and ascends to the lung.

27: 是動則病腰痛不可以俛仰，丈夫㿉疝，婦人少腹腫，甚則嗌乾，面塵，脫色。是肝所生病者，胸滿，嘔逆，飧泄，狐疝，遺溺，閉癃。為此諸病，盛則寫之，虛則補之，熱則疾之，寒則留之，陷下則灸之，不盛不虛，以經取之。盛者，寸口大一倍於人迎，虛者，寸口反小於人迎也。 If there is movement, it will result in pain in the waist; a man will have groin pain, and a woman may have abdominal distension, with symptoms such as dryness of the vagina, dusty face, and pallor. This is due to disease arising from the liver. Symptoms include fullness in the chest, nausea rising to the throat, vomiting, hiccups, pain in the hips and loins, dizziness, and deafness. For these diseases, if they are abundant, treat with bloodletting; if they are deficient, use tonics; if there is heat, use quick-acting medicines; if there is cold, use warm medicines; for those who have sunken pulse, use acupuncture; and do not apply bloodletting or tonics based on the pulse. When there is abundance, the pulsation at the wrist is larger than a normal embrace, and when there is deficiency, it is smaller than a normal embrace.

28: 手太陰氣絕，則皮毛焦。太陰者，行氣溫於皮毛者也。故氣不榮，則皮毛焦；皮毛焦，則津液去皮節；津液去皮節者，則爪枯毛折；毛折者，則毛先死。丙篤丁死，火勝金也。 If yin energy is deficient, the skin and hair will become dry. Yin energy controls the warmth of the skin and hair. Therefore, if there is a lack of Qi, the skin and hair will become dry; when the skin and hair are dry, the body fluids will evaporate from the surface of the skin and muscles; when the body fluids have evaporated from the skin and muscles, the nails and hair will become withered; when the hair has withered, it will die first. Wood conquers Earth in the Pentad cycle

29: 手少陰氣絕，則脈不通；脈不通，則血不流；血不流，則髮色不澤，故其面黑如漆柴者，血先死。壬篤癸死，水勝火也。 If one's hand has few fingers and the yin qi is absent, then the pulse will not be transmitted; if the pulse is not transmitted, then the blood will not flow; if the blood does not flow, then the hair color will not flourish, hence his face is black like lacquer, and blood dies first. In the year of Ren Tou Gui, Keng Die, blood wins over fire, water triumphs over fire.

30: 足太陰氣絕者，則脈不榮肌肉。唇舌者，肌肉之本也。脈不榮，則肌肉軟；肌肉軟，則舌萎人中滿；人中滿，則唇反；唇反者，肉先死。甲篤乙死，木勝土也。 When the essence of the foot yin is exhausted, then the pulse will not nourish the muscles. The lips and tongue belong to the muscles. If the pulse does not nourish the muscles, they become soft; if the muscles are soft, the tongue becomes weak and one has difficulty speaking; when one has difficulty speaking, the lips turn inside out; turning the lips inside out is a sign of muscle death. Wood overpowers earth in the sequence of the five elements.

31: 足少陰氣絕，則骨枯。少陰者，冬脈也，伏行而濡骨髓者也，故骨不濡，則肉不能著也；骨肉不相親，則肉軟卻；肉軟卻，故齒長而垢，髮無澤；髮無澤者，骨先死。戊篤己死，土勝水也。 If there is not enough yin qi, the bones will become dry. Yin refers to the kidney meridian, which nourishes and moistens the bone marrow; thus if it does not moisten, the flesh cannot be nourished either. When the flesh is not nourished, it becomes soft and weak. Soft and weak flesh results in long teeth and dirt accumulation, while hair loses its luster. Hair without luster indicates that the bones will die first. In the cycle of the Five Elements, Earth overcomes Water.

32: 足厥陰氣絕，則筋絕。厥陰者，肝脈也，肝者，筋之合也，筋者，聚於陰氣，而脈絡於舌本也。故脈弗榮，則筋急；筋急則引舌與卵，故唇青舌卷卵縮，則筋先死。庚篤辛死，金勝木也。 When yin qi is exhausted, the sinews will be severed. Yin qi refers to the liver meridian, the liver governs the sinew's unification, and the sinew gathers at the yin qi, while the channels are rooted in the tongue by nature. Thus, if the channels are not honored, the sinews will become tight; when the sinews become tight, they will pull the tongue and the egg, leading to the lips turning purple, the tongue rolling up the egg, and the tongue contracting; the sinews will die first. In the year of Pig, Wood is defeated by Fire, while Metal triumphs over Wood.

33: 五陰氣俱絕，則目系轉，轉則目運；目運者，為志先死；志先死，則遠一日半死矣。六陽氣絕，則陰與陽相離，離則腠理發泄，絕汗乃出，故旦占夕死，夕占旦死。 When the five yin energies are all absent, the eyes will be turned, and when they are turned, the gaze will be fixed; the gaze being fixed is a sign of determination to die. Determination to die means one is close to death for half a day. When the six yang energies are absent, yin and yang become separated, leading to the release of the sinews and orifices, causing sweating to occur. This is why daily death predictions and nighttime death predictions alternate.

34: 經脈十二者，伏行分肉之間，深而不見；其常見者，足太陰過於外踝之上，無所隱故也。諸脈之浮而常見者，皆絡脈也。六經絡，手陽明少陽之大絡，起於五指間，上合肘中。飲酒者，衛氣先行皮膚，先充絡脈，絡脈先盛。故衛氣已平，營氣乃滿，而經脈大盛。脈之卒然動者，皆邪氣居之，留於本末，不動則熱，不堅則陷且空，不與眾同，是以知其何脈之動也。 The twelve channels are hidden, moving between the muscles, deep and not visible; those who often see them, there is a foot Taiyin passing above the outer toe without any hiding. All the floating channels that are often seen are the Luo channels. The six Luo channels, from Hand Yangming and Shaoyang's great Luo, originate in the space between the five fingers and join at the elbow. When drinking alcohol, Wei Qi goes first through the skin, fills the Luo channel first, and the Luo channel fills up first. Therefore, when Wei Qi is balanced, Ying Qi is full, and the meridians are abundant. The movement of the pulse at a crucial moment is always due to evil Qi residing there, staying at both the beginning and end, not moving, so it is hot but not firm, prone to sink and be empty, not mixing with others, which allows one to know which meridian's pulse is moving.

35: 雷公曰：何以知經脈之與絡脈異也？黃帝曰：經脈者，常不可見也，其虛實也，以氣口知之。脈之見者，皆絡脈也。 Master Lái asked: How do we know the difference between the regular pulse and the knotted pulse? Yellow Emperor answered: The regular pulse is always invisible, being both virtual and real, it can be known through its manifestations of Qi from the mouth. Those who can see the pulse are all experiencing a knotted pulse

36: 雷公曰：細子無以明其然也。黃帝曰：諸絡脈皆不能經大節之間，必行絕道而出入，復合於皮中，其會皆見於外。故諸刺絡脈者，必刺其結上甚血者。雖無結，急取之，以寫其邪而出其血。留之發為痺也。凡診絡脈，脈色青，則寒，且痛；赤則有熱。胃中寒，手魚之絡多青矣；胃中有熱，魚際絡赤。其暴黑者，留久痺也。其有赤、有黑、有青者，寒熱氣也。其青短者，少氣也。凡刺寒熱者，皆多血絡，必間日而一取之，血盡而止，乃調其虛實。其小而短者，少氣，甚者，寫之則悶，悶甚則仆，不得言，悶則急坐之也。 Master Lái said: A needle cannot reveal the truth of a channel clearly. Emperor Hóu said: All the channels cannot circulate freely through the large joints, so they must go along the small channels and come in and out through the skin; all of these are seen on the outside. Therefore, when piercing the channels, one must pierce where there is much bleeding and urgency to expel the evil and let blood out. Leaving it will lead to swelling. In general, when diagnosing the channels, if the pulse is greenish-blue, it indicates coldness and pain; if red, it indicates heat. Channels in the stomach area often have a greenish-blue hue when there is coldness inside; when there is heat within, the extremity of the channels will be red. If they are extremely black, leaving them for too long can lead to swelling. Red, black, and green indicate the presence of cold and hot energies. Short green indicates a deficiency of energy. In general, when piercing cold and heat, one must repeatedly take blood from them every day, until the blood has all stopped flowing and then it will regulate the emptiness and reality. When they are small and short, there is a deficiency of energy; if severe, writing it out can cause weakness, severe weakness can lead to unconsciousness, and being unable to speak; weakness leads to sitting down in urgency, and not being able to stand up.

37: 手太陰之別，名曰列缺。起於腕上分間，并太陰之經，直入掌中，散入于魚際。其病實則手銳掌熱；虛則欠㰦，小便遺數。取之去腕寸半。別走陽明也。 The separate channel of the Shu (lateral) vessel is called Lěi Qiāng. It begins at the wrist crease and runs along with the Shu vessel, passing into the palm directly and dispersing into the finger tips. Its true manifestation is sharpness and warmth in the hand; its deficiency is numbness of the hand, and incontinence of urine. It ends at the wrist joint. It separates from the Yang Ming (Great Brightness) channel.

38: 手少陰之別，名曰通裏。去腕一寸半，別而上行，循經入于心中，系舌本，屬目系。其實則支膈，虛則不能言。取之掌後一寸，別走太陽也。 The hand method called Tonglu (penetrating interior), with a deficiency in the yin, is located at a point one and a half inches behind the wrist. It ascends and enters the heart region, connects with the tongue's root, and belongs to the channel of the eyes. Its actual function is to support the diaphragm; if it is deficient, one cannot speak. It is located one inch behind the wrist and continues along the large intestine channel.

39: 手心主之別，名曰內關。去腕二寸，出於兩筋之間，循經以上，系於心包絡。心系實則心痛，虛則為頭強。取之兩筋間也。 The text refers to a point in acupuncture called Neiguan or Inner Gate. It is located three cun (approximately 3 cm) below the wrist crease between two tendons. The flow of the meridian is followed upwards, and the point connects to the heart and pericardium channels. If the needle manipulation at this point is done properly, it can alleviate chest pain; if done incorrectly, it may cause headache. This point is also used for taking the needle out.

40: 手太陽之別，名曰支正。上腕五寸，內注少陰；其別者，上走肘，絡肩髃。實則節弛肘廢；虛則生肬，小者如指痂疥。取之所別也。 The text refers to a point called Zhèzhēng, which is located on the back of the hand. It lies five cun above the wrist and is connected to the Shàoyīn channel. The Zhèzhēng point is located at the intersection between the shoulder tendon and hair, and its alternate location is at the elbow joint. When this point is healthy, it allows for flexibility in the elbow, but when it is deficient, it can cause swelling of the elbows or small nodules that resemble pimples. The text also mentions that this point is related to a separate technique or method for treatment.

41: 手陽明之別，名曰偏歷。去腕三寸，別入太陰；其別者，上循臂，乘肩髃，上曲頰傷齒；其別者，入耳，合於宗脈。實則齲聾；虛則齒寒痺隔。取之所別也。 The departure of the hand's Yang Brightness, known as Partial Reversal. Three inches below the wrist, it separates from the Taiyang; its separation proceeds along the arm, crossing the shoulder and hairline, ascending to the cheek and gum, and entering the ear, connecting with the Governor Vessel. It is actually linked to deafness; when it is deficient, it causes teeth chattering and numbness of the lips. The location from which it departs.

42: 手少陽之別，名曰外關。去腕二寸，外繞臂，注胸中，合心主。病實則肘攣，虛則不收。取之所別也。 The text in literary Chinese states: 手少陽之別，名曰外關。去腕二寸，外繞臂，注胸中，合心主。病實則肘攣，虛則不收。取之所別也。 Translated to English, it reads: The Yang Minor Meridian, called the External Gate. With one wrist width away and outside of the arm, crossing above the breast, grasping the heart channel. If there is actual pain at the elbow, if empty then do not grasp. The method for taking it varies.

43: 足太陽之別，名曰飛揚。去踝七寸，別走少陰。實則鼽窒，頭背痛；虛則鼽衄。取之所別也。 The translation of the given literary Chinese text is as follows: The channel named Flying Upward separates from the Foot Jupiter. It is located seven inches below the ankle joint and separates from the Minor Yin. In reality, it connects the lungs and causes head and back pain; when deficient, it connects the lungs and causes coughing. The point at which it separates is used for this purpose.

44: 足少陽之別，名曰光明，去踝五寸，別走厥陰，下絡足跗。實則厥，虛則痿躄，坐不能起。取之所別也。 The text you provided is actually written in modern Chinese, not literary Chinese. Literary Chinese uses classical characters and a different grammar structure compared to the modern language. Here's a translation of your modern Chinese text into English:

The difference between Yin and Yang is called 'Light and Bright.' It spans five inches from the ankle, separates from the Yang channel, and connects to the foot-Yang channel. In reality, it's deficient; if it's excessive, it leads to weakness and inability to stand. The passage describes a particular acupoint difference between Yin and Yang channels.

45: 足陽明之別，名曰豐隆。去踝八寸。別走太陰；其別者，循脛骨外廉，上絡頭項，合諸經之氣，下絡喉嗌。其病氣逆則喉痺瘁瘖。實則狂巔，虛則足不收，脛枯。取之所別也。 The text you provided is not actual literary Chinese, but rather it appears to be a description of a traditional acupuncture point. Here's the translation:

The Yangming separate point is named Fenglón. Located eight cun below Guān, separate from the Taínyī channel; its separate point follows the contour of the fibula, ascends to the Jǐn and Jǔ intersection, connects with the Qi of the Meridians, descends to the pharynx. If there is illness and the Qi is reversed, it causes a sore throat. The true condition is madness, while the false condition is the foot not retracting and the Achilles tendon becoming dry. The point is taken separately.

46: 足太陰之別，名曰公孫。去本節之後一寸，別走陽明；其別者，入絡腸胃，厥氣上逆則霍亂，實則腸中切痛；虛則鼓脹。取之所別也。 The separate channel of the foot yang minor is called Gong Sun. One cun away from this point, there is another named Yang Ming; its passage goes to the ligament of the stomach and intestines. If the controlled (or regulated) qi ascends inversely, it will cause hiccups; if it accumulates, there will be distention in the abdomen. This is where the separate channel originates from.

47: 足少陰之別，名曰大鍾。當踝後繞跟，別走太陽；其別者，并經上走於心包下，外貫腰脊。其病氣逆則煩悶，實則閉癃，虛則腰痛。取之所別者也。 The translation of the literary Chinese text to English is: The Great Chong, also known as the Sufficiency of Yin, is located behind the malleolus, away from the sun. Another location is on the course along the top, walking downward toward the heart-pack and below the diaphragm, extending outwards to the waist. If the condition is reversed, it causes restlessness; if real, it leads to constipation; if empty, it results in lower back pain. This is the alternative point for taking it

48: 足厥陰之別，名曰蠡溝。去內踝五寸，別走少陽；其別者，經脛上睪，結於莖。其病氣逆則睪腫卒疝。實則挺長，虛則暴癢。取之所別也。 The passage in literary Chinese describes a point on the human body, which is known as Jie Gou or Gutters Channel. It explains that this point is located five inches away from the inner ankle, separate from the Shao Yang channel. The text also provides information about its function and potential issues associated with it.

Translation: The point of divergence of the foot yin, named Gutter Channel. Five cun away from the inner ankle, diverging from the minor Yang. Its divergent point, on the bladder channel above the great toe, connects at the pubic tubercle. If there is a disease and the qi flows backwards, the toe swells and becomes rigid. When it is real (true), it extends long; when it is false (empty), it causes severe pain in the abdomen. The place where it diverges is called Jie Gou.

49: 任脈之別，名曰尾翳。下鳩尾，散於腹。實則腹皮痛，虛則痒搔。取之所別也。 The separate channel of the pulse is called Fei Luo. It descends from the tail of the sparrow and disperses in the abdomen. In reality, it causes abdominal pain and itching, and its location can be distinguished.

50: 督脈之別，名曰長強。挾膂上項，散頭上，下當肩胛左右，別走太陽，入貫膂。實則脊強，虛則頭重，高搖之，挾脊之有過者。取之所別也。 The separation of the governing vessel is called Chénggróng. Embrace the muscles on the chest, disperse on the head, descend at the level of the shoulders and hip bones, deviate from the greater yang, enter and penetrate the muscles. In fact, it strengthens the spine, weakens the head, when raised, embrace the spine, those who have excess will be corrected. The point where it is separated is the place to obtain it

51: 脾之大絡，名曰大包。出淵腋下三寸，布胸脅。實則身盡痛，虛則百節盡皆縱。此脈若罷絡之血者，皆取之脾之大絡脈也。 The large network of the spleen is called the Da Bao. It emerges from the depths of the armpit, extending three inches across the chest. If it is real, the entire body will hurt intensely, and if it is empty, all the joints will become limp. This pulse corresponds to stopping the blood in the large network of the spleen

52: 凡此十五絡者，實則必見，虛則必下。視之不見，求之上下。人經不同，絡脈亦所別也。 All fifteen connections are in fact either seen or not, and either true or false. If one does not see it when looking at it, and seeks it up and down, people's experience differs and the connections of the vessels also vary

docs.title: 經別
docs.text:
1: 黃帝問於歧伯曰：余聞人之合於天道也，內有五藏，以應五音、五色、五時、五味、五位也；外有六府，以應六律。六律建陰陽諸經而合之十二月、十二辰、十二節、十二經水、十二時、十二經脈者，此五藏六府之所以應天道。夫十二經脈者，人之所以生，病之所以成，人之所以治，病之所以起，學之所始，工之所止也。麤之所易，上之所難也。請問其離合，出入奈何？歧伯稽首再拜曰：明乎哉問也！此麤之所過，上之所息也，請卒言之。 The Yellow Emperor asked Yi Bo, saying: I have heard that people are in harmony with the Dao of Heaven. Inside they have five organs, which respond to the five tones, five colors, five times, five flavors, and five positions. Outside there are six departments, which respond to the six laws. The six laws build upon the classics of Yin and Yang and harmonize them with the twelve months, twelve stems, twelve degrees, twelve water channels, twelve times, and twelve channels of vital energy. These five organs and six departments are what respond to the Dao of Heaven. The twelve channels of vital energy are what make people live, give rise to disease, allow for treatment, cause disease to arise, form the basis of learning, and put an end to work. It is difficult to approach them, and yet easy to lose them. Please ask about their beginning and end, and how they enter and exit. Yi Bo kowtowed and said, How marvelous your question is! This is what causes them to be lost and is difficult to approach; please allow me to answer it fully.

2: 足太陽之正，別入于膕中，其一道下尻五寸，別入于肛，屬於膀胱，散之腎，循膂，當心入散；直者，從膂上出於項，復屬於太陽，此為一經也。足少陰之正，至膕中，別走太陽而合，上至腎，當十四椎出屬帶脈；直者，系舌本，復出於項，合於太陽，此為一合。成以諸陰之別，皆為正也。 The foot Taiyang channel is the proper one. It diverges from the Mingmen and goes downward five cun below the buttocks, entering the anus, belongs to the bladder, disperses it through the Shen, follows the Jue, enters the heart cavity; if straight, it comes out of the Jue from the Gaohuang, belonging to Taiyang, this is one channel. The foot Shaoyin channel reaches to the Mingmen, separates from Taiyang and unites, ascends to the Zhong, belongs to Guan, when exiting at the fourteen vertebrae; if straight, it connects with the tongue root, comes out of the Gaohuang, unites with Taiyang, this is one channel. The succession of the Yin channels is all proper.

3: 足少陽之正，繞髀入毛際，合於厥陰，別者入季脅之間，循胸裏屬膽，散之上肝，貫心以上挾咽，出頤頜中，散於面，繫目系，合少陽於外眥也。足厥陰之正，別跗上，上至毛際，合於少陽，與別俱行，此為二合也。z When the Yang Ming (the foot Yang Meridian) is in its proper state, it enters the hairy part of the

4: 足陽明之正，上至脾，入于腹裏屬胃，散之脾，上通於心，上循咽出於口，上頞䪼，還繫目系，合於陽明也。足太陰之正，上至髀，合於陽明，與別俱行，上結於咽，貫舌中，此為三合也。 The following text is already in English, with the exception of some archaic terms used to represent classical Chinese concepts. Here's a more modern equivalent:

The correcting function of Yang Ming resides in the foot Yang Ming and ascends to the spleen, which is housed in the abdomen and belongs to the stomach. When it disperses, it connects to the heart. It circulates up through the throat and exits at the mouth. It ties to the eyes, regulating vision, and joins with Yang Ming. The correcting function of Tai Yin resides in the foot Tai Yin and connects with Yang Ming, following a separate course. It ascends to the hip joint and connects with Yang Ming, representing the Three Meetings.

5: 手太陽之正，指地，別於肩解，入腋走心，系小腸也。手少陰之正，別入于淵腋兩筋之間，屬於心，上走喉嚨，出於面，合目內眥，此為四合也。 The hand Yang (radial) aspect proper, points at the earth; separate from the shoulder, enter the armpit and go to the heart. The hand Shao Yin (palmar) aspect proper, separate within the axillary sinew depressors, belongs to the heart, ascend to the throat, exit from the front, close to the eyes' inner corner, this is the four closings.

6: 手少陽之正，指天，別於巔，入缺盆，下走三焦，散於胸中也。手心主之正，別下淵腋三寸，入胸中，別屬三焦，出循喉嚨，出耳後，合少陽完骨之下，此為五合也。 The text describes a traditional Chinese medicine concept regarding the flow of energy (Qi) in the body. Translated to English, it says: When the right hand is above the right kidney, point towards the sky and separate from the peak. The Qi will enter the cavity and travel downwards along the three burners. It will disperse within the chest. When the palm faces downward, locate a depth of three cun below the axillary depression, entering the chest, not belonging to the three burners, it exits by circling the throat and exiting at the back of the ear, merging with the Shao Yang to complete the bone structure. This is known as the Five Meetings.

7: 手陽明之正，從手循膺乳，別於肩髃，入柱骨，下走大腸，屬於肺，上循喉嚨，出缺盆，合於陽明也。手太陰之正，別入淵腋少陰之前，入走肺，散之大陽，上出缺盆，循喉嚨，復合陽明，此六合也。 The channel of the Hand Yang Ming starts from the hand and follows the Radial Artery, diverging from the shoulder hairline, entering the humerus, descending along the large intestine, belonging to the lung, ascending along the throat, exiting at the umbilicus, connecting with the Yang Ming also. The channel of the Hand Taiyin starts by diverging and entering the well of the armpit of the Lesser Shao Yin, entering the lung, dispersing to the Great Yang, ascending and exiting at the umbilicus, ascending along the throat, connecting with the Yang Ming, thus forming the six connections.

docs.title: 經水
docs.text:
1: 黃帝問於歧伯曰：經脈十二者，外合於十二經水，而內屬於五藏六府。夫十二經水者，其有大小、深淺、廣狹、遠近各不同；五藏六府之高下、大小、受谷之多少亦不等，相應奈何？夫經水者，受水而行之；五藏者，合神氣魂魄而藏之；六府者，受穀而行之，受氣而揚之；經脈者，受血而營之。合而以治，奈何？刺之深淺，灸之壯數，可得聞乎？ Yellow Emperor asked Guan Pu: The twelve channels are externally united with the twelve channel vessels, while internally they belong to the five zang and six fu organs. The twelve channel vessels have differences in depth, shallowness, width, narrowness, distance, and proximity. The levels of the five zang and six fu organs also differ in height, size, amount of receiving the grains, and so on. How are they correlated? Channels are the paths that receive water and flow with it; the zang organs combine the spirit, qi, soul, and body to store them; the fu organs receive grains and raise them, receiving qi and elevating them. Channels harmonize and regulate, how is it done? Is it possible to hear about needling at different depths, moxibustion with numerous numbers?

2: 歧伯答曰：善哉問也！天至高不可度，地至廣不可量，此之謂也。且夫人生於天地之間，六合之內，此天之高，地之廣也，非人力之所能度量而至也。若夫八尺之士，皮肉在此，外可度量切循而得之，其死可解剖而視之。其藏之堅脆，府之大小，穀之多少，脈之長短，血之清濁，氣之多少，十二經之多血少氣，與其少血多氣，與其皆多血氣，與其皆少血氣，皆有大數。其治以鍼艾，各調其經氣，固其常有合乎。 Huang Di replied: Your question is indeed good! The sky is too high to be measured, and the earth is too vast to be calculated; this is what you are referring to. Moreover, humans live within the space between heaven and earth and inside the six covers (i.e., six sense organs). The height of heaven and the breadth of earth are not within human ability to measure. If an eight-foot man has his skin and flesh here, one can measure it and cut it around to obtain it; his death can be dissected and examined. His hiding place is rigid and brittle, the extent of his organs, the abundance of his grains, the length of his veins, the clarity or turbidity of his blood, the abundance of his Qi, the state of his twelve meridians with more or less blood and Qi, whether it is mostly abundant in blood and Qi or deficient in both, or solely deficient in blood, all have specific numbers. Treatment involves acupuncture and moxibustion, adjusting the meridian Qi according to each case, and fixing their constitutional balance.

3: 黃帝曰：余聞之，快於耳不解於心，願卒聞之。歧伯答曰：此人之所以參天地而應陰陽也，不可不察。足太陽外合清水，內屬膀胱，而通水道焉。足少陽外合于渭水，內屬于膽。足陽明外合于海水，內屬于胃。足太陰外合于湖水，內屬于脾。足少陰外合于汝水，內屬于腎。足厥陰外合于澠水，內屬于肝。手太陽外合淮水，內屬小腸，而水道出焉。手少陽外合于漯水，內屬于三焦。手陽明外合于江水，內屬于大腸。手太陰外合于河水，內屬于肺。手少陰外合于濟水，內屬于心。手心主外合于漳水，內屬于心包。凡此五藏六府十二經水者，外有源泉，而內有所稟，此皆內外相貫，如環無端，人經亦然。故天為陽，地為陰，腰以上為天，腰以下為地。故海以北者為陰，湖以北者為陰中之陰；漳以南者為陽，河以北至漳者為陽中之陰；漯以南至江者，為陽中之太陽，此一隅之陰陽也，所以人與天地相參也。 The Yellow Emperor said: I have heard of this, quick to the ear and difficult to understand in the heart. I wish to hear it once more. The Duke answered: This person is classified according to the Yin-Yang of heaven and earth, and cannot be overlooked. The foot Jueyin outside merges with clear water, inside belongs to the Bladder, and connects to the waterway. The foot Shaoyin outside merges with river water, inside belongs to the Gallbladder. The foot Yangming outside merges with sea water, inside belongs to the Stomach. The foot Taiyin outside merges with lake water, inside belongs to the Spleen. The foot Shayin outside merges with Swatow water, inside belongs to the Kidneys. The foot Jueyin outside merges with Gobi water, inside belongs to the Liver. The hand Jueyin outside merges with the Huai River water, inside belongs to the Small Intestine, and the waterway comes out of it. The hand Shaoyin outside merges with the Luo River water, inside belongs to the Triple Burner. The hand Yangming outside merges with river water, inside belongs to the Large Intestine. The hand Taiyin outside merges with the Yangtze River water, inside belongs to the Lungs. The hand Shayin outside merges with the Tongpu River water, inside belongs to the Heart. The hand Jingwell outside merges with the Chu River water, inside belongs to the Pericardium. All of these five viscera and six bowels have twelve waterways. Externally, there is a source of water, and internally, there is a place for it to be stored; all are interconnected between internal and external, like a circle without an end, just as human channels are the same. Therefore, heaven is yang, and earth is yin; above the waist is yang, and below the waist is yin. The Duke further said: The North Sea is yin, and the Lake is yin within the yin; the South River is yang, and from the North to the South is yin within the yang; the Luo River extends to the Yangtze River, which is yin within the yang of this corner. Therefore, people are related to heaven and earth by virtue of this yin and yang.

4: 黃帝曰：夫經水之應經脈也，其遠近淺深，水血之多少，各不同，合而以刺之奈何？歧伯答曰：足陽明，五藏六府之海也，其脈大，血多氣盛，熱壯，刺此者不深勿散，不留不寫也。足陽明刺深六分，留十呼。足太陽深五分，留七呼。足少陽深四分，留五呼。足太陰深三分，留四呼。足少陰深二分，留三呼。足厥陰深一分，留二呼。手之陰陽，其受氣之道近，其氣之來疾，其刺深者，皆無過二分，其留，皆無過一呼。其少長、大小、肥瘦，以心擦之，命曰法天之常，灸之亦然。灸而過此者，得惡火則骨枯脈澀，刺而過此者，則脫氣。 Yellow Emperor said: The meridians correspond to water channels, and the depth and distance of these meridians vary according to the amount of blood and qi. How should they be pierced when they are all different? Huang Di answered: The foot Yangming is where the six ministries and five zang meet, with large vessels and abundant blood and qi, it is warm and strong. If you pierce this area, do not go too deep and do not disperse or dissipate. When piercing the foot Yangming, go 6 cun deep and leave for ten breaths. When piercing the foot Taiyang, go 5 cun deep and leave for seven breaths. When piercing the foot Shaoyang, go 4 cun deep and leave for five breaths. When piercing the foot Taiyin, go 3 cun deep and leave for four breaths. When piercing the foot Shao yin, go 2 cun deep and leave for three breaths. When piercing the foot Jueyin, go 1 cun deep and leave for two breaths. For the hand Yangming and Shaoyang, as their channels receive qi more closely and their qi arrives more quickly, the depth of piercing should not exceed two cun, and the duration should not exceed one breath. The length, size, and fatness (of a person) are determined by intention; this is known as the constant way of law heaven, and acupuncture is similar in principle. If you go beyond this, it will result in evil fire consuming the bones and vessels, and if you pierce beyond this, the qi will escape.

5: 黃帝曰：夫經脈之大小，血之多少，膚之厚薄，肉之堅脆及膕之大小，可為量度乎？歧伯答曰：其可為度量者，取其中度也。不甚脫肉，而血氣不衰也。若夫度之人，消瘦而形肉脫者，惡可以度量刺乎。審、切、循、捫、按，視其寒溫盛衰而調之，是謂因適而為之真也。 Yellow Emperor said: Can the size of the meridians, the amount of blood, the thickness of the skin, the hardness or softness of the muscles, and the size of the veins be measured? Duke of Zhou replied: That which can be measured is doing so by degree. One should not strip away the flesh, as the vital energy will not decline. As for those who measure by degree, if they become thin and their body flesh strips away, they are bad candidates for acupuncture. Examination, puncture, examination, looping, palpation - these methods should be adjusted according to whether it is cold or warm, abundant or diminished. This is what it means to act appropriately in accordance with the principle of true medicine.

docs.title: 經筋
docs.text:
1: 足太陽之筋，起於足小趾，上結于踝，邪上結于膝，其下循足外側，結于踵，上循跟，結於膕；其別者，結于腨外，上膕中內廉，與膕中并上結于臀，上挾脊上項；其支者，別入結于舌本；其直者，結于枕骨，上頭，下顏，結于鼻；其支者，為目上網，下結于頄；其支者，從腋后外廉結于肩髃；其支者，入腋下，上出缺盆，上結於完骨；其支者，出缺盆，邪上出于頄。其病小趾支跟腫痛，膕攣，脊反折，項筋急，肩不舉，腋支缺盆中紐痛，不可左右搖。治在燔鍼劫刺，以知為數，以痛為輸，名曰仲春痺也1。1. 也 : 舊脫。 The sinew of the foot's Yellow Emperor begins at the tip of the small toe, ascends to the heel, and its path upward follows the outer edge of the foot, ending at the ankle; it then loops around the heel, ending at the malleolus. Its other branch ascends alongside the lateral condyle of the tibia, connects with the tendon of the adductor muscle of the thigh, and joins its fellow tendons to connect with the buttock; its supplementary branch enters the resultant and ends at the medial condyle of the humerus. Its direct branch results in the tendon of the supraorbital muscle, connecting to the skull above, descending to the cheekbone and ending at the nose. Its supplementary branch supports the eyebrow above, descending and ending at the nape of the neck; its supplementary branch enters the axilla and ascends to connect with the coracoid process; its supplementary branch enters the inframammary area, ascends to connect with the crest of the ilium, and descends from there. Its supplementary branch exits the crest of the ilium, deviates upward to connect at the nape of the neck. This sinew's disease involves swelling and pain in the tip of the small toe and heel, aching in the waist, bending of the spine, neck pain, inability to raise the shoulders, pain in the axillary tendon, and inability to swing from left to right; it is treated by acupuncture at the Jueyin hole. The number of needles used indicates the severity of the condition, and it is called the Zhong Chun Yao. Note: 也 - Old: Remove

2: 足少陽之筋，起於小指次指，上結外踝，上循脛外廉，結於膝外廉；其支者，別起外輔骨，上走髀，前者結於伏兔之上，後者，結於尻；其直者，上乘䏚季脅，上走腋前廉，繫於膺乳，結於缺盆；直者，上出腋，貫缺盆，出太陽之前，循耳後，上額角，交巔上，下走頷，上結於頄；支者，結於目眥為外維。其病小指次指支轉筋，引膝外轉筋，膝不可屈伸，膕筋急，前引髀，後引尻，即上乘䏚季脅痛，上引缺盆、膺乳、頸維筋急。從左之右，右目不開，上過右角，并蹻脈而行，左絡於右，故傷左角，右足不用，命曰維筋相交。治在燔鍼劫刺，以知為數，以痛為輸，名曰孟春痺也。 The meridian of the small and ring fingers begins at the shallow yang channels, rises from the little and ring fingers, ascends along the outer side of the calf, loops around the crest of the pubic bone, and terminates at the outer side of the groin; its supporting branch starts from the outer aspect of the ilium, ascends to the sacrum, one ending at the top of the scapula and the other at the nape, its direct branch rises over the axilla along the outer aspect of the anterior crest, attaches to the pectoralis major, and terminates in the inguinal region; the direct branch ascends from the axilla, pierces the inguinal ring, exits through the upper opening of the abdomen, runs along the auricle, loops around the superior margin, descends at the jaw, and terminates at the throat; its supporting branch terminates at the lacrimal sac as an external tendon. Its disease involves the little and ring fingers' support and transformation of channels, referring to the inguinal region's transformation channel, causing the knee to be unable to bend or straighten, straining the groin, referring to the ilium, and referring to the sacrum and nape, resulting in pain at the level of the axilla, breast

3: 足陽明之筋，起於中三指，結於跗上，邪外上加於輔骨，上結於膝外廉，直上結於髀樞，上循脅屬脊；其直者，上循骭，結於膝；其支者，結於外輔骨，合少陽；其直者，上循伏兔，上結於髀，聚於陰器，上腹而布，至缺盆而結，上頸，上挾口，合于頄，下結於鼻，上合於太陽。太陽為目上網，陽明為目下網；其支者，從頰結於耳前。其病足中指支脛轉筋，腳跳堅，伏兔轉筋，髀前踵，㿉疝，腹筋急，引缺盆及頰，卒口僻；急者，目不合，熱則筋縱，目不開，頰筋有寒，則急，引頰移口，有熱則筋弛縱，緩不勝收，故僻。治之以馬膏，膏其急者；以白酒和桂，以塗其緩者，以桑鉤鉤之，即以生桑炭置之坎中，高下以坐等。以膏熨急頰，且飲美酒，敢美炙肉，不飲酒者，自強也，為之三拊而已。治在燔鍼劫刺，以知為數，以痛為輸，名曰季春痺也。 The Jīn Chūn Yuán is an acupuncture point located on the foot Yang Míng channel, starting at the middle finger's metacarpophalangeal joint and ending at the heel. Pathological external factors may accumulate above the Cánguān, joining with the Shǎo Yáng channel, ascending to the knee, circling around the sacrum and connecting with the spine; its ascending branch goes up along the Zhènshū, connecting at the pubic region, moves across the abdomen and reaches the mons veneris, then gathers at the genitals. Its supporting branch connects at the pubic region and merges with the Shǎo Yáng channel, while its ascending branch goes up along the Fútù, connecting at the hip, gathers at the yin orifice, moves across the lower abdomen and reaches the pubic region, then passes by the neck and embraces the mouth, merging with the Tàiyáng. The Tàiyáng represents the brows, while the Yang Míng represents the eyes below the brows; its supporting branch starts at the chin and connects at the ear lobe. Its pathology involves the middle finger, ankle, knee joint, inguinal region (pubic area), abdomen, and urogenital system, with symptoms including painful and difficult movement of the hip, pain in the low back and waist, abdominal pain and distension, and swelling and pain in the genitals, face, and mouth. In severe cases, the eyes do not meet, the tongue is deviated, and there may be cold or heat sensations. To treat this condition, apply horse liniment to the urgent areas; use white wine and cinnamon paste for the sluggish areas, and use a loach fishhook on them. Apply fresh loach charcoal in the hollows and have the patient sit with both legs folded or straightened. Apply ointment to the urgent areas around the mouth, and have the patient drink sweet wine, eat roasted meat, and avoid drinking alcohol if possible; this should be done three times for a complete recovery. This treatment is performed during the Jīn Chūn period, and has been called Jīn Chūn Yún for short.

4: 足太陰之筋，起於大指之端內側，上結於內踝；其直者，絡於膝內輔骨，上循陰股，結於髀，聚於陰器，上腹結於臍，循腹裏，結於肋，散於胸中；其內者，著於脊。其病足大指支內踝痛，轉筋痛，膝內輔骨痛，陰股引髀而痛，陰器紐痛，上引臍兩脅痛，引膺中脊內痛。治在燔鍼劫刺，以知為數，以痛為輸，命曰孟秋痺也。 The ligament of the foot's yang minor originates from inside the tip of the great toe and ascends to the inner ankle; its straight part runs through the knee's auxiliary bone, ascending along the yin channel to the thigh, gathering at the pudendum, ascending to the abdomen and connecting at the umbilicus, circulating within the abdomen, and connecting at the ribs, dispersing in the chest; its interior part is attached to the spine.
