Its disorder involves pain at the great toe supporting the inner ankle, turning tendon pain, pain at the knee's auxiliary bone, referring pain to the thigh, pudendum pain, pain at the umbilicus referring to both hypochondria, and pain at the chest and spine. Treatment is by moxibustion or acupuncture needling at Jueyin, knowing pain as a departure, and called Meng Qiu Yan.

5: 足少陰之筋，起於小指之下，并足太陰之筋，邪走內踝之下，結於踵，與太陽之筋合，而上結於內輔之下，并太陰之筋，而上循陰股，結於陰器，循脊內挾膂上至項，結於枕骨，與足太陽之筋合。其病足下轉筋，及所過而結者皆痛及轉筋。病在此者，主癎瘈及痙，在外者不能挽，在內者不能仰。故陽病者，腰反折不能俛，陰病者，不能仰。治在燔鍼劫刺，以知為數，以痛為輸。在內者熨引飲藥，此筋折紐，紐發數甚者死不治，名曰仲秋痺也。 Translation: The channels of the foot yang minor and foot shao yin originate from below the little toe and unite with the great yang channel, ascending to join the jue yin channel at the renal depression, forming a loop around the genitals and joining the bladder channel at the occuput, uniting with the great yang channel. Patients with pain in these channels or along the course of the channels will have pain. Diseases arising from within cannot be pulled outward, and those arising internally cannot be elevated. Therefore, diseases of yang channels result in a reversed lumbar curvature that cannot be straightened, while diseases of yin channels result in an inability to be elevated. Treatment involves needle insertion at the appropriate points, using a counter-irritant and draining method, and internally administering heat-producing medicine. If this channel becomes twisted and knotted, the cord will emit signs of danger; if severe, it is fatal and is known as qu zhi yin.

6: 足厥陰之筋，起於大指之上，上結於內踝之前，上循脛，上結內輔之下，上循陰股，結於陰器，絡諸筋。其病足大指支內踝之前痛，內輔痛，陰股痛轉筋，陰器不用，傷於內則不起，傷於寒則陰縮入，傷於熱則縱挺不收，治在行水清陰氣；其病轉筋者，治在燔鍼劫刺，以知為數，以痛為輸，命曰季秋痺也。 The ligament of the foot's yin (Flexor Hallucis Longus) begins at the top of the big toe, ascends to the front of the inner ankle, loops around the tibia, connects to the adductor muscles, loops around the pubic bone, and attaches to the genitals. When this ligament is injured, there will be pain at the big toe supporting the inner ankle, the adductor muscles, the pubic bone, and difficulty using the genitals. If injured internally, it will not rise; if injured by cold, the yin will retract; if injured by heat, it will stand erect and not retract. Treatment for this condition involves regulating water and clearing the yin energy; for those with pain that refers to other areas (referred pain), treatment involves needing and cupping at strategic points, identifying the pain as Seasonal Imbalance of Qi.

7: 手太陽之筋，起於小指之上，結於腕，上循臂內廉，結於肘內銳骨之後，彈之應小指之上，入結於腋下；其支者，後走腋後廉，上繞肩胛，循頸出走太陽之前，結於耳後完骨；其支者，入耳中；直者，出耳上，下結於頷，上屬目外眥。其病小指支肘內銳骨後廉痛，循臂陰，入腋下，腋下痛，腋後廉痛，繞肩胛引頸而痛，應耳中鳴痛引頷，目瞑良久乃得視，頸筋急，則為筋瘻頸腫，寒熱在頸者。治在燔鍼劫刺之，以知為數，以痛為輸。其為腫者，復而銳之。本支者，上曲牙，循耳前屬目外眥，上頷結於角，其痛當所過者支轉筋。治在燔鍼劫刺，以知為數，以痛為輸，名曰仲夏痺也。 The hand Yang meridian begins at the upper part of the little finger, passes through to the wrist, ascends along the inner aspect of the arm and terminates at the interior sharp bone behind the elbow, twists towards the little finger above and enters into the axillary fossa. Its branch goes downward following the rear aspect of the arm, ascends around the shoulder blade, loops around the clavicle and exits to the front of the yang meridian, terminating at the mastoid process behind the skull bone. Its branch goes into the ear canal. The directing vessel goes out from the top of the ear, descends and terminates at the lower lip, belonging to the outer aspect of the eyebrow. If there is disease affecting the little finger, wrist, interior sharp bone, inner aspect of the arm, axillary fossa, shoulder blade, clavicle, or skull bone, it causes pain. When it spreads downward and causes pain in the throat, it refers to the ear, causing ear pain and causing pain at the lower lip, leading to temporary loss of vision before recovery. If the throat muscle is tight, this can cause yang muscle swelling and neck inflammation, with cold or heat in the neck area. Treatment involves using acupuncture and moxibustion on the jueyin and shaoyang points along the meridian, following the pain for guidance. For swelling, needle in the opposite direction. This is known as the Xia Zhi syndrome.

8: 手少陽之筋，起於小指次指之端，結於腕，中循臂，結於肘，上繞臑外廉、上肩、走頸，合手太陽；其支者，當曲頰入繫舌本；其支者，上曲牙，循耳前，屬目外眥，上乘頷，結於角。其病當所過者，即支轉筋，舌卷。治在燔鍼劫刺，以知為數，以痛為輸，名曰季夏痺也。 The hand's Yang channel begins at the root of the little and ring fingers, passes through the wrist, ascends along the arm, terminates at the elbow, goes around the outside of the elbow, across the shoulder, down the neck, and joins with the other hand's Yang channel. Its connecting point is at the lower lip, attached to the root of the tongue; another connecting point is at the upper gum, ascending in front of the ear, belonging to the external sense organ of the eye, ascending to the mouth, terminating at the horn. When disease occurs along this channel, it manifests as numbness and turning of the affected limb, with the tongue rolling up. The treatment involves needling at the Luo connective point, eliciting a sensation of distending fullness, and releasing, in the context of the Jisheng (Seasonal Evil) invasion. This is known as the Jisheng Syndrome.

9: 手陽明之筋，起於大指次指之端，結於腕，上循臂，上結於肘外，上臑，結於髃；其支者，繞肩胛，挾脊；直者，從肩髃上頸；其支者，上頰，結於頄；直者，上出手太陽之前，上左角，絡頭，下右頷。其病當所過者，支痛及轉筋，肩不舉，頸不可左右視。治在燔鍼劫刺，以知為數，以痛為輸，名曰孟夏痺也。 The Hand Yang Ming Meridian starts at the tip of the thumb and index finger, ascends along the arm, terminates outside the elbow, runs to the wrist, connects with the hair. The branch is wrapped around the shoulder blade and hugs the spine; it goes straight from the nape of the neck to the top of the head; its branch goes up to the forehead, connects at the temples. It goes directly out from the hand Shao Yang point, ascends the left cheek, connects with the hair root, descends the right cheek. If there is a disease along its course, there will be pain and numbness in the support, the shoulder cannot be raised, and the head cannot turn to the left or right. Treatment is available in fire needles and knife-like poking, knowing numbers, bleeding based on pain, called Mengxia Syndrome.

10: 手太陰之筋，起於大指之上，循指上行，結於魚後，行寸口外側，上循臂，結肘中，上臑內廉，入腋下，出缺盆，結肩前髃，上結缺盆，下結胸裏，散貫賁，合賁下抵季脅。其病當所過者，支轉筋，痛甚成息賁，脅急吐血。治在燔鍼劫刺，以知為數，以痛為輸。名曰仲冬痺也。 The sinew of the hand's yin is located above the great finger, and follows along the finger, terminates at the fish's tail, goes outward from the inch, loops up the arm, terminates in the elbow's center, enters the armpit's interior, exits the uterus' basin, terminates at the shoulder in front of the hair, loops up at the uterus' basin, and terminates inside the chest cavity. It disperses to the tendons and connects to the seasonal gates. When there is illness along its course, the sinew transforms and becomes painful, causing difficulty in breathing and urging vomiting of blood. Treatment involves inserting a needle at Gushing Spring and Bamboo Mound, counting the number of insertions, and treating according to pain. It is called Zhongtan (Middle Winter) Jian.

11: 手心主之筋，起於中指，與太陰之筋並行，結於肘內廉，上臂陰，結腋下，下散前後挾脅；其支者，入腋，散胸中，結於臂。其病當所過者，支轉筋前及胸痛息賁。治在燔鍼劫刺，以知為數，以痛為輸，名曰孟冬痺也。 The sinew of the hand's heart, originates from the middle finger, runs parallel with the Conception channel, connects at the inner elbow crease, reaches the anterior aspect of the upper arm, spreads downward and extends across the chest; its connecting point is located within the axilla. Its course follows a path beneath the breastbone, connects to the arm, and disperses above and below the chest. When it encounters disease, it manifests as turning cold, pain in the sinew channel, and chest pain with difficulty breathing. Treatment lies in needle insertion at the appropriate points along the sinew channel, following the direction of the pain, and is called Meng Dong Jian.

12: 手少陰之筋，起於小指之內側，結於銳骨，上結肘內廉，上入腋，交太陰，挾乳裏，結於胸中，循臂下繫於臍。其病內急心承伏梁，下為肘網。其病當所過者，支轉筋，筋痛。治在燔鍼劫刺，以知為數，以痛為輸。其成伏梁唾血膿者，死不治。經筋之病，寒則反折筋急，熱則筋弛縱不收，陰痿不用。陽急則反折，陰急則俛不伸。焠刺者，刺寒急也，熱則筋縱不收，無用燔鍼，名曰季冬痺也。 The hand's yin muscles, beginning inside the little finger and ending at the acromion, pass through the armpit, unite with the conception vessel, embrace the breast, and connect to the chest at the serratus anterior muscle, and descend along the medial side of the arm. When there is disease along its course, it turns and causes pain in the muscles. Treatment involves piercing with an awl or needle, using knowledge as the method and pain as the guide. If the disease leads to a collapse of the trapezius muscle and bleeding of blood and pus, it cannot be cured. The diseases of the channel of the yin muscle are characterized by pain when cold, causing the muscles to contract and spasm. When hot, the muscles become flaccid and do not retract. Deficiency of yin leads to a Yang urgency that causes contraction, and deficiency of yang leads to an inability to stretch. In the case of piercing with an awl or needle, it is for treating pain caused by cold, but if there is heat, the muscles do not retract and are untreatable with moxibustion. This is known as seasonal rigidity (Ji Dong Li).

13: 足之陽明，手之太陽，筋急則口目為僻，眥急不能卒視，治皆如右方也。 The text is written in Classical Chinese, a form of the Chinese language used for literary and scholarly purposes. Here's an English translation:

Regarding the treatment of conditions where the Yangming channel is affected and the Taiyang channel is agitated, causing the mouth and eyes to become red and swollen, and the eyes being unable to close properly – all such treatments are as follows:

docs.title: 骨度
docs.text:
1: 黃帝問於伯高曰：脈度言經脈之長短，何以立之？伯高曰：先度其骨節之大小、廣狹、長短，而脈度定矣。 Yellow Emperor asked Bo Gao: How can one determine the length, shortness, and other aspects of a pulse based on the classics? Bo Gao replied: First, determine the size, width, length, and shortness of the bones and joints, and the pulse measurement will be established.

2: 黃帝曰：願聞眾人之度。人長七尺五寸者，其骨節之大小長短各幾何？伯高曰：頭之大骨圍，二尺六寸，胸圍四尺五寸。腰圍四尺二寸。髮所覆者顱至項，尺二寸。髮以下至頤，長一尺，君子終折。 Yellow Emperor said: I want to hear how the people measure their height. A person's height is seven feet and five inches, how big or small are the bones and joints? Bo Gao said: The circumference of the skull is two feet six inches, the chest circumference is four feet five inches. The waist circumference is four feet two inches. From the forehead to the nape, it is two inches in length. The hair below reaches the chin, which is one foot long, and a gentleman would cut it off.

3: 結喉以下至缺盆中，長四寸。缺盆以下至𩩲𩨗，長九寸，過則肺大，不滿則肺小。𩩲𩨗以下至天樞，長八寸，過則胃大，不及則胃小。天樞以下至橫骨，長六寸半，過則迴腸廣長，不滿則狹短。橫骨，長六寸半。橫骨上廉以下至內輔之上廉，長一尺八寸。內輔之上廉以下至下廉，長三寸半。內輔下廉，下至內踝，長一尺三寸。內踝以下至地，長三寸。膝膕以下至附屬，長一尺六寸。附屬以下至地，長三寸。故骨圍大則太過，小則不及。 From the larynx below to the cavity of want, it measures four inches. From the cavity of want below to the point of the sternum, it measures nine inches, exceeding it becomes large, falling short it becomes small. At the point of the sternum below to the pivot, it measures eight inches, exceeding it becomes large, not reaching it becomes small. At the pivot below to the transverse process, it measures six and a half inches, exceeding it becomes wide and long, falling short it becomes narrow and short. The transverse processes measure six and a half inches. From the upper transverse process to the lower transverse process at the level of the pelvis, it measures one foot eight inches. From the lower transverse process to the pubic symphysis, it measures three and a half inches. Below the pubic symphysis to the ground, it measures one foot three inches. From the ground below to the knees, it measures three inches. The kneecap is below the patella, measuring one foot six inches. Below the patella to the ground, it measures three inches. Therefore, if the skeleton is too wide, it is excessive; if it is not large enough, it is insufficient.

4: 角以下至柱骨，長一尺。行腋中不見者，長四寸。腋以下至季脅，長一尺二寸。季脅以下至髀樞，長六寸，髀樞以下至膝中，長一尺九寸。膝以下至外踝，長一尺六寸。外踝以下至京骨，長三寸。京骨以下至地，長一寸。 From the angle bone down to the pillar bone, a foot long. If it cannot be seen at the armpit, four inches. From the armpit down to the place of the elbow, a foot and two inches. From the place of the elbow down to the hip joint, six inches, from the hip joint down to the knee pit, a foot and nine inches. From the knee pit down to the outer ankle, a foot and six inches. From the outer ankle down to the capital bone, three inches. From the capital bone down to the ground, one inch.

Translation: The length measurements of different body parts according to traditional Chinese medicine.

5: 耳後當完骨者，廣九寸。耳前當耳門者，廣一尺三寸。兩顴之間，相去七寸。兩乳之間，廣九寸半。兩髀之間，廣六寸半。 The length of the ear lobe is 9 inches. The width of the area in front of the ear, where the earlobe is attached, is 1 foot 3 inches. The distance between the two nostrils is 7 inches. The distance between the two nipples is 9 and a half inches. The distance between the two hip bones is 6 and a half inches

6: 足長一尺二寸，廣四寸半。肩至肘，長一尺七寸；肘至腕，長一尺二寸半。腕至中指本節，長四寸。本節至其末，長四寸半。 The following literary Chinese text has been translated to English:

Length: one foot and two inches, width: four inches and a half. From shoulder to elbow, length is one foot and seven inches; from elbow to wrist, length is one foot and two inches and a half. From the wrist to the base of the middle finger, length is four inches. From the base of the middle finger to its end, length is four inches and a half.

7: 項髮以下至背骨，長二寸半，膂骨以下至尾骶，二十一節，長三尺，上節長一寸四分分之一，奇分在下，故上七節至于膂骨，九寸八分分之七。此眾人骨之度也，所以立經脈之長短也。是故視其經脈之 The hairline to the spine is two and a half inches long, from the pectoral girdle down to the tailbone there are twenty-one vertebrae, with each vertebra one inch and a quarter in length. The odd one is at the bottom, so from the top seven vertebrae reach down to the pectoral girdle, measuring nine inches and three-quarters. This is the standard length of human bones, and this is why we use it to determine the length of meridians. Thus when examining the meridians in the body, one must take into account the lengths of the corresponding channels

8: 在於身也，其見浮而堅，其見明而大者，多血，細而沉者，多氣也。 In the body, those who appear to be superficial and firm, those who appear bright and large, have more blood; those who are subtle and deep have more qi.

docs.title: 五十營
docs.text:
1: 黃帝曰：余願聞五十營奈何？歧伯答曰：天周二十八宿，宿三十六分；人氣行一周，千八分，日行二十八宿。人經脈上下左右前後二十八脈，周身十六丈二尺，以應二十八宿。 Yellow Emperor said: I wish to hear about the five zang organs. Duke of Shao replied: There are 28 mansions in the heavenly cycle, and each mansion consists of 36 degrees. When human qi circulates one cycle, it covers a distance of 108 degrees (1,000 miles) per day, traversing 28 mansions. There are 28 channels/vessels on the body, above and below, left and right, front and back. The human body's meridians encircle it with a length of 16 feet and 2 inches to correspond with the 28 mansions.

2: 漏水下百刻，以分晝夜。故人一呼脈再動，氣行三寸，一吸，脈亦再動，氣行三寸，呼吸定息，氣行六寸；十息，氣行六尺，日行二分。二百七十息，氣行十六丈二尺，氣行交通於中，一周於身，下水二刻，日行二十五分。五百四十息，氣行再周於身，下水四刻，日行四十分。二千七百息，氣行十周於身，下水二十刻，日行五宿二十分。一萬三千五百息，氣行五十營於身，水下百刻，日行二十八宿，漏水皆盡脈終矣。 A drop of water misses each hour, separating day and night. A person is called when the pulse moves again; the breath flows three inches, a breath moves the pulse again, the breath flows three inches. The inhalation and exhalation are measured, the breath flows six inches per cycle. Ten cycles, the breath flows six feet, one walks two steps. Two hundred and seventy cycles, the breath flows sixteen yards and six inches, breathing is evenly distributed throughout the body, sinking water twice an hour, walking twenty-five minutes per day. Five hundred and forty cycles, breathing is evenly distributed throughout the body, sinking water four times an hour, walking forty minutes per day. Two thousand seven hundred cycles, breathing is evenly distributed throughout the body, sinking water twenty times an hour, walking fifty stays per day. One hundred and thirty-five hundred cycles, breathing is evenly distributed throughout the body, sinking water a hundred times an hour, walking twenty-eight stays per day, every drop of water lost is measured by the pulse's end.

3: 所謂交通者，並行一數也。故五十營備，得盡天地之壽矣，凡行八百一十丈也。 As for those who travel, there are few who can match their speed. Therefore, with fifty tents prepared, they can complete the journey of eight hundred and ten paces in heaven and earth.

docs.title: 營氣
docs.text: 1: 黃帝曰：營氣之道，內穀為寶。穀入于胃，乃傳之肺，流溢於中，布散於外，精專者，行於經隧，常營無已，終而復始，是謂天地之紀。故氣從太陰出注手陽明，上行注足陽明，下行至跗上，注大指間，與太陰合；上行抵髀，從脾注心中；循手少陰，出腋下臂，注小指，合手太陽；上行乘腋，出䪼內，注目內眥，上巔，下項，合足太陽；循脊，下尻，下行注小指之端，循足心，注足少陰；上行注腎，從腎注心外，散於胸中；循心主脈，出腋，下臂，出兩筋之間，入掌中，出中指之端，還注小指次指之端，合手少陽；上行注膻中，散於三焦，從三焦注膽，出脅，注足少陽；下行至跗上，復從跗注大指間，合足厥陰，上行至肝，從肝上注肺，上循喉嚨，入頏顙之竅，究於畜門。其支別者，上額，循巔，下項中，循脊入骶，是督脈也；絡陰器，上過毛中，入臍中，上循腹裏，入缺盆，下注肺中，復出太陰。此營氣之所行也，逆順之常也。 Yellow Emperor said: The practice of Qi, the grains are treasure. The grain enters the stomach and is transmitted by the lungs, overflowing in the middle and scattering externally. The refined one, follows the meridian, constantly practices Qi without end, returning to the beginning, this is called the record of heaven and earth. Therefore, Qi from the Conception vessel comes out and registers the Governor vessel, ascending and registering the foot Yangming, descending to the heel and registering at the intersection of the large intestine, merging with the Conception vessel; ascending striking the pubis, from the Spleen registering the heart center; following the Governor vessel, exiting the inframammary, registering the inner corner of the eye, up to the apex, down the sacrum, descending and registering the end of the small intestine, following the Huiyin, registering at the foot Shuyang; ascending riding the inguinal ligament, exiting the armpit, exiting between the biceps, entering the palm center, exiting the middle finger tip, returning to the small intestine and the end of the ring finger, merging with the Governor vessel. Ascending registering the Ren (Kidney), from the Kidney registering the exterior of the Heart, dispersing in the chest; following the Heart mother vessel, exiting the armpit, descending the arm, exiting between the biceps, entering the palm center, exiting the end of the middle finger, returning to the small intestine and the end of the ring finger, merging with the Governor vessel. Ascending registering the Governing vessel, dispersing in the three Jiao, from the three Jiao registering the Liver, ascending and registering the Lung, looping the throat, entering the nostril hole, concluding at the lactation gate. Its diverging branches, on the forehead, looping the vertex, down the sacrum, descending and registering the end of the small intestine, following the Governing vessel enters the coccyx, this is the Governor vessel; enveloping the Yin organs, ascending through the hair, entering the uterus, ascending looping the abdominal cavity, entering the sacrum, down registering the Lung, returning to the Conception vessel. This is the practice of Qi's course, reversal and progression are constant.

docs.title: 脈度
docs.text:
1: 黃帝曰：願聞脈度。歧伯答曰：手之六陽，從手至頭，長五尺，五六三丈。手之六陰，從手至胸中，三尺五寸，三六一丈八尺，五六三尺，合二丈一尺。足之六陽，從足上至頭，八尺，六八四丈八尺。足之六陰，從足至胸中，六尺五寸，六六三丈六尺，五六三尺合三丈九尺。蹻脈從足至目，七尺五寸，二七一丈四尺，二五一尺，合一丈五尺。督脈、任脈，各四尺五寸，二四八尺，二五一尺，合九尺。凡都合一十六丈二尺，此氣之大經隧也。 Yellow Emperor said: I want to hear about the pulse. Gongsun Long replied: The greater Yang pulse is from the hand to the head, five chi, five six li. The greater Yin pulse is from the hand to the chest, three chi and five cun, three six li eight chi, five six three chi, total two li one chi. The lesser Yang pulse is from the foot to the head, eight chi, six eight li eight chi. The lesser Yin pulse is from the foot to the chest, six chi and five cun, six six li six chi, five six three chi, total three li nine chi. The Bladder Meridian pulse is from the foot to the eye, seven chi and five cun, two seven li four chi, two five one chi, total one li five chi. Governor Vessel and Conception Vessel, each four chi and five cun, two four eight li, two five one chi, total nine chi. In sum, all together is sixteen li two chi. This is the Great Classic of the Channel Vessels.

2: 經脈為裏，支而橫者為絡，絡之別者為孫，盛而血者疾誅之，盛者寫之，虛者飲藥以補之。五藏常內閱於上七竅也。故肺氣通於鼻，肺和則鼻能知臭香矣；心氣通於舌，心和則舌能知五味矣；肝氣通於目，肝和則目能辨五色矣；脾氣通於口，脾和則口能知五穀矣；腎氣通於耳，腎和則耳能聞五音矣。五藏不和，則七竅不通；六府不合則留為癰。故邪在府則陽脈不和，陽脈不和則氣留之，氣留之則陽氣盛矣。陽氣太盛，則陰不利，陰脈不利則血留之，血留之則陰氣盛矣。陰氣太盛則陽氣不能榮也，故曰關。陽氣太盛，則陰氣弗能榮也，故曰格。陰陽俱盛，不得相榮，故曰關格。關格者，不得盡期而死也。 The vital energy of the meridians is divided into three categories: branches, collaterals, and sinews. When there is a fullness of blood, it is dispelled by puncturing; when there is a deficiency, medicine is taken to strengthen. The five viscera are always within the cavity above the seven orifices. Therefore, lung energy circulates through the nose, so that when the lung is harmonious, the nose can sense odors and fragrances. Heart energy circulates through the tongue, so that when the heart is harmonious, the tongue can taste the five flavors. Liver energy circulates through the eyes, so that when the liver is harmonious, the eyes can distinguish the five colors. Spleen energy circulates through the mouth, so that when the spleen is harmonious, the mouth can discern the five grains. Kidney energy circulates through the ears, so that when the kidney is harmonious, the ears can hear the five tones. If the viscera are not in harmony, then the seven orifices will not be open. If the six bowels do not harmonize, then there will be a swelling. Thus, if pathogenic factors reside in the bowels, the Yang meridians will not be in harmony, and when the Yang meridians are not in harmony, energy will accumulate. Accumulation of energy leads to the fullness of Yang energy. When Yang energy is excessive, Yin energy is obstructed, and when Yin energy is obstructed, blood accumulates, leading to the fullness of Yin energy. Excessive Yin energy prevents the Yang from ascending, hence it is called relationship. Excessive Yang energy prevents the Yin from ascending, hence it is called constraint. When both Yin and Yang are excessive and cannot ascend, it is called relationship constraint. Relationship constraint means that death will not come at the proper time.

3: 黃帝曰：蹻脈安起安止，何氣榮水？歧伯答曰：蹻脈者，少陰之別，起於然骨之後。上內踝之上，直上循陰股，入陰，上循胸裏，入缺盆，上出人迎之前，入頄，屬目內眥，合於太陽，陽蹻而上行，氣并相還，則為濡，目氣不榮，則目不合。 Emperor Yellow said: If the Bubble Vessel is established and secured, where does the energy and prestige of water come from? Duke of Shao replied: The Bubble Vessel is the separate part of the Shao Yin. It begins at the rear bone of the kidneys and ascends along the Yin path, entering the Yin, rising through the chest cavity, entering the missing basin, exiting in front of the person's embrace, entering the throat, belonging to the inner eye, and connecting with the Tai Yang. When the Yang Bubble rises and circulates, there is a balance of energy, but if the energy of the eyes does not bring prestige, then the eyes do not unite.

4: 黃帝曰：氣獨行五藏，不榮六府，何也？歧伯答曰：氣之不得無行也，如水之流，如日月之行不休，故陰脈榮其藏，陽脈榮其府，如環之無端，莫知其紀，終而復始，其流溢之氣，內溉藏府，外濡腠理。 Yellow Emperor said: What does it mean that Qi acts alone, the six palaces not honored? Huang Bo answered: The Qi cannot be without movement, like water flowing, like the unceasing motion of the sun and moon, therefore the Yin channel honors its stores (cavities), and the Yang channel honors its manors (organs), like a ring with no beginning or end, ultimately it returns to its source, its overflowing Qi irrigates the interior stores and manors, and nourishes the exterior head hair.

5: 黃帝曰：蹻脈有陰陽，何脈當其數？歧伯曰：男子數其陽，女子數其陰，當數者為陰，其不當數者為絡也。 Yellow Emperor said: The Ying and Yang of the Chong Mai are present in the Bao Mai. Which one should be counted? Hui Bo replied: For males, count the Yang, for females, count the Yin. Counting correctly is called the Yin Mai; counting incorrectly is called the Lian Mai.

docs.title: 營衛生會
docs.text:
1: 黃帝問于歧伯曰：人焉受氣？陰陽焉會？何氣為營？何氣為衛？營安從生？衛于焉會？老壯不同氣，陰陽異位，願聞其會。歧伯答曰：人受氣于穀，穀入于胃，以傳與肺，五藏六府，皆以受氣，其清者為營，濁者為衛，營在脈中，衛在脈外，營週不休，五十而復大會，陰陽相貫，如環無端，衛氣行于陰二十五度，行于陽二十五度，分為晝夜，故氣至陽而起，至陰而止。故曰日中而陽隴，為重陽，夜半而陰隴為重陰，故太陰主內，太陽主外，各行二十五度分為晝夜。夜半為陰隴，夜半後而為陰衰，平旦陰盡而陽受氣矣。日中而陽隴，日西而陽衰，日入陽盡而陰受氣矣。夜半而大會，萬民皆臥，命曰合陰，平旦陰盡而陽受氣，如是無已，與天地同紀。 Emperor Yellow asked Confucius: Do people receive qi? How do yin and yang meet? What is the qi for defense? What is the qi for nourishment? Is the nourished securely established? Does defense meet with it? The elderly have different qi; yin and yang are not in harmony. I wish to hear about their meeting. Confucius replied: People receive qi from grains, which enter the stomach and pass them on to the lungs. Five zang and six fu are all nourished by receiving qi. The clear qi is for defense, and the turbid qi is for nourishment. Defense remains unrested in the vessels, and after fifty years it returns to a great meeting. Yin and yang intertwine, like a never-ending cycle. The defense qi circulates through the yin 25 times and the yang 25 times, divided into day and night. When the qi reaches yang, it rises; when it reaches yin, it stops. Thus, in the daytime, there is a peak yang, called the 'reinforcing yang,' and at midnight, there is a peak yin, called the 'reinforcing yin.' Therefore, the Taiyin governs inside and the Taiyang governs outside, each having 25 cycles divided into day and night. At midnight, it becomes a peak yin, followed by yin deficiency. At dawn, the yin is exhausted, and the qi begins to receive yang. In the daytime, there is a peak yang as the sun sets, and when it enters the yang, the qi receives yin. At midnight, there is a great meeting, and all people rest; the command is called 'merging yin.' At dawn, the yin is exhausted, and the qi begins to receive yang, just like the harmony between heaven and earth without end.

2: 黃帝曰：老人之不夜瞑者，何氣使然？少壯之人，不晝瞑者，何氣使然？歧伯答曰：壯者之氣血盛，其肌肉滑，氣道通，營衛之行不失其常，故晝精而夜瞑。老者之氣血衰，其肌肉枯，氣道澀，五藏之氣相搏，其營氣衰少而衛氣內伐，故晝不精，夜不瞑。 Yellow Emperor asked: Why do the elderly not sleep at night, and what Qi makes this possible? Why do the young and vigorous not sleep at night, and what Qi makes this possible? The Duke answered: The young and vigorous have abundant Qi and blood, their muscles are smooth, their meridians are open, and their regulation of internal organs is not deviated from the norm, so they rest during the day and sleep at night. The elderly have weakened Qi and blood, their muscles are withered, their meridians are blocked, the Qi in the five organs fight against each other, and their regulation of internal organs becomes weak while their defensive Qi attacks internally, so they do not rest during the day and sleep at night.

3: 黃帝曰：願聞營衛之所行，皆何道從來？歧伯答曰：營出于中焦，衛出于下焦。黃帝曰：願聞三焦之所出。歧伯答曰：上焦出於胃上口，並咽以上，貫膈，而布胸中，走腋，循太陰之分而行，還至陽明，上至舌，下足陽明，常與營俱行于陽二十五度，行于陰亦二十五度一周也。故五十度而復太會于手太陰矣。 Yellow Emperor said: I wish to hear about the functions of the warmer and weaker, and where they come from. Master Qi replied: The warmer comes from the center focus and the weaker comes from the lower focus. Yellow Emperor said: I wish to hear about the three focuses where they come from. Master Qi replied: The upper focus comes out from above the stomach and the throat above, passing through the conception vessel, spreading over the chest, going across the armpit, following the kidney channel, and running its course until it returns to Yang Ming. It ascends to the tongue, goes down to the sole, always accompanying Yang Ming in its course of 25 degrees, and also in its Yin course of 25 degrees in a week. Hence, it meets at the hand of the kidney channel again.

4: 黃帝曰：人有熱，飲食下胃，其氣未定，汗則出，或出於面，或出於背，或出於身半，其不循衛氣之道而出，何也？歧伯曰：此外傷於風，內開腠理，毛蒸理泄，衛氣走之，固不得循其道，此氣慓悍滑疾，見開而出，故不得從其道，故命曰漏泄。 Yellow Emperor said: In humans, there is heat. Food and drink enter the stomach, but its energy has not yet stabilized, and then sweat will come out, sometimes from the face, sometimes from the back, or from half of the body. This does not follow the path of defensive Qi, why? Duke of Shao said: This is an external injury caused by wind, opening the brain and marrow, causing the sweat glands to release, and making the defensive Qi move uncontrollably. Therefore, it cannot follow its path. This Qi is unruly, quick, and slippery, and appears when opened, so it cannot follow its path. Hence, it is called leakage.

5: 黃帝曰：願聞中焦之所出。歧伯答曰：中焦亦並胃中，出上焦之後，此所受氣者，泌糟粕，蒸津液，化其精微，上注于肺脈乃化而為血，以奉生身，莫貴於此，故獨得行於經隧，命曰營氣。 Yellow Emperor said: I wish to hear about the middle Focal point. Zhong Feng answered: The middle Focal point is also in the center of the Stomach, emerging from the Upper Focal point. The substances it receives are transformed by the Spleen and are turned into essence and rise up to the lungs where they become blood. This is extremely precious and unique, so it can only be transmitted through the Meridians, its name being Governing Vessel.

6: 黃帝曰：夫血之與氣，異名同類。何謂也？歧伯答曰：營衛者，精氣也，血者，神氣也，故血之與氣，異名同類焉。故奪血者無汗，奪汗者無血，故人生有兩死而無兩生。 The Yellow Emperor said: Blood and Qi have different names, but they are of the same kind. What does this mean? The Grand Prefect answered: The Guards and Ministers are the spiritual Qi, and blood is the material Qi; therefore, blood and Qi, although they have different names, belong to the same category. Therefore, if one loses blood, there will be no sweat, and if one loses sweat, there will be no blood; hence, a person has two ways to die but only one way to be born.

7: 黃帝曰：願聞下焦之所出。歧伯答曰：下焦者，別回腸，注于膀胱，而滲入焉；故水穀者，常并居于胃中，成糟粕，而俱下于大腸而成下焦，滲而俱下。濟泌別汁，循下焦而滲入膀胱焉。 The Yellow Emperor said: I wish to hear about the origin of piles. Huangdi replied: Piles refer to hemorrhoids, which are connected to the colon and attached to the bladder. They exude fluid; thus, cereal grains are always present in the stomach, forming husks and chaff, which are then excreted by the large intestine and form piles. The fluid is secreted through the piles and enters the bladder.

8: 黃帝曰：人飲酒，酒亦入胃，穀未熟，而小便獨先下，何也？歧伯答曰：酒者，熟穀之液也。其氣悍以清，故後穀而入，先穀而液出焉。黃帝曰：善。余聞上焦如霧，中焦如漚，下焦如瀆，此之謂也。 The Yellow Emperor asked: When a person drinks alcohol, the alcohol enters the stomach; before the grain is ripe, urine comes out first. Why? The Duke of Zhou replied: Alcohol is the essence of ripened grain. Its energy is strong and purifying, so it goes in after the grain and comes out ahead of the grain. The Yellow Emperor said: Good. I have heard that when the upper abdomen is like fog, the middle abdomen is like a tree leaf, and the lower abdomen is like a clam; these are what they refer to.

docs.title: 六節藏象論
docs.text:
1: 黃帝問曰：余聞天以六六之節，以成一歲，人以九九制會，計人亦有三百六十五節以為天地久矣，不知其所謂也。歧伯對曰：昭乎哉問也，請遂言之。夫六六之節，九九制會者，所以正天之度、氣之數也。天度者，所以制日月之行也；氣數者，所以紀化生之用也。 The Yellow Emperor asked, saying: I have heard that Heaven uses the sixes and sixes to complete one year, and humans use nines and nines for meetings, and they also count three hundred sixty-five nodes as a way to express the longevity of heaven and earth. I do not know what it means. The Duke answered: How enlightened your question is! Please proceed with your explanation. The sixes and sixes of Heaven's nodes, and the nines and nines for meetings are used to regulate the measure of Heaven's degrees and the number of its energy. The degrees of Heaven are used to govern the movement of the sun and moon; the energy numbers are used to record the use of the myriad things in heaven and earth

2: 天為陽，地為陰；日為陽，月為陰。行有分紀，周有道理，日行一度，月行十三度而有奇焉，故大小月三百六十五日而成歲積氣餘而盈閏矣。立端於始，表正於中，推餘於終，而天度畢矣。 Heaven is yang, Earth is yin; day is yang, month is yin. There are records of movements and reasons for cycles. The sun completes one cycle and the moon completes thirteen cycles, which results in anomalies. Therefore, the large and small months total 365 days and complete a year's accumulation of energy with some remaining, thus there is a leap year. Establishing the beginning, displaying the middle, and pushing the remainder to the end, and the heavenly cycle is completed.

3: 帝曰：余已聞天度矣，願聞氣數何以合之。歧伯曰：天以六六為節，地以九九制會，天有十日，日六竟而周甲，甲六復而終歲，三百六十日法也。夫自古通天者，生之本，本於陰陽。其氣九州九竅，皆通乎天氣。故其生五，其氣三，三而成天，三而成地，三而成人，三而三之，合則為九，九分為九野，九野為九藏，故形藏四，神藏五，合為九藏以應之也。 Emperor said: I have already heard about the Heaven's order, and wish to know how many breaths there are in order to merge them. Duke of Yi said: The Heaven arranges by sixes, the Earth establishes by nines. There are ten days in the Heaven, the Sun goes six steps before it revolves around and completes a year, three hundred and sixty days are its law. As for those who have communicated with the Heaven from ancient times, their origin lies in Yin and Yang. Their energy flows through the nine provinces and nine orifices, all connected to the Heaven's energy. Therefore, when one is born, they possess five energies; when three combine, they become Heaven; when three combine, they become Earth; when three combine, they become humans; when three combine again, they make nine, which are then divided into nine wildernesses, and these wildernesses contain the nine treasures. Thus, there are four form treasures and five spirit treasures, combining to total the nine treasures that correspond with the Heaven.

4: 帝曰：余已聞六六九九之會也，夫子言積氣盈閏，願聞何謂氣。請夫子發蒙解惑焉。歧伯曰：此上帝所秘，先師傳之也。帝曰：請遂聞之。歧伯曰：五日謂之候，三候謂之氣，六氣謂之時，四時謂之歲，而各從其主治焉。五運相襲，而皆治之，終朞之日，周而復始，時立氣布，如環無端，候亦同法。故曰：不知年之所加，氣之盛衰，虛實之所起，不可以為工矣。 Emperor said: I have heard of the 669 Gathering, and you mentioned accumulating qi to fullness, asking for an explanation of what it means. Please, Master Zhou, dispel my confusion. Zhou replied: This is something the Emperor has kept secret and passed down through the sages. Emperor said: I would like to hear more about it. Zhou said: A day refers to a phase, three phases refer to qi, six qis refer to time, four times refer to a year, and each treats its master accordingly. The five cycles influence each other, and all are treated accordingly until everything is exhausted and then returns to the beginning, establishing the qi arrangement, like a circle without end. Therefore, one cannot create works without knowing how much a year has been added, the waxing and waning of qi, and what causes the rise or fall of emptiness and reality.

5: 帝曰：五運之始，如環無端，其太過不及何如。歧伯曰：五氣更立，各有所勝，盛虛之變，此其常也。帝曰：平氣何如？歧伯曰：無過者也。帝曰：太過不及奈何。歧伯曰：在經有也。帝曰：何謂所勝。歧伯曰：春勝長夏，長夏勝冬，冬勝夏，夏勝秋，秋勝春，所謂得五行時之勝，各以氣命其藏。帝曰：何以知其勝。歧伯曰：求其至也，皆歸始春，未至而至，此謂太過，則薄所不勝，而乘所勝也，命曰氣淫。不分邪僻內生，工不能禁。至而不至，此謂不及，則所勝妄行，而所生受病，所不勝薄之也，命曰氣迫。所謂求其至者，氣至之時也。謹候其時，氣可與期，失時反候，五治不分，邪僻內生，工不能禁也。帝曰：有不襲乎。歧伯曰：蒼天之氣，不得無常也。氣之不襲，是謂非常，非常則變矣。帝曰：非常而變柰何。歧伯曰：變至則病所，勝則微，所不勝則甚，因而重感於邪，則死矣。故非其時則微，當其時則甚也。 Emperor: The beginning of the five phases is like a circle without an endpoint, and exceeding this is not good. Duke of Shao said: The five energies are established in their own strength, each having its own victory, the change between excess and deficiency is what is constant. Emperor asked: What is the balance like? Duke of Shao said: It has no excess. Emperor asked: What about too much? Duke of Shao said: There is a saying in the classics. Emperor asked: What do you mean by victory? Duke of Shao said: Spring triumphs over summer, summer triumphs over autumn, autumn triumphs over summer, summer triumphs over winter, and winter triumphs over spring; this refers to obtaining the five phases' time of victory, each controlling the spirit of its corresponding energy. Emperor asked: How do you know it is victorious? Duke of Shao said: Seek perfection, all will return to the beginning of spring, not yet reached but already arrived, which refers to exceeding the limit and triumphing in that which is weak, called chaotic energy. Not dividing good and evil, internal generation, skill cannot restrain. Already arrived but not yet arrived, which means not victorious, resulting in false actions and the illness suffered by what is weak, called pressing energy. That which seeks perfection refers to the time when energy is complete. Be careful of the time, energy can be anticipated; miss the time and reverse, the five treatments will not be divided, evil internal generation, skill cannot restrain. Emperor: Is there no end to it? Duke of Shao said: The energy of the sky and earth has no constancy. Energy without end is what is not constant, and thus changes. Emperor asked: What does changing mean? Duke of Shao said: Changing leads to illness, victory leads to mildness, what is not victorious leads to seriousness, causing people to pay more attention to evil, leading to death. Therefore, if it is not the time, it is mild, and if it is the time, it becomes serious.

6: 帝曰：善。余聞氣合而有形，因變以正名。天地之運，陰陽之化，其於萬物，孰少孰多，可得聞乎。歧伯曰：悉哉問也，天至廣不可度，地至大不可量，大神靈問，請陳其方。草生五色，五色之變，不可勝視；草生五味，五味之美，不可勝極，嗜欲不同，各有所通。天食人以五氣，地食人以五味。五氣入鼻，藏於心肺，上使五色脩明，音聲能彰。五味入口，藏於腸胃，味有所藏，以養五氣，氣和而生津液相成，神乃自生。 The emperor said: Good. I have heard that qi gathers and forms a shape, transforms and gives rise to the name through changes. The movement of heaven and earth, the transformation of yin and yang, how much is there in myriad things, can it be fully understood? Duke Huan asked: This is indeed a profound question. Heaven is vast and cannot be measured, and earth is immense and cannot be quantified. Great spirits ask about this, please explain the method. Grass produces five colors, the changes of these colors are beyond sight; grass produces five flavors, the sweetness of these flavors is beyond measure, desires differ, each has its own path. Heaven feeds people with five qi, and earth nourishes people with five flavors. The five qi enter the nose, are stored in the heart and lungs, and make the five colors clearer, the sounds audible. The five flavors enter the mouth, are stored in the stomach and intestines, the flavor has its own storage, nourishing the five qi, when the qi is harmonious, body fluids are produced, and spirit arises.

7: 帝曰：藏象何如。歧伯曰：心者，生之本，神之變也，其華在面，其充在血脈，為陽中之太陽，通於夏氣。肺者，氣之本，魄之處也，其華在毛，其充在皮，為陽中之太陰，通於秋氣。腎者，主蟄封藏之本，精之處也，其華在髮，其充在骨，為陰中之少陰，通於冬氣。肝者，罷極之本，魂之居也，其華在爪，其充在筋，以生血氣，其味酸，其色蒼，此為陽中之少陽，通於春氣。脾胃大腸小腸三焦膀胱者，倉廩之本，營之居也，名曰器，能化糟粕，轉味而入出者也，其華在脣四白，其充在肌，其味甘，其色黃，此至陰之類通於土氣。凡十一藏取決於膽也。 The Emperor asked: How is the storage of the dragon? The Grand Preceptor replied: The heart, being the source of life and spirit, has its brilliance in its face and its fullness in the blood vessels; it is the yang within the yang and reaches the qi of summer. The lungs, being the root of breath and soul, have their brilliance in the hair and their fullness in the skin; they are the yang within the yin and reach the qi of autumn. The kidneys, ruling over the concealed storage, are the place of essence; they have their brilliance in the nails and their fullness in the bones, being the yin within the yin and reaching the qi of winter. The liver is the source of extremes and the dwelling of the soul; it has its brilliance in the claws and its fullness in the tendons, generating blood and qi, with a sour taste and a bluish hue, being the yang within the yin and reaching the qi of spring. The spleen, stomach, large intestine, small intestine, three junctions, bladder are the depots of granaries, dwelling places of transformation; they are called organs, able to transform dregs and change flavors as they enter and exit, with their brilliance in the lips and whiteness, their fullness in the muscles, having a sweet taste and yellow hue, being the essence of yin and reaching the qi of earth. The storage of all eleven organs depends on the gallbladder.

8: 故人迎一盛病在少陽，二盛病在太陽，三盛病在陽明，四盛已上為格陽。寸口一盛，病在厥陰，二盛病在少陰，三盛病在太陰，四盛已上為關陰。人迎與寸口俱盛四倍已上為關格，關格之脈贏，不能極於天地之精氣，則死矣。 Originally, there was a person who had three bouts of illness: one at Shao Yang, another at Tai Yang, and the third at Yang Ming. After the fourth bout, it became a Gan Yang. He then experienced four bouts of illness at Jue Yin, two at Shaoyin, and three at Taijing, after which it became Guan Yin. When both Gan Yang and Jue Yin reached fourfold increase, they became Guan Gui (Relation between the channels). If the pulse in this relation is not strong enough to prevail over the vital qi of heaven and earth, then one will surely die.
